												Highly recommend itStory: is very good except for some parts when You use the second char for the Ending B, I simply don't like that char, probably personal taste, but I enjoyed a lot the other two, aside from the fact that they are somewhat sexy, but the first char You use, well, the story really got me (I am omitting intentionally their names)Fights: are somewhat cool, I finished almost all the game with only Bare Fists, but still the chars are way too strong for the enemies, even with Bare Fists You are litterally too strong compared to everyone, even Bosses are a joke, sometimes in just 5-6 seconds You kill them but You have to wait all their "phases" to finish the battle, so You basically kill them and wait for their speech or their next phase of the fight, I am sure most of GDR players can relate to this (It's basically a GDR so You are supposed to know how to grind properly for few minutes to gain some levels)The only weapon I started to use are the Bracers, love the Bruce Lee Fight StanceGame also reminded me from some internet video (before it's release) of Raiden from MGR, infact I found so many similarities in their moveset and fighting style, I appreciate a lotOther weapons I don't know to be honest since I never used them onceMusic: oh boy the music, waiting for the soundtrack to be released, just sayin...Litterally there are only good songs and themes, I like all of them, only MGS Saga gave me this feeling with musics, there is not a single one that I don't like, huge huge huge compliments for the SoundtrackAgain: not a single one I don't like, I can listen to all of them since I like all of them, again congratulationsOverall Gameplay: I am a quite instinctive player, I saw the running animation of the protagonist and decided to buy the game, (same with tales of Berseria, I saw Velvet the protagonist do a spinning aerial kick, and I purchased the game) litterally that's what I did, just to be precise on what drive me to purchase the game, the running animation is so fine and well made, something I was looking for for long time being a fan of the MGS Ninjas (and relating to Rising/Raiden of course)The Overall Theme: the game is sad, it's really sad, few few few games can really go that deep and make You feel in a certain way, Automata made me feel very sad for days (it's not very long game anyway, all achievements can be done in very few hours, and I spent lot of time going around before the game tells You do go here or there and without using the transfer function most of the time, so, except for some specific zones, I already knew all the map before the game even mention that)As said, it's sad, sad musics, sad story, sad everything (almost ;) )But what really destroyed me were the story of two chars in particoular, I will put under SpoilerEmil & PascalKnowing a bit of the story of the first I mentioned, well... It's sad...Actually he is still alive accoringly to the story even if You finish the sidequest so, all good :D infact You can find him again on his syuper cool tricicle-thing XDThe argouments like life, death, be Yourself or not to be anymore if You change something in Your body, it makes You think, a lot, may be just me but I just wanted to let You knowProblems: Most of the players on PC had problems with crashed and white screensSo far I had my PC turned on since January (over 60 days) and I got, as far as I remember, 5 white screens and only 1 actual game crash, luckily I am used to save a lot so I basically never lost anything, except for few minutes of game maybe, but so far it was quite ok, I rebooted only after finishing it, but being at 100% I didn't tested it again, maybe in the future :)The resolution problem, that bothered me the most because I wanted to play full screen, I have a GTX 780 and still whatever I do I always mantain 60 FPS, so, yeah, it's not an heavy game even pushed to the limit, I would like to try again when the resolution will be fixed so maybe it will be proper 1080p, so maybe it will be actually a bit heavy when it will be rendered properly, just my assumption anyway, only time will tell :)Mouse and Keyboard: I don't like to use controller but I had to in this case (last time I used one was probably 2010 or even earlier) this just because of the Evade system which on K&M lacks a dedicated key and in this game Evade is basically this: Evade = Immortal, double tap on the K&M is not working very good because You can't chain the evade movements, hopefully this will be fixed, and the shooting with POD is not very feasible in some situations where You should keep "dragging" the mouse to make the POD rise or lower the fire (I don't want to spoiler so I will just stop here)I probably need to write a lot more but overall, in the actual situation, my score would be something like 8/10When everything will be fixed (even if they don't fix K&M but just the white screen) it will go 9/10Still it miss something, some more in-depth on certain aspects or something that I would have changed into the story because as said one of the char was basically a pure hate for me, the playstyle too of that char was not very interesting and super boring, the thing about need more in-depth is not story wise, I just would like to have more contents, more story, something more to watch and listen, I really enjoyed the argouments and the story, reallyAlso would be cool to add a survival mode: all the enemies against You in an infinite sequence, even 2-3-4 bosses together, it would be quite cool to be honest as said when You are at the end of the last ending You will be most likely 99 like me and basically everything You touch will be destroyed instantly, so yeah would be cool to have an arena like that(not the Debug mode the game gives You in the main menu, don't really like that XD)

												I am amazed and positively stunned by the game (I have never played or even heard of the other Nier-games before). It looks great, the characters are fantastic and the world is perfectly sculpted to give you the exact feel you need to get drawn into the story. It is not just some open world to explore, it is a world where every step makes you feel that whatever war you think you are fighting there is ultimatively futile and not worth going for. And yet the nature and growth everywhere makes it clear that no matter what happens, life will go on and that there is always a future. A solid 10/10 from me and possibly one of the games I will remember and come back to for many years to come.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
17
												Going over the PC port first since Steam users are autismo about that.-Game supports up to 1080p, it can go higher res but that's not natively supported.-Framerate caps at 60.-Game does not have a borderless windowed option, took me about 20 minutes of crashing to get working with a workaround.-Supposedly the game has resolution issues? Works on my machine. GTX970 meme card and i5 4690K at 3.5GHz.Overall it's pretty w/e, mostly servicable.The game itself is fantastic. I'm not some bandwagoning loser who hopped on the Taro train for Automata or Drakengard 3. Played the original Drakengard in 2005 and bought Nier when it first came out in 2010. This is probably the most refined Yoko Taro's games have ever felt and SE should apologize to me personally for not giving him a budget. After the disaster known as Drakengard 3 I was somewhat skeptical about how the game would turn out. Gameplay:Despite being made by Platinum, gameplay definitely feels more like a sequel to Nier, with some flair. Rather than just mashing attack, you mash light and heavy attacks, pod for your magic/bullets, and a mediocre dodge function. Outside of combat, you explore an open area and fish/do sidequests/farm items. Pretty much like the original. Magic is interesting since you can bind up to 3 programs at a given time and swap between them when you find more pods. Boss fights are hit/miss. Sometimes you get something really cool and a lot of time you get something along the lines of a giant roboworm in the sky pooping out ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bullets and he hardly ever gets down. I really wish they expanded on boss fights but there are still good fights! Enemy variety is a bit low but since most people were deepthroating Breath of the Wild that shouldn't be an issue for you.Story:Gonna pair this with characters. The story wasn't as good as the original Nier, and the original does build up to this. Despite it not being directly related, there are many tie-ins to the original game that many people will miss. That's what you get for being a bandwagon cuck. It starts off on an interesting premise and takes a wild turn after the second ending. Many of the concepts and ideas Taro had while working on the game are great, but it just lacks the chemistry the original game had with it's cast and chain of events.Graphics????:It's a ♥♥♥♥ing Yoko Taro game what did you expect retart. Characters were designed by Akihiko Yoshida and I want all of the girls to sit on my face. Variety in regions is pretty good too, less grey than the original Nier. Still pretty grey. I don't know it looks fine. No blinding bloom like the original either.Controls:PLATINUM HAS A GAME WHERE YOU CAN FULLY BIND THE CONTROLLER WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥. I mentioned this before but dodge feels unsatisfying, that's my biggest complaint. Moving around the map feels good and combat mostly feels good and the shooting mechanic is pretty good. People hate on the lack of a lock-on on harder difficulties but honestly the lock-on isn't all that good and maybe you should stop being bad at games.Overall the game is great, and while Platinum did a wonderful job with the gameplay elements, I really don't feel they were the sole reason why the game turned out so well, and I see a lot of Platinum fans being disappointed with the game because "muh hype muh cuhrayzeeeeeeeeee game muh muh muh" and overall just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ up another community. It honestly feels like a Sequel to Nier in essentially every aspect. Go buy the game already jesus christ.*I originally played the game on PS4.EDIT: I ♥♥♥♥ING LIED BROS THE GAME RUNS LIKE ♥♥♥♥ ON MY 970 WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥ SO MUCH FOR THE MASTER RACE I PAID $1000 FOR THIS PC DEFEND THIS ♥♥♥♥ PCUCKS REEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEBUY THE GAME ON PS4 INSTEAD. IT RUNS LIKE ♥♥♥♥ BUT AT LEAST IT CAN HOLD 60FPS. SONY WINS AGAIN.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
19
												HOKAY So let's start with how much I've played through so far: I've done a couple side-quests, completed the first run through the story and ran around aimlessly for a good amount of time without being bored. The game still has more to offer, after your first playthrough you get a secret message as well that will explain more of what I mean. For newcomers, yes there is no auto-save, no it is not a bug that you cannot save for the first little while. It's aka. git gud, :^) I don't run the best computer so I could only run the game at a measly 1360 x 768 to play it at 60fps at medium levels, but even then the graphics are absolutely stunning and beautiful. I was able to load it into 1080p and max settings just to have a brief moment to look at some scenery and my goodness I've never loved a place in a video game so much in my life. The story itself is marvelous, after the first completion I couldn't (and still can't) get the fuzzy happy feeling out of my chest. The gameplay is creative and fun as it transitions into all sorts of styles which I actually love love love. Although if you figure out a strategy there are some battles that become time consuming rather than fun interactive battles, but that's what the difficulty changes are for. All in all the battle system is very fun to experience. tl;dr Pros: Graphics - Story - Characters - Gameplay Cons: ohno no auto-save - open world might make things a little confusing - whattheheck i can't do some things in the first playthrough my new favorite game, and I hope to keep up with more of Yoko Taro's work in the future. Time to experience more playthroughs ~

												A large amount of care has been put into NieR and it's replayability and fun factor is definately up there, might need to install a borderless software to play it at native resolution but that wasn't worth degrading it's value, overall it's fun, fast paced and got plenty of things to do, the sidequests also formulate to something of a mini-main quest that you won't see unless you are speeding through it. Graphics arn't everything when it comes to gameplay, and NeiR makes a beautiful map out of what it has, some edits to remove some needless invisible walls would be preferred in my opinion but it is fun never the less. The soundtrack is amazing. Lots of different weapons to suit your playstyle. Have tissues on hand. 10/10Truths:There is no borderless full screen but software can help with that.Don't trust other player's comments with less than 3 hours of gameplay.Myths:many people have been complaining about FPS drops, but it's down to their system, not the game itself.

												Regarding the game:Done with most of the game ! Gameplay's fun, mechanics in general are awesome (death penalties; perspective swap from 3D to 2D, top-down; etc), side-quests are greatly done and you can tell how much attention to detail they've put into this game; you even get beautiful bgm cues when you're doing side-quests ! And most of them are voiced over ! (so far, at least) I could be here all day praising this game for its story, bgm, characters, scenarios, art, gameplay mechanincs, battle system and much more, really.Optimization:While the base game is wonderful, I obviously can't ignore some flaws regarding its optimization. For me, it's great, I haven't experienced any crashes so far, but :- Sometimes the game fails to catch up with you and loads the textures for the scenario way later, I just give it some time- Some hiccups caused by the loading of the area (hasn't happened while battling to me, yet)- The game's resolution doesn't match the 1080p setting if I go full screen (it downgrades to 900p) *I'm using Kal's mod for now. I hope they patch it !I'm so glad the PC version happened. From the bottom of my heart, thank you. Taro Yoko, Okabe Keiichi, Emi Evans, J'Nique Nicole, Naim Nakagawa, Platinum Games, Squeenix et al <3 THANKS FOR MAKING THIS HAPPEN !

												AMAZING GAME! First game in YEARS that I  haven't regretted Purchasing at full price. The game is INCREDIBLE period. The music is amazing, very immersive one minute its an anime rpg, then bullethell, then side scroller,  then platformer then open world. Using my Skills for missions other than fighting is refreshing..."the robot race side quest". Love how the world opens up, at first I thought it was bland and too much greys and washed out green but as you play the game only gets better and the aesthetic works its grows on you and becomes more captivating. Water effects are very well done. Controls arre very responsive. Using both analog sticks while in the middle of combat is new but very natural and now I can't get enought of this twitch style of play. 2B looks amazing and moves like a woman possessed she owns the battlefield no matter how massive the opponent and they do get pretty BIG!!! The nuances in this game make it a breath of fresh air!  Very much satisfied with this purchase. INCREDIBLE GAME. I am only a few hours in but I hope there are unlockable costumes somewhere would to love mess around with that option.....and a Gameplay Tip ::  Many have comlained about the windowed mode, window play etc...I go into the Steam folder find the NIER folder, find the NIER exe file right click and run with my GTX1060 Card no issues after that.....HIGHLY RECOMMENDEDUpdate 31MAR...There is an item that drops down a curtain to change costumes. Bought it from Emil...Got what I asked for! Different Costumes!!! Now to Find'em....Perhaps Fishing? I mean I found another POD this way now I have 3.....This game is full of suprises!

												2B honest, came for the booty, stayed for everything the game offered:1. Amazing soundtrack (Made me feel as if I needed to make every fight near perfection).2. Enemy types (So far, enemy types just keep adding on).3. Side Quests (There's so many things you can do aside from the main missions, and its looking to go over 80 hours).4. Fight Mechanics (Each weapon synergizes with eachother smoothly, the countering makes every fight interesting).5. Voice Acting (Pretty decent work, nothing seems out of place, I went with the japanese voice overs).6. Map (Not the biggest open world game out there, but its definitely filled with secrets to explore).7. Difficulty (Believe me when I say it is near impossible to do the epilogue of the game on HARD, but it's still a fun challenge).That's all I could probably think of right now, but I definitely would recommend this to anyone i'd meet for sure. Developers took their good time with this game, and it really shows, though only annoyance i've seen so far is the invisible walls that you'll run into, can't complain though with the amount of content i'm seeing.

Review: NieR: Automata 
A Video of NieR:Automata™
By: Kain Klarden

			Short review of an amazingly strange action RPG/shmup from Yoko Taro and PlatinumGames. Text review here: http://klarden.dumdoi.com/2017/04/thoughts-on-nier-automata/		


The time where Yoko Taro genius finally got a good game, courtesy of PlatinumGames.There are minor issues, both in terms of slight technical issues and some of the design decisions. And the game is, probably, a tiny bit less crazy then some of the previous Yoko Taro works. But it's still amazing in how effortlessly it changes gameplay all the time, while remaining fresh, surprising, enjoyable and unforgettable. And the soundtrack is just stunningly awesome.Just, don't expect it to be good because of what the game says and does. Be ready to feel through HOW it says and does. And be aware, that completing the game once is far from it being over.

												Completely amazing game. One of the best games I have played in awhile. Story is AMAZING. Sound/score is AMAZING. The only con I can even think of is the game is locked at 60 fps (not too much of an issue really) and the cinematics are 30 fps (not sure why) but honestly it is not bad at all. Totally recommend it for everyone. The combat system is so fluid and easy to pick up, but it allows for you to show some skill with dodging. But like I said before, the selling point is its deep and complex story and its AMAZING songs that go with the combat and zones. I freaking want to download the soundtrack and play it in my car. The story made me tear up, and the amount of hours I've spent already makes it well worth it. I'll be excited to see if any story DLC comes out (looks like it).

												In the first few minutes of gameplay you are already excited and even more with the beautiful protagonist, 2B. NieR: Automata is a crazy game for crazy people. When you face your first boss, you think: What the **** is that? Ah yes . . . The wonderful world of Yoko Taro.But let's put all jokes to another place.This game brings some new innovations that I never saw, let me explane which one.Platinum used a mixture of formulas with hack and slash, platform, Arcade, 2D, RPG and other elements; Let's consider which games of this type would be considered "Mediocre", where in this generation what matters is FPS and graphics of last generation - and it is worth nothing that it was a very risky recipe, but Platinum did its homework. Throughout the game, you feel that you are part of the game's plot. Congratulations to all Platinum staff who did a great job. I am grateful to have lived all these years to play this work of art. Master Yoko Taro, take good care of your health, because we need more games like this :) PROS: 1 - Great gameplay. 2 - Great Story. 3 - Good design of main characters. 5 - Amazing SoundtrackCONS:1 - Boring Open World2 - 2010 old Graphics 3 - A bit boring enemy DesignWhat more can I say. I'm glad PC can enjoy this masterpiece too. PS: Still sucks to be a Xbox player though.PPS: For real though, how do they feel that Scalebound (also a game by Platinum Games) got cancelled by Microsoft (♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s) and Nier: Automata got released.PPPS: Don't try to play this game with Keyboard and Mouse

												AMAZING GAME! First game in YEARS that I  haven't regretted Purchasing at full price. The game is INCREDIBLE period. The music is amazing, very immersive one minute its an anime rpg, then bullethell, then side scroller,  then platformer then open world. Using my Skills for missions other than fighting is refreshing..."the robot race side quest". Love how the world opens up, at first I thought it was bland and too much greys and washed out green but as you play the game only gets better and the aesthetic works its grows on you and becomes more captivating. Water effects are very well done. Controls arre very responsive. Using both analog sticks while in the middle of combat is new but very natural and now I can't get enought of this twitch style of play. 2B looks amazing and moves like a woman possessed she owns the battlefield no matter how massive the opponent and they do get pretty BIG!!! The nuances in this game make it a breath of fresh air!  Very much satisfied with this purchase. INCREDIBLE GAME. I am only a few hours in but I hope there are unlockable costumes somewhere would to love mess around with that option.....and a Gameplay Tip ::  Many have comlained about the windowed mode, window play etc...I go into the Steam folder find the NIER folder, find the NIER exe file right click and run with my GTX1060 Card no issues after that.....HIGHLY RECOMMENDEDUpdate 31MAR...There is an item that drops down a curtain to change costumes. Bought it from Emil...Got what I asked for! Different Costumes!!! Now to Find'em....Perhaps Fishing? I mean I found another POD this way now I have 3.....This game is full of suprises!

Amazing Gameplay.Amazing Story. Amazing Music.Amazing. Amazing. AMAZING!Some may find the combat system not really challenging, but it has it fun, it's not entirely hack-n-slash. Though the level gap really have huge impact. If you really looking for challenge, there is Very Hardmode for you to try :^). Story? It's simple but it's a whole new level of complex. 												First off: I recommend this game to anyone. Don't let the internet only fretting over a characters ♥♥♥ distract you from the fact that this game is great in story, music, world and gameplay.Positives:- great soundtrack - took me 40h to complete (A-E, 97% quests)- good and satisfying battle system (dodging at the right time or using heavy attacks feels GOOD)- interesting design with perspective shifts- several fitting difficuties- good character design- fantastic story- if you are a completionist, you can't really miss anything - powerups allow for a specialized playstyle (like range? like tank? like glasscannon melee? all possiple)- other things i currently don't remembernow the negatives, or rather nitpicks, i encountered within my 60h of playing this game:- frames drop sometimes when entering a new area (gtx1070, for reference)- exploding enemies can spawn right in your attack in a certain area, which depending on the difficulty can end you without a chance- the pacing is partially off (meaning the game can slow down a little too much in certain parts and a particular quest involving the sandy lands is just stupidly tedious)- stumbling over small rocks, while being realistic, this feature feels like it serves no higher purpose other than being annoying- perfect dodge -> unwanted ranged counter killed me more often than it helped. infuriating- dark souls death system (1 time retrieve or else you lose the accumulated exp and power ups)and that is where bugs come in. It only happened once after 60h of playtime, but after a 4 hour exp grind just for fun, an explosive enemy pushed my body through a wall, making me lose the progress of those 4 hours since i can't retrieve my body through the wall...but except for those things its a solid game and probably my GOTY.Just ATM a little bit angry.i will edit in more, should i remember more things

content:

												Okay, so I had to jump through a few hoops before I could get the game running properly (that is 3 hours of testing multiple display settings, uninstalling and updating drivers, uninstalling and rolling back drivers, getting Borderless Gaming because the game looks awful in fullscreen, etc.). But if we ignore these technical issues that will most likely be fixed some time after launch with a couple of patches, and we evaluate the game as an experience, then I do believe this will be a mostly positive review.Before I start I want to make clear that I did preorder the game, for Hype reasons, but I'm reviewing this not as a fanboy, but as a veteran gamer that paid full price and expects a game that was properly made and runs as expected. (Don't be fooled by my not so impressive Steam library, after gaming for about 20 years you tend to amass quite a bit of physical copy games and experience.This Game Is AmazingOf course, this kind of game will not be for everybody. It requires multiple playthroughs if you wish to get the most out of its story, and even though it doesn't require you to know the lore of the previous games, you'll want to go find out. (Especially with characters like Emil appearing out of nowhere) The best way I can describe this game is an Open World JRPG-like Hack 'n Slash Combat Based game.Think about a game not quite as open as Xenoblade (in world size or open-endedness, with standard sidequests and inventory management for a JRPG, with a combat system not quite as flashy/complex/difficult as Bayonetta, but similar (considering Platinum Games are responsible for delivering this title to us). This description alone is enough to get someone like me to have a nerdgasm, but it might actually drive quite a few people away from the game; people who are looking for simpler action and not so much story (a little like the DmC with emo Dante).StoryI won't dive too deep into the story to avoid spoilers. Even though my gameplay time proves I've not yet completed the game, the whole story has been revealed to me through Twitch streams and YouTube videos. The story revolves mostly around YorHa androids 2B and 9S, which have been assigned to help out the android resistance at Earth. Even though androids are not allowed to have feelings, by the end of the story progression you end up feeling for them yourself. They speak their minds and desires with surprising freedom if you take into consideration the fact that they are synthetic beings. The story itself is not the best I've come across, but several quirky moments and instances of comic relief make me grateful that Yoko Taro was the producer. Brilliant and unusual storytelling + good gameplay and combat = happy gamers.GameplayThe gameplay can be as complex or as simple as you wish it to be here. You can set it to easy and relax while the plug-in chips do most of the hard work for you and enjoy the story, or set it to hard or very hard and get yourself punished mercilessly if you did not do the necessary preparations for a fight. The multiple sidequests of the game are the generic "go find this for me", "please find/save someone", "go kill these enemies", "go activate this" quests found in most MMOs and RPGs. This is not necessarily a bad thing. It gives you time to take the world in and do some exploration on your own. Exploration allows you to find materials and objects that you can sell or use to upgrade your weapons, Pods and yourself. Plug-in chips serve the function of trinkets or the kind of buffs you would find in a piece of gear in another game. Each has a certain effect (movement speed, % of health recovered after killing an enemy, max health up, defensive and offensive boosts for both ranged and melee attacks, etc.). You can find or buy these chips, and fuse them together if they are the same type and tier to get a new one with stronger effects while taking less space. You have a certain amount of "storage" available for these chips which you can expand with in-game currency. Each chip will have a certain storage cost to prevent you from becoming too overpowered. Better chips will take up more space, of course. Players going through the game in easy mode will be able to install chips that perform certain actions automatically for them; such as shooting, dodging, and healing (this last one can be found and equipped in other difficulties as well). Boss fights are intense but not unfair. Sidequesting is not required but recommended if you intend to have  a not-so-hard-time with some of the fights. Leveling up is not so important, as you'll be fighting machines with a higher level than yours most of the time during the story anyways (but don't expect to be able to go up against a machine 30 levels higher than you and not get instakilled).Combat feels fluid, and OH MY GOD thanks for letting us cancel out of combos with a dodge. There is nothing worse than committing to a heavy strike and getting punished by another enemy before you even land the hit. The Pods are there as your support DPS source, but have multiple programs that can be installed to provide even more support or devstating attacks. Combat does not have the depth of a DmC game, but does not feel shallow or simple either.The open world can sometimes feel a little barren and washed out, but the story provides an acceptable explanation for this. As humans have fled earth, and plantlife and the elements have taken over once more. There is not exactly plenty to do everywhere, but at least there are lots of collectibles scattered anywhere you care to look. These will help you in one way or another, so your time spent climbing that building for 5 minutes won't be wasted.VisualsThis is not the most graphically impressive game you'll ever lay your eyes upon. This is no DOOM 2016 or Rise of the Tomb Raider. You can most certainly tell it's a console port when you see some of the textures up close. Render distance and aliasing are quite bad. The art direction, however, is superb. There is a big contrast at play here. Dark abandoned factories highlighted by pools of glowing molten metal, huge cities with nothing but the dilapidated builings for evidence that humankind once resided here, a vast desert with nothing more than the scorching sun reflecting on the dunes as you slide down through them, forests full of flora that blocks out the sky, and an amusement park with machines dancing as fireworks light up the horizon. I think you get the idea. The atmosphere is well structured, and the fact that 2B can run at a decent pace will help you feel that you're not going too slow but still allowing you time to take it all in. All of this accompanied by the perfect soundtrack for each area... speaking of which!MusicVocals are the new thing here. Keiichi Okabe's work here is brilliant. You know a soundtrack is good when you can't wait to be able to download it and keep in in your playlist for casual listening or to replace another game's soundtrack as you play (looking at you League of Legends). I can't help but feel that all the tracks were rather similar but had a definitive distinction between them. Sadly, except for Beauvoir, the music was never really used to complement the fights themselves. The music definitely fits the pacing of the fight, but the bosses don't move and attack along with the music. Superb soundtrack. Even if you never play the game I recommend everyone to listen to it.PerformanceHere's where everything goes south. To say that the PC launch was bumpy is an understatement. If they at least bothered making a demo for PC we could have noticed many of these problems right away and have them ironed out by launch date. As of now the game has some serious crashing and FPS issues on certain setups. Solid 60 FPS so far on my rig tho.I've run out of available characters for the review. My final score is 9/10 2B butts. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

												Regarding the game:Done with most of the game ! Gameplay's fun, mechanics in general are awesome (death penalties; perspective swap from 3D to 2D, top-down; etc), side-quests are greatly done and you can tell how much attention to detail they've put into this game; you even get beautiful bgm cues when you're doing side-quests ! And most of them are voiced over ! (so far, at least) I could be here all day praising this game for its story, bgm, characters, scenarios, art, gameplay mechanincs, battle system and much more, really.Optimization:While the base game is wonderful, I obviously can't ignore some flaws regarding its optimization. For me, it's great, I haven't experienced any crashes so far, but :- Sometimes the game fails to catch up with you and loads the textures for the scenario way later, I just give it some time- Some hiccups caused by the loading of the area (hasn't happened while battling to me, yet)- The game's resolution doesn't match the 1080p setting if I go full screen (it downgrades to 900p) *I'm using Kal's mod for now. I hope they patch it !I'm so glad the PC version happened. From the bottom of my heart, thank you. Taro Yoko, Okabe Keiichi, Emi Evans, J'Nique Nicole, Naim Nakagawa, Platinum Games, Squeenix et al <3 THANKS FOR MAKING THIS HAPPEN !

												Let me start by saying, I was very apprehensive going into this game. I was reading reviews all last night while installing the game (slow internet, took me hours to install). The amount of negative reviews that were flooding in about the game not playing well/crashing and what not was very concerning.That being said. I have just beat the first main boss and made it to being able to save the game. NieR:Automata has run flawlessly on my PC (system specs will be at the end of this review). The gameplay is absolutely amazing. I am using a wireless Xbox 360 controller. And I love that I can customize my controls for it. That is something that is missing from a lot of ports. Swapping around my Action, Evade and Fire buttons made everything feel Right. The graphics are really nice and everything is running smooth for me in maxed out settings. However, I do have Blur turned off as I generally hate any kind of blurring effects in a game. The only negative I've seen so far is the 30fps Cutscenes. It gets jittery and takes away from the game because of that. The immersion just sort of dies for me when it goes to a cutscene.I am playing the game at 2560x1440 on a 144hz monitor. Game is locked at 60fps but still feels smooth. And I generally can't stand playing anything under 80fps because I notice the difference. I've been gaming at 144hz for 4 or 5 years now and 60fps is normally like 30fps was to me when I gamed at 60fps. I hope you follow that.Positives: Beautiful Graphics for a portSmooth gameplay with awesome CombatNever dips below 60fps during gameplayStory and immersion are great during gameplayThe couns is amazing so far as well. Loving the music and voice acting.Negatives:Cutscenes are locked at 30fps... This is the absolute most negative aspect of the game. As the frame drop causes stuttering during the cutscenes and, for me, it completely pulls me out of the immersion I have been sucked into fromt he actual gameplay.Locked at 60fps (Although it's actually really smooth, which is impressive. So this could be seen as a positive as well and is in no way a deal breaker, as I thought it might be before actually playing.)My System Specs:i7-5820k @ 4.7Ghz2x Nvidia Titan X in Sli (Maxwell) @1348mhz core (only one card is used during gameplay on this title, but Sli being on doesn't seem to negatively affect it at all)32 GB Crucial DDR4 @2400mhzSamsung Evo SSD game driveAsus G-Sync 2560x1440 @144hz MonitorI would definitely recommend this game. It's fun. One of the better ports I've played, if not the best. don't let the negative reviews sway you in buying this title. If you're waiting on a price drop, go check out Greenmangaming. I picked my copy up for $50 over there.

content:

												If you're looking to get NieR: Automata solely for android booty and/or Platinum combat you may either be sorely disappointed or pleasantly surprised by what you actually find yourself experiencing. NieR: Automata is the niche sequel to the niche first NieR game in the niche NieR series which is a spinoff of the niche Drakengard series (the games are pretty niche). While neither the first NieR nor the Drakengard series are required to be played to enjoy Automata, doing so will greatly enhance your experience and I'd strongly recommend that you at least familiarize yourself with the story of the first NieR and its connection with Drakengard before playing NieR: Automata (this will also help you decide if NieR: Automata is a purchase deserving of your time and money).  Whether you decide to take that plunge or not, avoiding spoilers would be something I'd also recommend. Now to get into why I'd personally recommend the game:PROS:-The gameplay is the best it has ever been for the series-The story is an emotional rollercoaster not quite like anything I've experienced before and a well deserved sequel to the first NieR-An absolutely incredible soundtrack that harkens back to the first game's, using its melodies and vocals for emotional impact as well as having entirely original songs that will leave their own new mark on you-One of the most profound moments I've experienced from a game in my nearly two decades of gaming (to say anymore would be spoilers)-Perspective and gameplay changes that keep things fresh and intense-Sidequests with great stories of their own-In keeping with the tradition of the series, multiple endings and further insights on repeat playthroughs that give you a reason to play through the game again-Countless "little things" that add to the overall experience CONS:-The PC port isn't the greatest at the time of writing (the community has already put out several fixes for various problems)-A gameplay mechanic introduced in the middle of the game can become somewhat repetitive-While the combat system is deep and fluid the game never requires or incentivises you (other than satisfying yourself with flashy combos) to expand past mashing light attack, holding down the fire button and spamming the incredibly forgiving dodge (at least on normal difficulty)-A somewhat bland but atmospheric open world setting-The sidequests are mostly menial fetch quests, gameplay wise-The English voice over isn't the best, in my opinion (luckily there's a Japanese voice option)While being rough around some edges, NieR: Automata is immensely greater than the sum of its parts. It's definitely left an impact on me, so much so that I've thought about the game non-stop since completing it and it's earned a spot as one of my favorite games of all time.

Game is locked at 60fps but still feels smooth. And I generally can't stand playing anything under 80fps because I notice the difference. I've been gaming at 144hz for 4 or 5 years now and 60fps is normally like 30fps was to me when I gamed at 60fps. 												With:- Stunning visuals- BGMs - Fighting system of each individual androids- the difficulty level- Story- Voice Actorsyou can't definitely find an awesome game as good as this one. It's almost perfect, but I gotta agree with some people, that there's not much wardrobe material for the androids(Or if I may theorize why few clothes are customizable is because they "might" want to match it to the game's theme of "black and white" motif in fashion.Watching the dialogue in japanese makes it look like you're watching anime, which is actually impressive, knowing that the japanese voice actor and actresses of 2B, 9S, and A2 are outstanding seiyuus(voice actor) in the anime industry. So far I've only unlocked three so far, which is quite interesting in my pace(since I did it in just 2 days). Of course, that is, if you're the type of person who is impatient to relive tons of re-playing events that you already finished.For music, EVERY MUSIC in this game has the good mix in the atmosphere per area. I also especially liked Pascal's Village the most, as they used a BGM with kids' voice in it-- which you can feel that Pascal's village is something like a kid's paradise and making it more friendly.Lastly, I would like to say thanks to the staff of Nier:Automata. I've never played any Nier franchise before this one, but this game really brought back myself to cherish gaming again. Buying it is really worth it. I hope this gets an impressive sequel despite having already 26 endings in one gameTwT

content:
3
A Very Welcome SurpriseOn my list of top ten games I've played, this definitely ranks on number four behind Radiata Stories and Final Fantasy X, and Warcraft 3, which for me is very high praise considering my wde array of games I've played to completion. At first, I thought this game wasn't going to be great, since I had never heard of Yoko Taro nor his works, so this came very much out of the blue for me. I paid it very little attention, and I'll admit, most of that was for 2B's butt, until about a week from launch, when one of my friends got it for the PS4. Out of humor, I watched him play the first portion of the game, and wasn't entirely amazed; it had the look of everything I'd come to hate in games: an overblown romance, very little substance beyond the combat, and an open world. Boy, was I wrong.A few days before launch day, I drunkenly, and probably spurred on by the friend who got it on PS4, got a copy for it. Not really wanting to pay full 60 for it, but having already done so, I planned on doing the two hour demo and just refunding it.The alarm I set for just under two hours buzzed and I turned it off. I was so enthralled with this game that I don't even remember doing so. Within an hour and fourty five minutes, I was already hooked into this pretty little game. Everything melded together so well - story, combat, art, voice acting (I played English, and the line delivery was fantastic for all characters, save a few specific lines, though the Japanese were their usual quality of fantastic as well,) and the atmosphere. So, I'll cover them in the order I've listed, for simplicity.StoryUnfortunately, for all the right reasons, I can't go too deep into the story, so let's make this the skim milk of reviews. The story is absolutely fantastic in every respect. It's deeper than what you expect in the first two playthroughs, but shallow enough to not need to go back to the previous games to get into it. It's truly fantastic, especially with some of the late game scenes, which can bring every emotion forward.Oh, yeah, I almost forgot.THE STORY DOESN'T BEGIN UNTIL THE THIRD PLAYTHROUGH.That was important because I almost put it down after the second, but decided on continuing. Moving on,Combat2B, A2, and 9S, all the characters you play, have very distinct fighting styles. 2B and A2 share the same moveset, but they differ in how quick they are. 2B is agile in every way, able to strike quicker, and A2 is weightier and feel far more impactful (I have been told this is complete false, but to me the two seem entirely different while sharing the same moveset. So bugger off.)9S, though, has a unique combat style. While lacking in a heavy attack like A2 and 2B, he has hacking, which is borderline overpowered and, overall for me, out of place in how well it works. It takes you to a top down bullet-hell twin stick where the objective is to shoot the enemy's ball(s). If you fail, you lose maybe 10% of your health (Never tested this in the hardest difficulty to see if it kills you,) while if you win, you deal AT LEAST 25% of the enemy's health.The difficulties range from Easy (game literally plays itself), normal (fairly easy,) hard (more of a normal difficulty than Normal,) and the hair pulling out one shot mode. I personally recommend it on Hard after you realize what your playstyle is. Also, a minor nitpick is that I wish there were more varied enemies outside of bossfights. You see the same 10 or so types everywhere, and it gets dull after a while when you learn their percise behavior. ArtThis game is bloody beautiful. It takes the whole idea of "what if Humans got driven from Earth for a few thousand years, yet somehow the buildings still stand?" to a new level. The city you're in is never specified, it's simply City Ruins, though it is within the northern hemisphere and, I personally think Greenland based on a cutscene. But you'd never know it, because the four biomes - City Ruins, Forest, Desert and Underground are all within spiting distance of eachother.The weapons in this game are weaponporn. Pure and simple. If you like the old gritty weapons, they got that for you. Beautiful weabo swords? They got that too. Want sexy kawai girls? We got that apleanty. Want a cute little femboy? We got one of those in stock yesterday!Put simply, this game never got to be a sore on the eyes, since each place was so drastically different from the last that, even after almost 50 hours, nothing ever looked more than familiar, and if you look in all the nooks and crannies, it gets even better, since there's some gorgeous views hidden away.Voice ActingAlways a most controversial topic among nerds is to dub or sub. Well, I can say that for me, and a lot of others, the English dub is spot on in -almost- every situation. There are a few lines that are very much out there, and some where the VAs were obviously not having a good day, since the tone convayed was a bit... Diluted. But to be fair, for every bad line, it had at least two or more good to great ones to make up for it. 9S, especially near the end of the game, portrays a lot of that.Atmosphere.This game is about androids on a world familiar to us without us. You will explore it with the eyes of someone who knows it, while behind the eyes of someone who doesn't entirely. It feels lonely. It feels dark. But it has light moments as well, and the occasional comic relief.The atmosphere of living where people once did, without seeing any signs of violence not left in the current year, is deeply disturbing at some points. The machines also make this point far more abundant. In Yoko Taro's style, it's truly unsettlingly creepy on some of its basest levels, and it's that that brings the whole game together for the better.Easily my game of the year. 9.5/10. Only problem is the frame dipping, which they've said they're patching. Get it. It's worth it.

												Nier Automata has been one hell of a ride. After of around 87 hours of playing the game and 6 sleepless hours after completing ending E I’ve concluded that this game is unlike any game that will ever come out.First off, the gameplay is made from the creators of Bayonetta and Metal Gear Rising fame, so it’s solid. The light attacks feel light and swift and the heavy attacks have impact to them. The dodge responds when it needs to and feels satisfying when done perfectly. The hacking games were hard at first but eventually you get used to the simple controls.The soundtrack and only be described as godlike. The previous game Nier also has an outstanding soundtrack but it suffers a bit because you can notice it only a single track that loops. With Nier Automata the soundtrack transitions into each other seamlessly that you’ll think it’s only one track playing continuously. The 8 bit tracks are excellent evidence of this. The game will transition to whatever is currently playing to the 8 bit tracts and back without losing its place.The highlight of this game will most undoubtedly be Ending E. Everything about this ending is unquestionably perfect. The song, the struggle, and the twist in your emotions as you realize what is happening. I will say that I have never experience a game quite like this that could stir emotions in me. The many games I’ve played have all been a one and done deal for me but this game will stay with me for a long time.

content:

Good•	The game itself is fantastic, it has a lot going for it story-wise. Basically you’re an combat android tasked with dealing with machines that want to wipe out the human race. This is the type of game were you can’t really talk about to much because of spoilers and plot twists everywhere but from my experience it was unforgettable and I definitely recommend it to any fan of the RPG JRPG genre as well as anyone who really cares about how a story is told.•	The combat in this game is awesome and Platinum really outdid themselves with how smooth the transition between weapon combos and how tactical you can get with the upgrade system in-game.  The enemies are pretty much different versions of the same 4 or 5 types but there are some unique ones in there and because of the story it actually makes sense that that would be the case making it feel less repetitive and more routine.•	The graphics are alright really but nothing spectacular. There are some areas where important places are very well done but for the most part the character models, story and combat take center stage in this game. The world itself is open world-ish.. (areas unlock) with side quests scattered around keeping you busy.•	The gameplay doesn’t stay repetitive long, it switches between play styles every now and then to keep you on your toes, something you find out within the first few minutes of playing.The Bad•	Glitches all over the place for just about anyone with a card under a gtx 970. White screens, freezes, fps drops, blurry fullscreen, you name it this game has it for a portion of gamers. There are community fixes but you should probably make sure they work for you before purchasing just in case.•	The enemies do become a bit repetitive hours in because the large majority of them are just the same models with different weapons and colors so later in the game once you’re higher level you may find yourself ignoring a lot of them. Even if the game itself tries not to stay repetitive the enemies do.•	A lot of running around collecting things for side-quests. Unless you’re like me and like to grind the basic side-quest is “go kill this so I can have this”SummaryIn all I had an absolutely amazing time playing this game glitches and all; over 100 hours and about 20-30 freezes and I still love this game. The story is one of the best I’ve seen in my years of gaming and the combat was very fun. I found myself wanting to know more about all the side characters and I definitely got emotionally attached to the main ones; you won’t walk away apathetic in the least. Personally, I will definitely be playing this again in the near future but for now I am satisfied with my experience and recommend it without hesitation because of the story but cautiously because of the performance issues.

												Pros:-2B's a.rse-2B's a.rse-2B's a.rse-2B's lips-2B's mole-2B's clevageokay for real now-Brilliant and well executed story with many interesting side-stories, great characters and lots of them! Lots of fun hacking and slashing, feels and feels, and that soundtrack, my god it flows so well with the specific areas you're in and whatever's the situation, hats off to the guys who made that OST!Cons:The port to PC isn't the best, out of the box in full-screen mode there are issues with resolution (I have a 1440p monitor and even when 1440p is selected in the settings it ends up looking like 900p or something). In-game AA absolutely murders FPS, I recommend disabling it and use the AA solution that AMD or NVIDIA Settings can offer. To get the best out of performance in this game you need FAR (Fix Automata Resolution), look it up on the Steam Community. That will fix resolution problems and potentially some other performance issues too, so after that with that combined I can pretty much max out the game on 1440p @ 60fps 95% of the time (i5 3570k, 16GB RAM, R9 390 OC'd). But still, shouldn't need to resort to third-party patches to fix performance/resolution issues in the first place.TL;DR Yoko Taro pulled off a damn masterpiece, just to keep in mind that this isn't a perfect PC port though.

												A little rough around the edges but I'd put that down to Japan lacking experience in developiong for the PC as a platform, the game itself however is...unique.  if you judge each aspect of it on its own you might think its a bit naffvisually it swings from being decent to looking like a dogs ♥♥♥♥ and the combat lacks the depth of some of platinums previous outings, however the way how it all comes together is something truly special, its a game that rewards your time invested in it and needs multiple play through's to enjoy.  Each run is very different from the last both from a story and gameplay perspective and when you hit run 3 the game goes off the ****ing chain and is a completely different game entirely. I have never been so moved by an ending to a video game as much as I have just been through Ending E of N:AThe final battle, the helping hand, the chorus, The ramifications of failure, I actually started welling up as I pushed on.In the end I helped someone.N:A isn't so much a game; its more of an experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
25
												If I were to grade Nier Automata against other action RPGs I would give Nier a B+, in comparison to Skyrim and Witcher III which would get A+'s. Nier Automata is a fun, action-packed game with a lot of uniqueness that boarders on quirkiness. For example, the game depicts sexuality in many ways, just look at B2's short skirt and white panties, but never goes so far as a sex scene like Witcher III. There are also a plethora of childish, goofy-looking robots populating the Nier Automata world, along side scarier looking, more serious bosses. One of the things I appreciated about the Witcher III world was the cohesiveness and seriousness of the storyline. In Nier Automata there is a wide mixture of adult themes coexisting with kiddy comic relief. All in all that was my biggest pet peve with the game. The game delivers both a serious and comical atmosphere, which may be appreciated by some, but I prefer my games to have a serious and adult storyline and art style. Interestingly, Nier Automata is a game that must be replayed several times. After beating the game you will be invited to play through the game again as a different character, experiencing their story and abilities. I am currently on my second pass through the game and I enjoy getting more of the story by experiencing the game through the eyes of a different character who's missions sometimes overlap with the original character's, but often diverg into completely different missions and different areas. The gameplay in Nier Automata is fun and action packed. It behooves you to think strategically and master your build and combos, but simple button mashing will also work to a degree. I felt the game was a lot of fun, but button mashing was more viable than in Witcher III and less viable than Skyrim, if that gives you an idea of the technical skill required in combat. Overall I would say:Gameplay: Very good if you like action RPGs and light combos. Graphics: Very good, but could have been better. It is obvious that this game was a port from PS4. The port is a good one, but the graphics were not tweeked to accomodate powerful PC rigs and what they can handle. The FPS is also locked at 60 FPS. Story: The story is quite good, but with too much comic behavior, art, and style from the robots. If robots conquer the earth I expect them to be serious-looking. There is lots of replay value given that you can beat the game along various characters and story lines. Music/Sound Effects: Very good, as you would expect from a Tripple A title from Square Enix.So is it worth $60? If you like story RPG games like Witcher III you will like this and should buy it. If you are not into open world games with sexy fighting androids who combo you should wait for a sale or not buy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
20
Yoko Taro and Platinum come together in a perfect storm to make one of the best games everIn a world where gaming often feels uninspired and repetitive, NieR: Automata comes and breaks the rules and delivers an experience that feels entirely new in all areas. The story and plot is incredibly captivating and connected with me like few games have. The genre-mashing combat is insanely fun with a smooth hack and slash backbone combined with authentic feeling bullet hell moments. The overall graphics style is breath taking in parts and combined with an amazing soundtrack the presentation is endearing. This is easily one of the best games I've played in recent years and possibly one of the greatest games of all time.StoryNieR: Automata follows the story of androids 2B and 9S, who are part of Operation YoRHa that seeks to reclaim the world from machines. The story develops through understanding the greater context of the world and empathising with different perspectives. There are many different meanings, endings, tales and emotions explored throughout the game and most of them connected with me in a way that is incredibly rare in the industry. Only a handful of games have had such a powerful emotional and cognitive connection, but none have done it so regularly with most story elements. The relationship between the main characters has a great level of development, especially considering the amount of direct dialogue between them is not that large. What results is an almost unspoken synergy that develops naturally and feels very organic. Dialogue with supporting characters is great as well, with a mixture of very funny and incredibly sad moments. Something that NieR: Automata does very well is expanding character's history without overloading the player, this results in the player gradually learning about these characters and keeps the plot/quests very interesting. Just as an aside, I have not played the original Nier. Before starting the game I watched a summary of the original, in saying that the connection between the games is minimal with only a couple of references here and there. I would still recommend watching a summary of the original game, though not entirely necessary.GameplayTaro's games have not typically had great gameplay, which is why I was so excited to hear that Taro and Platinum have worked together to make this game. With Platinum in charge of the gameplay I knew it would be in good hands. The gameplay of NieR: Automata is a mix of many genres, and surprisingly they are all a joy to play. The three main styles are 3rd person hack and slash action in true Platinum style, twin stick shooter and shoot 'em up/bullet hell with several other styles sprinkled throughout. The hack and slash combat is an absolute blast as would be expected. Throughout the game I never once got tired of the combat and executing seemingly infinite combos with perfect dodge counters is incredibly rewarding. The different weapon types change the combat styles and a combining these weapons makes for an enjoyable and visceral experience. The shoot 'em up moments are surprisingly very great. I was a little hesitant when I knew the game had these moments and feared it would be a lame gimmick, I am very glad I was wrong. The gameplay during these parts feels very traditional which is great.The only thing that I didn't really like was the difficulty settings. There are 4 settings: Easy, Normal, Hard and Very Hard. Easy is very customisable with optional auto controls (such as dodge) this setting is for people who don't particularly care for the gameplay and is a cool addition. I played on Normal, and I found it to be too easy mostly because I always seemed to be overleveled, I only died a few times. Hard however was a really large step up above Normal, and when I tried it I got pretty stomped even by lowly robots. Very Hard says that you die in one shot, I didn't test it, but I assume it actually means that which would make the game almost impossible (not my taste but glad it exists). I think the game could've really done with an enemy level scaling option and my qualms about the difficulty would've been basically invalid, my next playthrough will definitely be on Hard. PresentationIt's very hard to talk about the graphics of this game. On one hand the overall detail and quality is quite low, particularly in some environments mostly due to poor textures. On the other hand the style of the game is great and reminds me a lot of Shadow of the Colossus, there are many beautiful zones and moments in the game and overall I love the graphics of this game. Whilst the level of detail might not be the greatest the style is definitely king. The combat and movement animations are incredibly smooth despite the 60fps cap, the facial animations were slightly above average I'd say. Cutscenes are unfortunately rendered in low resolution (900p@30fps I believe) and this did detract from these moments and I would've preferred to see them rendered in native resolution.The soundtrack is incredible, and as soon as it is released I will be buying it. The most notable tracks feature an incredible choir that are an absolute joy to listen to. Battles are generally done with instrumentals only except in key moments and boss battles, the music added a lot to the game especially in boss battles and exploration."I see a bunch of games on the shelf, but I don't get as excited as I used to. I gave it some thought why am I not excited? The number of well made games has increased, but at the same time the number of games that makes my heart beat and give the feeling of "I have no idea what to expect" that excitement has gone down. [...] I want to strongly believe there is still a huge potential for games."-Yoko Taro, 2014

content:
29
												Okay now, this game I'm really lost for words. The sound track is amazing, I do not get tired of listening to the music this game brings with it. To me there is clearly good character development, the main character 2B goes from a strict millitary person to someone who slowly becomes more and more willing to give up her past ideaologies. The idea behind this apocoloptic world and the time it is set in is near perfect for my taste. The replay value of this game is also very high, offering different endings (26, from what I assume) that you can achive, and allowing you to follow through the story behind a different character. Visuals are great, although there is currently a bug that affects fullscreen mode in 1080 that is being fixed. The first playthrough offered me nearly 20 hours of entertainment and now going through the second time following a differnt character I assume will bring me the same amount, or more hours of enjoyment, considering that following different characters can also effect the amount of time it take to complete the game. Oh and lets not forget that this game is open world, offering you a wide variety of side quests to follow in many different enviorments. Looking forward to future expansions or continuation of the series.

content:

												This game is absolutely amazing. It is pretty much on a masterpiece level and is worth buying at full price.This is pretty much how games are meant to be done.What you get: An amazing JRPG styled story that touches some deep subjects.... and it does it a lot. The script, characters and quest-related narrative are very well crafted, characters are sympathetic, and I was genuinely interested what is going to happen next. There are frequent arcade sequences.Music is on a stellar level..Visuals...well, visuals on pc looks a bit rough around the edges, but for the purposes of this game they work well. The game could use a small performance boost as well. I played it with controller. I think there are keyboard bindigs provided, but I think that controller is the way to go with this title.Overall, the title reminded a lot about Ghost in The Shell, due to subjects it touches during storyline, and due to the music being used. The story gets quite dark on occasion too, which is good.The only minor complaint about this game is that there's a certain minigame, and you'll probably play this minigame a LOT. And this is pretty much the only issue.The main reason to buy this is music and story. Story is great, and there's lore and more stories everywhere in it. I gotta say that the guy responsible for this game is pretty much a genius. Stuff on this level is incredibly rare.So, highly recommended.

content:

												I love this game and everything about it. Yoko Taro's stellar storytelling and Platinum brand gameplay will easily make this the sleeper hit of 2017 for me. This game is actually a sequel to the lesser known NieR that came out on PS4 in 2010, and is everything the first game was supposed to be, and more. The plot subtly deconstructs and explores the notion of what makes us human, while never being preachy and overly verbose about it. The characterization is top-notch, and you may even find a few poignant moments that may make you shed a tear(Especially THAT ending). The gameplay is a distilled essence of a less complex Bayonetta and a more in-your-face Metal Gear Rising:Revengeance. NieR Automata is going to be one of those blessed, profound experiences in life that you will think about now and then, and may stick with you until the day you die.

												Yes this game has...resolution issuesPoor resolution in cutscenes Crashes poorly optimized  AMAZING OST amazing gameplayamazing characters to love amazing combat i could go on...But despite all that, this game is probably one of the most worth it experiences I have played in a long time. If you can look past the issues this port has, and they can be significant, this game will not only be entertaining in its gameplay, but keep you guessing on the story as well. Be forwarned, you may have to invest a hefty amount of time into the game to get a large amount of the story. Multiple endings and somewhat large changes in perspective across playthroughs will keep this game a more fresh experience than you may expect. My time played currently finished in a Thorough play through of the game. With the combination of Yoko Taro's writing and Platinum's game play, this is a "nier" must buy. 2B and A2 FTW don't really like 9s

												First experience with a Platinum game, as well as my first experience with a Yoko Taro game. The combination's left me absolutely blown away (and sometimes in tears- thanks Yoko Taro). The combat is extremely fluid and fun and the animations are fantastic. As well, the hacking/bullet hell elements lend a lot of variety to the game rather than it just being a simple hack and slash. The soundtrack is beautiful and ethereal, and the story is not only interesting but COMPLETELY wild. Wherever you're expecting this game to go when you start playing, you're probably wrong.The only real complaint I have is that Route B is somewhat repetitive, but Route C more than makes up for it in terms of story and gameplay.Unless you hate good gameplay, good music, and a good plot, you will love this game.Also, don't spoil yourself for the endings, you'll be kicking yourself later.

content:

												The first Nier was an ugly and slow masterpiece with a bland color palette and TONS of running back and forth through a mostly empty world. However, the story, characters, and frankly amazing soundtrack helped it punch in above its weight class.Automata is an excellent evolution of all of Nier's original parts. The bland colors are still there, but with hugely improved art style and character designs. The soundtrack continues to amaze and is much longer and more varied this time around. With Platinum Games at the helm, the combat system is also flashy and fun enough to sustain the longer, open-world format of this entry in the Nier (Drakengard?) series. And speaking of Drakengard, Automata borrows elements from the bonkers and frequely upsetting boss battles of Drakengard 3. I won't spoil anything, but...wow.The elephant in the room is PC performance. The game can look great, but it isn't on par with first-tier character action games like Tomb Raider. It doesn't seem to be very well optimzed either, particularly cutscenes, which are "locked" at 30 fps, but actually run MUCH worse, even on my pretty beefy system:i5 6700K @ 4.4 GHz16GB DDR4 2400 MHzOC'd GTX 1070Regular gameplay fares much better, at least for me. I've been enjoying 60 fps across the board at 1440p, with everything turned to high EXCEPT anti-aliasing, which is switched off. For some reason the AA seems to be the bottleneck for this game, with even 2x making the difference between a locked 60 and something more like 30-40.After the first Nier, I became invested in Yoko Taro's games, and I have not regretted it. They're weird, sometimes messy, and powerfully told. Automata is his best. I'll leave it at that.

												This game is a refreshing take on your usual hack and slash.The fighting mechanics are very much like Devil May Cry or Bayonetta.The story is intriguing and I keep going back for more.The music is astounding and I am very interested in buying the OST as it is.The boss battles are fun to play through, dynamic, and often have mutiple stages. Great!What makes it unique is that the game transforms from free roaming world to 2D platformer to Gradius ish top down fighter jet simulator. I love  how the game interchanges them.My only issue:The biggest issue I am vocal about is the lifeless world the game. The world lacks immersion in the sense that there is a lack of clutter and items to fill the scenes. Sure there are NPCS, theats, and a few animals however all the buildings you enter are completely empty of technology, items, and life. It's as if I am are running around cities that were being built by a construction crew just to rot. The developer could have really added more depth by adding more to the scenery of the game. Was the building a school, a work place, or a public service? Players could have explored through the structures and find easter eggs and lore but there is none of this. I feel like the geography and mapping is their beta landscape for the game without any investment.Overall this game brings a unique gameplay style I haven't seen and am thoroughly enjoying it!9/10

												Yoko Taro has served everyone on the dance floor. They don't know it. He doesn't know it. He might not have meant to do it, but he has.Nier:Automata is an incredible statement on art, culture, and philosophy in the early 21st century.Androids and machines, clinging to past ideals, philosophies, ways of action, saying and doing things because it's what people before them did, despite those actions having no meaning in the present, imitating what has gone before without a shred of the substance within that made those things tick.Much like most cultural produce in these times, and the words people cling to as philosophies.BUT NONE OF THAT MATTERS TO THE FACT THAT THIS IS A REALLY REALLY REALLY GOOD VIDEOGAME.Any philosophy, and even the great story, with its twists, reveals, and everything else is unintrusive icing on the cake that is this game. The core combat is good (and the I-frames are nice and forgiving). The switches between Platinum Character Action/Spectacle Fighter, Twin Stick Shooter Bullet Hell, Sidescroller, and Neo Retro Twin Stick Shooter Bullet Hell, are stylish and (mostly) smooth, and unlike so many games, each different component manages to be good on its own.There's a level of care and consideration put into every aspect of this game (except possibly the 1080p 60fps max res/framerate lock, and the model pop-in) that's just incredible.Uninstall your OS program? There's an ending for that.Use the Self-Destruct in the hyper-secret orbital space station base? They thought of that too.Equip a spear and a large sword? Oh, yeah, there's a special combo and set of gorgeous animations for that.And the animations are so good, too. This whole game is great. It's wonderful. Buy it, play it, love it.Even if you're just thinking about how much you want to **** 2B.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
27
												This game has been a pleasant surprise. I expected a linear on rails hack and slash adventure, and instead got a fast paced open world RPG. Lets start with a basic list:Pros1. Great fast paced action2. Good story and plot3. A variety of play styles, bullet hell in a mecha jet, 2D platformer, 3D hack and slash and does them all well.4. RPG elements deep enough to engross but not convoluted enough to slow down flow5. Attractive characters, very refreshing considering the wests trend of making women ugly because of politics, male characters get the same treatment as the women including the ability to lose 9S's pants.6. Multiple endings and playthroughs that change the story and the main characterCons1: Very low res textures and low poly count for scenery2: Poor optimization, some speculate the games DRM Denuvo causes a lot of this3. The open world is a bit on the small side, it's not tiny like Lightning Returns but it gets smaller with each playthroughMusic is extremely subjective, all I can say is that it reminded me of Final Fantasy 13 a little.This has been the first game in a long time that I find very difficult to put down, there is always a lot to do and it's all fun. The game goes for a philosophical theme that a lot of people like to condescendingly put down to make themselves sound smart. The philosophy is implemented in such a way that it's more show and less tell, it's not shoved down your throat but it's there for you to think about or ignore at your own leisure. It adds depth without being pretentious or preachy and I'd say they got it perfect in that regard. Most importantly to me is that it never gets so deep into existential philosophy or so convoluted that it stops being grounded or making sense.The story itself is often serious and intense but it also doesn't take itself too seriously. It cracks jokes when it's appropriate and provokes emotion when it's appropriate. It doesn't break the 4th wall so much as it tries to blur the lines. Game elements like UI, death, and saving are implemented in a way to prioritize immersion over mechanics while still giving the functionality and player choice necessary. The RPG elements can use up a lot of time for people who enjoy loot grinding and min-maxing but are not so essential that someone couldn't play through without ever stopping to grind and still get the job done. Player progression can be divided into 3 parts, weapon upgrades, software enhancements, and exp levels. Aside from being able to equip software to boost exp gain, there isn't anything to the levels, no skill trees or points to distribute. The weapons feature an upgrade system with 4 levels per weapon and requires a combination of currency and materials to enhance. Simply doing occasional side quests and a little bit of looting during the story will be enough to max out a couple weapons well before you need them, but maxing all the weapons is an endeavor. Harkening back to the first Drakengard game, all weapons have a story that gets revealed with each weapon level. Lastly, the software in the form of chips is where players can tweak their builds to suite their playstyle and manage their HUD. Throughout the game the player will receive enough chips to keep their character functional, but optimizing a build, while unnecessary, will involve a lot of looting and is very rewarding. The game seems to be balanced around inefficient chips that are doled out during the story so people who go out of their way to min-max will likely find themselves overleveled and overpowered.There are difficulty settings to tweak the experience. I haven't played on easy but there are a plethora of optional chips a player can use to make the game play itself almost, so players who aren't very skilled can still enjoy the game. The higher difficulties receive a lot of mixed reviews for being way too hard or too easy, and I haven't seen any complaints about the normal setting. The one thing I can assure you is that you have options. While the game does not feature permadeath, it does have a death system similar to Dark Souls that can potentially be more punishing. If you don't recover your body before dieing a second time you lose your chips, which can be crippling. The game does not use auto save for immersion purposes so this can be gotten around in the rare case of a bug or for players who would rather wimp out and reload than lose a lot of time investment in chip building. I personally don't blame them as that would cause a lot of quitting if there wasn't a workaround, especially in the case of a crash or bug.The combat is what you can expect from a platinum game, fast paced, emphasizes timing and dodging, and mixes melee and ranged attacks. It's the meat of the game and the most fleshed out part, it's fast and fun and keeps the game going. It's probably the biggest reason I struggle to put the game down.Edit: Also, Jackass is best waifu ^_^

												Out of all the gems this year, (too many imo, my wallet is dying) this is the first true contender for GOTY.  I loved Nioh, Zelda was overhyped to the point it was maddening but it was still a great game, but Nier, Nier is something truly special.  For having so many different kinds of gameplay fused into one game, Square-Enix and Platinum has proven to be a match made in heaven.  It all flows together so well, it just never gets dull or repetitive.   Which was my only gripe with the original Nier, the combat and gameplay could have used some more time in the oven.This feels like a slightly toned down Bayonetta/Devil May Cry in a well realized Square Enix open world.  A world that is giving me strange Metal Gear and Ghost in the Shell vibes, possibly due to the stellar soundtrack, sound effects and source material.  The characters have that bizarre Nier charm that was more common to many of the anime from the late 80's/early 90's.  The world isn't the prettiest, but it's far from ugly.  The enemy and boss designs are on a whole other level, some being extremely memorable and even breathtaking to behold.Honestly, I'm getting the same kind of vibes I got playing Secret of Mana back in the day on SNES.  It's just so damned addictive.  It cleverly breaks walls like the popular rpgmaker title One Shot but I won't spoil any of it.  Just get this game, avoid any and all spoilers and dive in.  It's beyond incredible!  10/10

I'm glad to say I was wrong.It's hard to describe what makes this game so special since it does play like you'd expect but there's a secret sauce, a specific combination of atmosphere, story, style and music that just makes something that feels like a real game and not a calculated product.That being said, there are some PC specific issues that should NEVER be present in a $60 PC release. I believe NieR:Automata is a genuine classic, something we'll look back to for years to come and with a few patches/mods, a must have PC game.
