												I played about 80 Hours and got the plat trophy for the Japanese PS4 version. I won't say too much about the story, but if you have even a little interest in this game, you owe it to yourself to make sure you start your 3rd playthrough, just trust me. The gameplay isn't flawless, Platinum rarely is, you tend to get their extreme highs along with some rough edges. Theres some bland boss segments, a forced walking segment with enemies who can attack and stagger you(just an aggravating moment at a high story beat). The space shooter stuff is fun, but too easy, probably figured the play testers had trouble and toned it down or something. ♥♥♥♥it, the good is way better than the slightly agitating.Overall, the original Nier is a masterpiece of storytelling, but the gameplay is far from refined. I feel confident saying that Nier: Automata doesn't just bring an extremely good story and characters without making you deal with mediocre gameplay, but Nier:Automata brings all the Yoko Taro story with truly wonderful, smooth and satisfying P+ gameplay. You know that feeling you get the moment you control a Platinum game? Yeah, you get that and a lot of feels, what more could you want.

												At around 15 hours with this game I reached ending A. At that point I thought I had a pretty solid grasp of this game, and I was impressed enough to write a review (first time I've ever done that). After another 15 hours and 7 more endings, I can say with absolute confidence that ending A was nowhere nier (ha) what this game has to offer. This game truly blew me away.The story of this game starts off intriguing but a bit slow. Stick with it however, and you'll be rewarded with an above average experience as you finish ending A. However, the game truly shines once you return to the menu and start the game again. Side quests and boss encounters that seemed mysterious or pointless are suddenly filled with meaning and powerful emotion. The characters and their relationships are fleshed out so much further that you feel a genuine connection to all of them. The gameplay continues to astound and never ceases to surprise. Although 26 endings may be too many for some people, you really only have to play to ending E in order to experience the "main" story of the game and this is absolutely worth it. I cannot possibly give this game a higher recommendation. Nier:Automata is a masterpiece and has reached my top 5 games of all time list and I hope that you give it a shot too. And if all this doesn't convince you at least give it a shot for 2B's ♥♥♥...tounding sword skills ;).

content:
19
												Overall, a pretty good game, though you'll need a higher-end computer to play it without issues. NieR Automata is a sequel to the previous NieR game (though playing the prequel is not required) which is itself a spinoff of the fifth ending of the game Drakengard, which, again, is not required. NieR: Automata does a good job of introducing the characters and setting in a way that doesn't feel like a huge infodump.In terms of gameplay, it feels reminiscent of Dark Souls, in that if you die, instead of dropping all your Souls, you drop any plug-in chips you had equipped (the equivalent of skills, there is huge room for customization, particularly because you only have limited space, and more advanced chips take up more space) and a small amount of experience. If you make it back to your body without dying, you can reclaim the items you dropped (but not if you die en route). If you really want a challenge, the hardest difficulty (difficulty can be changed mid-game) causes you to die in one hit (the evade button is your friend). However, even on Easy, you can't get complacent, because there are enemies that can still oneshot you. Easy difficulty also has a number of "auto-battle" chips that you can equip, that do things like auto-shoot, auto-dodge, auto-melee that can be equipped at your leisure (and can only be equipped on Easy).The default keyboard/mouse controls are a little wonky if you don't rebind them (like \ and / being your melee attack binds, and left/right shift being your ranged attack binds), but there is the option to do so.There are also a ton of fun easter eggs, like a Steam Achievement for looking up 2B's skirt 10 times, or how if you self-destruct in the space station you blow it up and the game ends. Pros:-Fantastic combat system that feels fluid and responsive.-Great story-Voice acting is pretty good-Soundtrack is baller-You'll only get loading screens if you fast travel or die.Cons:-Highish minimum specs required to play the game above low graphics.-Fullscreen bug (alt-tabbing changes it to windowed mode)-The cutscenes are pre-rendered and can have framerate dips.-Much like Dark Souls, you'll have a better time playing this on a controller than with a Keyboard/Mouse. Unlike Dark Souls, it's very much playable with Keyboard/Mouse controls though.

												There are bad games, there are good games, there are great games, and then are games that blow your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mind and Nier is firmly in the latter category. Just when you think the game has reached peak insanity, just when you think the story has reached peaked insanity, it goes one better.. and then does it again... and again.. and again right up until you've finished the game in a handful of sittings and have no idea what to do next as nothing in your Steam library will compare to what you've just experienced.There are flaws, yes, performance could be better, the cutscenes are poorly rendered, the sidequests aren't all that great (in terms of being fun, story wise they're great), but who cares about any of that when the story is so captivating, when the characters are so captivating, when the soundtrack is godlike, when the combat is a blast to play. I could go on, but I won't. Buy it.

												Let's face it, this port is seriously sub-par. Fullscreen only has one resolution that works, cutscenes are jerky and have weird bars at the top and bottom of the screen, and the game just doesn't seem to know how to load anything. Hacking during combat is immersion breaking because it sometimes takes up to 10 seconds for the minigame to appear. I once stepped into a room only to watch all of the npcs in it fall into a bottomless pit, because they spawned before the floor did.But the fact is, I would still recommend this game. The gameplay is fun and engaging, though you'll want a gamepad and to rebind some controls unless you have two thumbs on your right hand. Even on higher difficulties, whenever you die it's because of a mistake you made and that's what makes me want to keep trying at it. The soundtrack is beyond excellent. The story and characters are compelling, and only get moreso as the game continues.If you think the port issues are going to be too much of an issue for you, hold off until this gets some patches. Otherwise, this is a great game that should absolutely be on your list.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
22
												Yoko Taro finally had his dream come true with having a studio: Platinum Games, capable of creating what he's envisioned properly. The biggest gripe of any of his games has been the gameplay whereas the plot has been one spectacle after another. If you don't know of the prior games it goes in this order:Drakengard 3 - Drakengard - Nier - Nier: AutomataNo knowledge of the former games are really needed except maybe Nier and Ending E on Drakengard. But those get explained fairly well in data-logs littered in the latter sections of Automata. To get the elephant out of the room immediately, the plot is good. It's developed at a reasonable pace and you're introduced to things as slowly as was possible in the oddity of a world. Things that initially made no sense and which I thought were products of bad writing were actually hidden meanings that you don't grasp until you fully explore the game. There's an open-amount of content unless more things become discovered to allow for each person to theorize how many of the plot elements came about. I think the fact that the plot can encourage such long conversations over the material is enough reason for anyone to understand that something meaningful is there.The gameplay is solid all around and it's how should I say... unique? The game was displayed as this Action-RPG game but is instead an Action-RPG, SHMUP, and Metroidvania styled game all rolled up into a great big jawbreaker. The elements come at a varied pace so it doesn't feel repetitive as you progress. To me the game reminded me SO MUCH of Kingdom Hearts, not the ones with QTEs but the original game but maybe it was just me.The music also gets a huge plus as I've followed since D3, Nier, and now Automata and the composer has only grown better with time. I had such high hopes for this OST and they managed to outdo my expectations.There are some elements I dislike about the game but it goes into mechanics for spoiler stuff so I'll leave it alone, all of the things I have 'problems' with could stem from me having sped through the game and playing nonstop but quite frankly I just couldn't put this game down until it was completed.SO PLAY THE GAME. FIND IT ALL OUT AND EXPERIENCE IT.Don't go looking for help, just go into this game blind and you'll come out completely blown away. Avoid spoilers with all of your strength. And remember to just keep going. You'll reach a point where you think you can't. But you can.

My "Semi-tl;dr-Review" of NieR: Automata™ProsInteresting story that really makes you think about lifeFluid combatGreat visualsTop notch animationsGorgeous soundtrackLarge open world with a lot of secrets that are right under your noseDifficulties for all kinds of players; from automatic functions to 1-shot killsCustomization through chips that affect the way you play the game (Offensive, defensive and support chips)Dead players leave corpses which you can retrieve for temporary boostsYou can also resurrect those corpses so they aid you in combatA lot of side quests that don't feel repetitive or boringBullethell "minigames"Tons of different endingsConsColor theme is kinda grey-ish, you'll get used to it thoughPS4 port with no PS4 buttons on PCMinor fps drops but no game breaking bugsHard to get invested in the story early on; It gets WAY better towards the endSome random thoughtsI've only played Drakengard 3 prior to this game and I can say that you don't HAVE to play the previous game to understand what is going on.If you're concerned about it or just want to be prepared, you can always check some of the many lore videos and walls of text made just for this situation.I have probably missed quite a lot of references to the previous games but that didn't stop me from enjoying this game.Some people may find it hard to justify spending 60€ on a single-player game, but the amount of content in this game is absolutely worth it.

												This game is probably one of my top 5 games of all time. The story is told so perfectly. I played this game for only a couple of days because it was just impossible to put down. Yoko Taro has outdone himself. Having not played the original Nier games, there was some confusion at first, but even so the game does a good job of leaving hints for you to find. On top of that, Keiichi Okabe's score is breathtaking. Not only are the tracks well-done, but each song has been tailor made for the mood of the area or time. If you play on the higher difficulties, there are some awful parts that you might die at, but overall it's well-paced and the checkpoints are plentiful, but not overwhelming. If you want the best experience, I'd recommend doing the first mission on normal, and then switching the difficulty to hard or very hard.This is not a game I'll soon forget. Not for the butt, which to be honest is glorious on its own, but actually for the game itself. If you have the chance, buy this game, whether it's on sale or not, it's worth every penny.

												I'm not usually compelled to write steam reviews, but this game touched me in a special way. A gentle curess, that turned into an inappropriate touch, that turned into a slap in the face, that turned into warm feels. If anything consider them "chapters" Chapter A, B, C. For maximum feels I recommend going through to E, it's what compelled me to write this review. Anyway, I'm exausted and I can't write when I'm at 100%. I hope you read through my gibberish and took something out of it.

Will update as I playthrough, but as for now, until the issues making the game slightly unplayable are fixed, you should wait for a patch before playing.

												After completing my first playthrough, I have now decided to write a review. Pros:+ Very fun third person action similar to DMC, but not as in-depth. There are some cool combos you can do but after a while it gets repetitive and you can only mix and match so much+ Large world that you can explore as much as you want as well as a plethora of side-quests which can get a little overwhelming but you are free to do them at your pace+ Really good story although I wouldn't necessarily call it a masterpiece but that may change with subsequent playthroughsCons:- Maybe it's just me but the world kind of felt a little fake to me. Due to this it was hard to get immersed in it.- 9S kinda annoyed me as I prefer to be aloneThe cons are not game-breaking obviously and are just my own personal thoughts on the world and 9S. But otherwise a solid game and recommended. Make sure you install FAR patch on steam discussion forums to get performance boost and fix any bugs with fullscreen.

												I have to say I was very much looking forward to Nier, and I was not disappointed in the slightest. I know you don't want me to get into a long paragraph so i'll hop into the pros, cons, and then what I think about NieR as a whole.PROS:-Great visuals-Great audio and music-Combat feels smooth and fluid-The voice acting is good-I find myself caring and sympathizing for the major characters-Gives a Dark Souls esk feel to a certain degree-The world is large, open, vibrant, and rewards exploration. With the world having a large sence of contrast between different areas.-Interesting story that gets right into it and doesn't break flow very often-Constantly switches to and from third person and top down combat that keeps things fresh and from getting to staleCONS:-Not everything is voice acted. There are quite a few conversations between characters, even early on in the game, that have no voices from either character that really kills the flow and immersion. Though for everything story related is fully voice acted.-The cutscenes are nowhere near 60fps, so if you run the game at a constant 60, then a cutscene pops up, it will seem very laggy.In conclusion I full heatedly recommend NieR:automana to anyone who is thinking about buying it. The amount of content, as well as the quality of it, you get within the game is well worth the $60 price tag. I've been hearing a lot about people having constant crashes with the game ot bugs with fullscreen, however, in the time I have played so far I haven't encountered a single issue so far.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
23
												Updated: Clean-up, tl:dr for those who don't like to read through a thesis.Possible spoilers ahead.Saw the trailer last February amongst many other recommendations of cat videos(thanks youtube) and thought its awesome and was going to be a console exclusive but then saw that it was going to be on steam. I really enjoyed Bayonetta on XBOX, so since its from platinum I was excited because I haven't played any since then. I tried not to give in to the hype and managed to hold on for a few days but the train ran me over and next thing I knew I had already pre-ordered(THE VALVE ACCESSORIES ARE F'KIN UGLY!!!). I was concerned because of the pre-order ♥♥♥♥storm in recent games and this is the only game I have pre-ordered ever. So to console myself I thought, 'if anything I'll just be satisfied from seeing 2B's butt' and only had expectations on 2B's backside. Woah this is one long prelude, I dont read and write reviews so forgive this wall of text.Butt I will write this anyway because I can't stop thinking about the game and can't sleep properly. I Played it 3 days straight from release with a few hours of sleep and got mindhumped. How the whole plot unfolded was probably how it made my eyes sweat a little bit, every character's part in the whole campaign against the enemy and their fate when it all ends.THE SOUNDTRACK!       I usually turn off the music/BGM everytime I start a game, but (very)fortunately for me the game did not allow me to mute it on the first screen and totally forgot to set it in-game, so I got to hear amazingly beautiful music(literally makes my head tingle every time, I hope it's not cancer). First time I've laid down controls just to listen to the BGM. I think plenty of thought has been put into the soundtrack and how they're implemented during in-game events. The track that plays on your first encounter with Adam & Eve(this cannot continue?) is a good example, it is a strange(ly good) tune but it captures the feeling of the event. Another good one is on a certain ending, once you accept an assistance offer, a whole choir starts to hum/sing with the theme song which is amazing(the songs included). The ending theme songs are awesome, they all relate to the circumstance, motivations and attitudes of the characters.Gameplay       I never expected a DMC/Bayonetta level of combat depth because it is a mash of multiple genres after all, but still the mechanics are very solid and is still very enjoyable. I really prefer the swordplay so 9S' playthrough felt less enjoyable since his move set doesn't appeal as much as the others. 'Open-world' - Environment stays true to the game's setting with bland colours throughout. It is small but enough for farming materials/chips or mindlessly slashing everything that moves. Eploration will reward you with fragments of background story information(archive entries mostly) so it's worth doing if you want to understand the whole plot. Raises a problem if you're a farmer like me where at some point your level will be way higher than the next story mission and you'll just be breezing through some stages. Controller/Gamepad - Not absolutely necessary, but will significantly improve your whole experience with the game especially with the shooter/bullet hell parts. They've allowed us to change keybindings with the kb&m, but there is just very little else to do for those who do not have controllers/gamepads. Besides you really don't expect the best experience with kb&m for this kind of game right?Performance       No complaints, dont really care about super fancy graphics. 2B's bottom still looks fabulous on my screen even on upscaled resolution. game runs at constant 60fps(1600x900 upscaled) on AMD R9 280x, blur & AA off all else max, might crash if you insist on clearing it alone, no other issues since launch. Issues - upscaling resolution, probably the only issue for me but I don't particularly mind because it allows me to ramp up the settings without performance loss(game still looks beautiful imo)and I have a relatively small monitor(1600x900). I have tried it with borderless gaming, it works great and everything looks crisp and better in true native resolution however framerate did go down 55 on a crowded battle and experienced noticable screen tearing(v-sync doesnt seem to work in window mode), it is possible to run better if settings are lowered.Story       Made my eyes sweat, can't stop thinking of the game after I cleared it. The different playthroughs will give you different perspectives of the story and insights to the character's attitudes and motivations. Doing the side quests will give you a better idea of the whole situation(how goes the fight and how the non main characters feel), plenty of philosophical questions too to fry your neurons. I have never played a lot of story heavy games, I can only think of Witcher 3, which could be the reason why I got blown away by this game. But whatever the case it was an amazing experience, alot of emotions, never had anything like it. I suggest you read the archive entries if you want to make better sense of all the things that are happening, it will really allow you to appreciate the story better.THE END      I think my system has cleared all that caffeine, so I'll go back to my corner and wait for another amazing fish to swim down the river. Maybe I'll try and clear hard with bare fists while I wait.Thanks to the selfless people who sacrificed their hard work to help out in the [E]nding.Square Enix, the true final boss.Supposed happy ending made me feel sadder than I expected.I hope this game doesn't get overshadowed by other big releases this season.I wish I could erase the memory of playing the game so I could experience the same high.Honestly though I got fished by sexy android bottoms on the trailers, I'm so glad I got a lot more than what I came in for.Futility & Irony.Awesome trip, totally worth it.If you've read all of this reflection paper pretending to be a review, you should just buy the game, seriously, you know you really like it if you read through all of this (ง°ل͜°)ง. I wonder if I can submit this 1000+word 'review' for my midterm paper realteer: GREAT BACKSIDE COVERAGE, BEAUTIFUL SOUNDTRACK, GREAT DESIGN, GREAT STORY, SOLID COMBAT MECHANICS & ANIMATIONS, AMAZING GAME, ALL OF IT![/b]. I will be thinking of this for a long time(ಥ﹏ಥ)[27/3]Possible technical issues(patch incoming): resolution upscaling, white/black screen, crashing, doesn't work well on a toaster.Other issues: Enemy scaling does not apply to all enemies when trying to replay thru your completed save, some enemies scale while others do not. You'll end up one hitting enemies or get one hitted(if you dont have defense upgrades) yourself on hard difficulty.THANK YOU PLATINUM GAMES AND SQUARE ENIX FOR BRINGING THIS AMAZING GAME TO PC!Updated: 27/3/17 Clean up. (slightly proper writing, justice for an amazing game)

												Game kicked my ♥♥♥ for 9 hours in the first mission(I love hard mode, since witcher 3). 42 hours later, I got nothing to show for it, other than achievements and missing bosses I'll have to grind back to.The game is damn good, I mean, while the story is kinda easy to predict, it's still worth going for it. Gameplay has all all the variety from Platinum and a bit more, you got guns, barehand, swords, greatswords, spears, lasers, missiles, super-tech-magic stuff, and you can combine it to suit your style(combat bracers and spears were my groove there).As for a Yoko Taro story, it's my first one, I really liked it, though, I don't think I'll be tackling all of Drakengard and NIer any time soon. The visuals are really cool. The whole world is not that big, dont' expect Skyrim size of open world, but very varied. The character design was astounding. Though, I was never a fan or A2's design. I guess we all have our favorites.Now, on to the technical issues, this game has them, in spades, sadly, not well optimized, prone to freezing, graphical crashes, that 900p. They were not a deal breaker for me, since I saved often, and I play modded Skyrim, so I got CTDs down. I really hope they fix it, since they are only technical issues, they are meant to be fixed at some point or well, look around for workarounds, that's PC gaming for ya.Aside from that, totally recommmended, at least get it during a steam offer or for like a 20% discount.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
28
												I'll start my review by saying that I have never been more satisfied with a video game purchase in my life. I knew what I wanted from this game, and it gave me exactly that -- I don't think any game no matter how good has given me exactly what I wanted. I mean, if it says anything, I think this is the only game I have ever not just 100%, but actually read every single tiny bit of side dialogue, every snippet, archive, and tiny bit of information I could get my hands on. That's impressive, when you compare it my time in Elder Scrolls games or even the Witcher 3, where I read maybe a few books out of the dozens in those games.NieR:Automata is a superb experience for anyone looking for a puzzling but not unpredictable story, with characters that all grow on you the longer you play. A lot of the cast I didn't even like at first, but as the game continued, I feel like I became more attached to them than a lot of more fleshed out characters in other games. That's quite impressive. Understanding why a character is the way they are is very satisfying, the the cast plays so well off of each other -- 2B and 9S's dialogue with each other specifically I found very charming. The gameplay itself is certainly a very nice blend of the original Nier and Platinum's usual affair. It's not wholly my cup of tea, as I prefer more concise combat engines, but for what it is, it is very responsive, satisfying and decently skillful. Sort of a 3rd person bullet hell at certain times, which can in certain instances in the game be a bit... hard to see, if nothing else. There is a lot of running around though, especially if you want to 100% the game, so prepare yourself for that if you're a completionist like myself. The sound design is also great, from the voice acting, sounds and the absolutely breath-taking OST, which I know is already going to be playing on loop for me for the next few months. I don't think it'll be everyone's cup of tea, as it involves of vocal elements, but to say it doesn't fit the game would be a downright lie. Some of the songs setup scenes and emotional responses so well it's -- well, it's nicely done, I'll be modest about it, heh heh.I guess this is the part where I just do pros and cons:Pros:- Great Story, that is possible to predict but can be quite puzzling -- which to me are the best kind of stories- Characters are very enjoyable and unique- Well written, very little dialogue felt off to me- No requirement to have played the first Nier, although it makes you appreciate the game more- Combat is fast-paced and skillful enough to keep you focused, while mindless enough when you're just treking away- Decent amount of character customization which opens up a lot of playstyles- Music is astounding- SFX is also really nice- Can alter the difficulty whenever and it has no hidden meaning other than challenge (no hard only endings)- 100%ing the game is at least convenient to do end-game, but it is tedious- World I would say is "just" the right size to not be overwhelming- Contains a few moments which will stick with you forever (a guarantee from me)Cons:- PC version has issues (resolution in full screen, shaky optimization at times)- A lot of running around- Certain side characters and areas COULD have been more fleshed out- Dialogue for side-NPCs rarely changes and acknowledges events (though I understand why)- Exploration "can" be rewarding, but is very tedious- Poor character balance (I don't mind in single player games, but it is very blatant that some weapons/sub weapons are way better than others)- Normal to Hard mode difficulty is mostly a damage scaling alteration, which can be annoying when some random projectiles might one shot on hard, but others won't - can be hard to tell, so slot max HP UP, heh heh- Completionists, prepare for a bit of randomness and farming- You won't want to go to work until you finish the storyOverall:I don't think every person is going to enjoy this game as much as I did, but if you're looking for something that will satisfy your desire for an intriguing story, that is not afraid to pull punches, then you may well enjoy this game as much as I did. This game climbed as I played it from okay, to great, to now being in my top 3 favorite games of all time. There's thousands of games to contend with, so if that intrigues you, I challenge you to find out whether this game deserves "2B" in your own top list!

content:

												I always thought that a great video game is a sum of its' parts. I always thought it's alll about combining engaging mechanics with a compelling story. When you judge individual aspects of this game, it's all far from remarkable. The combat is good, but Platinum has delivered much better games. The story is interesting but there's enough ridiculous plotholes  to drive anyone insane. The RPG elements and the questing system are functional but you could find similar systems done better in many games. Yet, having said all that, Nier Automata is one of the most special gaming experiences I've ever had in my life. Before playing Nier Automata I was simply unaware that a video game is capable of evoking such strong emotions in the player. Mr. Taro's masterpiece is a game that will  remain in your memory until the day you die. I don't want to talk about the specifics because literally anything I say could be considered a spoiler. I'll just say this: If you happen to harbor deep love for gaming as a medium, not playing Nier Automata would be a crime. If you want games to evolve beyond silly shooters for teenagers, this is it. It's a game that will not only make you appreciate video games. It will also make you appreciate fellow human beings and the constant everyday struggle most of us find ourselves inArigatou Gozaimasu Taro San  P.S:. 9s is supposed to be annoying, it's not bad VO, like the internet seems to be claiming :P Just give it some time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
30
												I rarely finish games. I play 10-20 hours of them, then get distracted by something else and move on. In my 15+ years of playing games, I can count the number of games that I've finished on two hands. After 60 hours of playing, I just finished all major endings of NieR: Automata. This game, far moreso than any long RPG I've ever touched, does everything it can to remain engaging throughout. I was still being surprised and delighted up to the very end -- and I mean the VERY end. It flirts with your expectations of what will and even CAN happen, and it does so with a confidence rarely seen in the RPG world.Without spewing out lines and lines of expository dialogue at every turn, it makes you care about characters, shows them change, breaks your heart, and manages to showcase an uncommonly nihilistic perspective while still, somehow, feeling uplifting.Oh, and despite all its experimentation, it sits on a foundation of incredibly polished and satisfying gameplay. Really, I can think of few negatives. Its less-than-AAA budget is clear, leading to some kind of empty environments and a lot of invisible walls. Also, the unnecessarily sexualized outfits of the main female characters wasn't great, but the sexualization begins and ends with the outfits, which is refreshing--the characters, animations, and most importantly, the camera never objectify the characters. So, unlike most cases, it really is a minor complaint.NieR: Automata has easily made it into the list of the most memorable and influencial video game experiences of my life. But because of its nature, it's really difficult to say any more without spoiling the experience. All I'll say is that the way it uses the medium of video games to tell its story is wholely unique and unforgettable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
27
												Confession: I'm honestly just going to gush about the game. If you're looking for a more in-depth, critical review, I'm afraid I can't help. If you're looking to read the ramblings of someone who just finished the game, then welcome.You might think that this is a game about androids destroying robots in the distant future.Well, you'd be right, actually. But it becomes so much more than that, to the point I don't even have words to describe it. If there was ever a game I'd say is a 'must buy', it just got knocked off the shelf and replaced by NieR:Automata, possibly for all time.Now, a heads-up: this is kinda a poor port, and i struggled with driver crashes and resolution issues (the latter I didn't entirely care about, however). That being said, I'm normally picky about that sort of thing, yet I pulled through and didn't let it hamper my enjoyment of the game much at all.I played through the entire game on Hard, and would heartily reccomend it. Granted, yes, the prologue can be fairly difficult, and you are unable to save until you've completed it, but I would nonetheless reccomend it - sharpening your combat skills that early on will go a long way, believe me. Of course, you can change the difficulty at any time, and there are NO achievements for beating the game on a certain difficulty. As I said, I reccomend Hard, but that's for a combination of Story and gameplay. If you just want to experience the story (and props to you if you do, it's amazing!), Normal is more than enough.The story is...admittedly convoluted and philosophical as hell, but that's what makes it so...beautiful.What does it mean to be human? To be an android? To be a machine?To be alive?To be?What does ANYTHING mean?Is it a simple difference of parts and logic circuits, or something more?The way NieR:Automata tells its story is unlike anything I've ever seen, and the endings (there's 26 of them!) are each  magnificent (and sometimes hilarious), ESPECIALLY the true ending. You owe it to yourself to leap in as blind as possible, and experience all that the game has to offer. It is worth it - every single bit is all worth it.....promptly followed by buying the soundtrack. And a second playthrough, probably.Of course, i'm not sure if anyone will read this review/recommendation/emotional ramble or not.But...Glory to mankind.

												This is the first game ive ever played that i believe deserves a review. NieR: Automata is truly a phenominal masterpiece. the graphics are ominous yet strikingly gorgeous, the open world is vast and diverse, combat is fluid and fully immersive, the changing camera angles brought on nostalga from old arcade games and threw you right back into over the shoulder mode keeping you on your toes, and the characters are deep and complex, with unique and changing dialouge to each character. i was so excited on my first playthrough to find out what happens next that i completely forgot about many sidequests and wanted to discover the mysteries this main plot had to offer. i finished the game in 6 hours straight. i loved every second of it. also with that said, i went back to do everything NieR: Automata has to offer. this is one of those games you will be thinking of long after the ending credits roll. the multiple endings leave much to still yet discover. absolutely 10/10 game.that said, the controls took a minute to get used to and the toutorial was on a racetrack to finishing itself. i would have wished to see it slowed down a little bit. but that was something rectified with a couple chances to reread the help screens. seriously Devs, fantastic job.

												NieR: Automata is one of those experiences i won't forget.It's enchanting OST, incredibly beautiful visuals, intriguing storyline and most importantly fantastic gameplay leads to a game that you just keep coming back to.My expectations for this game were high and it still managed to greatly surprise with its quality and also makes me want to try the previous games from the series, as it is my first one.What really brought me to this game was it's similarity with Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance since it was developed by the same company and i definitely wasn't left dissapointed, it was absolutely worth paying the full price, many other developers should watch and learn how to make a great fully priced titles.My only complaints would be about the game's optimalization in some places, and the developer's response to them, NieR: Automata has been out for a week and currently there is still no patch that would adress the most prominent issues with their product (although it was announced that they are aware of the game's problems and are working on fixing them).Also i feel like the game could have a bit better side quests and activities, since they can get repetetive after while, but i still might be a bit spoiled from The Witcher 3 so excuse me if i'm being picky.I would also like to give huge Thank You to some of the community members that worked on their own patches in order to fix the fullscreen bug and improve the game's performance, you guys are Gods among men.I hope that Yoko Taro-Senpai will team up with Platinum Games once more in the future to make another great product as it is match made in heaven.My final score for the game is a strong 9/10.

content:

												Excellent game, but terrible PC optimization.I'll start with this issue: the optimization is awful. It had me drop the game's resolution to 1600x1200 while my screen can support 1980x1080, and even this sacrifice couldn't make me play at more than 30FPS (mostly 25 in open world) with medium settings. It's been very hard to adapt to such low FPS. Furthermore, the keyboard controls (yes, I forgot my controller at home before leaving but couldn't wait to get it back to start playing this game) include some issues such as the dodging system, which requires you to double tap a direction key (WASD) instead of taping one key while moving. Navigating between usable items without opening the main menu is pretty tough as well, so what I did basically was binding the keys to my mouse and it works just fine.Enough of these system issues, let's now talk about the game. It is a true masterpiece. The main scenario is great, even though it is a little bit too short, but it doesn't really matter because the game is based on replaying the story several times to get every single spark of awesomeness this game can bring. The sidequests are even more excellent, the feeling of saving a fellow android or seeing machines think about what they can bring to the world they live in is a great experience and made me think about our own life as humans.In addition to a incredible scenario, what I HAVE to talk about is the OST. IT. IS. AMAZING! I seldom heared anything that good in a videogame to be honest. Chills, tears, happiness, fear, motivation, these are 5 of the countless feelings the different soundtracks brought me while playing. They contribute widely to an absolutely immersing environment.I could give more and more good points, but I have to make it a bit shorter (eh), so I'll just write down the only thing that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off: I really didn't enjoy being forced to playing 9S while doing some VERY important sidequests or roaming to find hidden chests. I think every character should've acquired the ability of hacking after completing routes A, B and C/D. Don't get me wrong, I like the character and the way it evolves through the entire story, but damn I would just like to play the other characters! But they keep forcing me into playing him because he's the only one who can hack things.Anyway, I HIGHLY recommend this game for anyone who likes RPG's. Though I think the PC version is not optimized at all, I think a better PC setup would actually make it run way more smoothely than my PC does. Still, running it in HQ would require a very powerful setup in my opinion.Have fun playing NieR: Automata!

												The PC version of NieR: Automata is an OK-ish "port". It certainly has its flaws but is by far not the worst.Let me show you how I run the game:GPU: R9 280CPU: FX 6300 (6 x 3.79 GHz)RAM: 8 GBOS: Win10 64-BitMy game settings are:Anti-Aliasing: x8---> offTexture filter: x16---> x8Blur---> onShadows: high/medium/low---> lowEffects: high/low---> highAmbient Occlusion---> offWith my system and these settings I can run the game on 1080p at 50-60 fps without any problems. Knowing that my system can run The Witcher 3 at high settings, yet maintaining a steady 60 fps, it's kind of a bummer. I'm pretty sure I could run Automata at max settings at a smooth 60 fps as well, if it was better optimized.Port problems:  fullscreen mode is buggy for quite a few people, myself included. The game internally renders the game to 900p and scales it up to whatever resolution you picked. A workaround is to use Borderless Window.  white screen/black screen for some people  if your CPU has an integrated GPU, make sure the game uses your dedicated GPU because it might use the former by default  game freezes for some peopleThe game itself is simply amazing, that's all I can say. I love every second of it. If you want more details you're better off watching a review on YT or something.Port:    7/10Game: 10/10

												I've been looking for "the game" for a long time now- something that sucks me in and makes me really want to keep playing  longer than an hour or so.  I thought I'd never find it, but I took a gamble on this one, and it is utterly transcendant.  It takes me back to the days where I could sit and marathon a game for days- looking for secrets, tweaking my stats, spamming the jump button, and smashing up bad guys.I'm entirely sold- worth every penny.  If you're looking for a game to help you remember what it was like to love gaming- one that gives you the chills you got the first time you saw a Colossus, that gives you flashbacks to the climactic combat of Chaos Legion, and has enough sparkles, whosits, and explosions to knock your socks off (even in 1600:900), this is it.RE: HardwareNo issues at 1900:600 on an AMD FX8320  @3.5GHz + 16GB DDR3 + Sapphire RX480 OC 8GB.  Haven't even tried a higher resolution yet because there's already so much stuff to look at my eyes are basically bleeding.  Do kids these days have supervision or something???  Honestly, my brain is having trouble not getting distracted by the sweeping landscapes as it is- I think I'd probably stroke out at 4k + 60Hz or whatever the new hotness is.Don't even get me started on the soundtrack- suffice it to say that it's tear-jerkingly beautiful and heart-stirringly epic.Plus, the whole thing just oozes a "cool sexy-carbon-fiber vs post-apocalyptic machinepunk" aesthetic.  Seriously, if you've got the money and you're on the fence- pull the trigger.  Treat yourself.  There are a heckuvalot of worse ways to spend the weekend.

												While there seem to be many people getting poor performance, stuttering, crashes and various resolution/display bugs I can't say I've had any issues in the 30 minutes I've played using 6700K/1070/16GB RAM/SSD.Max settings (but no AA). Playing at 2560x1440 (downsampled to a 1080p display, because I figured I'd rather have actual resolution than AA do the smoothing).Resolution/fullscreen settings are definitely working as 1600x900 looks very bad compared to 1920x1080, and 2560x1440 looks cleaner than 1920x1080 (though the UI seems in the menus seems to look identical no matter what resolution the game is set at). This tells me that people having issues with resolution setting/fullscreen mode are being hit with a bug of some kind (rather than those features simply not being implemented out of developer oversight or something).Not a single dip so far. A perfect 60, other than the cutscenes which run at 30. And I haven't seen any of the cutscene stuttering that some people have been experiencing.The long and short of it is whilst many certainly seem to be having issues with the game, others don't. So it's an iffy, tempermental port that may or may not play well with your machine, but it's not a hopelessly poorly optimised one that is doomed to run terribly either.If you're on the fence I suggest buying and trying.

												After finishing all the major endings, these are my final thoughts on the game.Pros:+ Great story and characters	+ Despite some cliche moments and characters its one of the best story lines in an RPG I've played + World Design	+ Every zone has its own charm, and it all wraps together nicely to give off a post apocalyptic/battle torn feel well. 	+ Perfect for exploring, some stunning scenery from places around the world+ Music and sound	+ The music in this game is incredible, the best soundtrack I've heard in a game. The sound design for everything else is top notch + Combat	+ While basic on the surface, it does have enough depth to make it fun to use while still leaving room for crazy combos	+ Weapons work together in a way that lets the player tailor their combat style to the situation at hand	+ Explore to find more weapons to suit your play style Not Pros but Not Cons:+- Hacking	+- If you're like me, you will probably get sick of the hacking...Its just too good of a "weapon" with not much variation. My solution was to kick it down to easy and let the game play the sequences instead of hating myself for the rest of the game. Then turning it back up when you get to do some actual combat. Cons:- Performance	- Fps Drops, low FPS cut scenes...While most of the game it performed fine, a few boss fights really had my fps chugging and the cut scenes are totally noticeable.	- Full screen bug, fixed with FAR (on the steam forums) but still annoyingAll in all, it was a fantastic game. Its too bad you don't lose your memory of the game along with your save at the final decision...I would love to experience the game over again for the first time.9.5/10 - 0.5 off for performanceSpecs:Intel i5 3550 3.3ghzNvidia GTX 960 2gb16Gigs 1600Mhz ramSamsung SSD

												----------------------------Nier Automata at a glance:----------------------------Pros:- Compelling narrative with great characters, lore, and thought-provoking concepts.- Great aesthetic and art direction.- Great combat. This game is extremely narrative-driven and as such it favors a much more accessible combat system so while it is not as sophisticated as many would like it is still extremely fun and satisfying as we've come to expect from Platinum.- Phenominal soundtrack. The composer from the original Nier returns to deliver an incredibly powerful soundtrack that truly sets the atmosphere and helps brings the story to life.- As expected from a Yoko Taro game, Nier Automata incorporates some unconventional story-telling and gameplay design but unlike his previous titles these elements are extremely well-implemented this time around making for a very rich gameplay experience that remains faithful to the original Nier while still adding a few extra surprises.Cons:- PC port is locked at 60 FPS.- PC port is poorly optimized, if you try to push for 4k resolution you will run into some trouble maintaining a smooth 60 FPS. There is also a bug that causes 1080p fullscreen mode to play at an upscaled 900p. A 3rd party solution like Borderless Gaming will be needed to circumvent this issue. While there are mods/fixes that rectify most of these issues, it is still an extra step that should not be necessary in the first place.- Cuscenes are 30 FPS locked and seem to dip even lower at times making for some choppy cutscenes which are extremely jarring.- While the aesthetic and great art style more than make up for it, graphics are not this game's strong point and graphics settings are also extremely limited on the PC port. That said, you can still get it to look better than PS4 on a mid to high-end machine and the game looks great at 4k resolution.- The game will stutter at times while traversing the world, not game-breaking by any means but definitely noticeable. Apparently this is also present in the PS4 version of the game.If you've played or are at least familiar with the events of the original Nier then you will be greatly rewarded with many references and juicy lore as well as smaller references/parallels to the Drakengard series. However it's not necessary to have played the original to understand the story in this game as it is very much its own world. This is a masterfully crafted game and easily one of the best games I've ever played.

content:

												Overall, a pretty good game, though you'll need a higher-end computer to play it without issues. NieR Automata is a sequel to the previous NieR game (though playing the prequel is not required) which is itself a spinoff of the fifth ending of the game Drakengard, which, again, is not required. NieR: Automata does a good job of introducing the characters and setting in a way that doesn't feel like a huge infodump.In terms of gameplay, it feels reminiscent of Dark Souls, in that if you die, instead of dropping all your Souls, you drop any plug-in chips you had equipped (the equivalent of skills, there is huge room for customization, particularly because you only have limited space, and more advanced chips take up more space) and a small amount of experience. If you make it back to your body without dying, you can reclaim the items you dropped (but not if you die en route). If you really want a challenge, the hardest difficulty (difficulty can be changed mid-game) causes you to die in one hit (the evade button is your friend). However, even on Easy, you can't get complacent, because there are enemies that can still oneshot you. Easy difficulty also has a number of "auto-battle" chips that you can equip, that do things like auto-shoot, auto-dodge, auto-melee that can be equipped at your leisure (and can only be equipped on Easy).The default keyboard/mouse controls are a little wonky if you don't rebind them (like \ and / being your melee attack binds, and left/right shift being your ranged attack binds), but there is the option to do so.There are also a ton of fun easter eggs, like a Steam Achievement for looking up 2B's skirt 10 times, or how if you self-destruct in the space station you blow it up and the game ends. Pros:-Fantastic combat system that feels fluid and responsive.-Great story-Voice acting is pretty good-Soundtrack is baller-You'll only get loading screens if you fast travel or die.Cons:-Highish minimum specs required to play the game above low graphics.-Fullscreen bug (alt-tabbing changes it to windowed mode)-The cutscenes are pre-rendered and can have framerate dips.-Much like Dark Souls, you'll have a better time playing this on a controller than with a Keyboard/Mouse. Unlike Dark Souls, it's very much playable with Keyboard/Mouse controls though.

content:

Nier: Automata is a unique game. There are many reason for that, yet talking about some of them could potentially spoil the experience. Just know that under all its nonsense about machines, aliens, humans on the moon and stylish Gothic Lolita androids, there is a fascinating and emotional tale about what it means to be (heh) human - in all its beauty and ugliness.Playing the previous games of the series isn't really necessary, since Automata rarely references the past games - with most times being more like nice little Easter eggs to long time fans than indispensable plot elements. That being said, this is my fist Yoko Taro game, and playing Automata certainly made me consider playing the original Nier and the Drakengard series. The combat mechanics are good. They are not as complex as other Hack and Slash games like Bayonetta or Devil May Cry, but are still pretty fun to mess with, especially considering there are many unique weapons, each with their own visuals and movesets. A Chip upgrade system that allows you to customize your attributes and abillities also leaves a lot of room for experimentation. This is important, considering Nier's unique type of storytelling, which makes you replay the game a few times before you can see the real ending. Since progress is carried between playthrough, you can expect to continue to improve your character's equipment and face increasingly challenging enemies.When it comes to the game replayability, It's not an understatement to say you haven't experienced most of what Nier: Automata has to offer until you've seen it's 3 first endings. Thankfully, each subsequent playthrough of the game dramatically changes its story and mechanics to the point you might think you are playing a completely different game.Oh, yeah. I almost forgot... The game's soundtrack is AMAZING. And I'm really not exaggerating when I say this is one of the best game sountracks ever made.Okay, now to the bad parts:Nier: Automta is far from perfect. The aforementioned necessity to replay the game may be an issue to some, especially for those that would like to experience it all in one go. Environments also end up being reused a bit much, since you end up visiting the same locations that, while beautiful, certainly begin to lose some of their charm after the 3rd time you visited them. Weren't big deals for me, but I imagine may bother some.What truly bothered me while playing automata were the boring side-quests, that, although usually have some sort of emotional plot twist that help to flash out the game world, are nothing more than plain fetch-quests. Thankfully, they are optional and only needed to complete one time, since progress is carried between playthroughs.Another thing was the grindy nature of the game when it comes to upgrading your equipment. The game is not that hard that you need to have everything maxed so you can progress in the story (and you'll probably end up way over-leveling your enemies if you decide to farm materials) but it's still frustrating to have to farm a certain enemy in a certain place for several hours so you can do the most basic upgrades. Also, despite the main characters and enemies being very detailed, the environments, while certainly beautiful, suffers from some low quality textures if you decide to look more closely, Finally, the PC port is less than ideal, with resolution issues (that can fixed by playing on widowed mode) and, apparently, performance issues and crashes on some systems. Issues I did NOT experience (with the exception of a few rare and isolated crashes) while playing at 1080p on a 970, with a i7-4790k and 16Gb of RAM. However, I did have to completely disable AA to get a stable 60fps. Every other graphic option was turned to the max (which leads me to believe that AA is, in some way, breaking the game).So, Should you play Nier: Automata?Yep, and do it at least 3 times! And then realize Yoko Taro is not even close to being through with you, and that there are still buckets of tears to be shed...

content:

												NieR: Automata is incredible at being a video game. Yoko Taro, the director, has combined his mad genius with the elegant combat stylings of Platinum to create an experience that truly explores what it means to be human.Notably, humans aren't even around.Instead, NieR first appears to be a game of dichotomies. There are segments of high action, segments of low action. You play adaptive androids, you fight mindless machines. An army of good, an army of evil. The duty of loyalty, the risk of curiosity. It is by ruthlessly breaking these concepts that Yoko Taro and his team manage to make you feel genuine emotion for these constructs. I dare not spoil any of this adventure, so suffice it to say that even what appears to be a silly fetch quest will surprise you or make you reexamine how you looked at a character.That is not to say that it doesn't have silly fetch quests, however. While any medium uses highs and lows to accent its points, jumping the difficulty every story mission means you are practically forced to wander the game's open world to be strong enough to progress. As meaningful as the game's content is, a quest to kill four giant robots is still just a quest to kill four giant robots, no matter the discussions and ramifications that come from it. This game is not a spectacle fighter or arena brawler -- my one word of caution before purchasing is to ask yourself whether you can handle either playing Easy mode or exploring the world maybe a bit more than you'd like before progressing to the next story segment.And that's everything off-putting I have to say about this game -- this beautiful experience. The use of music, voice, color, cinematography, queer ladies, and twinstick shooting segments coalesce into what can only be described as utterly magnificent.I have never played a game that so thoroughly made me think beyond "are these actions correct?" We have plenty of games that profess grey morality and make you choose aribitrary solutions. Again, NieR breaks the "do bad" and "do good" dichotomy. 2B, our mechanical heroine, must make her own choices and assumptions just like the player. Sometimes you will be struck by the childishness of a crying robot in overalls. Other times, by the frankness of an antagonist who freely speaks their plans. Or, perhaps, you will simply be struck by the buzzsaw arm of a sentient oil rig.NieR: Automata is a masterpiece.

												So, I decided to wait until I had completed every bit of this game to write this review and I should say: It was all worth it. This game is easily one of the best game I have ever played and enters the category of MUST HAVE- Soundtrack:The music in this game is AMAZING, one of its strongest points. It works so well with the story and bosses fights that makes you have goosebumps from how epic this makes you feel. Also  exploration have some nice and peaceful musics that keeps you really immersed. - Story:I wish some characters had more development on their personality. But overall, it is very nice and on some points really makes you think about life and existence. It has 5 main endings, 26 on total. All of them based on the choices you make during the game.- Gameplay:There's a variety gameplay elements and the combat is very responsive and fun. Also you have a lot of options to build with the plug-ins, weapons and pods you can find.- Difficulty:I like how difficulty works in this game. Yeah, theres some weird difficulty spike between normal and hard, but if you have never played this game before, you should play on normal until you are familiar with the controls, then you can change to hard. On hard you can be one shotted if you aren't careful, but it's cool that you have some sense of danger instead of just face rolling through everything on normal. Very hard are for hardcore people and pretty much anything can one shoot you, so you have that option too if you feel like it.- Graphics:It's alright, it fits the theme of the game.- PC Port:Until this day, the port still have problems with fullscreen resolutions and performance, but it can be somewhat fixed by some 3rd party mods and it's totally playable. Hopefully improve their next ports in the future.

												Confession: I'm honestly just going to gush about the game. If you're looking for a more in-depth, critical review, I'm afraid I can't help. If you're looking to read the ramblings of someone who just finished the game, then welcome.You might think that this is a game about androids destroying robots in the distant future.Well, you'd be right, actually. But it becomes so much more than that, to the point I don't even have words to describe it. If there was ever a game I'd say is a 'must buy', it just got knocked off the shelf and replaced by NieR:Automata, possibly for all time.Now, a heads-up: this is kinda a poor port, and i struggled with driver crashes and resolution issues (the latter I didn't entirely care about, however). That being said, I'm normally picky about that sort of thing, yet I pulled through and didn't let it hamper my enjoyment of the game much at all.I played through the entire game on Hard, and would heartily reccomend it. Granted, yes, the prologue can be fairly difficult, and you are unable to save until you've completed it, but I would nonetheless reccomend it - sharpening your combat skills that early on will go a long way, believe me. Of course, you can change the difficulty at any time, and there are NO achievements for beating the game on a certain difficulty. As I said, I reccomend Hard, but that's for a combination of Story and gameplay. If you just want to experience the story (and props to you if you do, it's amazing!), Normal is more than enough.The story is...admittedly convoluted and philosophical as hell, but that's what makes it so...beautiful.What does it mean to be human? To be an android? To be a machine?To be alive?To be?What does ANYTHING mean?Is it a simple difference of parts and logic circuits, or something more?The way NieR:Automata tells its story is unlike anything I've ever seen, and the endings (there's 26 of them!) are each  magnificent (and sometimes hilarious), ESPECIALLY the true ending. You owe it to yourself to leap in as blind as possible, and experience all that the game has to offer. It is worth it - every single bit is all worth it.....promptly followed by buying the soundtrack. And a second playthrough, probably.Of course, i'm not sure if anyone will read this review/recommendation/emotional ramble or not.But...Glory to mankind.

												I rarely finish games. I play 10-20 hours of them, then get distracted by something else and move on. In my 15+ years of playing games, I can count the number of games that I've finished on two hands. After 60 hours of playing, I just finished all major endings of NieR: Automata. This game, far moreso than any long RPG I've ever touched, does everything it can to remain engaging throughout. I was still being surprised and delighted up to the very end -- and I mean the VERY end. It flirts with your expectations of what will and even CAN happen, and it does so with a confidence rarely seen in the RPG world.Without spewing out lines and lines of expository dialogue at every turn, it makes you care about characters, shows them change, breaks your heart, and manages to showcase an uncommonly nihilistic perspective while still, somehow, feeling uplifting.Oh, and despite all its experimentation, it sits on a foundation of incredibly polished and satisfying gameplay. Really, I can think of few negatives. Its less-than-AAA budget is clear, leading to some kind of empty environments and a lot of invisible walls. Also, the unnecessarily sexualized outfits of the main female characters wasn't great, but the sexualization begins and ends with the outfits, which is refreshing--the characters, animations, and most importantly, the camera never objectify the characters. So, unlike most cases, it really is a minor complaint.NieR: Automata has easily made it into the list of the most memorable and influencial video game experiences of my life. But because of its nature, it's really difficult to say any more without spoiling the experience. All I'll say is that the way it uses the medium of video games to tell its story is wholely unique and unforgettable.

												This is my first experience within Yoko Taro's creative mind and I am in love with it.The themes are strong (even though most of them only truly appear in the last third of the story, after A and B endings). I'm pretty sure I will think about some of the questions asked for the years to come. The story left me with a bittersweet taste, which is pretty appropriate within the context.The gameplay is decently fun, don't expect DMC or Bayonetta level of mechanics but you should find enough customization within the system (through weapons, pods and chips choices), enough stylish animations and variety in the gameplay to find something that suits you. It should be noted that about half of the side quests are either pretty boring or just plain bad (lots of goings of comings), don't power through it if you don't want to, you can 100% the game after the final ending thanks to a mode unlock.The art direction is breathtaking. NieR is not the best looking game of this generation - far from it - but it fights its technical weakness with a deep dive in an apocalyptic dreamland. I find myself teared apart between the feeling of loneliness/desolation and the awe of this weird beautiful and fully living world that seems so familiar yet so alien.Last but not least the OST... let's just say it's hands down the best game soundtrack I have ever listened. Poetic, tragic, sometimes really catchy, it finds itself perfectly in sync with what happens on the screen.I never was a fan of JRPG, beat'em all or shoot'em up, yet this game found the perfect balance for me. With its unique perspective on the game as a media, NieR:Automata conquered my heart.THIS CANNOT CONTINUE.

content:

												Nier: Automata is an excellent and yet very strange slash'em'up + shoot'em'up hybrid.Pros:Superb soundtrackGreat animationsCombat has a nice, quick pace and changes in perspective and style on the fly works really well for most part. Hard mode seemed the best, since Normal is quite easy. Very Hard is... painful. Well, except in the first mission. Choosing Hard on first mission is actually quite hard. Like old-school hard with almost anything killing you with one hit and being thrown all the way back to the beginning of a long sequence. Just be prepared for some pain if you decide to try it like that.Certain dramatic sequences are pretty intense.Voice acting is actually pretty good (both english and japanese).Cons:Level system. It really hurts this game, since levels actually heavily affect the damage you can deal on enemies. Game would be better off without it and being balanced towards the chips and weapon upgrades the player has instead. For example, if you want to try to fight against the secret boss, don't bother being too much below level 99. At level 66 I was doing literally no damage to it, despite being able to stay alive for quite a while against its attacks otherwise. Needless to say that instead of going to a grinding spree to level up I just went and watched the sequences from Youtube in order not to waste few more hours. This felt even more absurd considering the game makes fun of gaming media trends and archetypical behavior in them in its quests and dialogue (killing, grinding, etc).Combat system feels bit superfluous, because you can go through the game without using it much. Even on highest difficulty, which is all about just avoiding hits to avoid instant death. For example, there are tons of cool juggles that you could do... But there is little reason to use them.Some of the dialogue is... odd. I never found out why 9S and B2 seem to take turns in being paranoid towards machines and supporting communication with them. On the plus side there are neat references to older Nier game if you are familiar with it.Spotty texturing work in some places. Also, currently there is no adjustments for lighting system quality, which occasionally can bring the game to its knees. There is a mod that can reduce the lighting complexity without much loss of quality that seems to radically increase framerates.

												tl;dr Nice to play once, should have waited for a sale.Story: Easy to follow, if you didn't play any previous games, like I did, though you get the feeling, that you missed one or two jokes and it hooks you for more (sorry, guys. didn't bite :) )Bugs, etc.: For PC turn down graphics and/or prepare for bugs. content:

												Yoko Taro, Keichi Okabe, Platinum Games, and all those involved in the development of this game have created something very special. After completing all the major story endings and secret boss battles, it is only appropriate to write out my thoughts on this game. In short, it is a masterful experience.From beginning to multiple ends, I was completely invested in the story of 2B, 9S and all those that appeared throughout the game's long, epic story. I loved how the first couple playthroughs were just a warm up for the darkness that was to come. The shifts in game play for traditional third person action to sidescrolling beat em up to top down bullet hell is so dang smooth and fun, I just could not get enough of it! Of course, there is the superb soundtrack that trumps even the first games Nier (heh) perfect soundtrack. I already purchased the soundtrack the minute it became available and have been listeing to it since.Those of you that have been on the fence on this game should discard all hesitation if you like at least half of the following things:1. Engaging and emotional storyline.2. Fast, smooth combat.3. Sublime soundtrack that will tug at your heartstrings.4. Interesting and tragic characters.5. Unique shifts in game play that can happen out of the blue.This game rewards those that have finished the first Nier since there are A LOT of references to the previous Nier game that will make you laugh, sad, and possibly happy, despite all the tragedy. That does not mean you need to have played the previous Nier to really enjoy this game, it is just a better experience for you if you have. I cannot recommend this game enough for those looking for a unique experience that exhibits a truly wonderful story that will be remembered for years to come. If there is ever another Nier game, I will instantly buy it!

Quick overview:_____________________________________________ Originally posted by Port Pod 29: 
Proposal: Fix following issues.

1. Some people are experiencing various issues with fullscreen mode, such as:
 Lower internal resolution / graphics being upscaled Worse performance2. There's an issue with effects such as godrays, where they are rendered at a lower resolution (possibly 900p), no matter what resolution you play the game at.

3. The game uses many samples for Global Illumination (on all settings, from high to low), which can result in poor performance.

To sum it up, the port is definitely not so broken that it can't be played, it's just disappointing that such a great game has technical issues. I will include a section at the end with resources to help improve your experience playing through the game.Well, how is the game itself?   The gameplay is great. 
The music is great.   The story is great. 
The concepts and themes    explored are great. 
The endings  are great. Is great.            Is great. 
Is great.         Is great.

              Is great.
                                  great.  _____________________________________________STORY:Quick note, do not watch the cinematic that plays in the menu before creating a new game.It spoils scenes from the story, just like the original Nier's intro did.I want to talk about this part of the game without spoiling anything, so please bear with me. It's going to be a little hard to convey.This game manages to take what the original game did and bring an interesting twist to the story and themes. Generally it feels very different and fresh.It's almost like taking the plunge from Drakengard to Nier 1, but it still manages to stay true to what people fell in love with in Nier 1.You have to play the game through  all the way to ending E to get the full experience.And no, playing through to ending E doesn't mean that you have to play through the same game four times. Ending B is the closest thing to replaying the game and even then you get a very different perspective along with very different gameplay. Everything beyond that is completely original content and gameplay. This was an aspect of Nier 1 that was blown out of proportions too by word of mouth.If you don't mind stories that are very weird and out there, and you have the patience to sit down and understand this game's story, then it's definitely one of the best and most interesting things you can experience in terms of games.Yoko Taro is a god.If you want to get caught up on Nier lore I recommend  Clemps' analysis videos  , he has some great ones on both Nier and Drakengard.If you want to see Nier 1 in it's entirety, you can check out  TheSw1tcher's playthrough of it. MUSIC / SOUND:All the track, ranging from overworld tunes to small encounters and big boss fights are all beautifully composed. Not only are there some extremely great tracks on this game's OST, but they also have many different variants, which are used extremely well, both to aid the story and gameplay.Keiichi Okabe is a god.I'd also like to mention that there are some very big pros in terms of the sound design in and of itself. Combat sounds satisfying and when characters interrupt each other they ACTUALLY interrupt each other. There's not some awkward pause, like in a lot of other movies and games, it feels much more natural. Also, you can freely choose between both the English and Japanese voices / subtitles, which is a nice touch. While there are a few performances that are a little lacking, the experience as a whole is great. There's a lot of emotion poured into many scenes.GAMEPLAY:This is one of platinum funnest games to play. There's a lot of good things to note here. First of all, the whole pod and plugin system is great. You get pods that have a main fire mode along with a special pod program. The pods are utilized, not only in normal 3D combat, but also in 2D / bullet hell like sections, along with hybrid sections mixing both gameplay types. The pod programs are powerful abilities on cooldown that can alter the combat a lot.On top of that, plugin chips allows you to create your own playstyle and optimize your setup for specific challenges.PlatinumGames are gods.One of the few games I'd consider giving a 10/10 to, but it's hard to rate a game objectively with a numerical value. It has touched me, entertained me, and made me think. I think it accomplished what it set out to do extremely well. _____________________________________________ an example of some of the atmospheric music ᶫᶦᶰᵏI recommend playing the game in windowed mode using  Borderless Gaming ᶫᶦᶰᵏ[github.com]to simulate fullscreen. This was the most stable and smooth way for me to play the game,and basically eleminated all issues I had.If you are still having issues with performance,then you can try  this mod ᶫᶦᶰᵏ to lower the performance hit of Global Illumination.You can use  AutoHotKey ᶫᶦᶰᵏ[autohotkey.com] to hide your mouse cursor while playing.Here's a link to a script that does just that: http://www39.zippyshare.com/v/G7HOa1rt/file.htmlMy own personal ReShade for the game: http://www108.zippyshare.com/v/xhELo8YZ/file.html(first time I've shared a ReShade profile, don't what the best way to do it is!) OFF ᶫᶦᶰᵏ [gifyu.com] ON ᶫᶦᶰᵏ [gifyu.com] Originally based on this preset by Kylie. ᶫᶦᶰᵏ [sfx.thelazy.net]_____________________________________________But luckily, it seems like the devs are listening and intend to fix the issues as soon as possible:

NieR:Automata™, Mar 22

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1
												Firstly, I'd recommend it for fans of hack & slash gameplay. However, it has several issues with the PC port. It's got a hard time with widescreen monitors. The resolution scaling is totally off! Setting it to fullscreen actually shrinks the game's screen and distorts the text, as if stretching a lower resolution. I needed a MOD to get it to run in proper fullscreen. Using that mod, I don't have a mouse cursor in the game... at all. Using the windowed mode doesn't let me adjust the size of the window, so I can only see about 1/3 of the game. The keybindings can be awkward since this game was designed for the PS4. There is no dodge button, nor can you bind it to a key. If I equip the taunt module for 2B and 9S, I can't use it using a keyboard. The "flight" sections of the game are awkward with a mouse and keyboard. If you play for long periods, it will begin to stutter more often, at least for my rig. I've had about 7 crashes so far. Most, if not all, crashes were due to using the steam overlay or alt-tabbing. Other than that, it runs mostly well. Though, with an i7 4790k, 16Gb of DDR3 RAM, about 4 TB of storage, and a GTX 980ti, I really should not be dropping FPS with this game's graphical fidelity.Onto subjective things: The melee combat, music, and story are all well done! The "flight" sections of the game are basically galaga sections or similar types of games. Combining that with the epic music and an epic setting TOTALLY destroyed my immersion. It's like putting nerf guns into the fight scenes of serious war movies. I would have liked them to do what games like Black Ops 3 did with their flight sections. They were simplified because the main focus is obviously infantry combat, but it did not destroy my immersion. I wasn't going to expect Ace Combat, nor should anyone. The big slow-moving jpeg bubbles of damage definitely didn't help with the immersion either. Sure, fire enough and it'll get very difficult to avoid being hit, but geez how did humanity lose to an army that uses bubble-blowers as their primary ranged weapon? Not to mention they can be destroyed by shooting them with bullets or smacking them with melee weapons. The machines are derpy-looking except for the bosses (thankfully). I do appreciate the effort that went into the story as well as the easter-egg types of endings and nostalgia-like gameplay segments, like with the hacking minigame (except for the "flight" sections). It makes sense why 9S is a young boy. (It's a stereotype) The graphics are... pretty bad. I wasn't going to expect Crysis or Battlefield, but geeeeeez they make half-life 2 look like a graphical masterpiece in 2017. The animations are thankfully well done, except for lip-syncing. It may sound like I expect too much from games, but this is a $60 release. It has to compare to other $60 games. It comes up short in too many areas to justify recommending it at its current price. This is a $50 game at maximum! $45 would be good. It's like selling a beat-up used car with a good sound system at the same price as a brand new car of the same model. If The Witcher 3's devs could do it, so could these devs. Now THAT is a game deserving of the $60 price!

												I would not play this game if you're not the best with the 'Hack and Slash' Genre of games.Seriously, at least 20 hours into the game and I find one mission next to impossible.After taking on Adam and Eve on Routes A & B thats where it becomes ♥♥♥♥off-worthy, Its still even a huge challenge when on EASY MODE!Thats my rant-ish thing over, now I want to put the rest of my review on the actual game:I firstly want to mention that I love the landscapes from the city ruins to the straight-up plain desert, its all great fun to tranverse from point A to B, even though the running speeds can be themselves and not fast enough and can take longer than you want it to be, I ADORE the fact that you can aquire animal bait and use ANIMALS as steeds, I absolutely love that feature, I have already seen the meme in the subject of that.The combat part of things... 												"A NieR sequel directed by Yoko Taro, developed by PlatinumGames, with character designs by Akihiko Yoshida, music by MONACA and available on Steam."Just two years ago the above statement would have sounded like such an insane pipedream that - as a huge fan of the original game ever since it first came out - it still feels somewhat unbelievable to think that it actually happened. While Automata wasn't quite as deliciously bizarre and memorable experience as it's predecessor was to me (and I wonder if anything ever will be), it's still a wonderful experience unlike anything else out there right now.If you're at all interested in action RPG's and/or clever and unusual storytelling in videogames, you should buy this game right now. If you're not familiar with the original NieR (which is not at all required) or Yoko Taro's other games, go in blind and enjoy the ride!Though I should note that as of this writing the PC version has some issues that have yet to be officially patched by Square/Platinum, but can be almost completely eliminated thanks to fanmade fixes.
