												As someone who has been gaming for 25+ years, it is more and more rare that I am truly impressed by a game.  Nier: Automata is one of those rare gems and it has restored my faith that excellent games are something to look forward to and not mere relics of a bygone era.  At once a fully modern open-world action rpg , a bullet hell shooter, a side scrolling beat 'em up, and a top down action adventure, this game is also a deep philosophical meditation on the essence of what it is to be human.  From the lush and convincing post-apocalyptic environments to the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, this is a game you will tell your children about in years to come.

												tl;dr Nice to play once, should have waited for a sale.Story: Easy to follow, if you didn't play any previous games, like I did, though you get the feeling, that you missed one or two jokes and it hooks you for more (sorry, guys. didn't bite :) )Bugs, etc.: For PC turn down graphics and/or prepare for bugs. Or google "nier automata white screen" to see common solutions. I didn't install a mod, just set my graphics to specific settings and it became entirely playable. Graphics still look nice.Controls: People recommended gamepad, so I used one, works good. Didn't try mouse/keyboard.Gameplay: heavy on bullethell elements, though you don't need to move through there in frame perfect precision. Most of the bullets are destroyable or you can dodge through. Combat is pretty fun, certain upgrades make your meleeattacks create shockwaves and you dance around on the battlefield. ♥♥♥♥ ton of pantyshots. Basically unavoidable.Japanese elements: emotionless robotgirl, young male anime character, mini-mechas, certain story elements, this game is full of this. Seems to be a downer for some people, so I wanted to point that one out, too.Hacking in hollywood style: personal pet peeves, but executed in a fun way.

												Confession: I'm honestly just going to gush about the game. If you're looking for a more in-depth, critical review, I'm afraid I can't help. If you're looking to read the ramblings of someone who just finished the game, then welcome.You might think that this is a game about androids destroying robots in the distant future.Well, you'd be right, actually. But it becomes so much more than that, to the point I don't even have words to describe it. If there was ever a game I'd say is a 'must buy', it just got knocked off the shelf and replaced by NieR:Automata, possibly for all time.Now, a heads-up: this is kinda a poor port, and i struggled with driver crashes and resolution issues (the latter I didn't entirely care about, however). That being said, I'm normally picky about that sort of thing, yet I pulled through and didn't let it hamper my enjoyment of the game much at all.I played through the entire game on Hard, and would heartily reccomend it. Granted, yes, the prologue can be fairly difficult, and you are unable to save until you've completed it, but I would nonetheless reccomend it - sharpening your combat skills that early on will go a long way, believe me. Of course, you can change the difficulty at any time, and there are NO achievements for beating the game on a certain difficulty. As I said, I reccomend Hard, but that's for a combination of Story and gameplay. If you just want to experience the story (and props to you if you do, it's amazing!), Normal is more than enough.The story is...admittedly convoluted and philosophical as hell, but that's what makes it so...beautiful.What does it mean to be human? To be an android? To be a machine?To be alive?To be?What does ANYTHING mean?Is it a simple difference of parts and logic circuits, or something more?The way NieR:Automata tells its story is unlike anything I've ever seen, and the endings (there's 26 of them!) are each  magnificent (and sometimes hilarious), ESPECIALLY the true ending. You owe it to yourself to leap in as blind as possible, and experience all that the game has to offer. It is worth it - every single bit is all worth it.....promptly followed by buying the soundtrack. And a second playthrough, probably.Of course, i'm not sure if anyone will read this review/recommendation/emotional ramble or not.But...Glory to mankind.

												The PC version of NieR: Automata is an OK-ish "port". It certainly has its flaws but is by far not the worst.Let me show you how I run the game:GPU: R9 280CPU: FX 6300 (6 x 3.79 GHz)RAM: 8 GBOS: Win10 64-BitMy game settings are:Anti-Aliasing: x8---> offTexture filter: x16---> x8Blur---> onShadows: high/medium/low---> lowEffects: high/low---> highAmbient Occlusion---> offWith my system and these settings I can run the game on 1080p at 50-60 fps without any problems. Knowing that my system can run The Witcher 3 at high settings, yet maintaining a steady 60 fps, it's kind of a bummer. I'm pretty sure I could run Automata at max settings at a smooth 60 fps as well, if it was better optimized.Port problems:  fullscreen mode is buggy for quite a few people, myself included. The game internally renders the game to 900p and scales it up to whatever resolution you picked. A workaround is to use Borderless Window.  white screen/black screen for some people  if your CPU has an integrated GPU, make sure the game uses your dedicated GPU because it might use the former by default  game freezes for some peopleThe game itself is simply amazing, that's all I can say. I love every second of it. If you want more details you're better off watching a review on YT or something.Port:    7/10Game: 10/10

content:

												To start off this review I believe it to be of note that this is my first time ever experiencing a Platinum game. With that being said I must say I was very much impressed with this game. Nier Automata is a game that takes place in the distant future where you take the role of a character named 2b and fight through a seemingly endless wave of "mindless" robots to complete your mission. The story in Nier Automata isn't one your likely to forget anytime soon as it plays out similarly to something straight out of an anime. While you may like anime this type or story telling leads to some cliche character personality and behavior making my personal experience a little less enjoyable. Even so throughout the whole game i never once felt bored of the characters, yes they maybe a little cliche but its handled very well through great voice acting and seemingly perfect soundtrack execution. Throughout my experience with the story I can say that Nier provides a great sense of direction and gives a peculiar sense of wonder as you hope to discover a deeper truth as to why the machines on earth are acting the way they do. Game play feels very solid and smooth and gives a great sense of accomplishment when taking down a hard boss. Though combat is buttery smooth I feel like there's too much spam, instead of having well timed dodges I found myself just kinda spamming the dodge button while being attacked by a boss or a handful of enemies. My problems with the combat is that even after 12+ hrs of game play i still find spam to be the most effective way to dodge and counter attack my enemies. Nier Automata's combat mechanics pulls straight from the books of a dark souls game, be it this game is more forgiving through your skill and upgrades, once you die you will lose them unless you go back to your body and retrieve your skill chips. This death system made me feel like I actually had something to lose if I died and provided me some great incentive to not just Rambo and die, but think about my next attack and if I should be saving my missile salvo for the next wave or use it now. Nier Automata's combat and game play I can say has given me the most fun I have had in gaming in awhile.Other things to note would be the performance of this game and how the PC port doesn't seem to run smoothly and needs more optimization in conclusion I can confidently say that if you are not planing on picking Nier Automata up for your PC/console in the future that your are doing yourself a disservice.8/10I have posted this same review on Metacritic where I will soon provide more reviews on other games please feel free to request any games if your interested.

												This game is amazing. Best game I’ve played in a while honestly. But to get the most out of the story you really need play through all of the main endings (a, b, c, d, and e) and read some of your intel. Also, having some knowledge of the original NieR, and some of the Drakengard games, helps too. Not that it’s required, It just gives you an idea of what you can expect. My only wish was that it worked better on pc, but being a last-minute decision it was expected. The genre swapping in this game is refreshing, especially with all the generic games being released recently. One minute you’re playing an action JRPG then the next you’re playing a platformer bullet-hell.There are 26 ways to end the game. It has 5 main endings, which each playthrough puts you in a perspective of a different character. The rest are funny ones, like removing your OS chip or running away from battle. The thought process that must have went in to each of these endings.... I bet this was a really fun project.The soundtrack is really, really good too. Even when not playing the game, it makes for some really relaxing music to listen too when studying. This was a work of art. I hope you guys take the time to look at the whole picture, not just 2B's curves.This is going right next to the Souls games as one of my favorite games of all time.

												This game.  This game starts off by confusing the hell out of you if you don't know what to expect.  Which is always fun.I was going to write a long review, but I won't.  Suffice to say, it IS worth buying, it IS awesome, and it IS unique.  You will be confused, but happily, and you will rage, but click Continue anyway.I actually have no idea when the game will end.  26 endings, and some endings are not endings but beginnings.  Cons?  Yes, one or two.  I WISH androids learned how to parry, rather than just dodge.  I WISH combat felt a little bit more visceral, as it's not always evident you actually hit anything.  I WISH the tutorial type beginning was a little more detailed (pod-throwing isn't even mentioned).But hell who cares.  The gameworld is ridiculously superb, the ... let's say, cast, is just awesome.  The music.. my god the music.  It's just impossibly atmospheric, and you absolutely don't care if you hear it over and over.  And then you'll get to a certain point in the game.. and hear it all over again - and you still won't care.Get the unofficial mod.  Set it to your maximum screen and window resolution, to avoid the clunky port upscaling (which I hope SE are going to fix).  Buy vitality pack.  A LOT.  Seriously.  Resist the urge to play on Easy mode, really, don't do it.  When you feel you just HAVE to, refrain from using the autoplay chips.  You'll enjoy the game a lot more if you feel like YOU defeated each boss.  And trust me.. these ARE bosses.  No spoilers.  Just throw away everything you know about other boss fights, as they're pretty useless here.Try to play the game without using a game guide.  When (not if) you get lost, stuck or confused, just backtrack and try again.  If you STILL can't quite figure out what's next, find a spoiler-free guide.  You do NOT want story spoilers here, trust me.Imagination, slightly out-the-box gameplay, stunning storylines.  THIS is what gaming should be about.  I know, after the 100 hours or so it's going to take to finally finish this, I'm going to have a 2B sized gap in my soul.  Next to a Velvet Crowe one.

content:

												Spoiler Warning for minor bits of the game.Introduction"Everything that lives is designed to end. We are perpetually trapped...in a never-ending spiral of life and death."I definitely don't write many reviews, least of all serious ones, but for NieR: Automata, I'll do it. For all the characters that PlatinumGames and Yoko Taro have given us in NieR, I don't think I've played a game in a while that made me feel this way or made me think about the ending or the fate of the characters days after beating ending E. I went ahead and collected 25/26 endings and am still on my way to the collecting ending Y and getting all the weapons to 100%. I just want to say this game is phenomenal and I'm sad that it's over (unless we're getting DLC) but also glad that I was able to witness this fantastic story. I went into this game 100% blind and bought it on a whim with no prior knowledge of the previous games or series and had no idea this was a spinoff. The game tells its story from a point of view that doesn't require any previous knowledge of the games, but gives out easter eggs and references to the previous games for returning players of the series. Gameplay Being able to control characters with different points of view of the story initially was something new to me, expecially with how meta the game was at the end, but I found it refreshing and new, and was glad that the breaks between characters didn't break the flow of the gameplay. The action-rpg style is something I generally dislike playing but for this game, it was fantastic and flowed easily. There was power behind each swing and the dodge mechanic was incredibly smooth. The music was probably one of the best I've heard in a really long time and I loved how well the music flowed into each different song without any strange or weird mixes. Sidequests are abundant and I really like how later on in the game you can go back and do anything you missed. While the achievement unlocker in-game was definitely a hit-or-miss for some people, I'm glad they included it personally, but I can see why it would be insulting for people who actually 100%'d the game to completion without shortcuts. There is also a debug room but I haven't had the chance to check it out yet.Character DevelopmentThe characters, while initially seeming a bit flat, slowly grow onto you and you begin to see the horrors and struggles of 2B and why she is the way she is. The voices for 2B (Kira Buckland and Yui Ishikawa) did an amazing job at portraying both the flatness of 2B's voice when she needed to, but were also able to portray the emotions behind certain scenes that tug at players heartstrings. Of the 3 characters, I found 9S the most interesting as a character in his slow decsent to madness from the truth of YoRHa's existence. I thought the vengeance in Route C might have been a bit cliche and weaker, but in the end with the logic virus from a certain limb, it made a bit more sense in why he was acting out more aggressively per usual. 9S's initial upbeat voice and happy-go-lucky personality slowly becomes corrupted with sadness and depression over the course of the game until there is almost nothing left but a shell of anger and vengeance against A2 for her act at the beginning of Route C.Route E Spoilers.This is also the second game series I had where the game directly addresses the player about what they thought of the characters and whether they love it enough to give up something important to help save other players. I have yet to do this as I want to get Ending Y and finish the last bit of content before I finally give this up. Thanks to MrCogneetoe for rescuing me during the credits scene.ConclusionI know this review is short and not really a true review, but if I go any longer I'll just keep rambling on about pretty much the same things and about how much I love this game. I don't own a PS3 or Xbox360 so I can't actually play the original series (will probably have to youtube a LetsPlay). I'm definitely looking forward to any future DLC or another sequel to this game and I've definitely become of fan of Yoka Taro now. I'm excited to see what comes next and the future of this story. Glory to Mankind.

content:

												Rather than make a review solely consisting of references about 2B's butt or blindly, wholeheartedly reccomending it, I'm going to reccomend this game- cautiously. Nier Automata looks to be a great game, but this port comes with some issues that are worth bearing in mind. First and foremost, you can tell the game was originally designed with the console in mind. If you have a controller for your rig, this is certainly the place to make use of it. For the most part it isn't bad, but there are two rather important aspects that demand their use: namely dodging, firing and frequent shifts in camera perspective. Both of these mechanics were clearly designed first with thumbsticks in mind, because on the PC port you'll be stuck with the 8 directional inputs you can use with WSAD. It's serviceable, but you're not going to be able to aim with precision when trying to dodge masses of projectiles. This is mostly negligible in the standard 3rd person perspective slash'em up stuff, but the game will frequently shift to isometrict and sidescrolling perspectives and it's here that it gets really janky. Secondly, and more importantly, dodge was clearly designed with tapping the thumbsticks, because you have to doubletap the directional keys to do so. Again, it's servicable, but it feels very weird and doesn't mesh well with the rest of the controls, especially given the amount of input you'll be putting in at any given time. Worse, you cannot rebind this. You are stuck with this. You can adapt to it, but it's awkward.More baffling is the act of keybinding. Namely, upon first inspection you'd be under the impression the game doesn't utilize mouse input- light/heavy attacks are bound to the '/' keys, and any attempt to bind them to the mouse buttons goes unregistered. Thankfully, another member pointed in my initial review that you can in fact use the mouse and it's button for these roles... It just doesn't show up or make any mention of it in either the control bindings or the opening 'tutorial' segments. I will admit I was quick to assume the worst, and egg on my face for that- thanks, Rexy.Ultimately the game is still playable with the default mouse and keyboard, but it isn't what I would call a comfortable experience, and is definitely an unessecary handicap that could have been avoided with a bit more of a thoughtful port. I strongly reccomend using a controller if you have one. Whether or not you want to buy one strictly for this game is a loaded question for you to determine. Regarding the large array of graphical complaints (blurring, 1080p resolutions, black bands, etc) a lot of other reviewers have made, I haven't experienced myself, and most likely boils down to how recent your hardware is. The two exceptions are:- Fullscreen mode. The game defaults to a windowed version for whatever reason. This can be temporarily fixed in the settings, but alt-tabbing programs minimizes it back to windowed size. - FPS. The cutscenes are hard locked at a choppy 60 FPS, and it's very glaring when the actual gameplay is a smoother framerate.TL;DR: Only just started playing, but I wanted to put some input in for anyone on the fence after hearing about the porting problems like I was. There's a good game I could reccomend underneath the host of technical problems that originate from a sloppy port job- if you already have a controller for your PC rig, I say go for it. Using that will negate most of the problems in junction with an up to date PC setup. If you don't have a controller it's still playable, but I cannot say it's a comfortable experience using the mouse and keyboard. I'd even say it is difficult at points. Whether or not this game by itself warrants going out and buying a controller is the real question, and one I'll be able to give a more solid answer to once I finish the game myself. Is this a particularly conclusive review? Not really, but I hope I can give people on the fence some additional information to help them make an informed decision.

												Nier: Automata is a rich and engaging game with themes such as human/machine consciousness and 2B's butt. There is no right or wrong choice, but rather the ideal and truth you strive for. This is one of those game that I can not only play for fun, but also suffer from my own moral dilemmas.The characters, 2B and 9S, have really grown on me through all their interactions. The game is really centered around the characters and their roles in the overarching plot. Hence why there are multiple endings to answer the questions that were left unaswer from a previous ending. There are those who may dismiss this game because it's a "weeb" game, but those are either close minded people or people who don't like the art style. That's unfortunate for them since this is one of those experience that I won't forget. There are plenty of reviews that will mention the gameplay or music, but I want to stress the importance of emotional connections to the characters. I understand not everyone plays games the same way and if you prefer playing for pure enjoyment and not thinking, this game is fine for that. However, the game isn't as shallow as that. There are plenty of details and the way the story progresses really does mean something. The themes in Nier really resonates well with people who gets attached to characters and those who questions their own morality levels. This is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ review for those who enjoy games similar to how I do. None of what I wrote is real. Please don't lynch me.

												Great game with a wonderful combat system and an even more amazing story. The characters all have their own unique personality, despite emotions being strictly prohibited. Seriously, this game has some of the most memorable and lovable characters of all time, ♥♥♥♥ Taro. The combat feels fluid and has endless possibilities, whether you have 100 hours or 10 minutes logged into the game, the combat just works and is easy for new players to pick up and rewards more experienced players. While the combat is good, the weapons variety feels really "meh" in comparison, however this is made up for by the dozens of ways you can pair them and get unique combos. The camera in this game is absolutely flawless and does its job very well, the transition from third person, to side scroller and top-down is seamless and just feels right. Enemy variety isn't the best, even though I love this game I can't lie and say that the majority of the enemies aren't just copy paste, slightly powered up versions, but despite this, you just can't get tired of fighting them, at least I don't. The NG+ type system in this game is fantastic, although it's more of "Current Game+". Changing perspectives after clearing the game for the first time, and then getting absolutely blown away after clearing it the second time was an amazing feeling, this game is good for what it is, though I personally feel that it lacks replayability after getting the "true" endings and all achievemts, which you don't even have to work for. All in all, I fully recommend this game, whether you're a gameplay or story kind of person, this game will surely fit whatever criteria you have. On a final note, to the dudes that deleted your save data, you guys are the real MVPs.

content:

For me, this might be the best game i have played in 2016 and so far in 2017.  This review might contain minor spoilers. A small summary is down below.  Nier Automata doesn't look great. It has some beautiful places and a lot more ugly places. The lightning is fantastic, the effects are just as good. Animations are really beautiful and smooth, even the transitions are really nice. Definitely better than some of the Triple A games that got released recently. They aren't perfect though, a lot of the NPC's don't move their mouth when talking to you for example. The world is relatively small, there are a lot of harder to find areas but all in all you don't need a lot of time to explore everything. Still the world isn't small either, it's just about the right size you need. There is a lot of stuff to explore and find though. Some of the weapons are well hidden. The characters all look pretty good. The models are well done and especially the protagonists look great.  Ohh and dat booty...Without the community-fix, the game suffers from some serious issues. There is no working fullscreen mode, the game renders at a very low resolution if you switch to fullscreen and you get constant framedrops. In the later game, the fps really go down and the cutscenes in general stutter a lot. There is a hard lock to 60fps and 30fps for the cutscenes. AMD people report getting whitescreens while playing. Soundwise the game is amazing. The SFX is well done and the general soundtrack is fantastic. If you happened to play Metal Gear Rising you will know what i mean. They even included English and Japanese versions of the songs, depending on what language you play. The voice acting is great as well. Both Japanese and English sound very good.The gameplay itself is also well done. The combat is fast and intuitive. Animations are smooth and most of the time, you don't need to worry about being locked in an animation. There is no blocking mechanic, it's either evade/dodge or eat the blow. Overall the combat is very satisfying and you get just about the right amount of feedback of your hits to feel good. The boss fights are just fantastic. Some might feel pretty easy, even if you play on hard, but overall it's just so much fun. It's not all combat though. There are some quests in which you have to find things, scan the areas, find hidden objects or play hacking minigames.The beginning of the game is pretty hard and might catch you off guard, especially because someone thought it would be a great idea to not include a single checkpoint/savepoint in the entire prologue and only give you a pretty basic tutorial. Afterwards there won't be checkpoints or autosave either, you have to find savepoints and be near them to actually save your game. If you happen to die, you lose your upgrades and need to salvage your dead body to reclaim them, similar to Dark Souls.Fitting to that, you can see where other people died and read their messages. You can either choose to salvage their corpses, or revive them to have them fight on your side for a while.  There is a good amount of main and sidequests, but it's not always clear what's what. Some of the sidequests are also required to progress, so it's a good idea to do them all. Most of the time you will also get some neat rewards out of them, but even if not, they are still worth doing, because overall they are well designed. The Story of the game is... weird at the beginning. The more you play, the more you will understand, but at the same time you also might end up confused. Then you start some kind of "New game plus" and you get different perspectives and characters to play. You do get to keep all your stuff though. Sidequests you completed will not reappear on your next playthrough. Only if you start a completely new game. Some new quests might pop up though.The game has about 26 endings, going from A-Z. Most of them are joke endings though, which you get if, for example, you die in a specific way. Nier Automata also comes with a good portion of humor, at the same time it also made some people cry. Sometimes it really is an emotional rollercoaster. You also get the opportunity to learn a lot of the games' lore. Each item got a little description or story to it. You can also find remnants of the old world, that tell a little bit about the places you are. Bosses also have their own stories, some of which you might find out way after you already beat them. I don't know what else i could say, so here is a quick little summary of the main pros and cons:  ConGraphics are nothing special.Without a community fix, the game often dips below 60fps or stutters. No working fullscreen without said fix. No borderless windowed mode.Bad controls on mouse and keyboard.Difficult prologue, basically a noobfilter.There aren't really many different enemies in the game, but it fits to the lore. Little to no communication from the developers. They promised a fix around 2 weeks ago. The only thing that changes when you crank the difficulty up is the amount of damage received. Most enemies got easy to learn/counter and repetitive patterns. ProAmazing story.Amazing soundtrack.Great character design.Very intuitive and satisfying combat and general gameplay.Easy to learn controls.A lot of different weapons with different playstylesEP, Shops, levelups, loot and upgrades.Great voice acting.Extremely fun bossfights (Even though most are a bit easy, others however might end up in a total cluster♥♥♥♥). Booty.Nier Automata is the first game in a while that made me lose track of time. I went ahead and started playing. The next time i looked at the clock, it was already early in the morning. The last time this happened was when Dragons Dogma came out for PC. If you still don't know if you should get it, let me just ask you these questions:Do you like games like MGR? Do you care about an awesome story?Are you okay with mediocre graphics? Are you okay with installing a third party fix?Would it bother you if the game doesn't feed you every bit of information and isn't guiding you by your hand through everything? (Like common triple A games. It isn't as bad as in Darksouls though.)If you answered Yes, then go and get it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
28
												I'll start my review by saying that I have never been more satisfied with a video game purchase in my life. I knew what I wanted from this game, and it gave me exactly that -- I don't think any game no matter how good has given me exactly what I wanted. I mean, if it says anything, I think this is the only game I have ever not just 100%, but actually read every single tiny bit of side dialogue, every snippet, archive, and tiny bit of information I could get my hands on. That's impressive, when you compare it my time in Elder Scrolls games or even the Witcher 3, where I read maybe a few books out of the dozens in those games.NieR:Automata is a superb experience for anyone looking for a puzzling but not unpredictable story, with characters that all grow on you the longer you play. A lot of the cast I didn't even like at first, but as the game continued, I feel like I became more attached to them than a lot of more fleshed out characters in other games. That's quite impressive. Understanding why a character is the way they are is very satisfying, the the cast plays so well off of each other -- 2B and 9S's dialogue with each other specifically I found very charming. The gameplay itself is certainly a very nice blend of the original Nier and Platinum's usual affair. It's not wholly my cup of tea, as I prefer more concise combat engines, but for what it is, it is very responsive, satisfying and decently skillful. Sort of a 3rd person bullet hell at certain times, which can in certain instances in the game be a bit... hard to see, if nothing else. There is a lot of running around though, especially if you want to 100% the game, so prepare yourself for that if you're a completionist like myself. The sound design is also great, from the voice acting, sounds and the absolutely breath-taking OST, which I know is already going to be playing on loop for me for the next few months. I don't think it'll be everyone's cup of tea, as it involves of vocal elements, but to say it doesn't fit the game would be a downright lie. Some of the songs setup scenes and emotional responses so well it's -- well, it's nicely done, I'll be modest about it, heh heh.I guess this is the part where I just do pros and cons:Pros:- Great Story, that is possible to predict but can be quite puzzling -- which to me are the best kind of stories- Characters are very enjoyable and unique- Well written, very little dialogue felt off to me- No requirement to have played the first Nier, although it makes you appreciate the game more- Combat is fast-paced and skillful enough to keep you focused, while mindless enough when you're just treking away- Decent amount of character customization which opens up a lot of playstyles- Music is astounding- SFX is also really nice- Can alter the difficulty whenever and it has no hidden meaning other than challenge (no hard only endings)- 100%ing the game is at least convenient to do end-game, but it is tedious- World I would say is "just" the right size to not be overwhelming- Contains a few moments which will stick with you forever (a guarantee from me)Cons:- PC version has issues (resolution in full screen, shaky optimization at times)- A lot of running around- Certain side characters and areas COULD have been more fleshed out- Dialogue for side-NPCs rarely changes and acknowledges events (though I understand why)- Exploration "can" be rewarding, but is very tedious- Poor character balance (I don't mind in single player games, but it is very blatant that some weapons/sub weapons are way better than others)- Normal to Hard mode difficulty is mostly a damage scaling alteration, which can be annoying when some random projectiles might one shot on hard, but others won't - can be hard to tell, so slot max HP UP, heh heh- Completionists, prepare for a bit of randomness and farming- You won't want to go to work until you finish the storyOverall:I don't think every person is going to enjoy this game as much as I did, but if you're looking for something that will satisfy your desire for an intriguing story, that is not afraid to pull punches, then you may well enjoy this game as much as I did. This game climbed as I played it from okay, to great, to now being in my top 3 favorite games of all time. There's thousands of games to contend with, so if that intrigues you, I challenge you to find out whether this game deserves "2B" in your own top list!

content:

												Easily the best game I've played in a long time. Please buy this game and play it.Nier Automata is a fantastic game on its own and as a sequel to Nier which is a game I hold close to my heart. While it doesn't have the most in depth gameplay you'd find in other Platinum titles, they really brought out a solid and good feeling gameplay to compliment Yoko Taro's great direction in plot and settings. It's a game that tells its story as much from its presentation and mechanics as it does from its cutscenes and there wasn't a single point that the plot didn't grip me in some way. As with any good game it's still going to have its flaws but I don't feel they hold it back but it's worth mentioning that the grind is a bit silly near the end if you want to get 100% and the flow of combat can eventually be stale once you find your optimal setup.To finish the compliment sandwich and not end on a note of complaint I'll say the side quests are (with few exceptions) just as interesting and gripping as the main plot and add a lot of value even if a lot are just fight and fetch quests much like the original Nier. Bottom line is this game expands on everything Nier needed to and still keeps the wonderful plot full of twists and turns that will make you feel uncomfortable or even upset and is absolutely worth your time to play to completion. Please don't spoil the game for your friends either!

												As someone who has been gaming for 25+ years, it is more and more rare that I am truly impressed by a game.  Nier: Automata is one of those rare gems and it has restored my faith that excellent games are something to look forward to and not mere relics of a bygone era.  At once a fully modern open-world action rpg , a bullet hell shooter, a side scrolling beat 'em up, and a top down action adventure, this game is also a deep philosophical meditation on the essence of what it is to be human.  From the lush and convincing post-apocalyptic environments to the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, this is a game you will tell your children about in years to come.

content:

												Nier: Automata is a rich and engaging game with themes such as human/machine consciousness and 2B's butt. There is no right or wrong choice, but rather the ideal and truth you strive for. This is one of those game that I can not only play for fun, but also suffer from my own moral dilemmas.The characters, 2B and 9S, have really grown on me through all their interactions. The game is really centered around the characters and their roles in the overarching plot. Hence why there are multiple endings to answer the questions that were left unaswer from a previous ending. There are those who may dismiss this game because it's a "weeb" game, but those are either close minded people or people who don't like the art style. That's unfortunate for them since this is one of those experience that I won't forget. There are plenty of reviews that will mention the gameplay or music, but I want to stress the importance of emotional connections to the characters. I understand not everyone plays games the same way and if you prefer playing for pure enjoyment and not thinking, this game is fine for that. However, the game isn't as shallow as that. There are plenty of details and the way the story progresses really does mean something. The themes in Nier really resonates well with people who gets attached to characters and those who questions their own morality levels. This is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ review for those who enjoy games similar to how I do. None of what I wrote is real. Please don't lynch me.

												Haven't finished it, and probably won't for a while (well I start to get the feeling that there's not going to be a good ending... And I don't want to feel sad about the story for a while lol). But from what I have played so far, this game is really good, especially how well the music fits with the atmosphere (though that only made me feel more pessimistic about the ending of the game). I actually found the characters interesting, but that might be just due to my exposure to these kind of character traits. Well since basically I liked pretty much everything of this game, I'll just say a few things that I wished would be there.First... Sometimes te camera would automatically move downward when sprinting and just generally move to certain fixed angles during some movements. Though I definitely liked the fan service that it brought about, I just didn't like a camera view so low down sometimes... Also being able to zoom out would be nice too, as fighting and managing camera angle frequently has never been my strong point. Second... It's probably just me, but when the game switches to a 2D scroll game while the map is still kind of 3D (so that I need to go around corners and stuff), I found the control to be a bit annoying. Maybe make it so that if, for instance, I want to keep running to the right around a corner, I can just keep going right instead of right-down/up-right.Lastly... Maybe have a even lower graphics setting so that I can run it on an older laptop? I see how the game is supposed to look really nice and lowering the settings would kind of remove that good side of it, but I would like to at least see the story at some point before I get my desktop up and running next year (well various situations determined this). I also know that there's a mod for lowering the global illumination points, but I would love to see it as an in game setting.All in all, a great game, since whoever sees this (probably no one) would probably have noticed that I was basically just nitpicking. Get it if you have confidence if your hardware, I think you won't regret it. Don't hold me accountable though :P

												So you've seen all the reviews and news about this game and think 'huh some jrpg hack and slash with some fan service thrown in there, whats the big deal'... oh my sweet summer child. This game takes you on an incredible journey in one of the best storytelling methods I've seen to date. After finishing the main story of the game I can assure you that this is an experience no other game has given me. The way it tells the story is something I've never seen in a video game. The game itself is an experience that everyone should experience. While a lot of people, that haven't played this game, will think that this game is mainly popularized through its fan service, I can assure you it isn't as forced during the game and is of no significance in what makes this game great. It's one of those games you can't just hear about or read about. It's an experience you have to enjoy yourself. This is the only game I've reveiwed and it is only because I want to urgy you to support the developers, and especially the game's director Yoko Taro, so they can keep making masterpieces like this. If you are a person that likes a game to have a good and compelling story with a lot of character, then you've come to the right place. While the gameplay may have been the selling point to a lot of the people that bought it, including me, the story is what kept us all playing without stop.GPU: AMD R9 280 3gbCPU: I5 4570Playing on high everything, texture filtering 8x. Used the fix you can find on reddit and steam forums, google for 'nier automata fps fix'. This lets me play the game in full screen at 1080p with frames varying between 55-60 but mainly staying on 60.

												Nier is one of the few that pushes forward what it means for a game to be a game and how we interact with the medium.This is an experience that has a few small dull sections followed by exciting events that are completely unexpected.   When you are first introduced to the open world and a few small fetch quests, please do not let that deter you from the rest of the game.I was surprised at how much I cared for the characters by the end of the game, even more so that some of the brief NPC characters for side quests evoked more emotion in me than main characters from other games.To note without spoiling, there is a side quest that eventually leads you to a beautiful area with a song exclusive to that place.   I teared up a bit not just from happiness or sadness- just the bittersweetness of the experience.    Having an excuse to revisit this place later with the same music resulted in me flat out bawling while I stood there listening to that song.   After that I research what song that was exactly, pulling it up resulted in the music by itself moved me to tears yet again.The only request I have for those that play:   Please, continue.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2
												NieR: Automata is incredible at being a video game. Yoko Taro, the director, has combined his mad genius with the elegant combat stylings of Platinum to create an experience that truly explores what it means to be human.Notably, humans aren't even around.Instead, NieR first appears to be a game of dichotomies. There are segments of high action, segments of low action. You play adaptive androids, you fight mindless machines. An army of good, an army of evil. The duty of loyalty, the risk of curiosity. It is by ruthlessly breaking these concepts that Yoko Taro and his team manage to make you feel genuine emotion for these constructs. I dare not spoil any of this adventure, so suffice it to say that even what appears to be a silly fetch quest will surprise you or make you reexamine how you looked at a character.That is not to say that it doesn't have silly fetch quests, however. While any medium uses highs and lows to accent its points, jumping the difficulty every story mission means you are practically forced to wander the game's open world to be strong enough to progress. As meaningful as the game's content is, a quest to kill four giant robots is still just a quest to kill four giant robots, no matter the discussions and ramifications that come from it. This game is not a spectacle fighter or arena brawler -- my one word of caution before purchasing is to ask yourself whether you can handle either playing Easy mode or exploring the world maybe a bit more than you'd like before progressing to the next story segment.And that's everything off-putting I have to say about this game -- this beautiful experience. The use of music, voice, color, cinematography, queer ladies, and twinstick shooting segments coalesce into what can only be described as utterly magnificent.I have never played a game that so thoroughly made me think beyond "are these actions correct?" We have plenty of games that profess grey morality and make you choose aribitrary solutions. Again, NieR breaks the "do bad" and "do good" dichotomy. 2B, our mechanical heroine, must make her own choices and assumptions just like the player. Sometimes you will be struck by the childishness of a crying robot in overalls. Other times, by the frankness of an antagonist who freely speaks their plans. Or, perhaps, you will simply be struck by the buzzsaw arm of a sentient oil rig.NieR: Automata is a masterpiece.

												Yadda yadda disclaimer I never review stuff I also haven't bought a game at $60 launch price in over two years.It's a pretty amazing game. Combat is very fun and diverse so the game never really feels stale, even after multiple playthroughs. Character movement and controls are extremely responsive to the point that even when zipping around, comboing and evading you still feel in control. The main story is very gripping and you will find it hard to put it down (even after finishing a playthrough). I am a big fan of the upgrade system, in which there are roughly a dozen of each category of weapon, with 4 levels that you can upgrade using rare materials. Additionally, you can upgrade your own character through a range of plug in chips which allow for you to essentially customize how you want to play.Difficulty in the game is managed fairly well. I played through all endings on "Hard" difficulty, which was certainly a good challenge (except for part B, where I felt a little over-leveled and could rely on a combat gimmick for the playable character). Maybe a little too easy, because with hard difficulty, most enemies can kill you in two hits, and you will always be able to heal yourself instantly after taking the first hit due to the abundance of recovery items. I can't even imagine playing on very hard difficulty (die in one hit) but I guess some people are tough (or patient) enough to brave it. My only gripes with the game are one that I wish the side quests were a bit more engaging. Aside from a few notable ones, most of them sorta felt like fetch quests, and they lacked voiceovers or cutscenes. Usually just a few lines of dialogue. Honestly, the most rewarding part of finishing quests was temporarily getting a song to play depending on the mood of the quest's resolution (did I mention the soundtrack is fantastic? Best of any game I've played). Additionally, even the game is open world there are a lot of invisible walls throughout the game's universe, with some being pretty jarring and unexpected. Hopefully these things could be fixed in a future game with a larger budget.Don't forget to download the FAR patch as it fixed all of my framerate and resolution issues!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
26
												TL;DR Nier Automata is the best game I've played since The Witcher 3 and it's expansions.Nier Automata tells a story about very bleak distant future where Earth became a battleground between human-like androids and machines controlled by aliens. Some time before events of the game humanity succumbed to alien invasion and relocated to the moon bases. Now elite android units are sent to the ruined surface to hopefully finally reclaim Earth. If this sounds outright bizarre and silly to you then I assure that there is more than meets the eye and story of Automata becomes much more complex and interesting as you go. It is sad, beautiful and very unpredictable.Gameplay is another part of Automata that stands out. Developed by people behind Bayonetta and MGR:Revengeance, it is fast, fluid, very responsive and deceptively simple at first glance. Between fast and heavy attacks, weapon switching on the fly, quick dashes and acrobatic dodges you have a lot of options to approach any threat that may come your way. Androids don't use ranged weapons, instead they are aided by robotic drones, with variety of different defensive and offensive functions. You can further customize your character by using performance enhancing chips that allow various buffs and passive abilities. Some chip combinations are borderline overpowered but there are four difficulty options that can be adjusted at any time should you fancy being brutally murdered in one blow. If that wasn't enough, Automata also contains parts that blends several action genres together. It is not uncommon for camera to move from classic third-person action to 2D platformer to top-down twin-stick shooter with bullet-hell elements sometimes even in a single combat scenario.Automata doesn't have classic New Game + mode. After concluding it (takes about 20-25 hours), you unlock effectively new chapters that flesh out this complex narrative even more. Including 5 main endings, there are 26 different ways to finish this story that vary depending on actions you take during your playthrough.Any gripes I'd have with Automata would be nitpicks. You could argue about how worldmap is designed, about washed-out color palette, about lack of tutorials for certain mechanics, but I feel that it was all done on purpose. It is rare to play a game with ambitious storytelling, polished combat system, replayability, incredible soundtrack, chunky jRPG elements and open world gameplay that doesn't suck.I hope to see another Platinum/Yoko Taro collaboration. Highly recommended.

												Yoko Taro, Keichi Okabe, Platinum Games, and all those involved in the development of this game have created something very special. After completing all the major story endings and secret boss battles, it is only appropriate to write out my thoughts on this game. In short, it is a masterful experience.From beginning to multiple ends, I was completely invested in the story of 2B, 9S and all those that appeared throughout the game's long, epic story. I loved how the first couple playthroughs were just a warm up for the darkness that was to come. The shifts in game play for traditional third person action to sidescrolling beat em up to top down bullet hell is so dang smooth and fun, I just could not get enough of it! Of course, there is the superb soundtrack that trumps even the first games Nier (heh) perfect soundtrack. I already purchased the soundtrack the minute it became available and have been listeing to it since.Those of you that have been on the fence on this game should discard all hesitation if you like at least half of the following things:1. Engaging and emotional storyline.2. Fast, smooth combat.3. Sublime soundtrack that will tug at your heartstrings.4. Interesting and tragic characters.5. Unique shifts in game play that can happen out of the blue.This game rewards those that have finished the first Nier since there are A LOT of references to the previous Nier game that will make you laugh, sad, and possibly happy, despite all the tragedy. That does not mean you need to have played the previous Nier to really enjoy this game, it is just a better experience for you if you have. I cannot recommend this game enough for those looking for a unique experience that exhibits a truly wonderful story that will be remembered for years to come. If there is ever another Nier game, I will instantly buy it!

content:
2
Nier: Automata is a unique game. There are many reason for that, yet talking about some of them could potentially spoil the experience. Just know that under all its nonsense about machines, aliens, humans on the moon and stylish Gothic Lolita androids, there is a fascinating and emotional tale about what it means to be (heh) human - in all its beauty and ugliness.Playing the previous games of the series isn't really necessary, since Automata rarely references the past games - with most times being more like nice little Easter eggs to long time fans than indispensable plot elements. That being said, this is my fist Yoko Taro game, and playing Automata certainly made me consider playing the original Nier and the Drakengard series. The combat mechanics are good. They are not as complex as other Hack and Slash games like Bayonetta or Devil May Cry, but are still pretty fun to mess with, especially considering there are many unique weapons, each with their own visuals and movesets. A Chip upgrade system that allows you to customize your attributes and abillities also leaves a lot of room for experimentation. This is important, considering Nier's unique type of storytelling, which makes you replay the game a few times before you can see the real ending. Since progress is carried between playthrough, you can expect to continue to improve your character's equipment and face increasingly challenging enemies.When it comes to the game replayability, It's not an understatement to say you haven't experienced most of what Nier: Automata has to offer until you've seen it's 3 first endings. Thankfully, each subsequent playthrough of the game dramatically changes its story and mechanics to the point you might think you are playing a completely different game.Oh, yeah. I almost forgot... The game's soundtrack is AMAZING. And I'm really not exaggerating when I say this is one of the best game sountracks ever made.Okay, now to the bad parts:Nier: Automta is far from perfect. The aforementioned necessity to replay the game may be an issue to some, especially for those that would like to experience it all in one go. Environments also end up being reused a bit much, since you end up visiting the same locations that, while beautiful, certainly begin to lose some of their charm after the 3rd time you visited them. Weren't big deals for me, but I imagine may bother some.What truly bothered me while playing automata were the boring side-quests, that, although usually have some sort of emotional plot twist that help to flash out the game world, are nothing more than plain fetch-quests. Thankfully, they are optional and only needed to complete one time, since progress is carried between playthroughs.Another thing was the grindy nature of the game when it comes to upgrading your equipment. The game is not that hard that you need to have everything maxed so you can progress in the story (and you'll probably end up way over-leveling your enemies if you decide to farm materials) but it's still frustrating to have to farm a certain enemy in a certain place for several hours so you can do the most basic upgrades. Also, despite the main characters and enemies being very detailed, the environments, while certainly beautiful, suffers from some low quality textures if you decide to look more closely, Finally, the PC port is less than ideal, with resolution issues (that can fixed by playing on widowed mode) and, apparently, performance issues and crashes on some systems. Issues I did NOT experience (with the exception of a few rare and isolated crashes) while playing at 1080p on a 970, with a i7-4790k and 16Gb of RAM. However, I did have to completely disable AA to get a stable 60fps. Every other graphic option was turned to the max (which leads me to believe that AA is, in some way, breaking the game).So, Should you play Nier: Automata?Yep, and do it at least 3 times! And then realize Yoko Taro is not even close to being through with you, and that there are still buckets of tears to be shed...

Honestly, the most rewarding part of finishing quests was temporarily getting a song to play depending on the mood of the quest's resolution (did I mention the soundtrack is fantastic? Best of any game I've played). Additionally, even the game is open world there are a lot of invisible walls throughout the game's universe, with some being pretty jarring and unexpected. Hopefully these things could be fixed in a future game with a larger budget.Don't forget to download the FAR patch as it fixed all of my framerate and resolution issues!

												Nier is one of the few that pushes forward what it means for a game to be a game and how we interact with the medium.This is an experience that has a few small dull sections followed by exciting events that are completely unexpected.   When you are first introduced to the open world and a few small fetch quests, please do not let that deter you from the rest of the game.I was surprised at how much I cared for the characters by the end of the game, even more so that some of the brief NPC characters for side quests evoked more emotion in me than main characters from other games.To note without spoiling, there is a side quest that eventually leads you to a beautiful area with a song exclusive to that place.   I teared up a bit not just from happiness or sadness- just the bittersweetness of the experience.    Having an excuse to revisit this place later with the same music resulted in me flat out bawling while I stood there listening to that song.   After that I research what song that was exactly, pulling it up resulted in the music by itself moved me to tears yet again.The only request I have for those that play:   Please, continue.

content:

												Actually mixed about this game.  Bad bits first - at the time of writing, it's poorly optimized.  The fullscreen option actually renders at a lower resolution and upscales, and it looks awful.  The game doesn't place well on dual screen setups. Lots of framerate drops, regardless of how powerful your GPU is.  If it hadn't been for a mod by Kaldaien which fixed a lot of issues, a lot of time would have been spent suffering rather than playing, and the overall experience would be negative.  I have a suspicion that this is related to being a timed Sony exclusive, and a lot of dev effort would have gone into preparing for that platform, whereas PC players were given the second-class treatment. As for gameplay, at times it feels like it's doing too much - the hacking minigames, the flight-suit sequences, they felt like chores and I was just waiting to get back into the main hack+slash mode, although a lot of other players seemed to enjoy it.  It's great running around with a fast character with fast combat.The good bits.  The characters, the world building, the NPCs.  A good amount of effort went into creating these and you can really see it.  It made me greatly curious about the backstories and the history of this world.  Sidequests didn't feel like fetch quests even if they were, I didn't mind running around in the beautiful environment. The skills system is interesting, it makes you think about what you'd like to prioritize (attack, defense, support etc) and you can play around with it quite a bit. I wanted to mention the soundtrack.  It's one of the most haunting and evocative game soundtracks I've heard.  You can really *feel* the city of ruins, the peaceful sleep of the main camp.  Every track fit nicely with the place or the fights.  Fantastic work.  I would love to buy it but it appears to be releasing for CD only on March 29 2017.

												A great game in terms of story and gameplay. The story centers on the themes of artificial life and existentialism along with the mentality of frontline soldiers. I felt the pace was fast, but overall the story was enjoyable at its  worst and tearjerking at its best. The gameplay is a 3rd person spectacle fighter and a bullethell shoot em' up aswell as many varients of the two mixing. The combat is fast and feels as good as it looks which is very satisfying.     The game has shortcomings though. The wild and seemless transitions of various gameplay styles makes it pretty hard to controll with mouse and keyboard so a controller is next to obligatory on higher dificulties. The game play has an open world and while I personally liked traversing it on foot that surely will not apease everyone. While you move swiftly (think Prototype) you cannot parkour and interact grab possible window ledges or wallcracks like in say Assassins creed or Infamous which makes the whole experience feel quick, but unsatisfyingly basic. Aside from doing sidequests, fighting robots and...uh, fishing, really? There's nothing else to do besides the story. That's not so bad however if you choose to see the game in a more linear way, going from plot point A to B so that by point C, at the games not so subtle proposals, you can put your attention to those other activities.     There are many more things to say about this game both in possitives and negatives, but overall I can't give it justice. I strongly recommend this game, especially to those who like games like Kingdom hearts (KH3 BETTER play this good after all this time in development).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:

												NieR Automata is an excellent game, with excellent story ideas, that constantly sets expectations for how good the game should be, and then manages to surpass them, not once but many times. Its goals are lofty, and its execution is quite marvelious.All of its elements in terms of gameplay are executed flawlessly.  They used the UE4 engines ability to support many type of gameplay options well, and the transitions between the styles are executed fantastically.  Sure, I wish they had added more to elements of flight combat, and had balanced very hard flight sequences vs ground fights better, but still I can't really knock it down.The story is awesome, but is not perfect.  All the concepts are well thought out and executed, but I feel some of them needed to be expanded more so they formed a more cohesive whole.  This is a worthy addition to NieR Gestalt and Drakengard 3 universe, and while you don't need to play the prior ones to enjoy the game at all, it is worth watching the history that leads up to this game on youtube.  That said, NieR Automata succeeded at being far more epic in scope than it ever was in the past, and is best hybrid game of its type that exists despite any flaws that can be found within.I'd give this game a 10 out of 10, even though the PC port needed a bit more work on its graphic card issues before release (Thankfully I'm using Nvidia and had no issues with this one). Still, it was one of the best game ports I've ever played on day of release, and hopefully those issues will be worked out soon.Voice acting was strong the entire time, which I just don't expect from an English dubbed Square game.Thank you to everyone who brought this game into existance. It was an awesome experience. Even more, thank you for allowing it to be ported to the PC!  If I had a complaint, it is that game left me wanting far more than it delivered (and it delivered a lot). Damn you Yoko Taro! Now to wait 7 years until the next sequel!Special thanks for the unused elevators. You guys just had to go and make a joke out of that, didn't you? ;P

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
17
												This review is my final opinion. I've completed all main endings, and will procede with the missed side quests later. To start this off, NieR: Automata was completely worth the price personally. It uses the medium of video games in a way that's, quite honestly, very refreshing and unique. I haven't been this impressed in years. I honestly think this is as close as you can get to a masterpiece, and I will never forget it. Game developpers around the world should look up to this game as an ideal. You won't ever be able to play other games without comparing them to this. An instant cult classic, to be sure. Now, for the details:Gameplay:Huge step up in comparison to the older titles Yoko Taro has directed. The game manages to mix intense bullet hell (both on foot and jet), powerful magic in the form of pods, and rapid melee combat with reactive inputs in an amazing way. The bosses, especially humanoid ones, are exhilarating and have many phases. Chips let you add different effects to your character: for example, launching shockwaves with your melee attacks or slowing down time on perfect dodges. Upgrading weapons and switching their position (light vs heavy attack) in sets changes up the attacks. Using different weapon types in your sets also gives you different attacks. You can even switch weapon sets during combos. While the game doesn't tell you what are the available combos, you can get really inventive with them, if you're willing to try things out. The game can be a bit too easy on Normal difficulty at times, but it becomes quite challenging in later parts.Music:Manages to do the impossible and surpasses NieR's soundtrack. An extreme pleasure to the ears. The "chaos language" from NieR is once again used and is downright haunting. The remixed themes from the original give off an insane amount of goose bumps. On multiple occasions, vocals kick in or the track becomes more dynamic after a more silent phase, which is extraordinarily satisfying. I've never felt that any of the tracks were misused. I've quite honestly stood still in certain places JUST to listen to the music.Story:Captivating right from the start. While delving into complex existentialist themes, the game also gives you a story with plenty of twists to spice things up. If you have played NieR / Drakengard previously, you'll notice many mysterious details. It'll make you depressive and you'll love it. Can't really tell much without going into spoiler territory, but it'll keep you at the edge of your seat constantly, especially in later branches. It is absolutely required that you continue after Ending A, as the story progresses further and further with every ending, until the last main ending, E. If you stop at Ending A, you'll only have seen 25% of the story and content this game wants to give you, so please, do continue, there is no way you can regret it.Characters:Japanese and English voice acting seem to be equal in quality: nothing seemed out of place with the English dub when I used it. I was actually quite impressed by the performances at times. I ended up using the Japanese dub for everything past Ending A by preference though. Characters interact in a very believable way and seem alive. It's nice to see them grow in personnality over time. I really like what has been done with Popola & Devola. As you continue further and further, you'll eventually get to see the true nature of the characters, which I'm sure you'll love. I kind of miss the banter between NieR and Grimoire Weiss, though.Art styleColour palette and effects such as godrays make the environments very pleasing to the eyes. Character design is simply great, and has a nice amount of variety. Environments are crafted masterfully. The different menus have a nice consistent theme. In terms of pure graphics, the game holds up very well but I've noticed a few jarring low res textures, while other elements (pods, for example) have, strangely, high res textures. There's maybe just one zone I don't like too much, nothing terrible but could have used more polish.PC Version QualityTo avoid the white screen freeze/crash with AMD GPUs, you need to roll back to these drivers: http://support.amd.com/en-us/download/desktop/previous/detail?os=Windows%2010%20-%2064&rev=16.11.5It's ridiculous, but it actually works. Blame AMD, not Platinum. The game itself runs at 60 FPS on maximum settings (without AA/Blur) even though my hardware is old-ish. However, there's a bug which makes the game render 1080p Fullscreen as 900p (?) Fullscreen, but this is easily fixed by using Borderless Gaming with the in-game 1080p Windowed mode and should be fixed soon anyway.

												The guy who made the end credits is a joke..I bet its the same person who couldnt come up with good hiding spots and just said hey lets make hiding spot out of the map, and ilogical..And now i finished it.. thanks for the kick in the nuts and the bad taste in my mouth... i mean why?No cosmetics or other wild plot can convince me to acturely play right now.. and BTW your end credits crash my game twice.. mind you i only had one crash since i begon this game..  after adam and eve fight first time...  i ran into a wall after the fight, and it froze.. Would i buy a game of this niche again? Nope Big fat NOPE, yes i had a good time in this game, and its beautiful.. but the thing is, if they want you to like their game... why Do this to it??Play the game yourselves, but be warned, dark souls is less rage inducing from death and loss, dark souls have heart and story... but they would never do this...I would almost commend this game to be redone, and prober..--------------Just got "What are you doing" 2bs little secret.. hehe hard to get, i guess.So now it deserves the judgement.-----------------So first of system experience:Im running this on the low end system hardware, i5 2500k 16 gb(old old ram), and a 750 gtx ti(yeah 2 gb), but i can run 1600/900(better then the reccommended size) with high quality.So yeah this game is console cropped, meaning it will run 30-45 frames at any given time(since consoles do better that way..) but since pc hardware is more designed towards better performance nomatter the cost, the cheap hardware in the consoles need this setup.. but some guy has spoken out and done the work for these lazy developers now adays, and rewritten the code.But since rewritting your game will stop achivements from being gathered or worse(i do care somewhat, since my game runs somewhat smoothly) so ill wait in hope that they add this 60 frame fix to pc edition someday.The animations look smooth, the moving around feels very nice and looks amazing.This games Fighting style is truely something new to me, and i have not seen the combination such as this, and i surely have not seen any work this well.-------------Gaming experience:I just cant tell anything because its spoilers.. they've added so many cool features to this game to make it feel alive aswell as incredible gameplay.There is great story hidden. The gameplay is sidescoller,  platformer, sideshooter(i mean like an arcade game flying shoooter), shoot them up, openworld, levelingand special spec, grinding weapons upgrades, the game just want to be all, but unlike sanic they do it well, sorry sanic, btw sanics got nothing on this girl 2b she is damn fast in those heels but bushes, the bushes got something on her and sand piles, hehe	Your person is the game, if it dies the game die(perma death is a thing in this game, so saving is going to happen alot, but might not save you at all)Everything you interact with feels alive and gets to become more so as it goes along,  be wary of who can die, oh it crushed my heart to learn this.(but in a good way? yeah)  Theres alot of differant enemies, weapons and even more ways to play this game!-------------------My personal experience.I loved this game from the start, then i died, and noticed the importance of saves.It was hard, but now i rly like it all over a new.Still loving the game ways of making me feel.

How to play Nier: Automata, step by step guide:Play the ProloguePlay the Prologue again, because you died.Finish the game.Finish the game again, from the perspective of other character.Finish the game again. At this point you don't really know if the game has ended or notReplay the game ending from chapter select, because you wanna switch character at the end.Shoot the end credits, leave the message to other players and sacrifice your save files to save random player.Repeat.P.S. the game is great, it gives you an unique game experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
19
												Pros: One of the best games I've played in a while The whole RPG element + the DMC combat system is the most attractive element IMO The eyecandy. What else can I really say about this? The OST is amazing. It's beautiful and extremely fitting for the tone of this game. Aesthetically pleasing. This game is just beautiful, and although it's not on par with most of the modern games, this game is definitely beautiful in it's own unique way and is not graphically demanding either, given that you've at least downloaded the optimization mod FAR.Cons: Minor technical issues. Apparently it's extremely demanding without the FAR mod. 30FPS pre-rendered cutscenes. All I can say is for such a fast-paced action game, 30FPS = choppiness No 21:9 support for cutscenes. It's either black bars, or the video just becomes strected. This is predictable I guess, since most games happen to be this way, but for a 2017 game, I would imagine that the developers would've placed more consideration into accomodating the fact that 21:9 isn't as rare as it was before. Lack of replayability? I won't say it doesn't have any, but after completing all the achievements and side quests and getting all the +8 chips, pod programs etc, there is actually nothing else to do. This game has a very good story and fun side quests, that's undeniable, but why not implement something that makes this game worth going back to? For example, a bloody palace like mode instead of just a debug mode, or at least allowing players to continue playing even after the game's end without having to manually select chapters.  No autosave is one of my least favourite features. I know this is done on purpose, but the developers could've considered making the game more challenging in different ways, rather than removing autosave altogether. At least have it in easier modes maybe?This game is definitely recommended. I love the combat, the visuals, the characters, and the OST. Unfortunately, the game has yet to release an official patch that aims to fix all the glitches and graphical issues many players are experiencing. Furthermore, the lack of 21;9 in cutscenes and the FPS lock at 30 for cutscens and 60 for in game is a bit of a bummer. The game is very well done, and we can definitely see that the developers have placed a lot of time and effort in the game but I do believe that these minor technical features should've been addressed ASAP. It's been almost a month at the time of this review, and people are still asking about whether or not we'll get a patch or not.

How to play Nier: Automata, step by step guide:Play the ProloguePlay the Prologue again, because you died.Finish the game.Finish the game again, from the perspective of other character.Finish the game again. At this point you don't really know if the game has ended or notReplay the game ending from chapter select, because you wanna switch character at the end.Shoot the end credits, leave the message to other players and sacrifice your save files to save random player.Repeat.P.S. the game is great, it gives you an unique game experience.

												As I was wating for this games release I wasn't quite sure what to expect from the gameplay but I was expecting a great story.And what a bonkers story I got that left me longing for more after i finished.Gameplay was hit and miss.The battle system and the smooth camera was great, although abit easy even for any averagely seasoned action game player.The perspective changes and the flightsuit minigame offered a nice change of pace and many of a smile over the roughly 30 hours of play.The only part of the gameplay that was ever so slightly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off was the hacking. I understand where the concept was coming from and with that it had to be combined, but i personally wasnt too big of a fan. Although there is, rather tedious way to deal with it due to switiching back and forth - easy mode and auto evade.All in all a great story driven game that left me with fonde memories I will keep on coming back to.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
3
Product received for free
												*Game gifted by friend (not affiliated with Nier and/or friends) for disclosure*WOW! Where did this game come from!? In a time where we are diluted with sub par games, I am so glad that I got a chance to dive into this world that I somehow missed out on with the PS3 era (Yes I am one of the new players to this series that I thought some of you could use an impression from going in blind).  Moving on with opening statements;NieR: AutomataAdd 1 part Taro Yoko (developer of Nier & Drakengard), mix well with PlatinumGames (publisher of Bayonetta & Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance), then sprinkle some Square Enix (Final Fantasy and friends), and you have this glorious game. What does this game intel? Plain and simple;-Fast combo melee action combat-Bullet hell style range attacks via Pod companion-Cyberpunk body modifications known as "Plug-Ins"-Etc.These are some good points, but check on the description to learn more. Onto the Pros, Cons, and Mixed;Pros:1. Fast combat via light and heavy melee attack combos 2. No stamina management (so dodge and counter to your hearts content!)3. Switches from multiple generas from RPG, Action, Bullet hell, Platform, and more4. The music is just awe inspiring. Cinematic and very fitting to the tone of the world5. The dark tones and greyscales are beautiful in this world6. "Plug-Ins" are fun to mess around with and configure to get the build your looking for7. As easy or as hard as you want it. There just for the experience? Use "auto" plug ins. Hardcore? Play 1 hit Kos8. NG+ is actually NG+. New mechanics and more without spoiling much9. The experience from the story you get with the NPCs of the game is crazy at times10. Multipule endings11. NPCs and the overall premise of the game really bring it together to get you hooked12. Booty, booty, booty, booty, walking everywhereCons:1. Buggy port on release. As time goes on, it seems to get better. Regardless, download the patch mod if you have any issues (Screen tearing, FPS cap, random crashes, Choppy cut-scenes, resolution not scaling correctly when set, and etc.) Nothing game breaking, but annoying2. Gamepad is HIGHLY recommended due to it being a port. Con for someMixed:1. Difficulty scaling (balance) through the game. Some parts for the difficulty felt off. Not hard, but at times, enemies will get really easy, then return to normal game difficulty. Granted, this is subjective (grinding, player skill, time, etc.), and as you can change the difficulty whenever, but feeling that it does change on occasion, I felt that it needed a mention2. Story. This is more mixed than a con. Overall, I loved the story and where the NPCs during my time in-game took me, but I did feel that the story start to feel “Generic” in parts of the game without giving away to much. This did not deter me from the game at all and keep in mind this is from one playthough, where with this game, things change with each, so take it as you willOverall this review comes from;-No prior experience to the franchise (Nier and  Drakengard)-One game completion at around 24 hours (Give or take due to bug fixing and moding)-Normal difficulty at a “normal” pacing (Last 1-2 hours was sped through)-Only “Route A” completed so far (doing next route as we speak)-Higher end rig (I5, 1080 and such)Recommend, Wait, or Don't?Overall, I loved every minute of this game, and I would recommend you do the same. There are very few games of recent memory that gave me a reason to really replay a game (Dark souls 3 and Fallout 4 being the more recent titles of this era for comparison), and this is one of them. If you are going by playtime however (cost per hour), then keep in mind this is one of the higher priced games ($60 release) for a possibly shorter first game, but the new NG+ mechanics and such that start after your first playthough are there if your looking for a SP game that has replay value.Edits: Typo and number edits.
