												A great game Directed by Yoko Taro and made by Platinum games.If you think that the current market became stale then this is the game for you; many risk-taking desicions in terms of gameplay and narrative.You don't have to play the original NieR to understand this game, you just won't get some minor refferences.The combat isn't as deep as DMC/Bayonetta.Thinks to look out for:-There is a resolution bug as of time of writing, there is a patch in the forums called "far"-2B's english voiceactor didn't catch her character at all, there is a lot of unneccesary sass added (just like with Zero from Drakengard 3). A playtrhough with japanese voices is recomended.-Some parts of the OST are arranged tracks from the original NieR, hearing themes of bosses/characters that apear later on in some sidequest might ruin the surprise.-Bosses speak during fights, switching to a Chip-set without damage modification when you see that you deal too much damage if you want to hear all the lines.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
25
												Okay, so you've probably already heard people praising Platinum's fluid and stylistic combat and Yoko Taro's stories.Though the combat itself is not necessarily as in depth as other Platinum games, the gameplay as a whole more than makes up for it with its width and variety.The story is just one of those gems where it could only be told through the medium of videogames.  To those new to Nier and looking for that specific experience, don't stop at ending A.  Go for E.  For veterans of the first Nier, you might have a guess as to what happens, but I dare you to guess how Yoko Taro does it again; BUT BETTER.It should also be noted that this soundtrack is not just amazing, it's dynamic!  Multiple layers and versions of songs are seeemlessly being being played at once with their versions switching in and out as sequences go on.  Going back to how this game is a story that can only be told through games, the soundtrack also does something during a specific fight.  What it does exactly I don't want to spoil, but man, it's probably the highlight of the game for me personally.My only words of advice for those of you who do get the game:  Power through the main storyline until you get fast travel unlocked, it'll make your life easier.  And as for the bossfight in E?  [It's an unwinnable fight.  But still, we're here for you.]

												PROS+weapons all have storys to them that makes leveling them up fun as you get to hear more about there past+offers a unique aproach to combat and level design for an open world RPG+game has multiple endings+great open world design with side quest that give you insight into the world and characters+one of best most customizable combat systems platinum has made to date.+soundtrack is well done on a professional level and changes along with the game mode your playing without missing a beat.+game has great art direction+custom controls and and camera control+very good voice acting for english and japanese dubs+decent enemy variety+great story+offers debug mode to play around with the combat.CONS--uses denuvo-pc port is average at best (if your an AMD user you might have problems) there is a fan made fix in the forums though-some textures take a second to pop in-there should be a demo to see if you can run this before you buy itPERSONAL OPINIONi have played alot of (clover,hideki kamiya,platinum) games such as DMCS 1-4viewtiful joes 1-2okamibayonetta 1,2metal gear rising revengencetransformers devastationthis is easliy the best game they have done out of the bunch when it comes to story,soundtrack, and dare i say combat for the amount of customization that can be applied to it.(next to bayo,and DMC4SE of course)i had a blast playing this and its my favorite game this year.if your machine can run this smoothly its worth the money at full price.

												This game was incredible. Phenomenal. Amazing. Words like these aren't enough to give justice to the story and gameplay of Automata. I will mainly be speaking on the story in this review because it was what captivated me the most. This is my first Yoko Taro game as I have never played any of the Drakengard series or any previous Nier game. But as other reviewers and, I believe Yoko Taro himself may have said, you do not need to know the lore of anything about the past games to appreciate what this game shows you through its 25+ story campaign. I was pulled into playing all the time because I wanted to know know more about the game's backstory and history. The plot twists in the game genuinely shocked me as I never even thought about the possiblity of them happening. I cried a few times during the game just because of the overwhelming sadness I had just thinking of the purposes of these Andriods fighting the war. If you have any thoughts about this game just drop them and buy it. This is definitely my game of the year and probably will be for a couple years. I really hope for the future for there to be story dlc as there are so many questions that I have that I want the answer for. This game is a 10 out of 10 Masterpiece and will be the best game I've ever had the pleasure of playing.

												Despite a slew of post-launch technical difficulties, I would highly recommend this game.  The combat and exploration is very fun, and just draws you in.  Combat is fluid and fun, and creates a feeling I can't describe that gets your adrenaline pumping and makes you feel invested. One thing that I had a tough time with in this game was deciding the difficulty to play on. Normal mode felt too easy, and Hard mode felt a little too difficult to get acquainted to.  So, if you go for the glory in difficult modes like I do, expect to do a little learning.  After a few hours of play Hard mode is fairly manageable.  Despite this and the technical issues that I hope will be patched, this game is still stellar. 8.5/10 would recommend, 10/10 when issues are fixed.

												The game has a few graphical hicups, some framerate drops here and there. mainly when you transition from one biome to another I.E. from the city to the desert. It's all seamless and there are no loading screens (when travelling around the map) framerate drops are the cost for being able to enjoy seamless gameplay IMO Other than that, the game is AMAZING, the combat, artstyle and everything is just down to a T and the story, well. If you're the kind of person that only plays a story through once when it has multiple endings. Break that habit NOW! A minor spoiler here. When you playthrough once, you'll then get the option to save and play it again. Except this time you'll be playing the same story from 9S point of view. After that, you'll be expecting the same story again from another characters point of view.You'll be pleaseantly suprised. So please don't be disappointed with the story and don't let those credits fool you. IT'S NOT THE END!

												I've played this game WAY TOO MUCH ALREADY to not come to love it.I was never a fan of RPG's, such as the Final Fantasy series, etc. I just haven't had the interest, ever. But out of all games, I just decided to pre-order it because I was getting really bored with the games I play now- I don;t even have a set 'interest' in any genre in particular.But this game had various core things that made it great for any player to experience, no matter the experience with RPG's or even the Nier series:- Stunning design- Easy to understand objectives- Lots of side quests for experience- Great features like hacking and different perspective - A teary plot ( no spoilers )- An incredible amount of dialogue - Variation in play style ( LOTS of variation ) - An incredible amount of work and sweat put into the INCREDIBLE soundtrack There are only a few cons, maybe a few crash bugs that happen incredibly rarely, and yes, graphical bugs with changing resolution. 												The game blind-sides your expectations; it's waaay more than it initially seems. The demo doesn't give you what the main game gives you.It's beautiful and baroque - unique (which's completely rare in big releases) and deep (really neat RPG systems for customizing character, etc.).A completely great game: I've only played it for 10 hours (which the game says is ~3% complete), and it's already one of the best games I've ever played.Like Zelda crossed with Metroid and MGS5, but with combat distilled from Bayonetta – all this with mental boss fights that rival the scale of Dark Souls 1 & 3.It’s an insane, ridiculous, cool game.

content:

												I haven't yet finished this game's story, but I have played enough to get a good feel for the themes and combat. So, here are my thoughts:Combat wise, the inevitible question is: is it most like MGR, Bayonetta or Devil May Cry? The answer, for me is... somewhere between MGR, Bayonetta and to an extent, Megaman Zero. The combat is, from what I've experianced, pretty shallow in terms of movesets for both you and your oppnents. However, fortutiously, that does not detract from it's enjoyment factor. That's where the Megaman Zero comparison comes in. As for MGR and Bayo, it's speed and grace is quite similar to Bayonetta, but it's ground-based focus and high speed are similar to MGR. Bullets in this game might be big and slow, but you still have to eihter dodge them, or get to your opponent before they fire them. The latter is my personal preference. What about the story, or rather, the themes? Well... I won't spoil the story themes for you, but I can tell one thing: this game seems to want to make you slightly uncomfortable. Not so much as you are aware of it whilst caught up in the fighting, but in things such as the haunting German and instrumental soundtrack, primarily made up of haunting piano and electronic music. Though what genre eludes me, since I'm not that familar with those things. A part of this is the combat animations. Normally, you move like a human. However, in combat, you are dodging every which way, jumping and swinging those weapons - and though it can look beautiful when the particles are up and you are just a flurry of blades and fists (if you can find any of that weapon class, which I have not been able to) you don't move quite right. You don't dodge - you dash. Or rather, glide. In a fight, you will be spending a lot of time pulling of moves that no human could, throwing and teleporting your weapons, gliding and jumping - or both - with your blades sometimes not even causing the enemy to react. In short, you fight with little semblance to humanity and that, due to your characters human appearance, doesn't quite click right. A lot of stuff like that happens in this game.  It's a good game because of it.Also, and I suppose this must be addressed: yes, 2B is indeed endowed with a trememdous booty. If emotionless female women whom also have a tiny spot of Lolita thrown in are your type (and I'm not judging, that's fine with me), then there you go.

content:

												Nier Automata combines Yoko Taro's story with Platinum Games combat to create a rather fun game. Its soundtrack dynamically changes as you play the game, with calm versions for running around and dynamic versions when fighting. Its combat is extremely fluid and getting hit is your fault most of the time. Difficulties Very Hard and Hard provide a very nice challenge while Normal and Easy are very accessible for new players. Controls for the gamepad can even be rebound completely in game without steam.There are some issues with the game however such as the tutorial has no checkpoints/save points. This is around 30 minutes at most to do once you know what to do, but some players will get stuck there for a couple hours if they refuse to turn down the difficulty. KBM is not recommended for this game, while it is playable it will be rather hard to play due to constant camera angle changes.

												Runs fine on 1080p full settings on my nVidia 970. Only bug I encountered was a game freeze when I changed the video settings and then continued to play.This game is interesting and unique, which can't be said for a lot of other games. There is always something unexpected around the corner and there is always something nice to look at.My main gripe so far with the gameplay is that there are lots of areas that seem traversable but that actually have invisible walls blocking the way. Kind of an immersion killer. In addition, things can get a bit repetitive in the second playthrough. Also, note that the first save point is an hour in.Reminds me of how games used to be when there were more quality titles and passion was put into them.8.5/10 so far. Higher if they manage to optimize it even more.

												The Best Game i've ever played! GotY and withouth a doubt Soundtrack of the Year.Story 9/10The Story was so good and beautiful.The Plot was amazing. Characters 10/10All Characters were so beautiful designed.Especially 9S. You really could see how the Characters developed.All the Enemys/Bosses had a understandable reason for their handle.Soundtrack 10/10I finished the game and now i cant stop listen to the Whole Soundtrack :/There wasnt any song i didnt like. My favourite Songs are the Amusement Park theme,the Desert Theme and Emils Memory Song.I usually skip the Credits but damn the Song was so beautiful i listen it 3 times xDGameplay 8/10The Gameplay was varied. Sometimes Side Angle, Birds Eye view but most of the time it was Third Person.It was really fun to play with A2 and 2B with their fun combos. The Dodge and Counter attack mechanic was really amazing to play. Another Thing i really like about the Gameplay were the Pods, they are so useful, you can keep the enemy on distance or poke the Boss Enemy when he try to do stuffs.Graphics 8/10Nier Automata's World is so good designed, the atmosphere of different Areas were amazing. It is not the High End Graphic but its more than enough to enjoy the World. The Characters are looking so good, i mean just look at 2B's...Lips ;)Voice Acting 10/10I played and prefer  the Japanese Voice Acting.2B's Voice is the same as Mikasa Ackermann from Attack on Titan and 9S's Voice is the same as Kaneki Ken from Tokyo Ghoul. The Voice acting was good and emotinal.Pros: -Amazing breathtaking Story-Beautiful designed Characters-Atmosphere -Best Soundtrack -A lot of things to discover -Good Game Mechanics-varied Gameplay-Your decision decide your Ending StoryCons:-Cutscene on 30 Fps Lock-Fullscreen bugConclusion:Nier Automata is my all time favorite Game. Did i already mention the stunnishing Soundtrack? xDIf you buy it you should prepare for a breathtaking addicting story and Sad Plots.

												NieR:Automata is one of those games that you will be proud of having experienced. Everything in this game deserves praise, the gameplay, the story (Though it is somewhat confusing) and especially the OST. In short, its a freaking masterpiece. Though I must say that the one gripe that I have with this game is the imbalance of its weapons, there are a lot of them sure but not all of them are good. If you're a total stats nerd like me then you'll want the best weapons out there and sadly the weapons that you get at the beginning of the game are so good ( Stats wise ) that I found little incentive to try or level up other types of weapons. This can limit your enjoyment of the game since it makes combat a little repetitive but nothing that a small patch can't fix :). Hopefully.

												I can definitely say this is in my top five best games I've ever played. I can see why this franchise is a cult classic. It is unlike anything I have ever played before. The originality is so refreshing and I regret not ever hearing of the Nier franchise sooner. I have to applaud the risks they made into making this game by how different it compared to stereotypical gameplay, and how effortlessly they seemed to implement it too. The soundtrack is absolutely amazing and that it was dissapointing to find out the game didn't come with it. Interesting storyline and abundant side quests that were just as captivating as the main story. Great character design and game animations. A lot of attention to detail was put into this game.Fun gameplay, and enemy scaling is accurate. You get to play as multiple characters who all play uniquely. The game has great replayablility, as the story doesn't just end with your first playthrough.I highly recommend to use a controller, not mouse and keyboard. The port handled fine for me; no problems. I honestly have barely any negatives to say about this game. Don't be that guy who plays for 0.3 hours and leaves a bad review because it isn't a stereotypical game.

												To be honest, this game is not for everyone - it's too wierd for that. But for those that can stand an eccentric game, this game will meet and rise above your expectations for it. Do not take my word for it, simply go play it. There are too many pros to list (not to mention many of them are spoilers in of themselves), so I will simply state a shallow list of cons I have experienced:The chosen way of storytelling, in bits and pieces leaves you confused, and possibly off put during the first playthrough. The dialogue is pretty cheesy (Although much like a Kojima game, despite its cheesiness it still stands effective to cause the player to grow attached and to feel emotion, and not simply laugh at it).Sidequests are not always super fun, and require backtracking quite often.Those are truly the only three cons, while only one (the third) is truly anything negative towards the game. 9/10.

												FIrst 8 hours so far are everything I could ask in a game, it feels like love. Very small complaints : 1. It has RPG elements, but is also an action game.What is good about action games is that you level up your own mind, not your characters, but with RPG elements you have to level your crap or you'll face monsters 40 levels above you and have to spend 30 minutes chipping at their health. Some people like it, I think it's for scrubs.2. It's sometimes hard to tell what is an attack and what is just an harmless effect as well as sometimes there are too much effects to know what's going on.3. You can slide "up" in the sand, that's weird.Otherwise, the attention to detail is phenomenal, the animations are beautiful, so far it feels like every bit of story might be significant, it makes the story very intriguing.

content:

												I am so sorry, everyone! ;_; I used up two of your lives in my attempt to finally overcome E route ending! I am so ashamed of myself that this is officially the first game that I ever review any game in any official capacity. I hope in the next life you can forgive me for my lack of strenght! I felt horrible losing your data over my own mistakes! ;m;Nier:Automata is possibly one of the only games that could not exist in any other form. It's transgressive entertainment that leaves you thinking long after you are done with it's multiple endings. It's not a flawless game, I doubt any game is, but as a piece of meta narrative driven, horizon expanding gaming goodness it's not matched by anything that I have ever seen in over 19 years of gaming.I would wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone interested in games in general, but only if you are willing to at least get all the main endings A, B, C, D and E routes. Eventhough A and B routes are a little slow, the speed and progression ramps up signifigantly after that and I doubt you can leave the game alone until you have seen all the rest of the endings.9,5/10, likely the most remarkable game of 2017, despite the fact that many heavy hitters like Zelda have already been released and the year just started. Simply put: Nier:Automata is a transcended game, one that will be remembered in the future for it's excellence in game design and direction.

												I want to thank you and spank you upon your silver skinRobots don't care where I've beenYou've got to choose it to use it, so let me plug it inRobots are my next of kinRHCP - Go RobotI'm not usually a fan of JRPGs/anime based stuff, but this game is fantastic. It has a MGS'esque story delivery(at least to me). The DX .dll hook fixes the resolution issues. Tomb Raider SLI nvinspector bits work great at 4K/60Hz with 2 GTX 1070s (if you were wondering if there was a profile/fix). A controller is a must. It will punish you if you die. Needs moar A2. Buy it.

												There have not been many games that have drawn me in as much as this game has, when I brought it I played nothing else for the whole time that it took me to get the 5 main endings.This game has a brilliant story that has some really moving moments, along with ones that really make you think about what is going on around you, and the story changes as you go through the different play throughs, which really expands on this story meaning that multiple play throughs are not a drag but an expansion of the original play through.Along with this story the soundtrack is simply mindblowing, I cannot think of many games that come close to the soundtrack that NieR has, and at no point did the music not match the setting or the mood of the game.It is definatly a game I would reccomend to anyone who enjoys well crafted games.

												Pros:Character developmentGreat storyGreat voice acting (japanese voices)GameplaySide quest are interesting and don't feel like choresPlot twistsMultiple endingsCons:Performance issues (there are fixes but it's unofficial but at least they work)Game crashing issues (white screen on AMD RX 480 cards, solved it by downgrading drivers to 16.11.5, but for now no official fix)English voice acting is terrible, definitely breaks immersion, I switched to japanese with english subtitles the first moment I could.All in all, this game is unique, it's jrpg but the storytelling is unique and it's not your typical new game+ rpg, the characters are very well made, they develop and you actually care about them and the story and the world.I fully recommend this game!

content:

												Very enjoyable character action game with a superb soundtrack which is second to pretty much none as far as AAA Games in recent memory go. It got really cool world building that throws you into a fascinating, somber feeling world (imho kinda Dark Souls-esque) which will make you ask a couple of existantialist questions. The biggest downside is that the much acclaimed different "endings" are mostly no endings at all, its just a pretense for you have to power through the same content twice with very little noteworthy difference until you are allowed to progress with what is pretty much the second half of the story. What helps is the fun and responsive combat that people assosiate with platinum games and which is also present and well realised in this title and the majestic OST. Characters are kinda bland and would have deserved to be more fleshed out, but androids be androids and they do a good enough job when it matters. Also Butts.

												2B or not 2B that is the question.I have to say that this game is worth every cent.With each playthrough you get to know more information about the story and see it from different angles.Every character is well thought through and you really care about what happens to them.There are different combat mechanics so it's not only hack and slash but who doesnt want to kill a bunch of machines with a nice combo?Also the game gets really hard some times at higher difficulties so remember to save! :)I loved the real ending when everyone is cheering you up not to give up.Pro:+story you couldnt tell through a movie+beautiful soundtrack and maybe the best i've heard in any game so far+diverse combat mechanics+likeable characaters even not the MC's+variation of questsCons:-only fix for screen resolution and fps during clips atm is community made (download, not that hard to do though)-you might lose some tears and start rethinking your lifeYou should definitely buy the game if you are considering it. Solid 10/10

												 Yoko Taro now has a free pass to put out a pile of flaming, smelly garbage, and I would buy it with my eyes closed and I would still find that better than 90% of the games out there. The word "Masterpiece" does not do justice to this game. It is all I can think about on my way to work, at work, on my way back, ♥♥♥♥ it, I'm applying for a week long sabbatical as we speak just to enjoy it. Nier made me feel emotions that I haven't felt in a long long time and I'm not just talking about games here, I haven't felt this deeply connected to anything, not even my favorite movies, tv shows, animes, cult classics, musicians/bands, you name it. Well for that matter, I'm not even that deeply connected to my girlfriend as I am to this game. You know when people say that a game is worth a 10/10 score but you still feel like there was something ever so slightly missing? I don't feel that while giving this game a 10/10. It is perfect. I cannot think of a better game. I just cannot.

ProsContrary to popular belief, no resolution lockGameplay is fantasticGorgeous graphicsStellar soundtrackConsGraphically demanding, especially 1080pLimited graphics options60 fps cap in game30 fps cap in cutscenesNo full screen windowed modeThe gameplay is just amazing. You don't have to take my word for it though, go check the reviews for the PS4 version. Steam reviews has typically become a place to talk about how the game runs technically, rather than what the gameplay is like (and thats ok, because its necessary information to have before you make a purchase). So rather than explain to you how good the game is, which you likely already know, I will let you know how it runs.Some have speculated that there is a resolution lock for this game, and they can't up the resolution past 1080, but thats false. I have a GTX 980ti and i7 6700k and was getting 30-40 fps at 4k resolution with minimal graphics settings. If you're planning on playing at 4k and want a smooth 60fps experience, make sure you have a better rig than I do. In 2k with settings maxed out, I got a steady 60fps through and through in every setting.It isn't the greatest port ever, but its not terrible by any means. If you can get past the frame caps, and aren't planning on running this in 4k, its worth a buy. Otherwise, wait for a sale.

												I've edited this review from a simple "It's awesome", because I feel that I need to give a more "extensive" review, just on the offchance that someone may read this and decide it's worth a shot. I want people to buy this game, just so the chance of DLCs or even another part increases. I need another fix!Don't be scared off by negative reviews - you NEED to play this game for its combat, for its soundtrack and first and foremost for its story. I promise you, you'll be blown away!It's true that the PC version has its problems (at launch and currently (26.03.2017)). They are easily remedied though, either by using fixes provided by the community or just playing around with some settings and using a controller (you should REALLY use a controller).But once you're past that initial settings hurdle that CURRENTLY exists, you will be starstuck by this game!The story will captivate you, the soundtrack will charm you, the combat will stir your bloodlust ...You WILL be taken for a ride on an emotional rollercoaster!

												I haven't played much of the PC version yet outside of checking out how it runs, but this game is absolutely fantastic. I've put around 60 hours into the PS4 version and got all the main endings, and this is a game that I could not stop thinking about after I beat it. The gameplay is very fun and polished, with Metal Gear Rising-like action mixed with bullet hell and other genre shifts, like Shoot 'em ups. The story is very good and well written, up there with the first Nier if you're familiar with Yoko Taro's previous work. The music is absolutely INCREDIBLE and one of the best soundtracks in gaming period. The first Nier was extremely hard to top in this department, but somehow this game managed to do it.Some little advice I'd like to give to anyone not familiar with Yoko Taro games: DO NOT think the game is finished after you get the first ending. There is a ton of new gameplay and story after you beat it the first time, so it's ok if you're confused at first. Trust me, keep playing it. It's worth it.

Why are you even asking that question & the game is legit itself/meant to be played on Hard mode, no higher, no below, however there are choices for you."[N]ow [In] [N]ieR Automat[A] ter[M]s;""[T]hank [Y]ou - [Y]okoo Tar[ō]""[G]ive [M}e - [D]rakengard [R]emastered""[G]ive [M}e - "[T]he [N]ext "[S]tage [S]oon"""[G]oodby[E] - [N]ieR Automat[A]..... [<3]"

												Nier: Automata is a masterpiece! A really beautiful game that was able to surpass my expectations, and oh boy that doesn't happen often nowadays. And in an industry that sometimes leans too heavily on sameness, it's wholly refreshing."God bless you Yoko Taro.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
20
												I can't remember the last time I was this invested into a single-player game. NieR: Automata is one of those games that I  would hang in a museum because this is a work of art. From the characters, the environments, and soundtrack, this game gives off a sense of beauty in a rather dark storyline, which has its uplifting moments and even had me giggling. The only negatives would be on the technical side of things. Fullscreen isn't working well, but can be fixed by a borderless application. Cutscenes tend to drop a lot of frames, which is weird because I can fight hundreds of enemies at a time and run a solid 60FPS, but two people talking in a cutscene drops that to about 20-30FPS. Speaking of frames, having any sort of anti-aliasing would kill my frames, so I had to turn that off while the rest of my settings were set to the highest. Game still looks great without AA, but some of the more *curvy* models in game do show some slight jaggedness. But a game isn't just about looks, it's about actual gameplay, which this game has a lot to offer. I'm writing this review with 20+ hours of game time and I've only gotten a few of the supposed many endings to this game. With that, there are also many side quests and tons of unlockables such as weapons, accessories, and upgrades that will surely keep me busy. The game also feels like many different games at time by smoothly adjusting from a third person hack-and-slash, to a top-down shooter, to a side-scrolling platformer, all within minutes of each other, which keeps the player engaged because for the first time I felt like my hands were having trouble trying to keep up, but I loved the challenge. Platinum Games and Square Enix have done a fantastic job with NieR: Automata, and this is coming from someone who doesn't really play their games. If you're looking for a fresh gaming experience, then Nier: Automata will deliver that.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:

												I've not spent much time with Nier at all yet, but I have been lucky to evade most of performance issues. My experience in action RPGs is very limited, but for some reason Nier had attracted my attention, and I had been eagerly awaiting its release for a while. Check out my video on Nier:Automata for a more in depth thoughts-on!


YouTube™ Video: Thoughts on Nier:Automata 

			Views: 12		

			Been waiting for this one for a long time. As a new visitor to the genre, I was welcomed rather than repelled. A fantastic action RPG that creates quite a memorable experince for me.		

I will keep this spoiler free as to me some even seemingly minor details were very impactful.What I will say is that as a whole experience Nier delivers very strongly. With fluid combat mechanics, interesting gameplay decisions, story I am interested in following as well as killer soundtrack it's a complete package, albeit not bug and issue free.The latter are, from my current exposure, performance related only and thus hopefully will be resolved in the nearest future. In the meanwhile, I have found Nier to be a game to get lost in, and then very meticulously dismantle some bad robots.Edit: Finished my first playthroughI have just finished my first playthrough. Boy what a journey it has been. Since this trend is popular, and to keep myself concise, bulletpoints! + Combat mechanics: being a moron that I am I finished it with kb+m. Not ideal, camera acts up sometimes, but it feels competent enough (definitely need to fish out my controller for subsequent play). Combos are joyful to pull off, plenty of them, too, amazing combat. + Story: made me weep for robots. tl;dr gripping. + Soundtrack: very immersing and well picked. Top notch stuff. Will listen to it outside of the game. + Navigation: found it quite tricky sometimes. But that's mostly due to my incompetence. + Story development: a little unexpected how sometimes it turns corners, leaving certain choices/actions unanswered. Makes sense, and that's why ng+ is worthwile. + Overall a powerful experience with great flushed mechanics and generally impeccable presentaion.I would definitely recommend this game to myself a year ago. You? Well, the reason you're here is to make up your own mind whether Nier will do to you what it has done for me :)

												Absolutely awesome game. Since the second I set foot in Nier: Automata, I have felt this familiar feeling to a game series I've been playing for over 25+ years since I was pretty young.  That series would be the Legend of Zelda series. Nier: Automata feels like a Zelda game through and through, with the NPC's you meet around the world, as well as the enemies and bosses. Where this game really shines is in it's combat. It is a hack n' slash game for sure, but it's a hack n slash game that rewards skill if you can believe that. Sure you can likely beat the entire game just by button mashing everything you come by and hoping for the best, but if you learn the combos for your weapons you can really do some awesome fighting moves. I went into this game completely blind, with only the trailer on the store page giving me a short preview of what the game looks like. It IS a port, and there are a few issues here and there. If you do not have a decen't rig, you might have some issues. KB/M is doable in the same way that KB/M is doable in a Souls' game, in that you can, but a controller is much better.

												I purchased this game without many expectations. I believed it to be a standard JRPG, and I quite enjoy standard.TL;DRThis game is worth more than the $80 that I paid. The game caters to both hardcore DS fans and super casual gamers. Can't do bullet hells? You only want to experience the story? No worries, they have automatic plug-in 'chips' that you can choose to use, on easy mode which performs 'attack' and 'evade' for you! (seriously you will never get hit.)'I highly recommend using a controller. KB/M is trash. Yeah, I said it, you ♥♥♥♥.If you have old PlayStation controllers, get a $4 CAD Bluetooth dongle off of amazon(probably cheaper in USD) and download the scarletcrush drivers, you cheap ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. It's like one burger at Mcdicks. Seriously, you can forgo 1 burger, you fat ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥?Series connections VVIt is connected to the Intoners, the events of Drakengard, and is set in the same world as NieR. After 80 hours of playing, my only wish is that Square Enix increased Platinum's budget to create DLC. ♥♥♥♥ YOU SE. ♥♥♥♥. YOU! BlTCH.______________________________________________________________StorytimeAfter completing the game, I felt sort of bitter and regretful about my purchase. The game felt extremely short and it left me with many unanswered questions.However, after the game credits, I received a message to continue playing through NG+, so that I could 'Experience the full game.' I thought, okay it's just the standard NG+ routine.Holy moly ravioli.WOW, I am so glad I decided to continue because, boy, is it ever different the second time around!After the second playthrough, I thought, for sure this is the end. But I was ♥♥♥♥ING. WRONG. When you replay for your third playthrough, instead, you start where the story ended the last playthrough. There. ARE. ♥♥♥♥ing. MORE. TALES. TO BE TOLD BlTCH! By the end of the third playthrough, I couldn't take anymore, but I wanted MORE. My brain was complete mush. My mind was blown. MY EYES. WERE RED. FROM TEARS.I realized,my whole life, I had been training for this one singular moment."How can I ever play another game?" I thought. My meaning for existence had been fulfilled.I can die happy, my life is complete.I can die happy, my life......is complete....but then I found out that there are more than 3 endings. WHAT. THE. ACTUAL. ♥♥♥♥! Anyways,I'm a pretty cheap b a s t a r d, so I am never satisfied with games that I purchased at full price.I can say that I am more than satisfied with Nier: Automata, and it is the only game that I deem worthy to write a serious review for, so far.Great job to Yoko Taro, and all the talented members at Platinum. I truly hope you can continue this amazing series.

												Not fond of these types of games usualy, but this is a exception.Im done with the main campaigns (about 20 hours) and am going to go do some sidequests and other stuff.Things i really liked:-The story(-ies) i find to be fantastic.-Characters, felt invested in them.-Self-destruct... ''function'' (it has its great purpouse).-Challenging enough (on normal).Neutral stuff:-Upgrading/gaining weapons require work-Didnt find much function for money, was easy to acquire.-Fishing-Simple combat (from what i understand).-Stat modifying chips.Things i didnt like:-Sidequests and traversing the map can be tedious (alot of back and forth movement).-First hour or so of the game has no save, so if you die you have to start all over.-More running.-Fastravel between set checkpoints comes into the game about half way through your first and second run.-Camera (both fixed and free) sometimes dont know what they want to do.-Keyboard support is weak.Note: I played with a keyboard and mouse, it works fine but youll have to mess with the camera options for it to be nice.Lazy review concluded.

content:

												I'm about 11 hours in and so far the game is running really well overall. I'm using a GTX 980 Ti, i7 5820k, 16gb DDR4 HyperX Fury, and an Acer Predator X34 monitor at 3440x1440 clocking at around 45-50fps in general, with AA set to 2x and everything else at the highest possible setting. It looks great, but you can definitely tell that an optimization patch is needed. The cutscenes in particular are capped at 30fps and stretched to 21:9 and it's almost killing it for me, but the game is so good and it being ported to PC is fortunate, but it definitely still needs work overall. As of right now I would recommend it if you're into this type of game and don't mind the obvious, early shortcomings, but if you're on the fence, waiting for a optimization patch might be a good idea. I could have bought it and played it on my PS4 Pro a couple weeks ago, but it's good to see developers embracing the PC and I decided to support that initiative.

The newest game brought to you by the team-up of moon headed madman Yoko Taro and action game crafters Platinum Games, NieR Automata plays to boths strengths; compelling story and characters and stylish smooth character action. 												I've played a good enough amount to write this review. And MAN i'm hooked!!First and foremost I played the first NieR on PS3 w/o ever having seen or heard of the Drakengard universe (the overall storyline and connections are VAST! Might be one of the more complex and brilliant storyline ever created), and I instantly loved it for it's unique story, style and gameplay... NieR: Automata adds to it.. though the PC version struggles a bit. But nothing which makes it unplayable in any sense. The mixture of RPG/Hack N' Slash/Isometric ARPG elements makes this game amazing and unique. The soundtrack is freaking awesome!Combat is fast paced and diverse. Customisation etc. is new and unique. And the death system takes Dark Souls and NiOH elements and combines them in a positive way, where (when online) at death the player leaves an android body behind for other players to benefit from, by either repairing it to get a companion, or simply retrieving the parts, to gain full health and loot... Setting the online thing aside, your own body is also retrievable, since you lose a bit of exp and loot if you die. But if you choose NOT to do anything. It can rise again, evil. Where killing it gives some bonuses... It's simply BRILLIANT!Overall I am just very impressed with this game, to such an amount that all negative things gets brushed off. Playing it made me see various videos to understand the lore and storyline of drakengard/nier. And even though I didn't get to replay the first NieR to all 5 endings.. I'm quite sure i'll be replaying Automata to get the full story and variations. :D I AM LOVING IT!P.S. DON'T EAT THE MACKEREL! xD

content:
5
												Nier Automata is a patchily optimised, derivative and linear game. One that likely cuts these corners under the pretense of having to lump on top it's mechanical development the aesthetic and thematic sensibilities of something that resembles Square Enix's self-image as a first rate developer of original fantasy titles. Platinum, a developer that can be heard over the wall crashing entrance of new Capcom, Konami and Enix titles faintly playing a second fiddle to them has been burdened with reeds and pages and a restrictive suit for this new recital and it can make the presentation (marketing) buckle it. Nier Automata is also without a shadow of a doubt the best game of the past five years. It is utterly definitive of a developer trying to do something constructive and exciting with the heart and head war that exists in contemporary design sensibilities. That is, do we make something for people that is fluid, structured, engaging and that tethers their emotional experience to distinctive pacing but is all the more linear as a result? Or do we the developer make something that is open, grants autonomy to the player, lends possibility to every situation and entices them with that irresistible premise that their experience of the game is going to be unique from everyone else’s? What Platinum have managed to do with Nier Automata is to create the most seamless, fluidly shifting fifty fifty balance of those two sets of rules and not a single one is worse for the presence or absence of the other. While one is keenly aware that the number and variety of mechanics (not one of them imprecise or poorly implemented) were 'traded in' by the guys at Platinum for more marketable spectacle, likely run as interference by Square Enix. But given Platnum's experience of dishing out this level of spectacle and their almost unique ability to marry it to visceral, frenetic gameplay, all the moments that look for all the world like they belong in an anime opening or a cutscene in a turn based strategy game or even in a visual novel are threaded in perfectly with those moments that you boast to your friends about pulling off, or that you try to boast about discovering first in your walkthrough. The relationship this balance of expected set-up and curveballs in execution that the core game has with it's own narrative is, to my view, the conceit of it's very design that ellevates it above the other major hack and slash adventure titles released this quarter with times upon times the marketting budget. You start this procedural genre-aware, mission based hack and slash swooping in to enemy territory on a mecha-plane contraption as a rank and file member of an android army. When you're immediately ambushed and put into the commander's position you must dogfight your way to relative safety from out of nowhere in the middle of the opening cutscene. You, 2B - the android caught up in this cluster♥♥♥♥ and the poor level desginer who had to shred all of his copies of the player being sat in a tutorial simulation or something experience the same violation of expectation - and in a very good way. This constant upscaling of how you fight, what you fight and why you're fighting it ripples throught he entire narrative, expressing itself at junctions of meaningful choice and fufilling exploration as well as distinct shifts in stakes, tone and of course difficulty level. The mechanics of this game and the world it renders with them are part of the exact same digesis. Fluff and crunch are united in making the visceral painful and the wonderous explorable. This breathing of life and meaning into a set of future sci-fi images and ephemera is utterly in line with the games' relatively complex themes and the wonderous tone this strikes is kept in line with the often action-packed pace of your adventure with a soaring, genuinely thespian score. By the time you have landed in enemy territory and must see for yourself what soulless machines have done with the earth that humanity has cultivated by the end of it's modern existence, you realise that actually there is quite a time limit on your life, that the same mechanics that controlled that ship and the mecha and your sword and your droid are all the same five or six buttons, that the machines are a somewhat bland opponent to start such a spectacular game with, you'll realise that nothing could be more appropriate for the story you're playing through. Much the same way that an artisanal film is going to use a confluence of sound and visual, still and moving, loud and quiet to craft it's digesis, Nier Automata pulls from the spice rack every conceivable piece of intrigue and excitement from Shonen Anime, Science Fiction literature, Post-Apocalyptic Fiction, Visual Novels, Arcade Games, Tabletop Games and just a few fun as ♥♥♥♥ hack and slashers to propell you along this adventure. But each perfectly timed dodge, each newly discovered secret, each well-earned upgrade and each eviscerated boss reminds you that you have the keys, the throttle and the steering in hand.In the form of your controller, not your keyboard, because Jesus ♥♥♥♥ing Christ.

												edit after ~36 hours of playtime and reaching all five main-endings... (a-e)This game - spite it's technical difficulties on the pc-platform - is a gem.Even if it does not completely reach the greatness of the original NieR and many of the ideas in the game are pretty were seen in NieR before, and even if there was no oh-so-big "wtf" moment as it was in the original NieR story - it's still just an absolutely awesome game.It's like the Dark Souls series - the gameplay gets smoother with every new title in the franchise, but the feels you have when playing the first one for yourself will just never be the same again as when you saw some things for the first time. Still, that does not make it any worse. It's just, that the old NieR was just unique. NieR:Automata is still great, but just not as unique when it borrows 80% of the gameplay elements from the original NieR...Still: buy it. Don't spoil yourself, don't read too much. Don't view streams of it. Just buy it and experience it for yourself! :)original review:Making even configuring the settings a part of the game - would press L3 + R3 again!NieR / 10

3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
21
 If there was ever a debate as to whether video games are art, NieR: Automata proves that they are. This is not Platinum Games' best game in terms of raw action gameplay, but it is Platinum's best game in general. And THE best game in general. Nier does a huge variety of things and does them all so well that it's impossible not to fall in love with the game. Gameplay Nier Automata initially starts off playing like any other Platinum Game. Fast paced, satisfying combat with a heavy reliance on player skill that provides a decent challenge. Though the challenge in Nier is much less than other Platinum Games (It doesn't come close to Metal Gear Rising in that respect), it does not detract from the experience. The combat and variety in gameplay styles between the characters is outstanding, and the RPG gameplay elements fit well in it. Levelling is a mere incremental increase in stats, but it still feels rewarding nonetheless, and the upgrade systems for Weapons, PODs and Chips helps the player feel as though they are actually progressing their character, and at no point do these upgrades really feel like they are taking too long or too quick; though certain upgrades for certain things can be extremely expensive and mildly irritating to discover how to get the required materials to create. The semi-open world works. Each area is very distinct and serves it's purpose with a variety of sidequests to complete; though not all sidequests are great. Sidequests are easily the biggest flaw in the gameplay of Nier: Automata. Some of them are fine, e.g. Photographs, Family Squabble though many are not (the worst offender for me being the repetitive, uninteresting back and forth walking of Jean Paul's Melancholy). Story This is by far the strongest element of Nier: Automata and is what I believe to be what makes this game a masterpiece, a work of art. The story of Nier: Automata may initially seem very generic, but it soon becomes very interesting, slightly convoluded, but always gripping (especially in the later two campaigns). Honestly, saying anything about the story of Nier: Automata would ruin it. Trust me here, you need to experience the brilliance of this for yourself without any previous knowledge. Sound Design (Music, Voice, Etcetera) Also pretty damn good, with some exceptions for the at times questionable English voice acting. To start off, the soundtrack to this game is downright beautiful, with each track fitting where and when they appear perfectly and causing ear-♥♥♥♥♥♥s to any and all listeners. The composer did an absolutely stellar job with the music for Nier: Automata. The sounds during gameplay and combat are fine, sounding and feeling almost exactly how you would expect them to and doing their job as well as they possibly could, though combat can sound a little repetitive with the expected metal-on-metal clashing sounds you would get from sword on machine. The voice acting is where problems start to crop up. On the main characters, voice acting in English is good. Not great, but good (though it does become outstanding all of a sudden during some of the more emotional and important plot moments). The problem is that almost every side character in the game sounds awful with the English VA, which means if you wanna understand what you're hearing you may have to put up with cringeworthy voices from time to time. I do have to mention that the VA in English for 9S is brilliant throughout though. Conclusion Nier: Automata is the closest thing to perfect you'll ever see in a game. Everything it does, it does well with a few flaws. It's stupidly fun, extremely engaging and my new favourite game of all time.

content:

												There’s a principle in video game design that Sid Meier calls “the Covert Action rule”. To quote Meier himself, the rule states “Don't try to do too many games in one package”. After four hours of NieR:Automata, I can only conclude that either the developers have never heard of the Covert Action rule, or they have heard of it but treat it with the utmost contempt. Within a single mission, often within a few minutes, the game goes from bullet hell to platformer to twin-stick shooter to hack’n’slash, all within the confines of an open world RPG.The strange thing is that all of this just works. The developers have managed to not only grasp the fundamentals of all these different types of games, but also make them work within a singular, easy to grasp control scheme and make the flow from scene to scene and genre to genre feel natural. Every mission so far has been a thrill ride where you can’t really tell what’s coming next.If it all plays delightfully weird, it also feels delightfully weird. Playing NieR:Automata is like playing a strange sci-fi anime, one where all the android soldiers are blindfolded gothic lolitas and all the enemies are thoroughly rusted cute-ugly robots communicating through confused soundbites and nothing is adequately explained. You just have to go with the flow and try to figure out the plot from hints.It might not be the best game I’ve played this year (although it comes close), but it is by far the coolest.

content:
17
												A sequel to Platinum's Transformers Devastation, Nier Buttomata is set after the bad ending where Megatron succeeded in roboticizing Earth.Also 2B is NOT HUMAN SHE IS A ROBOT STOP THINKING IMPURE THOUGHTS ABOUT HER. SHE IS AN APPLIANCE NOT A PERSON.Yoko Taro is an accurate assessor of how good his games are. Apart from animations and 2B's ♥♥♥, he has done everything possible to sabotage Platinum's usual level of quality. The result is a mess, a game with combat shallower than Korra, but with all the joys added of really boring shmup segments, and all the parts of Monster Hunter that aren't actually fighting monsters (So running through empty fields to collect shiny grindbits in hopes they will upgrade your weapon or a weapon you collect down the line.)But what about the plot? Well, it's typical Taro: "Machines don't have feelings," your blindfold wearing* protagonists intone as the robots proceed to display feelings in such a childish and goofy manner that it feels like this is some clown world cartoon... before you cut them all down ruthlessly**. 2B drops some loaded dialogue early on that practically spoils the whole game, too, but you don't get confirmation of this until much later because this game wastes your time immensely. You "clear" the game and get "Ending A" without a SINGLE thing of note happening in the plot. Then you're asked to do it all again, only with most action bits replaced with even more boring shmup segments if that's even possible. It's only until the THIRD play where the plot finally comes together. Even Nier 1 gave you a "complete" game with a real ending on the first play. (Oh and this means you play as the bootily-endowed heroine for less than half your game time.)  And in traditional Taro fashion, the actual finale wraps up so that everything is so utterly terrible that it blows right past depressing and into laughable clown-world territory again. There is no good, no evil, no heroism, nothing in Taro's world but sobbing, childlike victims of cataclysms so far in the past and so arbitrary as to be meaningless. The combat balancing is completely screwed up and nobody will ever notice it because on Normal it is nearly impossible to die. On Hard, you die in 2 hits, Ultra Hard 1 hit, and checkpoints are almost non-existant, usually in the 20-40 minute range, and most of that being awful unskippable chatter. And of course the hitboxes make From games look positively artisitic in that regard. And if it's not the hitboxes, it is the terrible camera work, often purposefully obscuring the action for absolutely no reason. Or the combat effects, so overdone to obscure reading the battle. Or that one major boss is fought in a literal dust storm, preventing you from seeing what he's doing half the time.Look, there's fun to be had here. Even a bad Platinum game is better by miles than most. Sprinting through fields, collecting goodies, slicing robots is just going to be fun no matter what, but on every other level this is flatly a mediocre and disappointing game.*(HRRRM I WONDER WHAT DEEP TARO SYMBOLISM IS MEANT BY THAT)**(Because of course the machines can't just be humans. They're autistic dopey adorable little kid humans that cry about their brothers because Taro can't make a plot work without crass emotional manipulation.)

												TLDR:Gameplay: 10/10 it's fun, solid controls. Action packed. Great stuff.Audio: 10/10 best soundtrack of the year. The voice acting sounds good. Etc etc.Visuals: 7/10 game looks good. Nothing amazing nothing bad either.Seems like a solid game. Performance has been great. Game has been fun. I played for an hour and have to go to work. I don't want to go to work. Gah.Ok. So obviously I like the game: you guys are for some reason not buying the game and need me to tell you why to buy it. I get it, $60 is preposterous and you can't make up your own opinion in 2 hours and refund if needed so below tells you why to buy it.Gameplay: Solid control. Responsive controls. I'm using xbox1 controller by the way. These are must haves because this game is quick with loads of action. Mind you I'm playing in normal and it isn't overly hard which is great. Always my fear that these action games can be too hard and demanding which means I can't play it. (Harder modes are definitely harder, I tried haha)So aside from the great controls the actual style of gameplay is fantastic. Seamlessly going from top down shooter, side scroller/platformer third person fee camera styles and more, each style plays similar but different and I love it. Really keeps you engaged.I was playing in top down, got knocked back into a side room and the camera seamlessly follows switching perspectives. Some big robot was in there so I kick his ♥♥♥ through the door, changing perspectives and proceeding to continue my battle. It's really thrilling and needs tried not explained.Audio: English and Japanese voice acting. I tried both. Both sound good. Always a fear the English sounds incredibly cheesy and fake. The soundtracks in the game are hands down ♥♥♥♥ing awesome.Visuals: nothing fancy nothing bad. Looks better than the trailers by a good amount though. I cranked aliasing textures and postprocessing to max. Off by default. I use sli 1080 it's probably only using 1 but meh. Most games don't support sli.Performance has been great. No slowdowns. Like I mentioned I turned aliasing and other things all the way up. Looks much better than the trailers.The game is much better than wildlands and for honor and some of the other "big" games out right now. Try it for yourself. Steam refunds if you end up not liking it or if your potato can't

												Really fun game overall and in my opinion lives up to the expectations, the port is so-so, not the best ive seen but not the worst either, controls work relatively well except for the dodge command which is pretty damm hard to pull of consistently with apropiate timing on account of it being a double tap of the direction keys. 												This is a review from about 10 hour into the game. Tldr; I reccomend this and rate it a 7/10. The best part of this game is the main characters;  they have the best models and their dialogue is very character defining. They stand out in this game and I find that important in a game that:looks like its many years dated in graphics and whoes side missions and story are very mediocre so far. the combat is a feels great, looks deep and hard kind of system that really doesn't utilize that too much. the skills you get will greatly alter how combat is defined and experience and while it is awesome once you look at it this was not the game I was hoping for, basically something sorta like dark souls. There is a lot of myustery that tugs on many gamers penchant to hold back in item usage but it really doesn't matter at all. I say this for normal mode only where it is still easy to die but only if you dont pay attention... otherwise when you get used to dodging it becomes a much easier game to win with.That said, I do still find the sombat enjoyable and the bland environments are at least interesting enough for me to find interest in exporation. The story is a bit intrigueing but definitely not unique on the slightest sense so far (if you are into sci fi genere works) and there are tales of having to play this game multiple times to find out what is actually going on in the story. Overall I rate this a 7/10 because it doesn't do anything poorly but doesn't seem to excell in any sort of area besides main character immersion.

												Just finished the game, got the endings A K W from 1 play through. Apparently multiple routes you can take, I think A is probably best ending but still leaves many answers unanswered. The design and everything is generally very engaging and definately will entice you to replay the game multiple times for different endings! The characters (especially 2B) is really likable from my experience. The music is simply outstanding. The artstyle is very unique and lovely, as long as you are okay with most of the game being in a ruined city greyish (there are 3 sections with different themes that I encountered so far from 1 play through).For my more technical thoughts see below.This game is pretty awesome, however if you do not have a controller don't expect to enjoy it as much with Mouse and Keyboard. You cannot dodge the same way you can with a controller with KB+M due to no dedicated button for evasion. Also the visuals on wide screen is kind of strange during cutscenes (probably stretched slightly or something), and there aren't many graphical customizations other than low medium and high. If you do not meet the minimum requirements for the specs you may find quite a few problems with the fps according to the community.Required:Specs to meet the game min.Controller for more enjoyment.Borderless gaming program for best resolution + borderless full screenPro:Game play is quite funVisuals is beautiful if not hindered by some glitches with the resolution at times switching to 720p for no reason. (Only in full screen.)Has Japanese voice/ English voice. Japanese voice is far superior (and the protagonist simply has a very likeable Jap voice)Cons:M+KB doesn't play that well in certain views (game switches from FPS/TPS/Top down/ many other)Cannot rebind evasion, cannot make Shift a toggle for shootingSome glitches and bugs (will probably be ironed out by the community)Cinematics are low fps and sometimes sutter for me (even though I have really high spec pc, however I use a 3440x1440 monitor)No borderless fullscreen. If you minimize at times you might be stuck with a mouse cursor on the screen so you need to save and restart the game to get rid of it... However there is no autosave. And you must find save points. Not to mention sometimes after minimizing your game is stuck in window mode. And if you are stuck in a cutscene you cannot change it back to full screen until you regain control of the game. Well you are stuck with watching those emotional/beautiful cutscenes in windowed mode with stutter and a mouse cursor in the middle if that happens to you (happened to me), unless you want to replay the whole section, since there is no auto save... (this can all be fixed by borderless gaming)

												13 hours played, ~4 year old PC upgraded with a GTX 970. Playing with an XBox 360 controller (worked out of the gate). The only technical issue I ran into was the fullscreen resolution bug, worked around it with windowed mode + Borderless Gaming. Since then everything works flawlessly, excellent framerate (there is the odd 2 second hitch when it loads in new areas). Very good about loading times.Gameplay is a joy to play for the most part. The camera and auto-aim fail at times and some of the finer points of the game's rules are seemingly left for the player to figure out through trial and error. Playing on normal the game is too easy but does feature the odd sudden difficulty spike.What takes it from good fun to remarkable are the setting, melodrama, comedy and weirdness. So far the story has been rather straight forward but I've not yet completed the first ending, so looking forward to more.

Framerate was not as much of an issue for me as the stuttering.EDIT 2: I pretty much completed all that is neccessary and really my only complaint about the game itself is the fact that the difficulty scaling on normal was pretty bad. I got to level 71 and it was OOOOVVERRKILL. Way too easy.

content:
18
												Nier Automata is a great game with a very interesting blend of action rpg and bullet hell. The camera itself adapts to these changes in combat which makes for a very interesting, admittedly jarring experience. The story is absolutely beautiful and I cried like a little baby. My only regret is not playing this in bite size pieces to really soak up the emotions, but thats hard to do when the combat and story are just so fun and engaging that I can't stop playing it.So lets do what everyone does and list the pros and cons about the game:Pros:- Combat: Its Platinum, so yeah the combat is amazingly fun. The blend, although it doesn't seem like it would work, works really well. Think DMC or Bayonettas use of guns. They aren't OP and you definitely won't rely on them too much for combat, but they help as a finisher and to take out arial targets, as well as add damage.- Characters: 2B, 9S and YorHa Androids, as well as defectors, are all pretty interesting. Granted I don't like 9S, but as the story unravels you really start to like him a bit more. Otherwise a lot of the characters presented have some interesting stories to them. As well as the post-apocalyptic Earth you find yourself exploring. I would definitely recommend that you read the log entires for the characters and world. While its later explained why things are they way they are, the logs really add that extra punch to the story.- World: The world is pretty open. Its really interesting and changes as the plot progresses. There isn't much you can do like climb the highest building and then jump off it, but its still all very beautiful and feels pretty big.- Soundtrack: Soundtrack is amazing.- Animations: Animations are really great. For those of you who are bothered by crappy animations such as myself, release that anal retention, because they're good.Con:- Combat: Is kind of weird, you can easily lose some enemies in the heat of combat. And the targeting system is pretty frantic. Say you want to focus fire on one enemy, expect the lock on to start jumping to other enemies close by. But this will usually be a problem in most games, because its kind of impossible to really select one enemy in a crowd to focus fire. As much as it seems to be a problem it really isn't.- Enemies: The enemies are carbon copies of each other with just some different adages, but seeing how the plot really fans out this makes a lot of sense, especially given the area they are in. So for example the desert bots have tribal clothing on, rather than the city ruins bots, which are the blank slates. (Note: Bosses are very much different, with only one being reused a few times.)- Presentation: Its a japanese game so it makes sense that it feels this way, but there are a lot of moments that feel stupidly anime. Just a plug for people who hate that stuff, but getting this game you should already expect that. Not much of a problem just letting you know.-  World: The world unfortunately does not change as much as most would like. Be warned that a lot of what happens story wise doesn't really effect the world all that much.- Cutscenes: A lot of the game uses in house rendering, which has caused isssues for me when audio desyncd. Be warned about that. Its more of a preformance issue, so if you meet the recommended reqs you shouldn't be experiencing this. However if you run a GTX 970 such as myself, you may run into this issue.- Graphics: If you have a GTX 970, you can play on high graphics and get all that goodness, just set anti aliasing off and turn vsync off as well. The fullscreen is a bit broken so I recommend sticking to windowed and getting an application that forces window borderless, until these issues are fixed.- Endings: This game does not have 26 endings. It has 26 possible ways of "ending" the game, i.e. like techincally dying in any game could be considered an ending because the hero is dead. However, there are the A B C D and E plots. I won't go into detail with those, but they are the true endings to the game. As for the other "endings" sorry to say, but they aren't groundbreaking, as they were not meant to be. A lot of them are jokes and are actually pretty funny.Conclusion:Thats about all I can think up for this game. Its fun and exciting, and the story is very engaging and shocking. I personally love the characters and how everything fans out.TLDR; Any game that can stop me from playing Overwatch for more than a day is a damn fine game. Take that as you will, but I love Overwatch. Also the game is just really good, play it what are you doing with yourself, nothing, thats what. You're reading reviews, just buy it and play it. Go spend your money.Side Note: For the very few of you who care, 2B is a strong independent woman who don't need no man. Its often 9S who needs to be saved by her. She isn't a pathetic weak girl who whines about everything. Very mission oriented and of course has a nice butt.Personal Note: You're absolutely insane if you think this is a mouse and keyboard game. Just stop right now and don't even bother. If you don't have a controller don't bother. If you complain about how it controls with a mouse and keyboard seek help immediately because there is something wrong with your mental state.More Notes!!: A lot of people are having problems running the game, I have yet to experience these issues. So do some research and approach with caution. Its a great game, but if your hardware can't handle it don't get it. The recommended and the minimum are there for a reason and some people choose to ignore it.

content:

Bullet Hell, Action-RPG, and Booty, all in one fine-tuned "Package"... but you're probably here to worship dat ♥♥♥.So before I talk about how great this game is, let me complain about THIS GAME IS HARD.I personally died 8 times in the tutorial section trying to play the game on hard mode (Not doing the harder difficulty... ♥♥♥♥ that). It hurt my pride so hard, I switched to easy mode, and then nothing could touch me. Then my pride hurt even more. If it weren't for that amazing soundtrack, I would have probably ragequit the game for a month.NieR: Automata is about a couple of androids created by humans to take back the world from some alien invasion. While playing the game, you are introduced to 3 different perspectives in combat that blend with each other. Traditional shooter, all-range shooter, and a third person action perspective. Each mode has an almost seamless transition between one another. You have access to all of your weapons and abilities within all 3 perspectives (weak attack, strong attack, gun, special attack?), however gun aiming mechanics differ between the shooter and third person action perspectives.The music is fantastic, the world is almost barren, and there are many weapons, chips, and upgrades to obtain in the game (You can even remove some features like being able to see how much damage you deal, UI elements). Learning from my mishaps in tutorial mode, I now understand if you want to survive in the hard difficulties, you better always be ready to tap that RT button (default). Tap dodge, tap dodge, tap dodge...Performance is... Great, but not perfect. On my gaming rig of an i7 4790K and a GTX 1080, I was able to achieve my ideal quality of 1440p 60fps with the settings on max (turned AA to 2x). The game for the most part kept the 60fps, however I did notice a few minor frame dips every now and then. Resource usage looked normal and does need a beefy GPU to keep within good frames. Oh, but a minor complaint of mine: Cutscenes seem to be locked at 30fps.As someone who has never played the original Nier (however I have played Drakengard 1 and 2), I like this game. The soundtrack was literally the only thing that prevented me from ragequitting during my frustrations with tutorial mode. It's going to be an abusive relationship of me dying over and over again in a hard difficulty, but I'll carry on...  for that booty.

content:

												A Nier game from Platinum? After playing this on the PS4 and then moving onto the PC, I guess I'm a skeleton trapped onto the Yoko Taro Wild Ride.The Good:- Characterisation. 2b and 9s are relatively charming along with the supporting cast. The enemies while repetitive and robotic clones of each other have their many quirks.- Combat. Infinitely better than the predecessor because Platinum know how to do combat. And Fishing. And the other side jobs.- The mechanics. Majority Action RPG, part platformer and shoot 'em up. The blend works.- That soundtrack. It helps to set the feelings trip up.- The previous game has no real hold over this one so it's easy to pick up and just play.The Bad:- The open world. So much of it is walled off and quite damn bland which is a shame. Lush areas are met with general buildings and environments that look the damn same. - Resolution and optimisation. I'm running the game on recommended spec and am experiencing frame rate loss. Could just be a driver issue but I've seen the complaints about 4k and Radeon optimisation. Hopefully it'll get quashed now it's in world.-Denuvo. Just no.The mixed.- Complete Emotional Rollercoaster. It helps to be either an emotional masochist or emotionless robot on a Yoko Taro game.- The timesink. It's real in this game and in a way part of the charm that sticks around from the first game. Endlessly replayable and if you're a casual gamer you're not going to get too much out of it from playing a little. Like Police Squad got cancelled, this is one that requires your attention if you want to get invested into it.In Summary.Former Radio 1 DJ John Peel used to operate a five star rating system and he took it to beyond 25 stars for his beloved song by the Undertones, Teenage Kicks. Do I recommend it? Yes. Yes. Emphatically like a Daniel Bryan chant.

												This game was an experience, a little fan servicey at times but all around had me yelling "Holy ♥♥♥♥!" most of the time, you can just pass over the enemies most of the time and the textures make it so that every thing looks blended together and it kind of hurts the eyes. The boss fights were all around pheonominal, even if i didn't have to move and just hold right bumper most of the time, i only did one play through of this game and i feel it didn't deserve the praise a lot of people have given it.  Not saying it's a bad game, but certainly lacks a certain polish. The story was compelling, making me want to get to the next story checkpoint after another, i was never really compelled to do any side quests. I saw no use, the only use for the other weapons was you would use whichever weapon you could upgrade. I do not regret this purchase but feel a smaller price tag would have made it more worth it. If i were to give it a meta critic score, i would give it a 7/10.

												Pros:- Great Combat system very fast paced, fluid and responsive I found myself amazed how fast i can react, dodge and counter-attack.- Story so far has been great about 8 hours in.- Amazing Music have not heard such great music in a game in quite awhile.- Better graphics than ps4 pro but at the same time it is one of the cons below.Cons:- Map could use some work it is easy to get lost.- Chip system is good( but not in death see below) for this type of game but again UI could be better to organize them better and not guess where they could fit in. Some early chips could use some work such as 2% move speed sounds pretty useless until you do upgrades.- DIfficulty i found normal to be good without much gear and chips but once i got a bunch game became too easy but switching to hard proved to be great but then I ended up being faced with the death issue in this game.- Death in this game is kind of like dark souls which by itself would be fine if i just lost all of my exp or money but the issue lies in losing all your chips which i spent all the 8 hours of the game collecting so i end up playing on nromal which tends to make the game too easy.- Camera angles in some situations are pretty bad especially on the side 2d view i tend to lose track of my character as it it becomes pretty small on screen and the companion looks too much the same so I end up confusing which one is me.- Graphics wise it is a pretty poor port as i end up running the game on 1440p@60 on gtx 1080 on max setting which is still a lot better than ps4 pro but most games i can run at 4k@60 with minor adjustments with better graphics than this game and the locked 60fps is really a shame as i think this game would really benefit @120fps because of the super fast action pace.Conclusion:I would really give this game a 10/10 if all of the cons were not in this initial release but for now i think it is a solid 8/10.

												I have been enjoying this game without issue thus far. The gameplay is very fun and fluid. The graphics are pretty and the soundtrack to the game is wonderful. I've been running the game in fullscreen at max settings at 1920x1080. The framerate has been at 60fps completely thoughout my experience, with several drops to 30fps at some cutscenes which I believe to be intentional. The controls on the keyboard and mouse are more than fine and better than I had anticipated. I would probably recommend trying the game on a controller to see which you prefer. I would recommend this game on the premise that you enjoy the genre. I don't know if I would recommend this purely on the story yet, as I have not completed it.CPU: i7-4770kGPU: GTX 1060 6GBOS: Windows 10

												So far, after about 6.4 hours of gameplay, this is my thinking on the game.As a whole, the game is absolutely gorgeous, great graphics, although there are some weird "artifacts" sometime, and they are not the top of the art, but the feel you get when roaming in the various places is overwhelming, so this is enough for me to count them as great, the soundtrack is perfect, great collection of music, that fits the game atmosphere perfectly, and the idea of mixing shoot'em'up and hack'n'slash is just brillant, and works flawlessly. Storywise, I've liked it so far, and the dark atmosphere of the whole universe is really well rendered.Now on the the negative points, because yes, although it is overall great, there are a couple of things to be improved.30fps locked cut scenes are a bit of a let down compared to the rest of the 60 fps rendered game, and the game fullscreen is being kinda,... capricious. Ok true, I have a 21:9 screen as main monitor and not many games are quite friendly with superwide screen ratios. So it took me a bit of fiddling with the screen res and switching windowed/fullscreen, but it is now settled to a cosy 2560x1080 fullscreen.That aside, the games run smoothly at 60fps, on a 6GB GTX 1070, with best possible graphic settings.Shortly, the game was completely worth buying for me, great gameplay, although the mix of shoot'em'up/bullet hell and hack'n'slash might not be to the taste of all, gorgeous graphics that fits the atmosphere perfectly, all that packaged with a flawless soundtrack.So if you can make-do with the little technical issues mentionned above, NieR : Automata is a game that should definetly get added to your collection.
