												TLDR:Gameplay: 10/10 it's fun, solid controls. Action packed. Great stuff.Audio: 10/10 best soundtrack of the year. The voice acting sounds good. Etc etc.Visuals: 7/10 game looks good. Nothing amazing nothing bad either.Seems like a solid game. Performance has been great. Game has been fun. I played for an hour and have to go to work. I don't want to go to work. Gah.Ok. So obviously I like the game: you guys are for some reason not buying the game and need me to tell you why to buy it. I get it, $60 is preposterous and you can't make up your own opinion in 2 hours and refund if needed so below tells you why to buy it.Gameplay: Solid control. Responsive controls. I'm using xbox1 controller by the way. These are must haves because this game is quick with loads of action. Mind you I'm playing in normal and it isn't overly hard which is great. Always my fear that these action games can be too hard and demanding which means I can't play it. (Harder modes are definitely harder, I tried haha)So aside from the great controls the actual style of gameplay is fantastic. Seamlessly going from top down shooter, side scroller/platformer third person fee camera styles and more, each style plays similar but different and I love it. Really keeps you engaged.I was playing in top down, got knocked back into a side room and the camera seamlessly follows switching perspectives. Some big robot was in there so I kick his ♥♥♥ through the door, changing perspectives and proceeding to continue my battle. It's really thrilling and needs tried not explained.Audio: English and Japanese voice acting. I tried both. Both sound good. Always a fear the English sounds incredibly cheesy and fake. The soundtracks in the game are hands down ♥♥♥♥ing awesome.Visuals: nothing fancy nothing bad. Looks better than the trailers by a good amount though. I cranked aliasing textures and postprocessing to max. Off by default. I use sli 1080 it's probably only using 1 but meh. Most games don't support sli.Performance has been great. No slowdowns. Like I mentioned I turned aliasing and other things all the way up. Looks much better than the trailers.The game is much better than wildlands and for honor and some of the other "big" games out right now. Try it for yourself. Steam refunds if you end up not liking it or if your potato can't

content:
20
												Nier Automata is a superb action game with a very interesting story that manages to bring up a load of philosophical questions without being too vague in what it has to say. But still leaving a lot for the player to think about.  The world building is really amazing and I think anyone who passes this game perhaps because they don't usually like Japanese games or RPGs is making a mistake.   The game does not require you to play the previous Nier(2010) as the story is pretty much unrelated, however if you have played it you will find a chunk of references and stuff you will recognize from it.   I think the game strikes a perfect balance with introducing elements, progressing the story and opening up the world for you. After an excellent introductory action packed section you're put in to the open world, if you're just interested in playing through the story and not do side quests or exploring running to the main objectives shouldn't take too long and you're never forced to do any tedious grinding of any kind unless you're thinking about 100% every item and side quest.   If you're playing this DO NOT STOP PLAYING AFTER ENDING A. You're not even halfway through the story at that point. I think its a bit misleading to call them "endings" as it really is more like different chapters, and the only part you are gonna be "replaying" is done from a different perspective from the first time with additional story elements revealed. After that everything will be new.   The fighting in this game is amazing, its incredibly intuitive when you're new and fun from the get go but also has a lot of depths as you discover combos or how equipping different weapons can affect how you attack, you can have two weapons equipped at a time and these weapons can change how you attack with both of them. For example equipping a heavy sword and spear you can do a cool move where you stick the spear in the ground and hold on to it then spin around it swinging the sword. Everything is really fast and fluid and since doing an action always cancels out whatever you're doing you always feel 100% in control.   Movement and dodging (or dashing?) feels wonderful to be honest. Even just running around is fun and exploring any of the areas in the game is just a blast, whether parkouring around the buildings in the city or sliding down sand dunes in the desert. Also it compliments the combat beautifully.   Beyond that you can equip different computer chips that can have varying affects. You get a certain amount of slots you can fill out, different chips take out different amount of slots. If you want to boost your damage you can fill out your slots with damage boosting chips and perhaps a couple to increase your chance of critical. If you value speed and dodging you can equip chips to boost movement and your dodging distance. Perhaps you like to go all in and go for a tanky hard headed approach, boost your damage and install a chip that will heal you X amount of what you deal out to your enemies. Combined with the different weapons you can really make something fun that you will enjoy. It's impressive how much variation you can get out of it.You also have your "pod" hovering above you which you can use to either shoot or unleash a special attack move or other function depending on what you put in it, different ones can be equipped and they all vary quite a bit with incredibly cool effects.Certain area's of the game switches up camera perspective and gamestyle. There are some parts that played with a side scrolling perspective and some where you're seeing things from a topdown perspective. These transitions are smooth as all heck and keeps the game interesting.   Overall design is beautiful both visually and the game design. The bosses are creative and fun and the many different enemy types that really keeps things interesting. Some "bullet hell" sections are just incredibly intense and really gets your heart pumping.   With that said there are some technical issues present on the pc version, however they should be fixable with mods if it hasn't been patched by the time you're reading this.   Ive probably forgotten to say most things I wanted to say about this game. But Its amazing. I usually have to force myself to finish a game, but this one I really have to force myself to stop playing instead.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
22
												This is the sort of game that comes along once a decade if we're lucky. Yoko Taro and the team at Platinum have managed to create a work of art that pushes the boundaries of narrative in a videogame. It is representative of absolute mastery of the medium.I won't delve into the story here, since I think it would be best experienced as blind as possible, but suffice it to say that I found the story compelling, nuanced, and interesting. Characters are well written and deep. There's some minor dissonance in tone from sentence to sentence and mission to mission, but overall, I can forgive those minor quibbles very easily in the face of such an ambitious story being pulled off, by and large, very well. For players who played Drakengard and NieR, there's a lot of tie ins and easter eggs and such, but it's perfectly possible to enjoy without that background.In terms of gameplay, this is a hybrid of the best of Platinum spectacle fighter, bullet hell schmup, and JRPG. The primary combat is fantastic spectacle fighting with great depth of combos, excellent responsiveness on the controls, flexibility of approach, and tons of room to gain mastery and skill. The game often limits your perspective to a certain camera angle, so sometimes it's a sidescroller or a top down beat em up, or a few other things, which further adds variety to the combat - though I did find it tough to time jump dodges in the top down perspective in the early game. I found myself kinda missing the scoring system that is often present on Platinum games as a utility for self evaluation of performance, but I can live without it given it's not primarily a combat game, and there's plenty of feedback for how you're doing in other ways, such as the Very Hard difficulty, which reduces your health to a simple one-hit-death - if you can survive there, you've mastered it. I'm still working on it, but I'll get there, and I can't wait, because this combat is super satisfying. The animations and weapon variety contribute greatly to the satisfaction to be found in this combat - everything your character does looks slick as hell, and it feels ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic to pull off a perfect kill or to wipe a boss with just a sliver of health left, or anywhere in between. Outside of combat, the gameplay consists of a semi-open overworld filled with interesting locations, gorgeous vistas, and compelling characters with many sidequests. Many of the side quests amount to little more than basic fetch quests - but I find that I didn't mind that because the combat was so compelling and I like the world, so the thin justification ("get me a pristine screw and three complex gadgets") for most of the quests were easy to ignore. As an additional form of combat, there are the flight/hacking segments, which present as a top-down shoot-em-up bullet hell game. The controls are tight, and the mechanics are clean. However, I feel like the hacking overstayed it's welcome a bit - you spend a lot of time solving the same hacking puzzles because there's not enough, and I'd like to see a little more mechanical variation. Still, it's solid and satisfying - it just doesn't match the polish of the primary combat system.The soundtrack is peerless - a true 10/10. Each track perfectly matches it's location/scene and is masterfully rendered. I'm not sure if they're digitally created or a full symphony, but either way, they did a hell of a job. Will be getting it on disc the second it's available.Unfortunately, this PC port is lackluster. As released, it has issues with setting resolution properly in fullscreen mode, and has relatively poor performance on anything but high end machines with modern graphics cards. Fortunately, enterprising community members have fixed most of these issues: Kaldaien's FAR patch and DrDaxxy's Global Illumination fix are must haves at this point. Keyboard+mouse controls are apparently also garbage, but I played on controller. Hopefully platinum releases a patch, but even if they don't it's worth fixing it yourself and playing it anyway. For what it's worth, I played it on a 4790k/980ti at 1440p and it was playable without those fixes, but they definitely helped lock the framerate. ~40 of my 50 hours (as I write this) were with the fixes, and I had no crashes or problems in that time.Overall, I cannot recommend this game enough. It has issues, to be sure - nothing is perfect - but the amount they set out to achieve here was simply immense, and they nailed 97% of it. I won't say it's for everyone, and I'm sure there's people who will ragequit the tutorial and never want more - but those people will have missed a masterpiece. And I think everyone should try it, because if it speaks to you the way it did to me, it's a borderline religious experience, a game I won't ever forget, that's made me think about things in ways I hadn't before, made me laugh, made me cry, made me actually feel something, from 'cover to cover.'To quote the great Jim Sterling on the matter, "If history forgets this game, then ♥♥♥♥ history."And I can't stop thinking about how much I want to **** 2B.

												NOTE: I AM A KEYBOARD/MOUSE PLAYER! My experience is DRASTICALLY different than those with a gamepad.EDIT#2: I bought a Controller (using an old 360 controller I found) and it's DRASTICALLY different. It is by far flawless now. Never going back. Still keeping my below post for future keyboard ventures. IF YOU WILL BUY THIS GAME AND DON'T HAVE A POTATO FOR A PC GET A CONTROL PLEASE YOU WILL LOVE ME FOR IT. DOUBLE TAP TO DODGE NEVER WORKS IN ANY GAME SINCE EVER. K i'm done back to playing Automata.Absolutely love this game. Flight missions area bit weird on keyboard but everything else is fantastic! To elaborate better; unless you lower the sensitivity to your mouse, expect to use the arrow keys for aiming. While this isn't much of an issue, I, personally, feel awkward using heavy attacks on \ key.FOR ME (as I am aware there's a lot of steam kids with potato computers crying No to recommendations), I have absolutely zero issues with this game loading and playing. I play max graphics, a MSI GTX 970 Graphics card i've had for years and have no had issues.I've even streamed my first four hours on twitch and it was smooth as silk. So I do not agree with everyone's negative vote when we were well informed about the things at hand.I DO feel there is a bug (or rather lack thereof) of a true Full screen mode. You can get full screen, but if you ever tab out you'll go right back to windows. For me, that is an issue mainly because I have to tab out to reply to viewers as well as my NeiR/Drakengard Discord and various messages on Skype. I would love for that to just stay in place. That'd be awesome.I do not like double taps to dodge. I never have in any mmo since ever. I much prefer the choice of hitting a key and pushing a direction in order to dodge in a direction. It's far more responsive and effective whereas double tap universally does not regester all the time.ALL IN ALL; This game is still great. Combat is fresh and fast and hold a challanging aspect to it that keeps my interest. I am a diehard Drakengard/NieR fan since 2003 so OF COURSE I am going to be extremely bias. I am use to much worse in a game I love (serious. Go play Drakengard 1 and then tell me NieR has loads of issues. This is gold in comparison.)10/10 would NieR again. Despite minor issues from me, I still love this game and will continue to push towards 100%, sacrifice my data, engage with my fandom in my discord and continue to play. To the people who are downvoting PURELY because they're crying about their horrible FPS, please. Do yourself a favor and buy a new graphics card before you ♥♥♥♥ on a game. It's your fault you have a potato. That is all.

content:

												NieR: Automata, where to begin. This game is a love child born between Yoko Taro's genius storytelling and the slick and refined action of Platinum Games (Bayonetta, Metal Gear Rising).Having already spent 50+ hours on the PS4 version and experienced all the endings; it is an incredible game, a masterpiece in fact. This is Yoko Taro's best game as of yet, and I am happy to re-purchase to support this game even more, as it deserves all the sales it can get. This is probably a game I will play from start to finish, time and time again.Although an entry to the Drakengard/Nier franchise, this game is completely enjoyable without any knowledge of previous entries to the series, although fans of Yoko Taro's games will be rewarded. It is so nice to finally see a game from this franchise on PC, and there is talk of a Drakengard collection to follow (if Square Enix funds it).Automata combines slick and satisfying combat with a distinctly unique and gripping narrative. This is coupled with intriguing open world to explore and one of the best game soundtracks of all time. My only words of advice is that to experience this game in its entirety, you must play new game+. Unlike other titles; new game+ is woven into the core of this game. After rushing through the initial campaign in little over 10 hours, I was quite shocked at an abrupt ending. Little did I know this was merely a prologue of what was to come.Yoko Taro uses the gaming medium to its fullest potential, delivering a storytelling experience which is strikingly unique, and will blow your mind.Lastly, give it time; this one gets better the more you play.Story 10/10Graphics 8/10Gameplay 9/10Soundtrack 10/10Overall 10/10TL;DROne of/if not favourite game of all time;You're in for a ride.

content:

												A Nier game from Platinum? After playing this on the PS4 and then moving onto the PC, I guess I'm a skeleton trapped onto the Yoko Taro Wild Ride.The Good:- Characterisation. 2b and 9s are relatively charming along with the supporting cast. The enemies while repetitive and robotic clones of each other have their many quirks.- Combat. Infinitely better than the predecessor because Platinum know how to do combat. And Fishing. And the other side jobs.- The mechanics. Majority Action RPG, part platformer and shoot 'em up. The blend works.- That soundtrack. It helps to set the feelings trip up.- The previous game has no real hold over this one so it's easy to pick up and just play.The Bad:- The open world. So much of it is walled off and quite damn bland which is a shame. Lush areas are met with general buildings and environments that look the damn same. - Resolution and optimisation. I'm running the game on recommended spec and am experiencing frame rate loss. Could just be a driver issue but I've seen the complaints about 4k and Radeon optimisation. Hopefully it'll get quashed now it's in world.-Denuvo. Just no.The mixed.- Complete Emotional Rollercoaster. It helps to be either an emotional masochist or emotionless robot on a Yoko Taro game.- The timesink. It's real in this game and in a way part of the charm that sticks around from the first game. Endlessly replayable and if you're a casual gamer you're not going to get too much out of it from playing a little. Like Police Squad got cancelled, this is one that requires your attention if you want to get invested into it.In Summary.Former Radio 1 DJ John Peel used to operate a five star rating system and he took it to beyond 25 stars for his beloved song by the Undertones, Teenage Kicks. Do I recommend it? Yes. Yes. Emphatically like a Daniel Bryan chant.

If i were to give it a meta critic score, i would give it a 7/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
23
												Wow...This game has left me breathless.I can't remember last time a game impressed me this much. I've been amazed and immersed on a completely different level than what I'd ever anticipate. Everything from the smooth, flowing combat and the deep, emotional - and also a bit weird - story to the fantastic musical score which apparently is made in a completely unique language solely made for the NieR universe. If that isn't just an amazing level of commitment and hard work then I don't know what is.Boss battles with several, widely varied phases which has to gripped tight in suspense all the time, hordes of minions to satisfyingly hack and slash through has had me more immersed than I'd ever hoped to be, and I was very excited for this game! It certainly hasn't disappointed, contrary to recent trend. I guess the only complaint I'd have is that many of the fights are very long, and in several phases, and there aren't any autosaves inbetween, so if you're playing on Hard or Very Hard it can be frustrating having to redo such long segments if you mess up.-Story-Storywise I'd say that there are some bits that you'd have much greater understanding of and that would give you much more enjoyment if you've experienced the prior games in the Drakengard/NieR series. Nothing gamebreaking, but you'd certainly miss out on the complete experience if you're going into this game without any prior knowledge of its universe and history.-Graphics-Many complain about this game having very high requirements in order to play at the highest graphic settings, and I have to agree that there has been a couple of hick-ups even on my GTX1060. Not many, as I've been able to play through the game almost consistently at 60 fps with everything maxed out. The graphics aren't the greatest in comparison to other high-end games like this, they're not the worst either. I'd compare them maybe to the new Hitman game but with a bit more desaturated color scheme. However, t even looks good in nVidia 3D vision, even if there are quite some shadow artifacts and other bugs. However, the community is working on 3D patches already, so hopefully a smooth 3D experience isn't far away.-Music-Once again...wow. Many times I just revisit zones to listen to the music. The soundtrack to this game is fantastic! It's a really enjoyable surprise that even the language is made specifically for these games which adds another dimension of amazement to something already very enjoyable! I think I've so far spent the most time in the Bunker. That music is just so soothing and peaceful. Once again I have to say that there are quite some references to earlier games even among the musical scores which will be even more enjoyable if you've gone through the predecessor games.-Combat-Flashy combos all day every day! That's pretty much the majority of it. The ability to combine different weapon types in various constellations as well as switching between two custom made weapon sets on the go really makes for some amazingly satisfying combos and attacks. Paired up with the pods various attack modes and programs makes the whole experience breathtaking. The major downside would be the camera in my opinion. It can be a bit finnicky, at least when playing with a controller, and often pan around or do things on its own which can often lead to obstructed views when you're in the heat of battle. I gave up locking onto enemies quite early since it more often than not would mess around with my camera and be more in the way than helpfull.I've played quite a few hack and slash games in my time and the feeling of smoothness of the combat here was very reminiscent of such pure action games. But not only that, you've also got your top-down spaceshooter and elements of bullet hell/touhou games, and it all just flows together in a smooth way that doesn't feel like an abrupt hindrance of your combat pace but rather a natural step over to the next phase of the fight. It's just amazing.-Difficulty-Many talk about platinum games generally being quite difficult, I don't get that reference. However, I have tried the Normal, Hard and Very Hard difficulties and I have to say that there's a huge gap from Normal to Hard. I don't know if it's heavily reliant on you keeping up with leveling between story quests or grinding to be in phase with the story quest difficulty, but Normal always felt very easy. The enemies do barely any damage, only the bosses does significant amounts of damage, which is easy mitigated with the right chip loadouts. Then we get to Hard. You do somewhat less damage to enemies, either that or they just have higher defenses, but they do truckloads of more damage to you. Very Hard is supposed to be a one-shot mode, that you can't even take one, single hit without dying, but many times Hard has been essentially the same as many attacks still one-shots you on that difficulty. I remember one, specific fight where the enemy projectiles did around 80% of my HP in damage, and they staggered me for a short while as well, so taking 1 projectile almost always meant taking another one, which essentially leads to a one-shot kill.It was quite annoying as I wanted a difficulty somewhere between Normal and Hard to get the most appropriate challenge for my skill level.However, in the post-game, when you've perfected yourself, even Very Hard isn't so daunting. But when on your first playthrough through the main game, it's quite the challenge!Man...what a great game.

content:

												Just finished the game, got the endings A K W from 1 play through. Apparently multiple routes you can take, I think A is probably best ending but still leaves many answers unanswered. The design and everything is generally very engaging and definately will entice you to replay the game multiple times for different endings! The characters (especially 2B) is really likable from my experience. The music is simply outstanding. The artstyle is very unique and lovely, as long as you are okay with most of the game being in a ruined city greyish (there are 3 sections with different themes that I encountered so far from 1 play through).For my more technical thoughts see below.This game is pretty awesome, however if you do not have a controller don't expect to enjoy it as much with Mouse and Keyboard. You cannot dodge the same way you can with a controller with KB+M due to no dedicated button for evasion. Also the visuals on wide screen is kind of strange during cutscenes (probably stretched slightly or something), and there aren't many graphical customizations other than low medium and high. If you do not meet the minimum requirements for the specs you may find quite a few problems with the fps according to the community.Required:Specs to meet the game min.Controller for more enjoyment.Borderless gaming program for best resolution + borderless full screenPro:Game play is quite funVisuals is beautiful if not hindered by some glitches with the resolution at times switching to 720p for no reason. (Only in full screen.)Has Japanese voice/ English voice. Japanese voice is far superior (and the protagonist simply has a very likeable Jap voice)Cons:M+KB doesn't play that well in certain views (game switches from FPS/TPS/Top down/ many other)Cannot rebind evasion, cannot make Shift a toggle for shootingSome glitches and bugs (will probably be ironed out by the community)Cinematics are low fps and sometimes sutter for me (even though I have really high spec pc, however I use a 3440x1440 monitor)No borderless fullscreen. If you minimize at times you might be stuck with a mouse cursor on the screen so you need to save and restart the game to get rid of it... However there is no autosave. And you must find save points. Not to mention sometimes after minimizing your game is stuck in window mode. And if you are stuck in a cutscene you cannot change it back to full screen until you regain control of the game. Well you are stuck with watching those emotional/beautiful cutscenes in windowed mode with stutter and a mouse cursor in the middle if that happens to you (happened to me), unless you want to replay the whole section, since there is no auto save... (this can all be fixed by borderless gaming)

content:
17
												NOTE: I AM A KEYBOARD/MOUSE PLAYER! My experience is DRASTICALLY different than those with a gamepad.EDIT#2: I bought a Controller (using an old 360 controller I found) and it's DRASTICALLY different. It is by far flawless now. Never going back. Still keeping my below post for future keyboard ventures. IF YOU WILL BUY THIS GAME AND DON'T HAVE A POTATO FOR A PC GET A CONTROL PLEASE YOU WILL LOVE ME FOR IT. DOUBLE TAP TO DODGE NEVER WORKS IN ANY GAME SINCE EVER. K i'm done back to playing Automata.Absolutely love this game. Flight missions area bit weird on keyboard but everything else is fantastic! To elaborate better; unless you lower the sensitivity to your mouse, expect to use the arrow keys for aiming. While this isn't much of an issue, I, personally, feel awkward using heavy attacks on \ key.FOR ME (as I am aware there's a lot of steam kids with potato computers crying No to recommendations), I have absolutely zero issues with this game loading and playing. I play max graphics, a MSI GTX 970 Graphics card i've had for years and have no had issues.I've even streamed my first four hours on twitch and it was smooth as silk. So I do not agree with everyone's negative vote when we were well informed about the things at hand.I DO feel there is a bug (or rather lack thereof) of a true Full screen mode. You can get full screen, but if you ever tab out you'll go right back to windows. For me, that is an issue mainly because I have to tab out to reply to viewers as well as my NeiR/Drakengard Discord and various messages on Skype. I would love for that to just stay in place. That'd be awesome.I do not like double taps to dodge. I never have in any mmo since ever. I much prefer the choice of hitting a key and pushing a direction in order to dodge in a direction. It's far more responsive and effective whereas double tap universally does not regester all the time.ALL IN ALL; This game is still great. Combat is fresh and fast and hold a challanging aspect to it that keeps my interest. I am a diehard Drakengard/NieR fan since 2003 so OF COURSE I am going to be extremely bias. I am use to much worse in a game I love (serious. Go play Drakengard 1 and then tell me NieR has loads of issues. This is gold in comparison.)10/10 would NieR again. Despite minor issues from me, I still love this game and will continue to push towards 100%, sacrifice my data, engage with my fandom in my discord and continue to play. To the people who are downvoting PURELY because they're crying about their horrible FPS, please. Do yourself a favor and buy a new graphics card before you ♥♥♥♥ on a game. It's your fault you have a potato. That is all.

												This is a review from about 10 hour into the game. Tldr; I reccomend this and rate it a 7/10. The best part of this game is the main characters;  they have the best models and their dialogue is very character defining. They stand out in this game and I find that important in a game that:looks like its many years dated in graphics and whoes side missions and story are very mediocre so far. the combat is a feels great, looks deep and hard kind of system that really doesn't utilize that too much. the skills you get will greatly alter how combat is defined and experience and while it is awesome once you look at it this was not the game I was hoping for, basically something sorta like dark souls. There is a lot of myustery that tugs on many gamers penchant to hold back in item usage but it really doesn't matter at all. I say this for normal mode only where it is still easy to die but only if you dont pay attention... otherwise when you get used to dodging it becomes a much easier game to win with.That said, I do still find the sombat enjoyable and the bland environments are at least interesting enough for me to find interest in exporation. The story is a bit intrigueing but definitely not unique on the slightest sense so far (if you are into sci fi genere works) and there are tales of having to play this game multiple times to find out what is actually going on in the story. Overall I rate this a 7/10 because it doesn't do anything poorly but doesn't seem to excell in any sort of area besides main character immersion.

												13 hours played, ~4 year old PC upgraded with a GTX 970. Playing with an XBox 360 controller (worked out of the gate). The only technical issue I ran into was the fullscreen resolution bug, worked around it with windowed mode + Borderless Gaming. Since then everything works flawlessly, excellent framerate (there is the odd 2 second hitch when it loads in new areas). Very good about loading times.Gameplay is a joy to play for the most part. The camera and auto-aim fail at times and some of the finer points of the game's rules are seemingly left for the player to figure out through trial and error. Playing on normal the game is too easy but does feature the odd sudden difficulty spike.What takes it from good fun to remarkable are the setting, melodrama, comedy and weirdness. So far the story has been rather straight forward but I've not yet completed the first ending, so looking forward to more.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
20
												Nier Automata is a superb action game with a very interesting story that manages to bring up a load of philosophical questions without being too vague in what it has to say. But still leaving a lot for the player to think about.  The world building is really amazing and I think anyone who passes this game perhaps because they don't usually like Japanese games or RPGs is making a mistake.   The game does not require you to play the previous Nier(2010) as the story is pretty much unrelated, however if you have played it you will find a chunk of references and stuff you will recognize from it.   I think the game strikes a perfect balance with introducing elements, progressing the story and opening up the world for you. After an excellent introductory action packed section you're put in to the open world, if you're just interested in playing through the story and not do side quests or exploring running to the main objectives shouldn't take too long and you're never forced to do any tedious grinding of any kind unless you're thinking about 100% every item and side quest.   If you're playing this DO NOT STOP PLAYING AFTER ENDING A. You're not even halfway through the story at that point. I think its a bit misleading to call them "endings" as it really is more like different chapters, and the only part you are gonna be "replaying" is done from a different perspective from the first time with additional story elements revealed. After that everything will be new.   The fighting in this game is amazing, its incredibly intuitive when you're new and fun from the get go but also has a lot of depths as you discover combos or how equipping different weapons can affect how you attack, you can have two weapons equipped at a time and these weapons can change how you attack with both of them. For example equipping a heavy sword and spear you can do a cool move where you stick the spear in the ground and hold on to it then spin around it swinging the sword. Everything is really fast and fluid and since doing an action always cancels out whatever you're doing you always feel 100% in control.   Movement and dodging (or dashing?) feels wonderful to be honest. Even just running around is fun and exploring any of the areas in the game is just a blast, whether parkouring around the buildings in the city or sliding down sand dunes in the desert. Also it compliments the combat beautifully.   Beyond that you can equip different computer chips that can have varying affects. You get a certain amount of slots you can fill out, different chips take out different amount of slots. If you want to boost your damage you can fill out your slots with damage boosting chips and perhaps a couple to increase your chance of critical. If you value speed and dodging you can equip chips to boost movement and your dodging distance. Perhaps you like to go all in and go for a tanky hard headed approach, boost your damage and install a chip that will heal you X amount of what you deal out to your enemies. Combined with the different weapons you can really make something fun that you will enjoy. It's impressive how much variation you can get out of it.You also have your "pod" hovering above you which you can use to either shoot or unleash a special attack move or other function depending on what you put in it, different ones can be equipped and they all vary quite a bit with incredibly cool effects.Certain area's of the game switches up camera perspective and gamestyle. There are some parts that played with a side scrolling perspective and some where you're seeing things from a topdown perspective. These transitions are smooth as all heck and keeps the game interesting.   Overall design is beautiful both visually and the game design. The bosses are creative and fun and the many different enemy types that really keeps things interesting. Some "bullet hell" sections are just incredibly intense and really gets your heart pumping.   With that said there are some technical issues present on the pc version, however they should be fixable with mods if it hasn't been patched by the time you're reading this.   Ive probably forgotten to say most things I wanted to say about this game. But Its amazing. I usually have to force myself to finish a game, but this one I really have to force myself to stop playing instead.

content:

												It's not even the second half of this year, and I think we've already got the GOTY 2017 on our hands. Amazing, memorable soundtrack composed by Keiichi Okabe, amazing story filled with bittersweet sidequests and 26 endings (5 of which are major) written and directed by Yoko Taro, sensitive and fluid combat crafted by Platinum Games, the team whose combat work can be seen behind the likes of Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance and whose respect for NieR can be seen in this very title.The PC port is kind of questionable, however Kaldaien's FAR (Fix Automata Resolution) will help overcome its limitations. (You can turn down global illumination to improve performance with little to no difference in visual quality; as well as increase the quality of godrays and bloom with the included fix by Durante) The former has compatibility for graphics injectors like ReShade which will help if you're not a fan of the game's grayish colors and want some vibrance to them. I personally used the Cinematic ReShade. For that to work with the former, I had to rename its dxgi as ReShade64 and ensured the paths the mod looks for the presets from match mine.Using a controller is highly recommended. If you're like me and you end up using Sony's DualShock 4, you might want to get the DS4 Button Prompts -mod whose ui -folder you'll place within the game's data -folder. While there's no official support for DualShock 4, you can utilize Steam Controller Configurator for it (if you don't like Big Picture Mode, just disable it from under [Steam > Settings > In-Game]), or get some unofficial third party programs like DS4Windows to do the job for you.Most port stuff can be looked up here though, including workarounds for the 60 FPS cap for example: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Nier:_AutomataI ended up having one crash out of the 53 hours I placed in this title. Framerate was mostly 60, with dips to 45-60 in the most vegetated areas. I'm on i5-2500K, GTX 970 (using WHQL 378.66 -driver), 16 GB of RAM.This game has a demo on PS4, so if you happen to own one of those, you should give it a spin and see if it's to your liking. The game doesn't emphasize enough how important it is for you to replay the game: ending A is only the beginning; ending E is something special for you to experience.

												It saddens me to write this review. I loved Nier and played the Demo for Nier Automata on the PS 4 and everything looked great and promising. It was one of the only games I bought close to its release in the last few years. I learned my "never pre-order"-lessons pretty well.  Sadly I now own a game I paid lots of money for and I can't play it because I have a critical common issue (white screen) and can't even get to the first checkpoint. My only two options are to downgrade my driver to a very old version which will cause other problems in other games or wait for the developers of the game to fix this common problem which affects graphics cards of both popular factories (even if the ratio is a bit different between them).Well, this is the first time I saw a developer having a GREAT launch of the game with a major incident like this and no patch in 20 days. Not even an experimental one or beta one. It is heartbreaking to say, but I feel very close to dropping this game, which is considered art by many, from my "most hyped game in ages"-list to my huge backlog of games and therefore might never touch it again.And the only way to express this to the devs is not by a refund as this will remove my rating here and not influence the score anymore thanks to Valves latest change to how reviews work if you refunded a game.I hope I can change this review in the future to a positive one. But I am not very optimistic anymore.

												For once, this is a Yoko Taro game I actually wanted to replay to get different endings. It's a really great sequel to the original NieR, but even if you haven't played that, this game still holds up well on its own.Music is great, setting and story are interesting. I honestly can't think of anything "bad" to say; not everything is perfect of course, for example the combat, while fast and fluid, is a bit shallow and spammy, and upgrading your weapons and using damage-boosting chips/items makes you stupidly OP. Some of the side quests are generic "go here, then here" or "kill x enemies in this location" or even the dreaded escort mission (where you can friendly-fire your client). But most of the side quests helped flesh out the world and characters a bit more. Also each run of the game is relatively short, but there is cool new stuff leading to each different ending. The characters have potential to be more fleshed-out but that doesn't really happen until at least the second playthrough, so until then they're sort of "ehh". The environments were pretty but somewhat lacked detail, there's not really much going on in them. But all this is basically nit-picking, I just wanted to present a more balanced view. One thing I did like was that, although most of the enemies you fight are machines, they have lots of variations and different abilities to make it a bit more interesting.tl;dr it's not "OMG EPIC AMAZING" but it's highly enjoyable, both for Taro fans and newcomers, and has lots of replayability and new stuff constantly being unveiled.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
29
												Might be one of the best games I've ever played. Literally everything about the game itself is pretty good at WORST. The game throws you into an incredibly rich and thought provoking world but still never lets you feel out of your depth if it's your first game in the series as it was mine. Prior story knowledge enhances the experience but is not requred, the right way to do a sequel of this kind. The themes this game deals with in its story are some that are not usually approached in such detail by video games of this scale.  I would assume that's because examining the rights of artificial life, humanity's predisposition for self destruction and trying to fathom why things are, can get really, really depressing.  And this game does get very depressing, but I would chalk that up as a gigantic positive that a game engaged me on that emotional level. The best thing though is that Nier: Automata doesn't just ask the hard existential questions, if you play through the whole of the 5 main endings it offers some pretty compelling food for thought in terms of possible answers too.  The game also presents dilemmas to you in ways that you may not expect.  Basic "choices" you make when playing any game, such as simply attacking an enemy, are given significantly more weight when you have the proper context applied. Each of the main characters in the story and several of the supporting ones also undergo a sometimes short but distinct arc which is a breath of fresh air coming off of some more recent RPGs where the main character basically learns that you have to be responsible, the supporting cast never change and that's it *cough*FFXV*cough*.  It took just the right moves to get me invested in just about every important character in the game.The soundtrack is sublime. Start to finish the music is a powerful, subtle joy to hear. Some great soundtracks just steal the show so all you think about after is the music; personally I thought it just felt like every single song was more a great accompaniment to whatever moment it was layed gently on top of.  The combat wasn't as complex as I'd have liked.  I would have much preferred a little more depth to combo/defensive systems such as in Bayonetta, but it was still incredibly fun, responsive and visceral.  Even the shmup sections were a lot of fun.  Almost all of them struck the correct balance between challenge and frustration, and on top of that they never outstayed their welcome. I don't think people give the level design enough credit either.  I personally found the open world in this game maybe one of the best in recent years.  It is subject to changes, sometimes minor, sometimes major, it has a large variety of settings with different enemies, music and a lot of the time playstyles and towards the end of the game I was still finding new areas I hadn't been in before and little tucked away secrets. The "collectibles" are also very rewarding.  Hacking open a chest is almost never a waste of time.  You can get anything from a report detailing important and well written lore or a new weapon to test out.  Aside from a few weird technical issues where the game would randomly lose focus on my PC to nothing at all on my 2nd monitor, the mouse not being locked to the screen in game and it popping itself back into windowed mode every time I Alt+Tabbed the port was pretty solid in terms of framerate etc.  The graphical fidelity is the one area where I wasn't simply blown away.  I mean the game aesthetically looks amazing, but in terms of texture quality and graphical effects it's not very impressive at all. On several occasions usually when a character is silhouetted against a bright light, they turn into an 8-bit version of themselves and transform into blocks around the edges.That's easily overlooked in favour of the numerous other plus points though. A must play for anybody who enjoys Platinum combat, likes actually thinking while playing a game or if you just want to experience some of Yoko Taro's own brand of insanity.

Having bought Nier:Automata recently, with no prior experience with this game's cre[A]tor or even games from a similar [B]ackground, I feel urged to write a review just for personal [C]losure.Before I start, let me get one thing out of the way: This game is not ashame[D] of it's cultural background - in fact, it openly [E]ndorses it. If you did not come in contact with japanese RPGs be[F]ore, you will have to accept one thin[G] - the game may very well weird you out at times. If you learn to love that (or already did) - excellent. If you can accept it - also good. If you can at least ignore what might bot[H]er you in[I]tially - just as fine. You may [J]ust learn to like something entirely new. Or you might not, in which case - I won't judge, but your loss - or not ;) [K]nowing this, if you are sti[L]l interested, you [M]ay just be in for an experie[N]ce that can only be described as wonderfully unique in every way, shape or f[O]rm. The game is not perfect by a far margin, yet easily takes the cake as the #1 single[P]layer game I have touched in the last years, and this is not due to something specific - the general composition, the final product, is what makes this game both uni[Q]ue and amazing in a way I have never seen befo[R]e.The combat is ea[S]ily one of the most attractive fea[T]ures to new players - it is extremely rewarding, fluid, fast-paced and multi-faceted (and to know what I mean with the last part, yo[U] need to play through the game *several times*). Speaking of which - this game handles multiple endings [V]ery differently than most RPGs you might kno[W]. In fact, not only the endings, but the entire game mechanics transcend the barrier between player and game in ways you might not have ever seen before (especially if you did not play related games). This will only gradually reveal to you as you continue to play the same(!) savegame, and it manages the journey from something initially appearing as generic (maybe even "cringey" to use a horrible wording sometimes found on the internet to describe unknown territory) to something truly e[X]traordinary in every way, shape or form, ultimately ending in an experience that can best be described as thoroughl[Y] "meta" and astonishingly memorable. By the time I had achieved the last unlockable ending and watched myself [Z]oom by the credits (you will eventually understand what I mean and before you do you have not truly finished the game!), what had started out as a low expectations test run of my first JRPG for a long time ended up with a permanent place in my personal hall of fame of the best games ever made.10/10 - NOT an "AAA title" - NOT for everyone - does contain minor flaws - but if it is for you (even if you don't know it yet), you do not want to miss out on this masterpiece. Any rating below 10 would (for me personally) not do it justice, given that I was blown away by Yoko Taro, not having played any of his games before (or even knowing he existed). This man is a genius, and his product shows.

content:

												Let me first be clear that NieR: Automata is a flawed game. It suffers from technical and design problem, some of which are quite severe; however it also gets so many things right that I'm willing to overcome the negative aspects of the game and still enjoy it.Pros: The combat system is awesome. It is smooth and responsive, you play as a very powerful character (with fantastically stylish animations too) yet not so much as to be blatantly overpowered, so being good at the game is still rewarding. To break it down to its bare minimum, it is a system about dodging and attacking, rinse and repeat; therefore it is relatively easy to be decent at this combat system. But there is actually a lot of depth hidden beneath, and the skill ceiling is extremely high as a result (you can actually juggle enemies if you are good enough). As a result it is more akin to Devil May Cry than it is to previous Platinum titles (although some of the animations are clearly inspired by Raiden). The story is serviceable and requires multiple playthroughs to be fully understood (3, to be exact). For the first playthrough it is a mostly non-cerebral plot about good guys and bad guys, but most of the story is reserved for further playthroughs. There are lots of dialogues and cutscenes added in each playthrough, and the gameplay mechanics are also drastically changed. The characters are also decent. At first I thought the protagonists resemble Lightning and Hope, but that is thankfully not true. For those that didn't play FF13 (good for you), that means the protagonists are likable and not bags of ♥♥♥♥♥♥. The villains on the other hand tend to spout philosophy about existentialism, which should be cringe worthy, but the voice over is good enough and it makes sense thematically that it works. Although they sadly don't have such classic one liners as "nanomachines son". (who is a character in the game, honest) The world is very intriguing and reminds me of Wall-E and 40K (I thought I would never put those 2 in the same sentence). It is a world where there is only war: after an alien invasion humanity abandoned the Earth and constructed androids to fight the alien's machine lifeforms, and the fight continued for a whole 6000 years. In the meantime humans have become something of a legend in this world, and it is fascinating and hilarious in equal measures to see characters study mundane facts of our lives and be thoroughly bewildered by them. Calling the music of NieR good would be an understatement. The tracks are all beautiful in their own rights, and the vocal by Emi Evans only makes it better. Also pretty much every track in the game has an 8-bit remix version. The camera perspective changes are interesting. Sometimes the game turns into a side scroller or a top down game. They do introduce problems of their own, however, such as difficulty interacting with things in side scroll perspective. The level designs encourage exploration. With the exception of one mission the entire game takes place on a world map, and different areas are connected with hidden passages. The size of the map isn't exactly massive when compared to some of the open world games, but it's still decent. Items are placed all over the map, and some are very tricky to get to. It sometimes take advantage of the 2D perspective as well: in the prologue for instance [spoiler alert]there is a part where you walk on a railing in 2D, which seems like there are only 2 directions you can move in, but there's actually a hidden path that requires you to walk toward the camera. It was one of the coolest secrets I have found in a long time. The aesthetics is intentionally drab, but it fits the omnious atmosphere, and serves to make the more colorful parts stand out even more.Cons: The PC port isn't great. The performance is mediocre, frame drops are somewhat common, and resolutions higher than 1080p are hugely demanding on the hardware. The resolution itself is also bugged and can be fixed with a mod on the forum. All cutscenes are also locked at 30fps. Moreover, some textures are awful looking (especially on walls), distant object pop-in is an issue, I have also encountered more crashes than I'd like (at least 4 in my playtime). Healing items are extremely overpowered. These can be bought from venders, are extremely cheap, and you can carry 99 of each type so running out of healing items should not be an issue. However they also are consumed instantaneously, so spamming healing is an easy way of overcoming the enemies. The caveat here is that using items require a few button presses, but once you get used to it it can be done in no time (or you can just pause and use it in the inventory). As if that wasn't enough there are many more passive bonuses that provide even more healing, so by the end I wasn't even using healing item much in all but boss fights. It does a poor job of explaining certain mechanics. There is no tutorial on some of the more advanced moves; and also some of the item descriptions are cryptic for no reason, example: down attack up. What exactly is a down attack is never explained. The sidequests are mechanically repetitive and boring. They are limited to escort someone, kill something, go to a place and interact with/pick up something, the obligatory racing minigame, etc. They also tend to need you to travel far and wide to complete the objective, often from one side of the map to another (there is fast travel). Thankfully they are thematically interesting and sometimes have decent stories attached to keep me engaged. Escorting a random NPC is one thing; escorting a machine wearing a ribbon that thinks it is a teenage girl is quite another. There is a Dark-Souls-like system where you need to get to your corpse after you die, and if you die twice in a roll you lose some of your stuff. But because of the lack of auto save this consequence is never permanent since you can just savescum. While the overall story is pretty good, the same cannot be said about the individual lines, as some are cringe inducing. During the 2D segments there are lots of invisible walls. The companion's pathing AI is incredible poor and will keep running into walls constantly. Not a big deal as they are still helpful in combat but it's still immersion breaking. The difficulty levels are also not well balanced in the early game. While on normal you are very resilient to damage, on hard even trash mobs can kill you in one or two hits, since hard enemies do more than 5 times as much damage as normal enemies. Later however you become so overpowered that even hard becomes much less intimidating though, which serves as a nice consolation.

content:
4
												So everyone really, really likes NieR: Automata. The only negative reviews I see on Steam are because of the problems with the PC port or just people giving up after a couple of hours for whatever reason. I played this game through to the end, all 5 important endings (ABCDE), so I've given this game its fair shake. I still don't like it and I can't really understand why others do like it. I understand the themes it was going for and admittedly those themes are interesting. However, I think the game fell flat in its execution. First off I could not care less about any of the characters. None of the tear jerking moments caused any emotion in me. Now, you might think I'm a heartless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or a psychopath, but that's not the case. I just felt like the characters and their relationships were never really fleshed out. I still feel like I don't know a whole lot about 2B, 9S and A2 (apart from 9S liking 2B). Most of the cast don't have any real personal motivation for what they do in the story (again with the exception of 9S). It is, at best, vaguely hinted at in the main story. Maybe a lot of this is hidden in away in text entries, but I don't spend hours reading that stuff. But, if important things like character motivations are hidden away in text form, then that's just bad storytelling, in my opinion. Add on top of all this death has no real consequences for reasons explained in the story, and any semblance of my personal investment in the characters or what happens to them just disappears compeletely.Second off, I absolutely HATED my second playthrough. Barely anything changed content-wise, which leads to a 6-hour slog through a portion of story I've played already. The game drip feeds you some tiny droplets of story, but it wasn't anywhere near enough to keep me interested. ALso, 9S's hacking minigame got extremely stale after doing it for the umpteenth time. The gameplay overall is fairly shallow. The spectacle fighting has less going on than, say, God of War or Bayonetta with less moves than either of them. I enjoyed it during my first playthrough, but after those 10ish hours, I'd had enough. The bullet hell gameplay is much worse and just straight up boring to me. If you hold down the square & R1 button on a PS3 controller and move around a bit, you'll usually be fine.Also, side quests are Dragon Age: Inquisition levels of bad: fetch quests galore. I stopped doing them after the fifth one had me walking 10 minutes to go collect 5 more bear's asses with barely any story and no voice over to make up for it.Finally, I felt the overall story was poorly patched together with important plot points being glossed over and hardly explained. I asked myself multiple times why or how a particular event was happening and could not come up with a satisfying answer. Again, I didn't spend too much time reading the text entries. I'm sure many people will tell me I didn't get it and they may well be right. I'm definitely eager to watch some deeper analysis videos on this game. I might come to appreciate the game more in time.PS: I should add the caveat that I haven't played many JRPGs and no Yoko Taro games before this one. The ones I did play, I didn't really enjoy. If you are a fan of that particular genre or of Yoko Taro, this may well be right up your alley.

												TL;DR :  Wait for it to be patched, there are issues for many people across each major graphics card manufacturer and across the spectrum of PCs with low mid and high range hardware.  Initial Review on release 3/17/18 (To be updated in the near future)Pros:Gorgeous visualsFun and varied gameplayFantastic soundtrackSexy protagonistPretty Good performance with a mid to high end rigCons:Hack & Slash heavy which may bore some30fps cap on cutscenes that tend to drop below 30fpsPerformance issues Fullscreen causes performance issuesFullscreen only renders at 900p and upscales for 1080p and aboveConfiguration settings for display, cameras, and controller can suddenly revert for no reasonNetworking integration has been blamed for stuttering on otherwise capable systemsSome graphics cards are overloaded at 100% utilization due to game codeGame is capped at 60fps due to the method of timing for events used in the codeMy rig is a water cooled i7 4790k, samsung SSDs, 16GB DDR3, and a 1060GTX w/ 6GB ram.  I run games such as DOOM, GTA V, and Rise of the Tomb Raider with all settings maxed out at 1080p with nearly perfect 60fps.  NieR: Automata runs in the 50's with nearly constant stuttering at 1080p with AA disabled, blur disabled, windowed mode enabled, and all other settings maxed.  The stuttering causes noticeable hitches and screen tearing that take away from the experience.  This card is easily capable of smoother experiences in other games.  With Fullscreen enabled, the frame rate dips into the 30's with the same settings and that's just ridiculous.This game is in need of some optimization, but by no means is this a mess like the recent Batman bomb.  If you're going to pay $60 for a game, the experience should be better optimized than this.  Even considering that it is a port, it's still not a great port.  As such, I simply can't recommend the game in its current state.  The various issues need to be resolved.  If that happens, I'll gladly recommend it.

content:
20
												Don't even try to play this game above normal difficulty with mouse and keyboard.... A potentially great game ruined by some of the worst controls I've seen since the original Dark Souls port.Using the dodge is one of the fundamental keystones to actually playing the game well, but when the game eats your inputs, you end up getting destroyed by things you absolutely saw coming. Things you absolutely reacted to. Things you should not be getting hit by. Dodge is bound to double-tapping your directional movement key, and is locked to that same key. You cannot, for instance, hold shift and tap a directional key or something along those lines. This becomes a hue problem to enjoying the game, since without the ability to dodge in and out of enemies to use your melee attacks, you end up slowly walking backwards while using your ranged attacks to slowly whittle them down. A lot of the potentially fun gameplay is lost.Enhancements are a pain in the ♥♥♥ to use. These things grant tiny bonuses, lasting 15-30 seconds each (with enormous benefits, mind you), but you have to pause the game every single time you want to try and use them for a small portion of a single boss fight, tab through menus, get to the correct ones you wish to use, and then go down the list to reapply them. You end up spending more time trying to apply the buffs you receive, than actually using said buffs. Using them completely destroys any prospect you have of enjoying the difficult fights (and you will need to use them, as half your dodges are eaten by your keyboard inputs).Also, since you can't open the menu to actually find the enhancements until you are completely standing still on the ground, you have to deal with pausing and unpausing over and over again until you can finally open the menu. I wouldn't care about this as much, if you could reliably escape enemy attacks.Aiming your pod to shoot is quite nearly (nierly) impossible for some sections, and you have to rely on the lock-on mechanism to whittle away at certain enemiesin some of the most dull, uninteresting waste of time I've ever experienced. Your pod will default to aiming in the direction you are moving, and you have to constantly push your mouse in the direction you wish to fire, unless you prefer to stand still and eat ♥♥♥♥ the entire time. This would be okay if you have mile-long arms, as well as a mile long and wide desk, but you don't, and this is only acceptable if you have two analog sticks to work with. Auto-aim is not permitted on the harder two difficulties, so good luck without it.The camera angle and controls are barf-worthy. I ended up needing to play in a much smaller window / resolution than normal, and had to zoom the camera almost to its maximum distance just to actually play. The thing swoops and swoons all over the place as you struggle to keep your screen facing a mobile enemy. Auto-lock doesn't help this, but is required to actually keep some semblance of an eye on your target, especially when there is a very specific weak spot you need to hit. This has less to do with the PC controls, and is more to do with poor choices when it comes to actual development. Even simply running along the ground becomes barfy when the camera slowly shifts to be completely horizontal with your character's running line. I have to consistently pull my mouse down in an attempt to get a view from a higher vantage point. If I don't, it automatically resets to directly behind your character, and it makes (me and everyone I've spoken to) feel sick. Also, it makes it artificially difficult to find things you need to pick up. tl;drControls are ♥♥♥♥ for mouse + keyboard, either play with a controller, or don't play at all. Or wait until it goes on sale. Or for someone who has ever actually used a mouse and keyboard to play a game fixes the setup.

												Messy port. Massive hassle to switch between displays, different resolutions, and full screen/windowed. GTX-1070 needs mostly low settings at 1440p to maintain a decent frame rate.I want to like the game, I want to enjoy it, but I have not been able to just sit down and start playing it. If I need to alt+tab to respond to a message, I have to sit through a minute of my displays turning on and off before the game says "♥♥♥♥ it" and stops responding. Every time you change a single graphical setting, you have to wait ~6 seconds before you can confirm and move on. You have to restart the game to decide which display you want to use for full-screen. I almost wish I had a PS4 just so that I could play this on my TV without having to deal with so much non-sense. I want to give the game a positive review but I can't recommend something that puts up this much hassle over simple things.Lovely voice acting, character designs, and atmosphere. Will keep the game and keep playing instead of  refunding but it looks like I'm stuck to playing on the 1080p monitor at my desk instead of the 4K TV in front of my couch. Really  bothersome when games I've paid much less for had these things figured out and sorted.

I had to turn all visual options off and set low what I could.  With the lowest possible setting I get an inconsistent 30-40 frames.I bought the game on PC instead of my PS4 Pro because of the ultrawide support.  The 21:9 ratio is there, but the resolution (3440x1440) does not look the part. Additionally, the UI is not set to 21:9 and the cut-scenes run stretched as opposed to black bars.  It's a mess for ultra-wide. Batman: Arkham City wasn't this bad, I have absolutely no idea how this game made it pass QA on the PC.  I have not had any issues running anything I toss at my PC till I came to Nier.  The game is not a visual landmark to quantify anything more then I am already providing.  Do not make the same mistake and buy this on the PC till a patch is release.  I would love to give more input on the game itself, yet the frustration of the inconsistent frames during game, yet also in cut-scenes and menu navigation has made it impossible to progress without encumbering to motion sickness.The soundtrack is great, does not skip!

												Warning: This game doesn't autosave. You cannot manually save for the entire opening mission. If the game crashes before you finish it, you have to restart the whole thing. If you don't finish it for any reason, you will have to start over. This game also has framerate issues in the cut scenes, and I cannot get this game to play over 40fps even with the settings reduced, it seems to make no difference either way. The framerate isn't an issue as it still seems to be smooth while playing, other than the cut scenes. The game kicked me out of full screen in the middle of combat multiple times, and the window shrank to the size of a dialogue box on my desktop. I could not change it until out of combat and it was extremely difficult during a boss fight.The lack of save feature is really what is killing it for me though. Regular saves should be a standard for games.Gameplay and mechanics are decent, nothing ground-breaking. The story is meh, the map is difficult to read at least for me, and the camera is annoying. I like the game so far and think it has a lot of promise, though with the current issues I can't justify giving this a thumbs up at the moment. Perhaps after a patch or two have been released, I can change my review.Just my honest opinion, and yes 1.3 hours is plenty of time to get a healthy opinion of this game.

content:

												tl;dr If you like a good story, sound and atmosphere, it's a great game. If you also enjoy good gameplay and more deep mechanics than repeatedly pressing the same one or two buttons, then mybe skip this one.So the game is really good when it comes to worldbuilding, story, atmosphere, music. And for that reason alone I'll finish it for sure eventually.The real problem and furstration comes from the lacking game design. What you actually DO as a player is rather simple and repetitive. They add a lot of elements to the game, like twin stick shooting third person hack and slash and neither really is well fleshed out. I hoped at least the melee combar part of the game would be good, since it's the same company that also made Bayonetta. But apparently they must've fired all people invovled in that and hired some trainees for that job or something idk.Mostly you just hit evade and then attack. You can't really combo well or creatively as you'd expect if you played Bayonetta or DMC before. It's just hit the same buttong multiple times for some cool looking moves and that's pretty much it.Also difficulty is really badly designed. It's either a cakewalk or you almost die in one hit. No change to enemy behaviour though (which would make it actually interesting and challening), just more damage/life and that's it. Oh and for some reaons also no lock-on on higher difficulty. Apparently, limiting player controls is good game design now and the way to make games challenging -_-Also you can easily end up in sidequests or areas that are wayyyy too hard in terms of simple player vs monster level. I tried doing a sidequest that was on the way to some other main quest and was lvl 12 and encountered lvl 32 enemies there. I did vitrually zero damage and died in like 2 hits. Generally speaking, it feels like enemies have wayy too much hp most of the time, even small trashmobs take forever to kill and just feels like artifically lengthen the gameplay time without adding much. Speaking of not adding much. Enemies are mostly the same few general models, sometimes with a small twist, but mostly the same, except later they get higher levels thus deal more damage and have more hp. So, not so much variety there either.Bossfights are mostly cool and interesting though, gotta give them credit for that. But yeah, all in all, unless you wanna simply play it for the story, I wouldn't play the game at all. Gameplay-wise it has too little to offer that's well fleshed out and challenge-wise it's not well enough balanced and the mechanics are too lacking to provide a fun and fair challenge.Alos might want to add, this review comes from a guy who spends a lot of hours daily playing games, so if you just want to find something cool to relax after working, this game might be pretty good for you.

												Do not buy this game yet as it has multiple day one bugs and poor optimization that makes it crash for a lot of people regardless of PC specs. I'd recommend waiting a week or maybe even a month until they hopefully make this game playable.If you still want to buy this game because you think it looks great, don't be surprised if it does nothing but crash for you and make you reach for the refund button.From the tiny amount of progress I've managed to make between crashes:The game looks okay once you get around the fullscreen bug that causes the graphics to render in a lower resolution and then upscales it which makes the game look like it was made for the PlayStation 2. Anti-Aliasing doesn't seem to have any impact other than making the game no longer run at a smooth 60FPS. Cutscenes are all locked to 30FPS while the rest of the game is locked to 60.Music score is great, game mechanics are great.Highly recommend playing with a controller unless you want the game to be even more challenging as KB+Mouse isn't optimal. Controller input can be fully customized if you don't like any of the 3 layouts.If you're here for the story or want an extreme challenge then both Easy and Very Hard will make you feel right at home. Easy Mode enables access to various Auto-Chips that can be toggled on and off on the fly (At the cost of manual auto-aim control since there's no auto-lock-on chip that you can disable and instead disables if you manually uninstall all auto-chips) which essentially enables god mode as you will automatically attack and evade. Meanwhile on Hard mode lock-on is completely disabled and on Very Hard you die in one hit.

												Release day review:Considering this game had extra time to release on PC, the issues Square Enix has released this game are unforgivable.Major cons:1) No proper 4k resolution support2) Clear optimization issues for the PC version3) Not enough key/button customization for PC users, (i.e. no option to rebind mouse button controls). Also no option to setup another dodge key setup other than the cancerous double tap method.4) No decent consideration for mouse looking camera controls All of the above is especially unforgivable when you compare a perfect analogy to Square Enix's release of Nier Automata and another Square Enix title, Final Fantasy 14.What both share (so no room for arguments on "but it's different!|"):1) Same publisher2) Both games have console and PC versions, which both favoring console mindset/control schemesAnd yet, FF14 has none of the cons of Nier Automata and even more so goes far beyond to being very considerate of PC version setup and control schemesWhat FF14 does better for PC version:1) Allows FULL 4k support2) Runs very well (with even better graphics despite being an older game than Automata) on PC even at 4k (I get solid 60fps)3) FF14 probably has THE most best customization options for keys and UI that has ever existed in an MMORPG or any game for that matter, also allowing "key bindings" to use mouse button bindings (unlike Automata)4) Very good mouse camera controls and options, again probably the best in not only MMORPGs but most other genre gamesMy sub for FF14 just so happened to run out of Nier Automata's PC release date and as I was looking forward to playing it, I figured would not resub until I was done playing Automata. But since there is a lot of issues that need to be fixed in Automata. I will go back to playing FF14. And if the issues don't get fixed in Automata, I will refund this game.I actually also suggest people refund this game until it is fix (not liking you are losing a preorder discount [unlike many Steam release games). If anything, you might up saving money by refunding now and rebuy when it is on sale and actually a proper PC port (if they ever manage it).

												I want to love this game. The couple of hours I actually managed to slip in between freezing/crashing made me love it. I CANNOT reccommend currently to anyone with a 780/780ti as of write now a few weeks after launch it is unplayable for MOST 780/780ti users. As well as quite a few AMD and gtx980 users. Please do not buy if you have these cards until an official patch as there is not even a reliable fan patch yet. Steam should warn people on the store page to be honest. If you don't believe me look at the thousands of comments on steam forums and reddit as well as nvidia forums just by googling Nier freezing. The game image will freeze yet still plays in the background but forces you to quit and restart OR it just crashes to white. Some times this happens every 5 minutes sometimes you can go a couple hours without it. It seems the prologue and the amusment park are the biggest problems with this at the moment. Most people will pass the two hours refund time while trying to fix it youself. It can't be done so just wait for an all clear if you have these cards. Especially if you don't usually spend 60 dollars on games.

												Day 1 review:Well, even considering the bad reviews mentioning the fact that it doesn't have full controller support, only 720p in fullscreen and not too good performance I bought the game, because the gameplay looks good.I started the game and it was fine, no performance issues, graphics looks nice, the voice acting is good etc.35 minutes into the game, in the middle of a fight, the image just froze on me, the sound still went on but the image was frozen, I waited for a few minutes but nothing changed, checked google for some tips and apparently this is a common issue. Well I ALT + F4 the game and start it up again, while thinking about how the game told me that there's no auto save feature in the game so you need to save it manually, the pain I felt when I got back into the game, went on continue and saw that I had 00:00:00 on my playtime, knowing that I had to go through the painfully boring start where you fly a transformer/jet and need to listen to dialogue. Well I went through all that and got to the melee combat again, only this time it froze in the very first fight, I started over AGAIN, went through the same tutorial again and got to the melee part again, this time I got to the buzzsaw fight (the first one) and guess what, it froze again. :)One last ALT + F4, now I will wait for some kind of update that fixes some of these issues, well at least the issue that makes the game unplayable, if not then i'll just return this piece of ♥♥♥♥ and get my money back.Hardware: Intel I7 3820 3,6GHz16 GB RAMGTX 780

content:

												Whether you're eating the booty like groceries or giving anal $ex a shot NieR: Automata is brilliant. It strikes the balance between RPG and action game unlike anything else in the genre. It’s a game you kind of have to meet halfway, with a story that gets more complex and interesting the more your prod at it. Pros -Satisfying combat-Inventive and surprising-Movement feels incredible-Brilliant soundtrack-Nice booty Cons -Invisible walls-Camera can be annoying-Ugly in places-Some game breaking bugs (Edit: most of them were fixed by modders)Thanks to Platinum Games knack for riveting and gratifying combat, Automata is Yoko Taro's most exciting game to date. The combat mechanics click after hurdling a low learning curve, and the end result is a skillful dance where balletic dodges complement wushu-inspired aggression. Moreover, this multi-ending trip is generously peppered with surprises and revelations, as well as easter eggs that call back to the first game and the Drakengard series from which Nier spun off. It's a meaty, often exhilarating trek that showcases Platinum Games and Yoko Taro's unique blend of genius.

												Each second this game reminds me how much better it could be, how many opportunities were ruined, how many useless design decisions were added to the game...It was good at some points but all of them were followed by a big freaking BUT:The story itself might be interesting BUT not when it's mostly told by the childish character (the worst of the main trio).The animations were awesome and the combat system was great BUT why in the name of all gods were they sometimes pulling camera off to the ceiling or one of the sides making the game look like a freaking 2d with no option to turn this feature off?The characters... well... in my opinion it was a greatest mistake of the game, to use the worst of them as a main storyteller (based on the actual gameplay time and his appearance in the story routes) I bet my life there was a better way to tell this story.Would i recommend it? Maybe...Would i call it a good game? I'm not sure...I was really trying to love this game, but in the end it only led me to a bigger disappointment... and to a story with no conclusion.
