												A cult classic in the making.Don't let technical (and fixable) issues drive you away from this gem.The game plays really smoothly, having a fast paced combat suitable for both novices and experts: it has depth if you want to experiment with moves and weapons, but it's not strictly required to progress. Navigating the areas also feels very smooth, and while the prologue is completely linear, the more open maps allow for quite a bit of freedom of movement, complemented by hidden areas and secrets.Everything else, from music, to visuals, to the setting itself, has a strong sense of identity, and it's beautifully crafted with an eye for details. A unique world with unique storytelling that seamlessly ties together gameplay and story elements.

												While i have yet to finish the game, i can say without any doubt that this game is a masterpiece.  Nothing prepared me for Nier: Automata.  I had heard the first one was a great game even though it was not crtically acclaimed or a financial success.  SE took a risk here and boy does it pay off.  Nier Automata is one of the best games this generation EASILY.  The combination of Platinum games and Yoko Taro storytelling is perfect.  The fast paced combat of the game accompanied by one of the best OST's in gaming history and a gripping emotional story make this game a must have for fans of both jrpgs and action games.  The PC version did have its faults, but its FAR from being a bad port.  Once you get the mods to fix the small issues you are good to go at full 60fps 1080p glory.  Highly recommended game.

This game does not support Auto-Save...So that has left me in a situation where the game has yet to get to a point for me to save before it crashes again. Everytime I start over....I HAVE TO START OVER, OVER. Until this is resolved I will request a refund until these issues are addressed. I am quite disappointed by yet another low quality assured port.

												While i have yet to finish the game, i can say without any doubt that this game is a masterpiece.  Nothing prepared me for Nier: Automata.  I had heard the first one was a great game even though it was not crtically acclaimed or a financial success.  SE took a risk here and boy does it pay off.  Nier Automata is one of the best games this generation EASILY.  The combination of Platinum games and Yoko Taro storytelling is perfect.  The fast paced combat of the game accompanied by one of the best OST's in gaming history and a gripping emotional story make this game a must have for fans of both jrpgs and action games.  The PC version did have its faults, but its FAR from being a bad port.  Once you get the mods to fix the small issues you are good to go at full 60fps 1080p glory.  Highly recommended game.

content:
6
												Upon 100% completion of this game I only felt one thing. I want to play and experience this masterpiece of art all over again. Every single aspect of this game works toward the goal of creating a meaningful and unique experience that is unmatched by the majority of games that are made these days. The passion and dedication required to make this game oozes through every single moment. This game doesn’t try imitate another medium like film or novel instead it embraces its identity as a game and utilizes this to become one of the best games of all-time and a defining moment in the history of video games. Gameplay The gameplay in this game is one of the most gratifying things in existence. It is one of the most original mashups of two different genres of game I have ever played. It combines the best elements of hack and slash with bullet hell into a tight, highly enjoyable package that never fails to be a blast to play. Its addictive nature means that even in the late game it never becomes a chore to play. There are four different types of weapons these are small swords, large swords, spears and combat bracers. All of the weapons have a sense of weight behind them meaning every weapon is both satisfying and entertaining to use. There is a whole sleuth of weapon combos that can be achieved leading to you wanting to find the best combo that suits your playstyle. At first it may seem like there is a lack in enemy variety however this is not the case. As you progress through the game each enemy type becomes more advanced and varied with their weapon choices. So one moment you may be fighting two goliath bipeds and the next moment you are faced off against a mixture of small flying units and a horde of medium bipeds equipped with axes. All of this means every engagement has a sense of originality. The bullet hell aspect comes from the fact that you have a pod unit that fires either bullets, laser or missiles however the laser and missile types must be found throughout the world. The game does not feature a normal leveling up upgrade system rather it uses a plug-in chip system where you have an allocated number of slots that you fill with plug-in chips you find in the world. From this you can build your character the way you want play.  Sound Now nothing in this game sounds completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic except the music. Now that is not me saying everything sounds like trash. The weapons sound like they are making a real impact when they hit the enemy and the ambient effects all sound good aswell but nothing ever stands out but when the music is a completely different story. This is perhaps the best video game OST I have ever heard. It effortlessly transitions from awe inspiring to downright depressing at times. The music works great within the context of the story and helps punctuate the more emotional moments of the game. Every area you visit has a unique theme that changes depending on what you are doing in that area for example when you first arrive at the amusement park the music starts off with a slow piano and equally slow vocals but as you progress into the area it gets faster and by time you are fully engaged in combat the music is fast and exhilarating fitting excellent with the gameplay. There is not a single weak track in the game. Some of my personal favourite tracks are Amusement Park, A Beautiful Song, Weight of the World, End of the Unknown, Dark Colossus - Kaiju, Copied City, Mourning, Song of the Ancients - Atonement, The Sound of the End, Weight of the World the End of YoRHa and Emil - Despair. The voice acting is also amazing across the board with especially great performances from Emil’s, Pascal’s and 9S’ voice actors.   Graphics The texture work in this game isn’t the greatest however the impressive lighting made every environment look stunning and it was a joy just to wander around this beautiful world. The character models all looked great and some parts of the characters bodies looked absolutely gorgeous most notably 2B’s ♥♥♥. I wouldn’t mind her sitting on my face. Also I would let the commander choke me with those thighs. All the weapon models look highly detailed. There was some texture pop-in in some places like when I first arrived at the forest castle the walls where all untextured until I walked right up to them. The cutscenes are all displayed 900p @ 30fps which is extremely puzzling and is jarring as you transition from smooth 1080p @ 60fps to a choppy cutscene. I never experienced any framerate or resolution problems. I wouldn’t say it’s a horrible PC port but it isn’t a good one either. Story I have never played the original NieR but I do know a lot about it’s story as I have played the original Drakengard (To which NieR is a spin-off). You can go into this game without knowing anything about the original game and still understand and enjoy this masterfully told, poignant story. The game is set in the year 11945, during the 14th Machine War. Aliens have invaded Earth using machine lifeforms and the humans fought back using androids. Eventually the humans retreat to the moon. You play as YoRHa android called 2B and you are accompanied by another android 9S as you try to destroy the machines and win the war. I won’t go into to much detail about the story itself as it would spoil it however rarely has any story of any kind had such an impact on me. All the twists that happen don’t happen just for the sake of being a twist but there are hints dropped throughout the game in some of the main story moments and even in the sidequests as well. Some of the character stories are absolutely heart-wrenching to witness. My only criticism is that some of 9S’ and 2B’s interactions with the machines are bit out of character sometimes but other than that the story in this game could potentially be the best storyline ever written for a video game. Conclusion  This game is a masterpiece. It fully uses the fact that it is a game and delivers a memorable and unforgettable experience that I have had the pleasure of enjoying. Never before has a story being so impactful that I constantly think about it. Never before has a game been so fun that I just want to play more. Never before has characters been so well written that I couldn’t help but fall in love with them. I would fully recommend this game to anyone who enjoys games as true art and this is perhaps one of the best games ever made and this is definitely my favourite game of all time.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
18
												Tech Performance Details:I own both the PS4 Slim and PC edition, and wanted to share some experiences with performance comparing the two.PC Rig: i7-3930K / 32gb Ram / 980TiIn full screen it runs at 900p, using the windowless hack it can run at my screen's native 1440p, but it causes jitter issues. Even though it has the same resolution as the PS4 version, it still looks a little nicer due to better AA, filtering, shadows and shader effects. 60fps lock doesn't bother me as my screen cannot handle any higher anyway. The PC version holds the 60fps nearly perfectly. Much better than the PS4 version anyway. My PC has the same cut scene frame drop issues others have reported. Over 10 hours on the PC version and not a single crash or freeze. There have been a few camera glitches, but the PS4 version has had some too. Overall, I don't think it's a terrible port. There's a few issues with it, but it still looks and plays better than the PS4 version at least on my rig. I do hope that patches unlock the resolution though.-- Actual Game Review --Starting Adventure:I killed a robot the size of an oil rig. Arrived in a city where I jumped straight off a tall building not thinking about fall damage. Just survived the fall, and then a moose came up and finished me off. All this game needs is great characters with futuristic gothic lolita clothing and it'd be perfect...Gameplay:A game that doesn't necessarily do anything original, but takes some great elements from many others and glues them all together in a surprisingly coherent way. There's a little bit if variety with side scrollers, bullet hells and of course, high speed hack 'n' slash. Really responsive controls with a brilliant free-flowing combo system make for one of the best combat games I've ever played. The attention paid to character movement is fantastic and makes all the excessively long jaunts around the world quite enjoyable.Difficulty:Normal mode. Pretty easy actually. This isn't a complaint though. It's fun to just sit back and unwind and get into that lovely combo groove. Most problems are generally caused by stupid mistakes or not learning the mechanics properly. If a harder time is wanted then there are two more difficulties above that. Maybe more, don't know as I'm trying to avoid potential spoilers.Story:No spoilers. So far, really good. It has a more dire tone is general, but then features the usual quirky and silly elements blended in. Due to the main tone though, the silly elements can often feel a little more disturbing which is a great addition.Graphics:Massive fan of the art style. Great costumes, environments and colour palettes. 2B's animation deserve special note as well. Beautiful weight and response to the environment around her. The best illustration of this is attack once with a staff weapon and wait for her sheathing animation. Just beautiful.As for technical achievements, it is damned impressive. Nice skin shaders and cloth physics. Excellent environmental draw distance, but characters and props do suffer from noticeable popup. Some textures are a little low res, so they stand out a little. Same with some NPC models.Sound:This is a real strong point for Nier. The soundtrack is nothing short of gorgeous, with it's mix of instrumental and vocal tracks. The use of multi-track fades makes it even more enjoyable as the music changes to fit the environment and action. Massive credit needs to be given for the use of stereo imaging on the soundtrack, something that very few games seem to even attempt, let alone do well. Wasn't a huge fan of 2B's English voice, so switched to the Japanese track which feels a lot more appropriate given her design and personality. Thank you for keeping that option available. The Japanese dub has been really good in general.The sound effects are also outstanding with really nice positional audio and great filters for reverbs when needed. The text dialogue typing noise is a little grating, but I have that problem with most games.Conclusion:A really nice game that really deserves a try. The only reason to not play this game is if you really dislike hack 'n' slahes. If you feel a game needs to run at the highest resolution with the fastest frame rates to warrant consideration, wait it out for now.

												Warning: Not everyone's computer can run this at a steady 60 FPS at 1080p. If you lose your ♥♥♥♥ at 56-59 FPS, if not running a game on ultra chills you to the bone, or playing in borderless window mode makes you vomit this game is not for you.So far this game feels like Bayonetta in an "open world" environment. It's not totally open world but the maps are huge with lots of places to just get lost in, finding treasure and sidequests. My only gripe so far is the camera likes to "showcase" different angles at times, sometimes transitioning from 3D controls to 2D controls at some parts. Sometimes it does a horrendous top down angle on some parts of levels that really screws with depth perception (like a lot of the game is aerial combos but with the top down angle you can't tell if you're in the air or not or how close you are to the ground.)This feels a lot like Platinum and Square's attempt at a Souls game. Screwing up even once can lead to death (if you're playing above easy.) Dying forces you to fight your way back to your body or lose your chips (equipment), you can see other player's bodies everywhere and can either obtain a random chip from them or temporarily turn them into an NPC to help you fight. It's no Dark Souls 1, but at least it's no Dark Souls 2

												I like the game and think it is worth getting in one form or another. However, I'm "not recommending" it because I think it's necessary to present the flaw with the port:-Specs are misleading. I run a 1080 w/16gb ram but this is beyond the rec. People who have the recc specs are having issue with performance-Gameplay is locked at 60fps, cutscene at 30 fps. With a good rig it will stay at 59-60 fps but refer to the spec issue. You can't go above 60-Resolution bug at launch defaults 1080 to upscale internal resolution. There are workarounds but this requires some actual work-DRM using Denuvo, make of that what you will-KB&M setup not recommended. You need a gamepad if you don't want to have a hard time.As a port/pc game it is bad. I would only recommend Automata under following criteria:-If your rig is well beyond the recc specs-If you prefer gamepad over KB&M-If you're ok with locked 60fps-If you want better graphics, perfromance and customization than the PS4-If you don't own a PS4

content:
18
												I spent a long time pondering whether or not to buy this game or not over the past weeks and Im glad that I did! Before starting the review, let me just recommend playing with a controller (Im playing with a 10E one) because it makes gameplay so much more smooth and enjoyable. On another note, I have only completed ending A but felt that just that was worth giving this game a review.Gameplay: amazing combat system in which timing evades is a central concept and something that isnt always easy. It feels abit like skyrim mixed with assassins creed; i.e hack and slash with dodges and counters. However this is not all there is to it, different scenarios call for different approaches; ranged or melee....or why not  both? The combat was seamless and fluid, every hit feels good. Furthermore, the blend of 2d platformer, alien invaders and the "from above" diablo perspective at the perfect times in the game really did it for me (if youre not into that, fret not! the vast majority is from the 3rd person 3d perspective)! Last but not least, the BOSS FIGHTS are fantastic, and due to the limited "save game" feature of this game, these fights will have your heart pounding as youre on your last legs with no more restores, cause if you die, you are gonna be starting that fight over!Visuals: Im using a gtx 970 and thus far I am having no issues at 1080p. in the beginning the world is very dull, with mostly greyish buildings and some greenery...kinda bland. However this personally made me appreciate colours more, and I can tell you that when you do encounter more vivid scenery, it will be all the more special! Also, it is worth mentioning that the scenery is very well adapted to the story and feelings that they want from you. the player.  Story: now as I mentioned, I have only played the fist ending but wanted to review it anyway. The story is very interesting, deep and explores alot of interesting themes; everything from machines having a family to religion. It also had me questioning several times who the real villain is, the machines or me. Many moments are emotionally touching aswelll but I wont reveal any of that bc its better that you experience that for yourself ;)   On the final note I would like to say that just because this game has several storylines DOES NOT mean you are doing the same thing over and over, it is in no way the same thing as "grinding" in other RPG games. It shows you the story from another perspective and you get deeper and deeper into the story and learn new things. So the game doesnt end aftet the first playthrough and it is definately worth the additional playthroughs!Sorry for the long review, hope this helped somebody! :)peace.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
18
												Tech Performance Details:I own both the PS4 Slim and PC edition, and wanted to share some experiences with performance comparing the two.PC Rig: i7-3930K / 32gb Ram / 980TiIn full screen it runs at 900p, using the windowless hack it can run at my screen's native 1440p, but it causes jitter issues. Even though it has the same resolution as the PS4 version, it still looks a little nicer due to better AA, filtering, shadows and shader effects. 60fps lock doesn't bother me as my screen cannot handle any higher anyway. The PC version holds the 60fps nearly perfectly. Much better than the PS4 version anyway. My PC has the same cut scene frame drop issues others have reported. Over 10 hours on the PC version and not a single crash or freeze. There have been a few camera glitches, but the PS4 version has had some too. Overall, I don't think it's a terrible port. There's a few issues with it, but it still looks and plays better than the PS4 version at least on my rig. I do hope that patches unlock the resolution though.-- Actual Game Review --Starting Adventure:I killed a robot the size of an oil rig. Arrived in a city where I jumped straight off a tall building not thinking about fall damage. Just survived the fall, and then a moose came up and finished me off. All this game needs is great characters with futuristic gothic lolita clothing and it'd be perfect...Gameplay:A game that doesn't necessarily do anything original, but takes some great elements from many others and glues them all together in a surprisingly coherent way. There's a little bit if variety with side scrollers, bullet hells and of course, high speed hack 'n' slash. Really responsive controls with a brilliant free-flowing combo system make for one of the best combat games I've ever played. The attention paid to character movement is fantastic and makes all the excessively long jaunts around the world quite enjoyable.Difficulty:Normal mode. Pretty easy actually. This isn't a complaint though. It's fun to just sit back and unwind and get into that lovely combo groove. Most problems are generally caused by stupid mistakes or not learning the mechanics properly. If a harder time is wanted then there are two more difficulties above that. Maybe more, don't know as I'm trying to avoid potential spoilers.Story:No spoilers. So far, really good. It has a more dire tone is general, but then features the usual quirky and silly elements blended in. Due to the main tone though, the silly elements can often feel a little more disturbing which is a great addition.Graphics:Massive fan of the art style. Great costumes, environments and colour palettes. 2B's animation deserve special note as well. Beautiful weight and response to the environment around her. The best illustration of this is attack once with a staff weapon and wait for her sheathing animation. Just beautiful.As for technical achievements, it is damned impressive. Nice skin shaders and cloth physics. Excellent environmental draw distance, but characters and props do suffer from noticeable popup. Some textures are a little low res, so they stand out a little. Same with some NPC models.Sound:This is a real strong point for Nier. The soundtrack is nothing short of gorgeous, with it's mix of instrumental and vocal tracks. The use of multi-track fades makes it even more enjoyable as the music changes to fit the environment and action. Massive credit needs to be given for the use of stereo imaging on the soundtrack, something that very few games seem to even attempt, let alone do well. Wasn't a huge fan of 2B's English voice, so switched to the Japanese track which feels a lot more appropriate given her design and personality. Thank you for keeping that option available. The Japanese dub has been really good in general.The sound effects are also outstanding with really nice positional audio and great filters for reverbs when needed. The text dialogue typing noise is a little grating, but I have that problem with most games.Conclusion:A really nice game that really deserves a try. The only reason to not play this game is if you really dislike hack 'n' slahes. If you feel a game needs to run at the highest resolution with the fastest frame rates to warrant consideration, wait it out for now.

With this game the camera changes a bit more than regular 3rd person games. Sometimes the character is so tiny that I'm controlling.  And I love that.  It's artistic and used properly when done.Pros+ Deep story+ Combat+ Runs well for meCons- Invisible walls - No auto save- Learning curve

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
18
												System Specsi7-4790kGTX 980ti 16gigs RAMWindows 8.1PerformanceAbout 5 hours into it and no performance or graphics glitches. Whatever is causing the odd 1080 fullscreen bug isn't effecting me. I'm running V-sync on but AA off, i haven't tried it with AA on since it looks fine without so i can't give any info on that. The framerate is capped at 60fps and the cut-scenes are capped at 30fps, there is minor stuttering when the framerate drops to render a cut-scene but it's short and doesn't effect much aside from being noticable. No crashes to report so far. (i'll update if any of that changes).StoryIf you've played a Taro game you already know what you're in for so i won't bore you with details and if you're new to his style of story telling i won't spoil it for you other then to say there's multiple endings so don't stop playing just because you've made it to the first set of end credits, infact, the best plot lines usually happen on the second or third playthrough. VisualsThey look better then the first Nier but they're a bit crude by modern game standards but it's first and foremost a RPG and by that measure it looks good. They balanced the wash of browns and greys with the occasional splash of color and it has good special effects and they even gave some of the characters jiggle physics in just the right places as well as other items such as clothing and weapon hangers, overall simple but very nice looking. The weapon effects can be a bit overwhelming at times and you may get lost in a large crowd of enemies with all the explosions and sparks flying everywhere. Overall, it looks great. No weird or badly done textures or meshes, it all look uniform and detailed to a point you'll be immersed in the gameplay in no time. Sounds and musicHaunting and epic music are standard for a Taro game and this is no different, you can adjust all the major sound effects such as music, voice, and effects all seperate.Weapon combat and other Misc sounds are well done.CameraSo far it's been a bit annoying for me to keep it tracking properly on M&K so i switched to a PS3 controller and it feels much better. However, there's more options to finely tune the camera in every way you can imagine and probably in some you never though you needed, if anything it's a bit overwhelming just how many fine tuning option for the camera there are. CombatMUCH improved over previous titles. Fast, frantic, and the enemies are actually good at fighting. I found myself in an area where the enemies were 3X my level and i gave a good fight but got plastered to the floor a good 7 times before i finally gave up and moved on (for now). I lost a few upgrade chips but learned a valuable lesson in humility. It's good solid real-time combat and watching someone else playing doesn't do it justice, it's much more fun and difficult when you're doing it yourself. I like it. Unless the performance suddenly goes south later on I'm keeping my review firmly in the recommend. I've played all the previous titles so i have a good idea what I'm in for plot-wise and the performance of the game itself has been some of the best of any PC game I've bought in a solid 2 years, the 30 fps cap on cut-scenes does make me grimace a little but I'm willing to live with it since it's a minor complaint at worst and me just being a bit of a PC gaming snob at best. If you're into RPG's and Sci-fi plots with bizzare twists that will leave you at a loss for words then have i got a game recommendation for you, swords, smexy female andriods, killer robots the size of small cities, and a plot so crazy that even after playing the entire Drakengard series i still don't understand, it's crazy and I'd want it no other way.

												9/10Great graphics, fantastic play, amazing story. GRAPHICS: Fullscreen mode is weird right now, only because it will pop back into window mode if background apps get crazy. I fixed the issue for myself, and you can too if you have technical experience. I am running a 980ti, intel 4650k DC, and 32gb RAM. No issues have happened to me yet. A few stutters when I happen upon the bodies of dead players, but that's attributed to the network and not the actual game. If I turn off the network connection, the game runs flawlessly on all highest settings and in 1080p. Never once have I had below 55fps, even with hundreds of enemies on screen.For those of you posting bad reviews due to technical issues: this is a 2017 game. Running it with 6GB RAM on a GTX700 card from 2012 is NOT recommended. This is why you have issues. Upgrade to a newer card and RAM set before playing new games on ultra.GAMEPLAY: This game will take you through a lot of different play styles from RPG action, to hack and slash, to Dark Souls esque timing fighting, to platforming and to top down shooting. Its an awesome ride.STORY: This has one of the most thoughtful story lines I have ever played or seen play out in a video game. You will cry. If this was a movie, it would get awards for screenplay and writing.

												This game is wonderful but it does have its cons especially because of a lack luster PC port.Overall this game is amazing and most the issues if not all of them with the PC release will get fixed. Otherwise i recommend this game to anyone and everyone.Pros+Animations are suberb, very realistic and gives you a real sense of power and speed.+Combat is fantastic and is a very rewarding experiance although some of the controls could probably be better (kind of awkward to shoot the pod and dodge at the same time.)+Story is amazing so far.+Short stories for a lot of items/weapons+World and characters look amazing.+Good amount of character customizability (for combat)+Best Soundtrack ever+Open World+Camera changes from top down, side scroll and third person seamlessly+Multiple game types in one+You can talk to an npc to help reduce motion sickness if you need it+Japanese voice acting is amazing+Multiple language support+Makes you feel badass even if you're ♥♥♥♥ at it+Difficulties actually change things significantly+Made for replayability+A ton of different endings (27 in total but 4-5 "serious" endings)+Multiple references to Drakengard and original nier+Dark souls esk death where you have to find your body to get your stuff back.+Mechs+Self Destruct your dress+Get slappedCons-KB+M is trash, dont use it with this game you will have an awful experiance-Some textures are very low resolution-Performance issues with the anti aliasing (will most likely get fixed)-Stretched widescreen support (might get fixed)-Currently 1080p and above does not render correctly in fullscreen mode (will get fixed)-AMD RX4xx cards currently have issues with the game (playable if you use the 16.11.5 drivers though, this will get fixed)Non-issues that could be improved~60 FPS cap~30fps cut scenes are a bit jarring~Would be nice if there was full controller support although Steam does a good job of converting the input to work with this gameNon issues that wont be changed (maybe)English voice acting doesnt suit a lot of the charactersNo full voice acting (for side quests)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
18
												System Specsi7-4790kGTX 980ti 16gigs RAMWindows 8.1PerformanceAbout 5 hours into it and no performance or graphics glitches. Whatever is causing the odd 1080 fullscreen bug isn't effecting me. I'm running V-sync on but AA off, i haven't tried it with AA on since it looks fine without so i can't give any info on that. The framerate is capped at 60fps and the cut-scenes are capped at 30fps, there is minor stuttering when the framerate drops to render a cut-scene but it's short and doesn't effect much aside from being noticable. No crashes to report so far. (i'll update if any of that changes).StoryIf you've played a Taro game you already know what you're in for so i won't bore you with details and if you're new to his style of story telling i won't spoil it for you other then to say there's multiple endings so don't stop playing just because you've made it to the first set of end credits, infact, the best plot lines usually happen on the second or third playthrough. VisualsThey look better then the first Nier but they're a bit crude by modern game standards but it's first and foremost a RPG and by that measure it looks good. They balanced the wash of browns and greys with the occasional splash of color and it has good special effects and they even gave some of the characters jiggle physics in just the right places as well as other items such as clothing and weapon hangers, overall simple but very nice looking. The weapon effects can be a bit overwhelming at times and you may get lost in a large crowd of enemies with all the explosions and sparks flying everywhere. Overall, it looks great. No weird or badly done textures or meshes, it all look uniform and detailed to a point you'll be immersed in the gameplay in no time. Sounds and musicHaunting and epic music are standard for a Taro game and this is no different, you can adjust all the major sound effects such as music, voice, and effects all seperate.Weapon combat and other Misc sounds are well done.CameraSo far it's been a bit annoying for me to keep it tracking properly on M&K so i switched to a PS3 controller and it feels much better. However, there's more options to finely tune the camera in every way you can imagine and probably in some you never though you needed, if anything it's a bit overwhelming just how many fine tuning option for the camera there are. CombatMUCH improved over previous titles. Fast, frantic, and the enemies are actually good at fighting. I found myself in an area where the enemies were 3X my level and i gave a good fight but got plastered to the floor a good 7 times before i finally gave up and moved on (for now). I lost a few upgrade chips but learned a valuable lesson in humility. It's good solid real-time combat and watching someone else playing doesn't do it justice, it's much more fun and difficult when you're doing it yourself. I like it. Unless the performance suddenly goes south later on I'm keeping my review firmly in the recommend. I've played all the previous titles so i have a good idea what I'm in for plot-wise and the performance of the game itself has been some of the best of any PC game I've bought in a solid 2 years, the 30 fps cap on cut-scenes does make me grimace a little but I'm willing to live with it since it's a minor complaint at worst and me just being a bit of a PC gaming snob at best. If you're into RPG's and Sci-fi plots with bizzare twists that will leave you at a loss for words then have i got a game recommendation for you, swords, smexy female andriods, killer robots the size of small cities, and a plot so crazy that even after playing the entire Drakengard series i still don't understand, it's crazy and I'd want it no other way.

content:
22
												Although I sympathize, I can't comment on performance issues because I never encountered any. The game ran smoothly on my setup [i5 4960K, GTX 1070 EX, 8GB Kingston HyperX DDR3]. I'm reading most people encounter issues on a GTX 700 series or earlier model GPU. Someone pointed out that fullscreen doesn't give full 1080p resolution, but it never bothered me after I noticed it.For the game, on a first playthrough it is a good game but the lack of story explanation and backstory threw me off. Then I realized that you unlock more backstory on a second playthrough. Having this second playthrough and replaying the scenarios gave me a much greater feel for the setting of the game and the emotions/driven ambitions of the main characters. Furthermore, the second playthrough didn't feel like a drag whatsoever for me because the combat is immensively fun and the story is just different enough to feel like a somewhat new experience. Then the third playthrough is when everything changes, it unlocks the second half of the game, and it caught me entirely off gaurd. I loved it, it feels like a complete and well structured game with a very nihilistic approach in story telling. The characters are well understood near the end and how they develop at this point is very satisfying. Along with the story, the game also very fun to play. If can be challenging (but fun) if you set up the appropriate difficulty setting for you. The combat feels smooth and nice. It's simple, but there are so many subtle ways to combine abilities and button commands that I felt I was still learning new combat techniques and getting progressively better even on the second and third playthrough. It's dynamic and there is flexibility for the gamer to fight how they want and still learn more.  I love this game, and I recommend giving it a chance through all the playthroughs.

												I have not played the other titles by this dev. I found this game to be remarkably engaging. 												Welp, I completed it. The ending kind of creeps up. I was hoping for a bit more out of a single playthrough but I am reading that the gimmicky deal for this game is the multiple playthroughs. So, I guess I'll be jumping back in. The combat is pretty impeccable. It's certainly not the most complex character action title I've played but it's satisfying. No, it's not God of War simple but it certainly isn't DMC3.          The biggest, glaring problem in the room has previously been stated. It has some port issues but nothing that couldn't be fixed. But I beat this game in a wee two sittings. I guess that could be a compliment because I wasn't bored for a second but it feels like I wasn't given enough time to approach bored. Maybe not even enough time to approach the Platinum Climax...(sqerm joke). Just be warned, it won't be one of those $1/hr kind of games if that's usually how you operate. Personally, I will be logging more time in. I want to know how much content has been hidden from my first timer eyes. Oh, and 2B is really, really, unbearably, overthetop hot. Enjoy the Doujin.

												Loving the game so far. Some points I want to make:- 4K is only an upscale. Any other resolution is fine. Quite disappointed as I always play at 4K, but probably won't affect the majority of players.- For the first hour, was playing on 4K and the frames froze 3 times while upscaled. However, not very surprised at this as it's a port from a console.- Haven't tried using a keyboard yet, but definitely recommend using a controler. I'm sometimes pressing 3 - 4 buttons at once or in quick succession.- Soundtrack is definitely up there with the best.All in all, I haven't encountered any other problems besides the infrequent freezing on an upscaled 4K, and is an extremely fun game with, as expected, a really good soundtrack.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
18
												tl;dr: If care about writing and story, characterization then wait for a sale. If you just want to hack and slash through enemies with satisfying gameplay, and some great set pieces then by all means go buy it. I would highly recommend it for that reason alone.Edit: I understand that the story gets better through the second and onward playthroughs but my argument stands that if the game cannot grip you in the first playthrough (in which they think we'll actually care about anything because of the poor characterization) if we want to continue playing with a forward thinking mind.The combat is fun and good. It's what platinum game does best. However, while the game runs and plays great, the actual content of the game isn't good. The game forces you to play through the game multiple times just to get a decent story because honestly the first playthrough does not bode well in characterization, story narrative and discards a few plotlines along the way. It doesn't even compare to it's parent game, Drakengard, specifically 1 and 2.The main antagonists have a surprising assertion into the story but that's all the time they're given. You never get to know them, what they're thinking as you play the game. Once you reach certain story bits, they show up and you kill them. That's it. There's an interesting lore to behold in Nier Automata but it's disregarded for philosophical talk about "androids...machines...emotions...not so different..etc". It's cliche. 2B is just as bad. You never get to know her. Sure you know that she listens to HQ but that's HQ's opinion and orders on things. She never has her own opinions that really drive the story. She doesn't assert herself as one of the main characters. 9S does most of the talking and so he has a little more character but it needs 2B's cooporation in order for both of them to grow to the potential they have. And there's not much to elaborate on other side characters because while some may seem important you'll never really get to know them as much as you want. But all in all, the game doesn't ever set things up to really get to know anyone. It's just "we got orders for this...orders for that..."Some side quests will automatically fail without any warning if you progress in the story. And the side quests for the most part are simply just for materials and gold. It doesn't offer anything special to the world other than some subtle characters of the npcs.And before I knew it the game just ended...like seriously...? That was the ending? Are you ♥♥♥♥ing serious? And you're gonna say I have to play the game again just to get the story experience that was deliberately missing from the first playthrough?? That's not how you do it if you are giving players such a weak first playthrough experience. Give us something strong to hold onto....and then we can move forward onto multiple playthroughs..but Nier Automata thinks this is a cool way to tell story by chopping it into pieces forcing you to play hours upon hours of the same content just to get a decent story.In my opinion, all those 9/10s from game outlets hyped the ♥♥♥♥ out of me and it honestly hurts that I feel so different from it. The first game I ever bought was Drakengard 2. It was my first taste with the franchise And I loved it. The characters and story were there. The english voice acting were ♥♥♥♥ing good too. Then I played 1 and it was my first taste with Yoko Taro's vision. Nier Automata .....disappointing really. Though the soundtrack is amazing again and again. This is still a decent game for pure unadulterated gameplay alone. Which ultimately saves Nier Automata.

												pro+ gameplay (especially the melee fighting) is awesome. i mean, its a platinum title. but it even overshadows metal gear rising and bayonetta!+ atmosphere+ meaningful, big story (got 40hours - have done 85% of all side quests) with many endings (u need to read everything / do all(or at least the most) sidequests etc to get all informations about     the main plot and sideplots)+ THIS SOUNDTRACK OMG+ graphic style (beautiful but sort of depressingly dull, which underlines the whole setting)+ the feels // when u start to care even about non protagonistic characters+ great humor whilst still being serious//con- u get madly overpowered on normal and even on hard if u abuse some dodge chains, use the right plugin chips and max crit weps- could've used less shooting parts (hacking counts as shooting for me)- graphic quality is very muddy in some places- very prone to spoilers - avoid them if u want to play this game!//-> if u like good, philosophical stories - instabuy-> if u like bayonetta, MGR:R or even DMC you should consider buying it (no its not as fast as dmc and it has a "light attack strong attack" mechanic-> only ppl who shouldnt buy r ppl who dont like action based games in my opinion. but even they can buy it and play it on easy while autoplay is enabled (u dont need to fight by yourself and can just watch ur char do all the fighting while getting the story - but in this case a youtube summary or lets play would do it probably too.

												TL;DR - 11/10 will delete saved file again.Came for the design, stayed for the ... Everything.Story - 10/10. It's just so damn well written that it's like reading a book that you never wanted to put down. It's the game that all games should strive to be. Gameplay - 10/10. Nothing felt "off" - that's to say the gameplay needed to be fun, refined, well thought-out first. You can have a great system set in place, but many times after say, at least 30 hours into the game, you start to feel something "wrong" about it. NOT THIS GAME.Music - P E R F E C T. The tiny details in the music swap in different zones, the IMPACT that is delivered in supposed epic scenes, the sadness that is seeped into your heart in the piano/violin. It's not just about having the right music, it's about having right music at the RIGHT TIME.

												NieR: Automata™ is one of the biggest surprises on the year and one hell of a game. It offers a diverse variety of genres in a well-designed title with fluid and dynamic controls and fast-paced action that never stops. Fun and refreshing, looks and plays just like a good made mix of a Devil May Cry game's combat with Final Fantasy JRPG elements in a Final Fantasy game setting and story (Although it's a VERY dark story).On top of that, its full and rich cast of characters and well-set story makes this one of the most interesting games of 2017 and a game that no one should miss out on. A title well deserving of being one of my personal Games of the Year!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
24
												It is not often I am surprised when playing games. Even less so when I go into a game with no expectations at all but is blown away at the sheer quality that exists in the game. NieR:Automata does both of these things, and have so far easily provided me with over 40 hours of entertainment (of which some included quite the frustration).There's not a lot one can say about the game that spoils it, but if you love fluid combat, hack-n-slash, interesting story, New Game+ as well as multiple routes then buy this game and play it. It will most likely not let you down. Just remember to Dash/Evade often and even the most challenging fights will be possible to overcome.Just a few minor notes that are important to mention:- Remember to save often.- A controller is highly recommended.- Dashing/evading doesn't require precise timing.- The unskippable and checkpoint-less prologue is notoriously hard. Remember to dash/evade and take your time. If the prologue is too hard, don't be afraid to lower the difficulty to Easy. You won't lose anything and you can set the difficulty up to Normal after the prologue is complete.- The PC port currently (2017-03-25) experiences a white screen occasionally when the game engine crashes. No community fixes exists yet that solves this to 100%. Hopefully the developers will patch this soon enough.- Use the FAR mod/patch/fix by Kaldaien (see the Steam forums for the game). This fixes fullscreen resolution scaling as well as allows users to lower a graphic setting in the game that tanks the performance on most builds.- Replay the game! The first credit text is only the beginning...

												So... NieR:Automata, also known as 2Butt: The Game. This is a game about a female android with an butt that me and half the Internets would tap all day, erry day, twice on Sundays. When you play this game, listen very carefully and delight in the screams and tears of thousands of femnazis and SJWs as they collectively get told by 'The Man' Yoko Taro exactly what they can do with their opinions. After you play this game, remember to collect the weekly zip of more 2B butt so you don't have to go a further moment without that sweet, sweet butt. Remember to vote 2B for Butt of the Year, All Years(tm) too.Oh, and uh, she apparently has a sword and goes around cutting up these other tin can trash robots while they're trying to have sex... not sure why. Not that it matters however... There's a plot here somewhere, probably involving butt.Wait... It doesn't? What do you mean it... well... That's DUMB! Or is this the so-called often lauded OMG CONTROVERSY!!! I hear about in gaming nowadays? Either way, not sure it's needed... This game already has plenty of controversy! Like for example, do you tap dat butt or do you bounce coins off of it? I mean, I could bounce coins off dat butt ALL. FREAKING. DAY! Drop 'em from a height of 10 feet and it'd be like *poiiiing*... and you could probably aim it at a jukebox or something if you wanted to be cool!Alternatively, you could just tap it like everyone else would. I like my 2B butt like I like my beer: On tap.Now back to your regularly scheduled butt.Damn, dat butt... I freaking swear, I'd tap dat like Tap of the North Star freaking...Out of 10? Sure! Butt/10

content:

												NieR: Automata™ is one of the biggest surprises on the year and one hell of a game. It offers a diverse variety of genres in a well-designed title with fluid and dynamic controls and fast-paced action that never stops. Fun and refreshing, looks and plays just like a good made mix of a Devil May Cry game's combat with Final Fantasy JRPG elements in a Final Fantasy game setting and story (Although it's a VERY dark story).On top of that, its full and rich cast of characters and well-set story makes this one of the most interesting games of 2017 and a game that no one should miss out on. A title well deserving of being one of my personal Games of the Year!

												Beat the first playthrough in 15 hoursThe first playthrough was stunning. I haven't played any games by this developer yet (I have played kingdom hearts from this publisher though, which I never finished but it was amazing and do want to finish it some day), and now I'm a fan. The director admitted to not really doing much for the production of this title (he seems like an amazing guy though), so pretty much all the credit goes to Platinum games, and so far I can't think of a thing about this game to change.The story is beautiful so far, which makes me all the more excited to play the second time for the changes, which is a first for me, because usually I end up stopping after the first playthrough even if the second has more changes (granted, however, these are games where the second playthough only offers a little extra). I'm super excited to see what comes next in this series (if there ever will be more(hopefully!!)) and wanna say great job to Platinum games and square enix. :)

												This game is amazing!This game is probably my favorite game in the last couple of years. The combat is tight and the effects make it look a whole lot cooler. Everything in the game has an immense amount of detail and care poured into it by the developers. The sound in the game is by far the best thing ive heard this year hands down, the way the music tranitions between locations is seamless and the combat music gets you completely pumped. The first time you play the game you will be amazed but every replay adds soo much more, it answers questions of the previous playthrough but leave more to be answered by the other playthroughs.This game always keeps me entertained and I hope it does the same for you.If you are on the fence on wondering if the game is worth the money, I 100% think that this game is worth the money, even though I thought that the day one edition bonuses are dumb.

content:

												This is one of the greatest games I have played in my entire life, the gameplay is rewarding and relies on your own creativity using combos with wapons abilities and attacks against an everchanging variety of enemies. The soundtrack is absolutely amazing creating an atmosphere that pulls you into the games action sequences as well as relaxing or emotional ones. The story is fairly conveluted but easy to follow the basics of it with some events making you think deeply about certain concepts and have a connection with the characters. The only problems I can see are the requirements of a controller as this game is impossible to paly without one and the game isnt too well optimized but still runs fine with the occasional fps dropThis game is also a sequel in a franchise but does not require prior knowledge to understand but if you are more interested in the events prior to the game this story takes place after the events in the games are Drakengard 3 Drakengard 1 and NieR If you are going to purchase this game DO NOT STOP AFTER THE FIRST PLAYTHROUGH, once you have beaten the game you will be given an option to replay with many differences and extra content. This is fun because many things are different but afterwards the story continues onwards leading into the third and fourth parts.

												NieR:Automata did this amazing thing where I was smiling the whole way through. At no point did I feel like I was doing something tedious, nor at any point was I uninterested in what was going on. Each playthrough was unique and fresh. content:

												Before I start with this Review to: NieR:Automata, I want you to know that english isnt my first language. If there are some mistakes. Happens.NieR: Automata is a blabla...I am pretty sure you already read the steamentry to it. So I will just focus on what you cant know as someone, who didnt play the game. I have quite the progress already and I will list the pros and cons down here:Cons:Performance: The Performance is not good. Atleast for me. I am pretty sure the frame stuttering and the tearing in cutscenes is not intended. I recommend checking out the system-requirements and be sure that you hat atleast a bit better then "minimum". (to be fair, I didnt reduce the resolution so everyone should be fine. But there are some problems in cutscenes and really smoky scenes and stuff.)Open world: This game isnt exaclty "open world". You often get blocked by invisible walls or sometimes you also think 2-B is kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. However. "Can I move about terrain and around the world and stuff?" "Yes you can." Can I go everywhere I want to?" "Nope you cant."Resolution: This is something I dont know really if it is intended or not. But I feel like the game is a but "blurry" (?) or something like that. But thats personal. It just feels strange sometimes. Pros:(Holy jesus. There are lots of pros)Soundtrack: The soundtrack is one of the best I have ever heard. Music is personal taste however but the bossfights and all around the world there is just good music. :D2-B and 9-S (The Protagonists):I know, I know. Its pretty standart. The "tough" one which just want to do her duty and her job and the other "sidekick" who does puns and is for the happy feels in conversations. I just really like how they interact with each other and overall the persons.The Battle-System:There is just one word for it. Fluid and clean as f*ck. It just feels so nice to kick roboters around with katanas. This is something you need to experience yourself or on youtube. For me it is very fun and I like it alot. Is it Repetetiv?If you are used to RPGs I dont think so. The camermovement, the pods and sometimes the mechs. Its a nice all around pack. But remember it is an hack `n slash game. So It can get sometimes boring. (Not for me, but I can imagine that) The Bossfights:One of the biggest pros I have on this list. Holy ♥♥♥♥. The boss battles. The only game which comes "nier" to that (kms) is Dark Souls and Final Fantasy. But Nier doesnt need to hide. Especially two bosses at the first 2 hours are amazing. No spoilers here. ^^The Story: I played like 4 hours or something but already got mind♥♥♥♥ed 3-4 times. I am so curious how it will develop itself Oo.2-Bs Butt: Are you suprised? :D (I will continue this review as I progress through the game :))Until here: If you are a fan of RPGs, have a acceptable pc and you like hack n` slash games buy it.

												Now the only reason you might some negative reviews is because of a few launch day bugs/quereys that was quite quickly fixed, for the most part at least. I'm running NierR at the lowest settings and i'm still enjoying the game. I've had a low end pc for a long time and i've gotten used to/not bothered by graphics at all now, and neither should you. The game is a great hack and slash rpg with great a waifu: 2B. I love the combat system in this game and i'm not gonna lie, on pc it might take a little getting used to, but I found myself comfortable with it after the first quest. However, the game does not have a windowed fullscreen mode which is a slight annoyance but a third party program called Borderless Gaming fixed that problem, this may also fix a resolution bug that a couple of people may have. Also note that even though I haven't played the other NieR/Drakengaurd(something like that) I still enjoyed the game. Other than that, its a great game and you should definatly buy :)

												This game is incredible. There's rough edges to be sure, but it grabbed my attention and did not let go.The action is sublime and entirely not the point. Platinum made an incredible combat engine, and combat is far from the most engaging facet of this production. This is a game with a story and a narrative that could not be told in other media. It needed to be a game. Yoko Taro will grab your attention, and refuse to let you look away.If you buy this game, play it to the hilt. Go all in on it.It will reward you.

content:

												TL:DR[Proposal: [In the face of Overwhelming Adversity, Never Surrender!] [Canada]]Review:I'm not going to give you a grand overview on this game.Combat:The combat is fluid and delightful.The long stretches of bullet hell shooting segments can get pretty annoying if you're bad at them like me.The skill system, and customizable combat types are very indepth, and you'll find a playstyle you like.Technical Issues:Fullscreen defaulted game into 4:3 mode without a way to make fullscreen work properly. (Above problem may be fixed in future patch.)Had 1 crash during 40 hours of play. Could not reproduce it.Story:HA. No. You ain't getting nothing from me. It's a perfect story for what it wants to do, and it does it damn well.Final:If a game is about the interaction of a player and content, then this IS a perfect game. You can not replicate it's genius in any other format. It is a perfect game.

												Phenomenal game with an amazing story and soundtrack. Gameplay is a ton of fun, though fighting the same enemies with different skins can get a little old after a while. I highly those who are on the fence give the game a try. The major cons are the long load times (when you actually have to load, which isn't often), the reskinned enemy types, how easy the game gets once you've beat the game (there's no enemy scaling, so even on Hard you'll end up 20+ levels higher than the strongest enemies and your only option is Very Hard which is 1-hit = death), and how jarring the 30 fps cutscenes are after 60 fps gameplay.I absolutely love this game despite those issues and can't recommend it enough.

												Loving the game so far. Some points I want to make:- 4K is only an upscale. Any other resolution is fine. Quite disappointed as I always play at 4K, but probably won't affect the majority of players.- For the first hour, was playing on 4K and the frames froze 3 times while upscaled. Playing at 1440p eliminated the frame freezes. - Not many graphical options. Options that can be changed include: AA, Texture Filter, Blur, Shadows, Effects, Ambient Occlusion. However, not very surprised at this as it's a port from a console.- Haven't tried using a keyboard yet, but definitely recommend using a controler. I'm sometimes pressing 3 - 4 buttons at once or in quick succession.- Soundtrack is definitely up there with the best.All in all, I haven't encountered any other problems besides the infrequent freezing on an upscaled 4K, and is an extremely fun game with, as expected, a really good soundtrack.

												For starters I will say that this is a review for the game, which is fantastic, the port on the other hand is awfull. You should not purchase this if you have mid/low end pc and you might have big problems running it with hardware around the min. reguirements. Mods might help you there.Nier: Automata was a experience more than a game... I haven't played any other Nier games before this so I have missed quite a bit referenced here and there but the game is worth it even if you haven't played any Drakengard or Nier game before. Nier: Automata is a philosophical meta game that distracts you with flashy fights and genre bending game mechanics(It's at least Third person shooter, shoot'em'up, rpg, hack and slash, platformer and spectacle fighter)The story is fine but the characters are so fleshed out that I can't believe it.Where Nier: Automata shines truly is how it studies philosophical consepts about metaphysics and purpose. Although you can reach "happy ending" in the game it still also embraces the fact that purpose, hope etc. are subjective and some people might find reality dark and hopeless, meaningless. Although everyone can find peace in the end if they want to.

												Unlike my other reviews I'm simply at an almost complete loss of words for what to say about this.Despite the port issues, despite combat that while good, can become a slog at times, I can already tell this can likely be my GOTY and 100% in my top 10 games until I die.By all means, this game is a work of art. I'm not typically a person who's too big on the videogames=art thing but, I..I simply do not know how to describe it any other way.A game has never touched me so emotionally and shaken me this much. I got ending E not to long ago (of 26 endings) and I can already tell it's going to be my most fond gaming memory of this year, if not this entire decade.This game should be played at all costs and desevres to be played. You owe it to yourself as a gamer to see this agme through to the end.9/10No game is perfect, and while this game has many personality quirks which will be considered annoying by some, I'm willing to overlook ALL of them to give this game a near perfect score, because I know it's the score this game deserves.

												This is one of the greatest games I have played in my entire life, the gameplay is rewarding and relies on your own creativity using combos with wapons abilities and attacks against an everchanging variety of enemies. The soundtrack is absolutely amazing creating an atmosphere that pulls you into the games action sequences as well as relaxing or emotional ones. The story is fairly conveluted but easy to follow the basics of it with some events making you think deeply about certain concepts and have a connection with the characters. The only problems I can see are the requirements of a controller as this game is impossible to paly without one and the game isnt too well optimized but still runs fine with the occasional fps dropThis game is also a sequel in a franchise but does not require prior knowledge to understand but if you are more interested in the events prior to the game this story takes place after the events in the games are Drakengard 3 Drakengard 1 and NieR If you are going to purchase this game DO NOT STOP AFTER THE FIRST PLAYTHROUGH, once you have beaten the game you will be given an option to replay with many differences and extra content. This is fun because many things are different but afterwards the story continues onwards leading into the third and fourth parts.

content:

												Do not buy the PC version of this game. The game can't actually bet set to run at 1920x1080 (or any widescreen resolution for that matter), instead it creates a distorted 4:3 1440x1080 image like early '00s "anamorphic widescreen" DVDs. That's in addition to horrible frame pacing where the game will constantly stutter and hitch despite technically running at a 60 frames per second average. Of course you will need a 1000 series nvidia card to even get to that level of awful performance in the first place. Cutscenes also have bizarre problems because somehow the team responsible for this port couldn't even get prerendered video to play back properly.It's worth noting that the above problems only become apparent after you solve the even more glaring issues like ambient occlusion and antialiasing being broken (it's 2017 and apparently Platinum doesn't know what FXAA is).If you want to play Nier, get it on PS4. I've heard the base model PS4 experience isn't stellar either but it cannot possibly be worse than this.Bizarre and disappointing since Platinum's last PC port, Metal Gear Rising was, if not excellent, at least entirely competant.

content:

												I've heard only good things about this game for its console release, but so far this seems like a fairly bad PC port.Resolution is upscaled from 900p to your monitors resolution when in fullscreen. There's no way that I can tell to fix this, I guess we have to wait for a hotfix. There is no borderless windowed mode to circumvent this issue. I've seen people saying they're also having weird scaling issues with their game running in 4:3 when set to 1080p.Keyboard + mouse controls are AWFUL. Don't even bother, use a controller. Which leads me to my next point...Only XInput controllers are recognized. This is a port of a PS4 game that doesn't have support for the Dualshock 4. You have to use DS4windows to mimic a 360 controller to play using a DS4. I've heard varying information on the performance, myself not getting past the main menu yet due to the above points. It seems to run fairly well on most high end systems. Note: I know I could use a program to force borderless windowed. But a game should not ship in a state where it requires a third-party application to run it in one of if not the most common resolutions on the market.If these problems don't bother you, the game itself is fantastic. Just read any reviews for the PS4 version. These issues can be circumvented with third-party apps like I said, but I myself find the need for apps to get basic functions working indicitave of lazy developers/porters. If they fix these issues, I won't hesitate to enjoy the game.

content:

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME YET.It's 2017, for ♥♥♥♥'s sake. The PC community has voiced how frustrated they are with the pathetic ports so many times now, and companies still manage to ♥♥♥♥ things up this badly. It's pathetic.I was so excited for this game, and when it finally came out on PC, I booted it up, played a bit and closed it, since I was focusing more on how angry I was at this terribly flawed port than on the experience the game was trying to provide.I've faced a few unacceptable problems in the few minutes that I've spend playing this poor excuse for a port:- There are plenty of resolution options, but as soon as you choose fullscreen, the game goes ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and locks its internal rendering resolution to something like 1600x900 (or maybe even less), playing it windowed fixes it, but it's not something I want to look for 3rd party software to fix, since it's a simple configuration that is very much expected to work flawlessly;- Every single time I press or hold anything on the controller, a mouse cursor pops up in the middle of the screen, as if the game is forcing KB+M configuration at any given moment, further proven by the fact that the control scheme shown is that of a KB+M config, attempting to show me controller configurations whenever I held any button, but alternating quickly between that and keyboard buttons;- Cutscenes have sort of transparent black boxes on the top and bottom of the screen. I'm not sure if this is an intended design decision or poor porting of a "cutscene overlay", but given how some very pathetic things actually went through, I'm not doubting it's just another bug.I am not playing this game any further and will keep my negative recommendation until I see a patch that properly fixes those issues and makes the game flawlessly playable, as it should have been from release. In case we, the paying customers, don't get the product we deserve and paid for in a timely fashion, I'm refunding immediately.

content:

												An amazing game filled with the potential of being a masterpiece. However, like other SE games, Nier comes with the badge of being unfinished and broken. Thankfully the story of this game makes a fascinating plot that uses a quirky way of expanding the limited content of characters, bosses and the world itself in way that extends the game's playtime narratively, as well as changes to the game-play for better or worse. The fashion of how the story is conveyed creates an experience most unlike other games on the market today, an experience that I highly recommend - unlike most Square Enix games. Because of that, I highly recommend waiting for a patch or acquiring the console version due to the PC version being inferior due to bugs, or simply for the negligence of porting the PS4 version to PC and not the PS4 Pro version of Nier. Nier Automata’s cut-scenes are rendered at 900p / 30 frames per second on PC, while on PS4 pro they run at 1080p / 60 FPS. An issue that forces the game to run in different resolutions despite the selected choices in the options menu. However if you run the game in windowed mode, the resolution with be correctly displayed -- in window mode. Third-party fixes are available, which allow borderless window mode. After just finding out a lot of these issue after some decent play-time, I'm a lil' dishearten'd with not being able to leave a full recommendation. Thankfully the game is still playable, enjoyable.

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
19
												I want to start off by saying this game is a very fun concept, I love the idea behind the bullet hell, hack n slash, rpg action game it is. It was fun to start off on Hard, fight some enemies that can 2-3 shot, feel good while dodging, pulling off stylish combos enjoying it for the melee/ranged gameplay it is, much like Bayonetta or DMC. Then it happened. The game just starts one shotting you, now you may say, well that makes the game hard, and it is hard get good scrub etc. I have played every Dark Souls, BloodBorne, Demon's Souls, and many other games considered hard, and very challenging, I've never had problems in those games, because it was fair and challenging, you can learn adapt, play better. This game isn't that, I never had any trouble in hard in this game either, rather, the game just became extremely boring to play. You will end up spamming dodge constantly, rarely getting your licks in with your melee attacks, rather, you will dodge dodge dodge dodge then proceed to shoot them and maybe attack 1-2 times, never really risking the reward of your melee attacks because dying is just frustrating. This was the game for me, I was on hard, it was enjoyable, then it turned into a mess, so I said okay this is just BORING, straight BORING, I'm not really dying to being "bad" rather being impatient and simply bored so I go to attack and dead, so fine I'll just spam shots.So I changed to normal, normal was just as boring because enemies died so fast, so easily, it was not even worth comboing them, just detroying them quickly with a skill and the same thing basically happens, I end up bored. Beyond bored, so bored of "hard" which should be thrilling and turned it down to "normal" to which it was just boring because there was no thrill. There in lies the problem with this game, it is simply boring, the combat is fun, WHEN enemies get stunned and you can actually use it the way as intended. When they don't get stunned, it devolves into a bland repetitive experience where you attack 1-2 times, dodge attack 1 time, dodge attack 1 time dodge, all while holding down your auto attack.Extremely disappointing, the music is fantastic, the animations are amazing, honestly, if you own this game, just attack one time, watch 2b, 9s, a2 recover, it is great, the life they add to the character when they are done with their aerial ground slam, or their 1-2-3-4-5-6 hit combo, it feels great, they don't go back to there normal stance, rather, they slowly recover back into their normal stance. It looks and feels great when you play it. The music gets you hyped for the fight to come, the amusement park theme was one of my favorite because it just felt great to fight in that arena with that music, superb. But, all this is meaningless if I can't hold my own to continue to play because of boredom. The boss fights are fantastic too, playing a bullet hell while then playing a minigame while fighting is great, it flows well, it feels good and all that, in fact, the boss fights are the one thing I am okay in dying in 1 hit and recommending you switch to very hard/ hard on.This game is not bad by any means, in fact, I just don't think it is very fun. If you enjoy the old Nier game, or Drakengard, I am sure you will like this game as the combat is better, but for a game, it is bland and boring and I just can't really accept it as what it is and enjoy it.

												I was very hyped for this game, and I will keep playing it, however I dont think the game is worth of 60 euros.Basic checklistPros:- Combat is amazing- Animations are top notch- Character models are great also- Japanese voice acting is good- Camera position changes are amazing- If you die, you have to retrieve it - Interactions with other players bodies- Boss battlesAnd then the cons, a lot of these are in a lot of JRPG's which is shame.Cons:- Mundane side-quests (Fetch this, get 5 of this, escort this.)- Map is very barren and copy paste everywhere.- Tons of invisible walls.- Lot's of running at start of the game, alter you unlock teleport between savepoints.- No autosave.- Tons of different kind of materials and most of make no sense. Why do I need moose meat to upgrade my weapons?- Graphically enviorement is low quality.- 2B, flat chested bad-♥♥♥ emotioneless android, very used anime trope.- So far (6 hours in) story is nothing to praise about. Might change later.- NPC's personalities are flat.- Non boss combat either you kick enemies ♥♥♥ 100% or you get cheapily stunlocked- Tons of different healing and boost items, good luck navigating them.While yes, I love the combat of this game, its nice when playing in short bursts.If you think pros outweight cons, feel free to grab the game.If you don't wait for a sale some sort, its nowhere near full price on my opinion.

												Yoko Taro and Platinum are back with a masterpiece!This one is a weird one, the gameplay its really good, its mainly hack/slash with rpg elements and mixes a ton of genres in some points of the game, it changes to sidescroller, sidescroll shooter, metroidvania, dungeon crawler and more.The story is weird, but a great one, mixes a lot of serious philosophical things about life and weird Japanese stuff and humor, the soundtrack its just beautiful and epic and the graphics are okay but the word and characters have a great designYeah the game is awesome, gameplay, story, and soundtrack! But... the port its ok with some graphics options, its running a 60fps, having some issues at the cutscenes (30fps) with some weird slowdown, the view distance its awful have a lot of popin. Outside of that its running fine for me (i7-6700k, gtx 1070, 16gb ram) but i heard for some people is having some issues with the fullscreen and the framerate.At this point this kind of hurts me but i cant recommend it for pc at fullprice thanks to the port issues, but if you can get around this issues or get it for ps4 pro or on sale price is a must buy!pd: i really love the game but i dont want to support bad ports on release thats why i will change my review to recomended if this get a patch or after a price drop/sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
21
												Nier is an action RPG telling the story of 2B the android as she fight other robots on Earth along her android buddies. 2B and her side kick might not be the brightest of the bunch, but 2B specifically has one thing which makes her much more powerful than anyone else: a really fancy skirt. She's so protective of it she's even configured it to self-destruct to ensure no one else gets their hands on it.The combat is reminiscent of the gameplay in character action games (Bayonetta, Devil May Cry, etc), but the moveset is smaller, there's a much bigger focus on ranged combat, and you've got a dodge mechanic with an extremely forgiving amount of invincibity frames with no cooldown. The result is unique, fun combat with the downside that it's very easy cheese your way through fights. You can up the difficulty, but the only major difference I could find was that the game drastically increases how much damage the player takes when getting hit, which I don't feel is a fun way to make it challenging.The game will occasionally mix up the gameplay by throwing in some light platforming, different camera angles (which is often more frustrating than novel), and dual-stick shooter sequences. If you experiment with the controls, you'll find some additional moves to mix things up, but I found the combat isn't good enough to stay entertaining for the full duration of the game (if you're a completionist, reaching the first ending can easily take more than 20 hours).The world is fun to explore and there's some neat easter eggs/secrets hidden around, but some of the environments are bland to look at (post-apocalyptic cityscapes aren't very exciting to begin with, but it doesn't help that we've seen this type of landscape in so many other games already). The quest design is one of the weakest parts of the game. Side quests typically ask you to return to area X to kill enemies you've already fought in order to gain item Y. There's even several main story quests with the same design.Where the game really fell apart for me is how tedious it is to get to the final ending. You'll find yourself essentially repeating the entire game with minimal changes. The game tries to mix up the gameplay along the way, but I feel the changes only ended up making the combat worse, and there's no option to choose what type of combat you'd prefer. People who are more invested in the story might have the patience to play through the blatant repetition of content, but I found the structure to add a lot unnecessary tedium.Once you've completed the entire game, you unlock a chapter select feature which presents the story in a different, but far more sensible way. I'm confused as to why it wasn't designed that way to begin with as it would have drastically improved the flow of the game.I wish there was some kind of side-ways thumbs "up" option for Steam reviews as the exploration, combat, music, and a lot of the visual design manage to carry the game quite far despite its flaws. I can imagine some people will be able to look past the flaws if they really like the writing and story telling, or they might be satisfied with the first ending and be okay with stopping there, but overall I was left feeling disappointed by the game.

												I normally don't review games I play, but I felt the need to review NieR: Automata as I purchased this game based on all the great reviews it got and after playing through the first run, I totally disagree. Here are my thoughts; The game isn't bad but it's no where near the great reviews it's getting. Here's why I don't think the game is that great.1- Invisible walls: Some buildings look like they have an open door that look like 100% traversable, but you can't go through them. Same thing in different places. 2- Little to no interaction: There isn't much to interact with in this world, just fight, save and read your email?3- The "complete" campaign forces you to play through and through the game with different characters, with the first play through, I couldn't believe that this was the "end" of the game. 4- Not to spoil the game, but the last boss fight is frustrating to say the least, not fun, just frustrating. 5- Graphics: not that great. 6- Story: Can't really say as I have not completed the other character campaigns, but overall, it's ok but again not as great as what's in the reviews. I enjoyed the fighting mechanics in the game, but that's about it and yes, it does get repetative.
