												Q: Should I play Nier Automata?A: the real question is: have you already played all the games in your list? If yes than you should play NierA friend, once told not to play the new Zelda  as i would never play other games,  here is the same.The last 2 years gave us  games like The Phantom Pain,The Witcher 3,  Rise of the Tomb Rider,  Xenoblade Chronicles, The Talos  Principle,  Zelda, and few others.What i consider the final chapter of this list is Nier, and than there will be the void, unless some surprise show up, read Cyberpunk 2077.I startet gaming on the Vic 20 and commodore 64, writing my own games,  i got mad for Mario and Mike Tyson Punch Out on the NES and California Games on Atari Lynx, and i'm still a gamer, this is my passion and my job, I remember few games of the many i played, but this one i'll remember.Nier has a deep twisted story.Dynamic global illumination never seen before,Combat system that is close to perfectionSome of the best "sub stories"  ever written for a game,The game does something that only FEZ did  at a similar level.and aside from the game there is the soundtrack, that alone, is a reason to buy the game.Yes  I will remember this game you bet i will.

												I feel sorry for the people having issues but it plays like a dream for me. i7 and 980 TI, have the game at max settings. No complaints. Visually and instrumentally a masterpiece. Combat is smooth. Depending on where you are in the level or enemies you are fighting, the game changes from 3rd person behind the shoulder to over the top or a side scrolling game. Which sounds stupid but it is done so flawlessly. I never knew I wanted it.  It's like blending old school arcade games with the action genre that the guys at Platinum about invented. (Looking at you Kamiya.) I guess if you don't have a strong PC you might want to stay away until they fix some of the issues. But if you are confinite in your machine, then I definitely recommend it.

content:

												3/20/17- Turn off Ambient Occlusion! (if you're having fairly extreme pop in issues). Hopefully that advice is short lived, and things are running properly soon.I've only played about 9 hours so this could be considered more of an initial impression:I've been looking forward to NieR: Automata since I saw a trailer for it back in 2015... or more accurately, heard the trailer. I liked the dramatic music it was set to, which reminded me of Ghost in the Shell (and I guess Macross Plus a bit too). Turns out the game also reminds me a bit of Ghost in the Shell... and Macross Plus too, at times. With that said, I'd say the game itself is a big mix of familiar mechanics and story or character tropes... but it's how well it's all mixed together that keeps this game exciting. Even the game's settings get a unique spin to them. The combat also provides hack and slash simplicity and fluidity with a fairly deep customization system. The pods add a decent bit of bad assery as well. There are "specials" sort of like a quick time event... but without the usual excessive slowing of time that makes those more cinematic events less special. So I can appreciate that. I'm playing at normal difficulty so I'm not sure if it'd be different while playing it "easy". I might just not be too skilled but the "normal" difficulty is still pretty tricky, since dying is part of the gameplay, as you learn early on.It is my opinion that the story of this game comes before gameplay and aesthetic polish, but I could see someone arguing that they view the gameplay as the main draw. The art design is really great and so far has been pretty well suited, but the finish is pretty "meh" (invisible walls everywhere)... although sometimes it's due to the shift in style/perspective.So far, the story is cool, well paced, and I find it engaging. If you're into anime, or sci fi, or dystopian / post apocalyptic worlds, or sexy androids, etc, this game is worth picking up. Also if you're into the genre... or perhaps one of the genres this game blends in (adventure, hack and slash, RPG/JRPG, twin stick shooter, side scrolling shooter). The voice acting is good, and you can play with English or Japanese dialogue, which I always appreciate since I think the Japanese VA provides more melodrama. Just know that there will be times when dialogue pops up, mid battle, that you might miss tidbits of, due to not being able to read the subs without dying.

content:
27
												Последний раз я покупаю у подобных долбаебов кривые порты. Вместо того,чтобы фиксить игру, они делают  8-Bit Bayonetta!!!!! Так держать, только всех ПОХУЙ на вашу байонетту, после такого ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥а с NierПройти пролог на харде - как будто пройти целую игру! Охлаждение пукана +1000, как только сделал первый сейв.Многие отзывы конечно преувеличены, да, игра особенная, необычный сетинг, сюжет, отличная боевка, НО  косяков целый вагон (тем более для PC версии ) и они далеко не мелкие: - местами откровенно ужасная графика (спасибо сонсолям), хотя даже для PS4 графоний слабый.  Такое ощущение, что весь ресурс ушел на 2b, да и то,  не такая уж там суперполигонная модель, чтобы сжирать все ресурсы.  Стоит посмотреть на НПС или некоторые объекты, вроде металлических бочек/остатков автомобилей/стены домов и из глаз течет кровь. Если запустить эмулятор PS2 и включить FF XII, там НПС будут выглядеть лучше, чем в Nier. Я далеко не графо♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, до сих пор легко и с удовольствием играю в старые добрые финалки, готику и т.п. Но настолько ужасные полигоны делать нельзя, тем более это не бэкграунт, а вот они, перед носом, ты пробегаешь мимо, забираешься на них и т.д.- откровенно дурацкая градация сложности. Есть легкий режим проходящийся на автомате благодаря чипам, ок.  Есть нормальный режим, с ним понятно. Есть сложный режим, что же в нем отличается? Да только то, что урон по персонажу увеличивается в разы, при этом сами враги остаются такими же ватными. Т.е. играя на сложном, кроме входящего в тебя урона, сложности ты не замечаешь. Рядовые враги все так же кладутся за 2-3 секунды, драться с ними просто скучно и неинтересно. Дополнительную легкость игре придает то, что с тобой бегает еще один андройд... Итого игра автоматически в 2 раза легче, что печалит. При этом пролог такие надежды подавал на игру, т.к. там ты был один. Но после него вас уже 2-е и игра становится в 2 раза легче. + можно поднимать погибших игроков которые будут драться за твою сторону + куча бафающих, пусть и на короткое время, итемов + сильно повышающийся с каждым грейдом оружия урон. Короче, явно перебор, казуальщиной прет за версту. Единственное, что от вас требуется, это вовремя нажимать уворот, которым можно спастись ОТ ЛЮБОГО снаряда/удара/каста и т.п. (привет DS и его перекаты)- невидимые стены... это вообще фейспалм. Бегаете вы по развалинам города, вокруг серые низкопалегонные коробки домов. В некоторые из них можно залезть, но как правило это видно по большим дыркам в этажах. В остальные же БОЛЬШИЕ проходы/арки/дырки/ пройти тупо нельзя! втф? Перед вами дверной проем в который одновременно могут войти как минимум 3 андройда, НО ВЫ НЕ МОЖЕТЕ В НЕГО ВОЙТИ, там просто невидимая стена. И это бред, для 2017 года это полнейший бред. Такие места нужно закалачивать/перекрывать/завал какой то делать (ну завалы есть иногда).  -открытый мир на самом деле представляет собой кишку, просто чуть шире, чем в обычных играх, и толку от лишнего пространства никакого, т.к. в основном это тупо полянки с травой/земля и т.п.  Да, в некоторые места вы можете пойти сразу, без бумаг/пропусков и прочего, но враги там банально на 20-30 лвл выше, следовательно делать вам там просто нечего.- во время обычных диалогов ни персонажи, ни нпс не шевелят губами, да что там, у них вообще никакой мимики нет на лице! При этом иногда идет озвучка... Такое себе- некоторые текстуры прогружаются прямо перед тобой! Это ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ товарищи. Возможно это такая оптимизация, или это сделано специально для консолей, чтобы они хотя бы могли 50-60 фпс вытянуть, не знаю. Но когда в играх с подобной графикой происходит такое, это очень печалит. При чем это не знависит от конфигурации вашего пс, у людей с gtx 1080 те же просадки фпс и прочие глюки.

content:

												I'm happy with this game so far.Pros:+ No major technical issues (it supports 21:9 resolutions and I'm getting actually good performance with GTX 1080 @ 3440x1440).+ The game itself is very unique (I got the feeling that abandoned Earth feels more "alien" than supposedly alien planets in Mass Effect: Andromeda) and the plot is enjoyable.+ It has a really great soundtrack. Sometimes I just sit there and listen to music instead of continuing to play further.Cons:- Minor technical issues (1. You need to use "Borderless Gaming" application to run the game in borderless fullscreen mode; 2. Normal fullscreen mode isn't working properly with screen resolutions above 1920x1080 at this moment; 3. Ambient Occlusion may cause texture/mesh pop-ins in some areas).- Since it's a console port, there's a good chance that you'll find this game less enjoyable if you use a keyboard.This review is a subject to change. However, I don't think that my impressions will change drastically.P.S. Why didn't I say anything about the gameplay? Well, because I don't want to spoil things, and because it's a story-driven game. If you expect a braindead diablo-like slasher where you can mute the game and talk to your friends on some voice-chat while playing, you will be disappointed. Don't get me wrong: gameplay is fun and engaging, but (most of the time) you don't kill things to kill even more things in NieR. You do it to continue the story.

content:

												3/20/17- Turn off Ambient Occlusion! (if you're having fairly extreme pop in issues). Hopefully that advice is short lived, and things are running properly soon.I've only played about 9 hours so this could be considered more of an initial impression:I've been looking forward to NieR: Automata since I saw a trailer for it back in 2015... or more accurately, heard the trailer. I liked the dramatic music it was set to, which reminded me of Ghost in the Shell (and I guess Macross Plus a bit too). Turns out the game also reminds me a bit of Ghost in the Shell... and Macross Plus too, at times. With that said, I'd say the game itself is a big mix of familiar mechanics and story or character tropes... but it's how well it's all mixed together that keeps this game exciting. Even the game's settings get a unique spin to them. The combat also provides hack and slash simplicity and fluidity with a fairly deep customization system. The pods add a decent bit of bad assery as well. There are "specials" sort of like a quick time event... but without the usual excessive slowing of time that makes those more cinematic events less special. So I can appreciate that. I'm playing at normal difficulty so I'm not sure if it'd be different while playing it "easy". I might just not be too skilled but the "normal" difficulty is still pretty tricky, since dying is part of the gameplay, as you learn early on.It is my opinion that the story of this game comes before gameplay and aesthetic polish, but I could see someone arguing that they view the gameplay as the main draw. The art design is really great and so far has been pretty well suited, but the finish is pretty "meh" (invisible walls everywhere)... although sometimes it's due to the shift in style/perspective.So far, the story is cool, well paced, and I find it engaging. If you're into anime, or sci fi, or dystopian / post apocalyptic worlds, or sexy androids, etc, this game is worth picking up. Also if you're into the genre... or perhaps one of the genres this game blends in (adventure, hack and slash, RPG/JRPG, twin stick shooter, side scrolling shooter). The voice acting is good, and you can play with English or Japanese dialogue, which I always appreciate since I think the Japanese VA provides more melodrama. Just know that there will be times when dialogue pops up, mid battle, that you might miss tidbits of, due to not being able to read the subs without dying.

content:

												Последний раз я покупаю у подобных долбаебов кривые порты. Вместо того,чтобы фиксить игру, они делают  8-Bit Bayonetta!!!!! Так держать, только всех ПОХУЙ на вашу байонетту, после такого ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥а с NierПройти пролог на харде - как будто пройти целую игру! Охлаждение пукана +1000, как только сделал первый сейв.Многие отзывы конечно преувеличены, да, игра особенная, необычный сетинг, сюжет, отличная боевка, НО  косяков целый вагон (тем более для PC версии ) и они далеко не мелкие: - местами откровенно ужасная графика (спасибо сонсолям), хотя даже для PS4 графоний слабый.  Такое ощущение, что весь ресурс ушел на 2b, да и то,  не такая уж там суперполигонная модель, чтобы сжирать все ресурсы.  Стоит посмотреть на НПС или некоторые объекты, вроде металлических бочек/остатков автомобилей/стены домов и из глаз течет кровь. Если запустить эмулятор PS2 и включить FF XII, там НПС будут выглядеть лучше, чем в Nier. Я далеко не графо♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, до сих пор легко и с удовольствием играю в старые добрые финалки, готику и т.п. Но настолько ужасные полигоны делать нельзя, тем более это не бэкграунт, а вот они, перед носом, ты пробегаешь мимо, забираешься на них и т.д.- откровенно дурацкая градация сложности. Есть легкий режим проходящийся на автомате благодаря чипам, ок.  Есть нормальный режим, с ним понятно. Есть сложный режим, что же в нем отличается? Да только то, что урон по персонажу увеличивается в разы, при этом сами враги остаются такими же ватными. Т.е. играя на сложном, кроме входящего в тебя урона, сложности ты не замечаешь. Рядовые враги все так же кладутся за 2-3 секунды, драться с ними просто скучно и неинтересно. Дополнительную легкость игре придает то, что с тобой бегает еще один андройд... Итого игра автоматически в 2 раза легче, что печалит. При этом пролог такие надежды подавал на игру, т.к. там ты был один. Но после него вас уже 2-е и игра становится в 2 раза легче. + можно поднимать погибших игроков которые будут драться за твою сторону + куча бафающих, пусть и на короткое время, итемов + сильно повышающийся с каждым грейдом оружия урон. Короче, явно перебор, казуальщиной прет за версту. Единственное, что от вас требуется, это вовремя нажимать уворот, которым можно спастись ОТ ЛЮБОГО снаряда/удара/каста и т.п. (привет DS и его перекаты)- невидимые стены... это вообще фейспалм. Бегаете вы по развалинам города, вокруг серые низкопалегонные коробки домов. В некоторые из них можно залезть, но как правило это видно по большим дыркам в этажах. В остальные же БОЛЬШИЕ проходы/арки/дырки/ пройти тупо нельзя! втф? Перед вами дверной проем в который одновременно могут войти как минимум 3 андройда, НО ВЫ НЕ МОЖЕТЕ В НЕГО ВОЙТИ, там просто невидимая стена. И это бред, для 2017 года это полнейший бред. Такие места нужно закалачивать/перекрывать/завал какой то делать (ну завалы есть иногда).  -открытый мир на самом деле представляет собой кишку, просто чуть шире, чем в обычных играх, и толку от лишнего пространства никакого, т.к. в основном это тупо полянки с травой/земля и т.п.  Да, в некоторые места вы можете пойти сразу, без бумаг/пропусков и прочего, но враги там банально на 20-30 лвл выше, следовательно делать вам там просто нечего.- во время обычных диалогов ни персонажи, ни нпс не шевелят губами, да что там, у них вообще никакой мимики нет на лице! При этом иногда идет озвучка... Такое себе- некоторые текстуры прогружаются прямо перед тобой! Это ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ товарищи. Возможно это такая оптимизация, или это сделано специально для консолей, чтобы они хотя бы могли 50-60 фпс вытянуть, не знаю. Но когда в играх с подобной графикой происходит такое, это очень печалит. При чем это не знависит от конфигурации вашего пс, у людей с gtx 1080 те же просадки фпс и прочие глюки.

												I have only played about 2 and a half hours of this game.  I might be biased because I am a huge fan of how it looks, how it plays and how good looking 2B is.I started this game up with the expection that it would run terrible and that I would end up refunding it.  I was wrong.  Most of the people on here are people with outdated computers, complaining about how "bad" the game is.  I will give you one thing, for a game with an AAA price, it should be better at launch - but all of that aside, the game is absoulutely beautiful, it plays phenomenally, and the soundtrack is a masterpiece.The game does have its issues, sometimes I can't click on menus and have to use enter, etc.  Sometimes when I launch chrome or discord it makes my character move all by itself.  This might be due to it thinking im doing something on my second monitor, but who knows.  I am running this game on a MSI GTX 1080 FTW 8GB, Intel i7-6700k, 16gb ddr3 ram, and an SSD for loading times and the only problem I have had was with the 1 frame fps drops when going into a new area which is understandable.  My settings are all maxed and still run a solid 60.I saw people complaining about how they're bothered by the fact that the cutscenes are in 30fps.  Some games such as 'For Honor' had the same "laggy" cutscenes, and I havent seen people talking about that.  If SE/Platinum fixes the fullscreen glitches and the anti-aliasing problems, we should be just fine.   WARNING BEFORE BUYING:   - The game is pseudo open world, meaning that its open world but you can't go into every building on the map, etc.  - The map is HUGE, been playing for 3 hours and only have seen 1/30th of map.    - Auto Save is not a feature in this game, you have to find places to save in game.    - There are 26 endings in this game, DO NOT stop playing after the first credit screen.Overall, this is an amazing game and I can recommend this to anybody, it isnt worth the amount they are charging and if you want you can wait for the sale in a couple weeks/months.

content:

												This is the most infuriating game I've ever played and none of those reasons are for the gameplay.First every single one of the cutscenes in the game is 1600 x 904, compressed in MPEG1 at FORTY megabits. Thats an abomination right there. If you've ever had stuttering in this game, thats why, your computer was trying to load this huge bloated uncompressed MPEG1 files, a video standard introduced in 1993 thats just as outdated as WINDOWS 3.1.Then the game has NO SAVE POINTS for the first part of the game at all, now that wouldn't be too bad but the first part of the game varies WIDLY in performance. So if say the game crashes, tabs wrong(it always tabs wrong, do not alt tab this game), you forgot to read the "This game doesn't have autosaves" disclaimer and shut it off, or you don't feel like playing for over an hour after you've already spent FOUR HOURS fighting with the games ancient MPEG1 FILES and horrible performance issues, or you die. Thats it, WELCOME TO THE VERY BEGGINING OF THE GAME.Now I wouldn't have too much trouble with the Save issue if the game just worked, IT DOES NOT, this is an abomination of a PC port the likes of which I've seldom seen, these cutscenes are huge, just doing some fairly basic compression on them brings down their size by half and solved all my cutscene stuttering problems with the game. But the game wasn't done yet and I had to deal with other issues involving performance and fiddling with settings INSIDE OF A FIGHT, and because there ARE NO SAVE POINTS FOR THIS PART OF THE GAME, I can't just throw the fight and get my settings right first time, no I have to go through the ENTIRE INTRODUCTION AGAIN if I ever exit out of it for ANY REASON WHATSOEVER.Then there is the huge amount of fiddling and tedium I had to go with this game in order to get it to run properly, first the cutscenes. They suck, they're horribly HORRIBLY uncompressed and actually cause performance issues and even doing a quick hack job fix with re-encoding them in a basic and fast way cut their size down by over half. Then the game constantly ran into performance issues while running and I had to get somebody else's performance fix to un-break the game's broken lighting system which was about half of the game's performance problems right then and there. Keep in mind every time I test one of these things I have to do the same introduction shooter segment again in order to get to a point in the game where performance is actually an issue, EVERY SINGLE TIME, because the game doesn't save and doesn't allow you to save.So what game time you see that I have is the same things again and again and again, the first time it was fun, the third time it was tiring, the fifth time it crashed and I had to do that shooter segment again was too much. This game has infuriated me more than any other game I've ever known, and I've played CS:GO with Vsync on against other players.TL:DR: The game is a poor PC port that more or less requires you to re-encode all the cutscenes in the game yourself, implement 3rd party fixes for the needlessly intensive lighting system, doesn't let you save while you're doing this so you have to play the same scene over and over to finally find out of you've fixed all its problems, then it won't let you save for the next hour or so. I hate this game so much for all that.

TL;DR
Not recommended until the main issues are fixed.Main issues : fullscreen bug, performance issues, shader issues, clipping.This is sold at full AAA price and should be held up to AAA standards. For now this is barely a 30$ port.Too many issues to even call this a lazy port.I wonder how blocking pirates for 2 weeks is going to help sales if this kind of broken product is released. Devs would have been better off spending these 10 days working on the port instead of implementing Denuvo.PC Port IssuesFullscreen bugAs of now (17th march), the game cannot be played in fullscreen as it doesn't show up in the chosen resolution. It even pixellises the steam overlay. You can either play in windowed mode or use a 3rd party program to go pseudo-fullscreen (borderless windowed).Testing setupPretty strong pc ; i7-6700k, 16GB DDR4 RAM, GTX 1080Windowed mode, 1440p, no v-sync, AA x8, texture filtering x16, everything else the highest possiblePlaying with wired Xbox 360 controllerPerformance reportGame is locked at 60 fps.No performance issues during gameplay, but I have a strong PC so you might want to check other reviews.Horrendous stuttering in cutscenes. (~10-15 fps)Pros+ Not locked at 30 fps+ Runs at 60 fps most of the time+ No screen tearing without v-sync nor g-sync (no g-sync because no fullscreen)+ Controls can be rebound (even for your controller! nice surprise)Meh* Not possible to go over 60 fps (I have a 144 hz monitor :/ )* Can select up to 4k but bigger resolutions are not fully supportedCons- Fullscreen displays in wrong resolution bug- Performance issues, lower resolution and strong aliasing in cutscenes- Weird aliasing on most meshes even with AA x8- Shader issues causing heavy aliasing on models (chunks of pixels "taken off" the mesh + blur ; ie the giant boss with crane arms that was in the demo), mainly the sky shaders- Clearly noticeable clipping in open world- Shadow resolution is subpar- UI/menu/texts have a fixed resolution so they appear blurry in resolutions over 1080pThe game itselfPros+ Impressive character design and modelling work on main characters+ High quality gameplay animations (meh for cutscenes)+ Gameplay is fun and varied+ RPG elements are interesting and pretty open (you are not forced into 1 fighting style and can change pretty much anytime)+ Music is top qualityMeh* Not a fan of the character design of most enemies* Not a fan of the english voice actors so far and it feels like there is something wrong with the voice recording qualityCons- PC port- Denuvo (might cause performance issues and leave files behind even after uninstalling the game)- Pretty terrible environment models and textures (~ mid PS3). I didn't expect the devs to fix this for the pc port but damn I have seen better looking indie games with similar map sizes.

content:

												Well where to begin. I initially gave this a poor rating because it runs poorly, but now that I've played through the entire first storyline I'll actually review it. Pros:-Fluid combat-Complicated backstory-ButtsCons:-Some textures are honestly awful.-60 fps cap-Plagued with technical issues that I haven't experienced but many others have-The game runs like crap for how bad it looks. I get higher average frame rates in Rise of the Tomb Raider and that game is much more visually impressive.-Lack of combat depth. Its very fluid but you're limited to 4 weapons and no real combos. Nothing intricate-Basically zero enemy variety. They're all a mod of the regular robot, you get big ones, bigger ones, really big ones, flying ones, and weird dinosaur shaped ones, and thats basically it. Sometimes you get shooty ones.-For a game that relies so much on story it's annoying you have to play through the game again to see it from 9S's perspective.-The world is really pretty small and feels pretty dry-There are no interesting characters outside of the ones interacted with in the main story-The twist isn't surprising at all-Basically everything besides the main story feels like tacked on garbage, I mean its Ubisoft go here do this/escort/random meaningless crap in the open world but instead of interacting with likeable characters you are interacting with machines who have voices that will drive you insane.Uncertain:-The music is ♥♥♥♥ing weird. Its good in that it fits the game but bad as in its a pain to listen to. Honestly this game feels like it should have been a movie or a book. Being a game actively detracts from the narrative and makes the story less enjoyable overall. If you are into this game just for the story I would definitely recommend it. Skip most of the side missions as they are a waste of time.If you want a game with meaningful gameplay elements I would say to pass on this one. Original Review: (Still true)Runs and looks like garbage, another ♥♥♥♥ pc port.Can't hold 60fps on a gtx 1070 in 1440p

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
21
												First thing is first. I've played Nier: Automata for just over 4 hours. This is not a review of the full game experience, it is a "so-far" review. I don't usually write reviews, and I have certainly never written a review before finishing a game before. But then, I've never played a game as frustrating as this one.And that's not because of the gameplay, which so far is pretty solid DMC-meets RPG lite-open world fare. The machine enemies are really great. They have more character than pretty much any protagonist in any game I've played in recent years. So far, 2B fares much less well. Mostly tells people to shut up. She shuts down any interesting conversation before it gets going. Because of that, 9S is more endearing to me so far as he likes to ask real questions about what he knows of the world and why he is there. As the game is I can't wait to play more of it to find out what the machines will be doing next to make me question the nature of humanity, communication and emotions. Unfortunately that brings me onto the real reason I am writing this review.System specs out of the way first:i7 6700k (stock clocks)GTX 970 Gigabyte G1 Gaming16GB 3000mhz RAMWindows 10Installed on a 7200RPM 1TB hard drive (NOT SSD)GPU driver 378.92 installedNow the first thing is the well known "Fullscreen bug". This bug essentially causes the game to render inaccurately on your monitor causing a black border all around the screen along with squashed text. The output is reported as 1080i. This greatly reduces the fidelity of the game and makes it much more difficult to play. You may have seen a fix called "Borderless Gaming" which is a seperate app that forces the game to run in a full borderless window and sidesteps this issue. This works fine. However I find it unacceptable. The only other game I have had to use a seperate app to get it to render appropriately was Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition. No gamer should have to download a 3rd party app just to access a game they've purchased.The second problem I have with this game is stuttering. Now I don't know if this is because I am using a dinosaur Hard drive, but while traversing the world it hitches pretty regularly. Combat isn't really affected but it dampens the experience somewhat. The animations are pretty good and very fluid. This just breaks that.The third, and the most grievous problem I've had is the screen freezing issue. In this game it randomly freezes the image on the screen while the game continues to play out in the background. You can hear characters moving around and hear the menus etc, but so far I have been unable to remedy this problem without restarting the game. Now sometimes games freeze. I can accept that as a PC gamer. The real problem here is how the save system works. You are unable to save until completing the tutorial/opening area (this took me 50 minutes) and even after that you can only save at old fashioned save points. There are no automatic checkpoints. This means saves every time you see an oppurtunity in case the game crashes and progress is lost. This is the killer for me that has convinced me to wait to play the game until it's fixed. Although save points are plentiful in some areas, there is a complete lack of them in others.A final word performance wise. Settings at 1080p, high except shadows which are medium. AO off, AA off. I get a solid 60fps (except those stutters I mentioned) and it's mostly fine. It doesn't look great. It looks a bit like a jazzed up last gen game unfortunately, but it is enough to convey the world appropriately so I'm not going to complain too much.Hopefully when some of the issues with this port are fixed I can revise this review and give it a recommended, which I would happily do if it just worked.TL:DR: This game has great promise from what I have played. The port is rubbish. Wait until fixed.

												Very poor performance ie. low frame rate.  A third-party mod improves this but cutscenes can still plummet to 30FPS.  Oddly, they appear to be downscaling the resolution when this occurs as well (pixellation visible).  No borderless window mode.Buggy.  Running in dedicated fullscreen results in the image being stretched lengthways.  Changing graphics settings such as ambient occlusion causes the game to slow down to 10FPS, or causes the screen to go blank.  Occasionally, you can change a setting without the game breaking.Odd, unintuitive, unresponsive controls.  In the shooter sequences the heavy attack frequently failed to activate or cut right through an enemy while dealing no damage.  In the turret-mode sequences one cannot aim with the mouse; you have to use the WASD keys.  I gave up and just spammed heavy attack.  Dodge cannot be rebound; it's double-tap WASD or nothing - and that's too slow to be useful.In short, unplayable.  Pop it on your wish list and give it 6 months for fixes (or further mods) to be released and hopefully turn it into a functional product.Specs:i7 3930K @ 4.2GHz16RAMGeforce GTX 970 4GMWindows 10 Pro

I recommend this game.  It's a fun, hectic hack 'n' slash and just what I wanted out of the first 40 minutes.I do not recommend purchasing it if your PC does not readily exceed the "recommended" specs by a great amount, and even then you will likely have to step down your resolution a few steps from what you're used to/your native resolution.  The game has some kind of niggling issue with optimization that the specs in the store page do not account for.  This is not related to MSAA, either.Because of the fact that people will be misled into purchasing a game that they cannot run well or cannot run at all due to technical issues, I am forced to give this game a thumbs down.  I will revise this review on any sort of patch, but as of posting this is the fourth day with no infomation from the developers about technical fixes.  It kills me to do this, but I can't recommend this title in good faith in its current state.

content:

												Edit: After finishing the game, I must say this is one of my favorite games of all times, it does such special and unique things which I clearly do not want to spoil here. I think few games ever managed to make me feel like this one did. Honestly I can not think of a person who would not be better of making this experience in their life, even if in the end they might hate it (which I think most won't). A masterpiece.Ok so this is just a short review: First of all the game runs with 100% stable 60 fps at 1440p (GTX1070) for me and I had no resolution bugs or whatsoever in my entire playtime so far! The gameplay (mashup of twinstick, sidescroller and mostly(!) 3rd person action shooter/brawler mix ala Vanquish meets Bayonetta + partially open world RPG) is fun and engaging and the story and the way it is told really is something special!I am playing on hard difficulty, and besides the introduction section the game is fairly easy to play on hard, thx to an amazing doding mechanic, which unlike bayonetta does not require ultra precise timing to work. This is perfectly ok, as the game was designed around being one or twoshot, which requires you to be able to dodge a lot more reliable.I would highly recommend this game to gamers of ANY skill, as the easy mode literally allows (optionally) the game to play itself, even partially if wished for, great for gamers who only want to witness the world and story or have diabillities!(As a side Note: I actually really enjoyed the initial challenge and design of the introduction a lot and might have wished for more of that during the game as the RPG elements do tend to be fun but create an entirely different experience which is not as challenging and fast paced, but sometimes rather relaxing and meditative due to the great soundtrack and rather slow pacing in most parts of the open world. Also the abundance of healing items (you can literally carry up to 400 in your inventory at once, making oneshots the only threat) is maybe not othe best design decision for a higher difficulty setting, which is probably why very hard only consists of oneshots. As I do believe it is highly unrealsitic that everythign onshots you in this game, it does take away a lot of the immersion for me, and I like the partial oneshot approach of hard a lot more, but having less healing available would be nice.)I will update this review once I "finished" the game some more.SLIGHT SPOILER ALERT, read AFTER beating the game (you might miss out on a lot if you do not do what I "spoil" here): Press continue after the games ending, seriously do it.

Any ways good game, ending upset me, and upset that the majority of the game is in new game plus.

												A combination of my 2 favorite Platinum Games titles, Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance and Bayonetta. The game is primarily a hack and slash with very lite RPG elements. The reason I say "primarily" is because the game shifts between hack and slash to bullet hell shooter to platformer seemlessly. At the time of this review, there are a few technical issues but not entirely game breaking depending on your rig. This game seems to be hit or miss depending on your setup. I have a GTX1080ti, AMD FX-9590, and 16 GB RAM and I get constant 60. It also ran smooth with a GTX 1060 for me. I have heard people with less powerful rigs running it smoother than those with powerful rigs. If you can get it to run smmothly, it's a great game.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
22
												This game is a hit and miss for me on spectacular levels in either direction. Firstly I really like the elegant look of the characters(even besides erotic!), the soundtrack is good and memorable, the game looks pretty good, the mechanics are interesting, the atmosphere is very consistent and invokes a feeling of near constant dread. But most of all it is it's presentation and flawless transition between sidescrolling and third person(the camera work is really something in this game).On the other hand it's way too much anime-ish for my liking. The plot is okay and unforgiving(without further spoilers), the characters are painfully predictable and generic - which brings me back to point one: it's exactly like watching an anime - you just know what's going to happen in each dialogue that comes by because the character's motives are as flat as one characterizing trait that intermittently gets broken/softened. I don't really mind the concept of having a bombshell female character in the lead but the game's kinda pushing it too much in my face for my liking(other people praying it'd be as literal as formulated). The controls, at least for keyboard and mouse, are awkward. The combat is alot of fun, but very inaccurate for it's clearly a console port. The game is, besides the initial impression being very different, actually rather easy. The story counts more plotholes than I can keep track of, but is still legitimately surprising on more than several occasions(I wouldn't dare say it's as good as others do - but as far as it keeping you glued to the game it does a really good job). The main writer made a serious effort to overcomplicate it by messing with the order in which it plays out - which to me feels a bit pretentious considering the initial story(and it's "explanation") are very weak.Overall it's a very unique game, with excellent design and sounds, that's an awful lot of fun to play with a twisted pulp story that doesn't fail to surprise.

												This game is immediately everything I've ever wanted in a game. (2 hours played)EDIT: Now for a real review, after ~13 hours played.Music: ♥♥♥♥ing awesome.Designs: God damn.Environments: Beautiful.Story: Anime/10. I love the setting so much that the actual story is superfluous to me. Its got some nice themes, and a surprising amount of clever elements, but little actual depth from what I've seen. Might change as i experience more endings.Gameplay:I can easily see this becoming monotonous or grindy to a lot of people, but its interwoven into the story quite nicely, and the experience is actually just genuinely fun. A younger me wouldve probably ragequit a few times, but the variety of skills needed just to progress in this game (assuming youre playing on hard or above) keeps it interesting pretty constantly. I especially love the save system, but I can see why some might hate it. The plugin system is pretty refreshing too; the fact that UI isnt changed by settings, but by loadout and character progression, is really cool. Haven't had any performance issues, but I've only played it on powerful hardware. Have only really played it with an XBox controller, but the keyboard and mouse integration seems to be well done. However, the gameplay skills used in this game are virtually all designed around using a controller.Fullscreen is a bit wonky, but I suspect this varies highly depending on your hardware. 1080s have had displayport issues. Shiftwindow is definitely recommended software for this game, if you play above 1920*1080.

content:

												I am a mouse and keyboard player, and for 60€ I do expect good controls. I don't expect them to be as good as a controller, but they should be at least plausible and follow some canvation. The thing is, they are almost there, there are just two main things that really bug me and I don't even think they are that hard to change.First of all the dodging done via double tapping a directional key. There is literally no good reason why you would do something like this. In a game that requires fast reaction, doing this is just sloppy and unresponsive. What really astounds me is that this was a conscious decision by someone, as it's harder to implement a double tap, then literally just a single button. Somebody thought this was a good idea, no it isn't, we have more than enough buttons, and this game doesn't require that many in the first place.Second, the third person camera, the camera perspective that you use most of the time. It's damn annoying that it is constantly trying to "correct" your perspective. If you run forward then it's trying to swing your camera in that direction, the same with any other direction, or if a enemy attacks. With the mouse this "feature" is not needed, I can be my own camera man just fine (and I am not talking about the different camera perspective shifts, they are fine and fun). It is just annoying that I constantly need to countermotion the camera to keep a overview over a bettle, this just don't makes things better, but the opposite, much worse. The thing I am asking here are just some IF statements, so we can just disable it.That's it, this two things would make the controls hugely better and almost as good as a controller. I be honest, I don't think this is much to ask, as I don't think it is that hard to implement. A competent programmer should be able to do it fairly quickly. Harder to fix is the hacking minigame, but I never found them that hard, so I am fine with them.As it stands it's a great game, with grand philosophical questions (less escort missions would been nice thought), and I am happy to see that this games start to come out on pc. But with this problems I just can't recommend it.

												This steam review consists of mostly port related issues and certain design choices which pretty much made me not want to continue playing, at all.Well, first of all, the controls. The game jumps in and out of many different control schemes. 2D, 3D, space shooter... side scroller... it goes in and out of everything, yet most of them control terribly with KB/M. Basically every time you have to manually move the camera or manually target your bullets along with moving, the mouse control hinders you."It's not the kind of game that works well with kb/m" you might think. That's objectively false. Almost every single aspect of it could have worked fine if they had made it properly, as it's mechanics taken right out of other games, and they work fine with kb/m. They simply gave it the middle finger.While on the subject of kb/m, there is no dedicated kb/m dodge button, making the combat way harder than it should be. Even the double tap they have is not responsive.Next on the list, performance. It stutters on my system (specs at the bottom), a lot. Not even for a second the game felt as if it was running smoothly during the hack'n'slash sections. Weirdly enough, during the shooter sections it works fine, but during the grounded sections it feels like a chore.Gameplay wise, I can't say I'm impressed either. It was just boring smacking these tiny little robots. Not because of the size or skill required, but it was closer to me rubbing my literal sword on them than trying to slash them. It felt bland, very very bland.And finally, on the matter of design choices, getting past the intro of the game itself is just a test of nerves. The game attempts a mixure of Souls-like deaths, meta-game endings and bullet-hell "do it all again, no mid saves" mentality, which translates to the size of 2-3 "levels" as a tutorial, and if you die you start from the beginning, not even skipping real-time cutscenes and dialogue. Honestly, this annoyed me the most. I ended up skipping like half of the enemies in the intro just because I was getting tired of it and wanted to save my progress. Again, that was just the intro of the game, and just that made me dislike my experience with it. Combine that with all the issues above and there was no way I could have opened the game again after that.CPU: AMD FX8350GPU: GTX 1070RAM: 16gbOS: win 64bitGame running from an SSD.All drivers up to date.

content:

												Unplayable on Mouse and KeyboardNow, let me preface this by saying. Yes, I am aware that this, along with most spectacle fighters, are primarily supposed to be played on controller. Yes, I know Japanese games' checkered histories with PC port. I have successfully managed to play Dark Souls on keyboard and mouse, so I have a pretty good tolerance for this sort of thing.I'm also not going to get into the obvious graphical issues (clear upscaling, 4:3 resolution(the FAR fix didn't work for me), etc)I get a pretty bad feeling from the very beginning when the settings menu doesn't include any keybinding(Instead it's in a "Controls" section that you find with each save). In addition, menus are designed so that as long as you have your mouse hovering in the screen and not out of it, when you try to scroll using the mouse wheel, it is stuck to whatever you're hovering over. Then I get into the game itself. Ho boy. The default controls are a mess; very odd buttons all around, but nothing keybinding can't fix. For some reason the PC version has no evade button while the controller does? I don't even...In the twinstick shooter sections, it seems like the mouse has to act exactly like an analogue stick. So when you try to move in one direction, it tries to override you to point in that direction, unless you keep on moving the mouse to the other direction. No aiming reticule or anything to show where your cursor is, either.Camera control in third person is just abysmal as well. It's struggling just to move the camera, and there's no lock function like in Dark Souls. And again, no evade button - instead you doubletap keys. So I'm pretty damn frustrated, and I go to try and fix this a little in keybinding. And there's the final straw - you can't rebind your mouse controls. Only keyboard. Frankly, this is ridiculous. I expected some clumsy controls, maybe lack of mouse support in menus, but this is just unplayable on keyboard and mouse. I'll give the game a week or two to see if they come out with a patch(or a mod fix), and if not, I'm refunding the game, which is a shame, because I was very excited for this title.

content:
18
												----EDIT------After having the game crash several times on me, I decided to set the game to its default settings. After some testing, I found that turning on AA was the primarly cause of the issues stated below. There are still dead zones when using the mouse to control the camera, but the game is actually playable now. Some conclusions from turning off AA:-applying 2x AA multiplies the deadzone by a factor of 2, approximately-higher AA settings do the same-keyboard inputs are significantly more responsive when AA is off-texture filtering might have the same issues as AA----------------------------------------------------------------------------ORIGINAL POST----Keyboard and mouse controls for this port are genuinely ♥♥♥♥ing awful. If you do not have a gaming pad, do not buy this game.Explanation for kb+m:It seems like the game attempts to simulate the mouse as the analog stick (why Platnium thought this was a good idea is beyond me, or better yet why didn't play testers for this port say anything about it?). It does not work well at all. During the top-down and side-scrolling portions of the game, using the mouse is not ideal at all. In order to shoot in your intended direction, you have to continiously move your mouse in that direction at a relatively slow speed, or else the direction that you're attacking will reset to the direction of your movement or your aim will be off by an order of magnitude. Using the mouse for this game does not get any better in any section of the game. During the third person spectacle fighting portions of the game, using the mouse to control the camera is just downright infuriating. You cannot aim accurately or precisely. The camera never points where you want it to point. Even after modifying the atrocious default camera settings, moving the camera with the mouse is still awful.Camera movement is not dependent on the displacement of your mouse. The camera ONLY, and i emphasize, ONLY moves predictably if you move your mouse at a relatively slow speed (somewhere around an in/s). If you move your mouse any faster or slower than that speed, the camera barely even moves, especially if your using the default camera settings. The game doesn't even register speeds lower than that target speed as a proper input (again somewhere around an inch per second) because, as I've mentioned before, the game seems to simulate the mouse as an analog stick. Moving your mouse at a speed lower than the target speed is akin to hitting the deadzones of an analog stick. Slow mouse movement results in no camera movement. Too much movement ♥♥♥♥s with the camera-mouse logic and results in the camera moving a significantly lowered displacement.As for using the keyboard in this game, the one and only major issue I have with it is the lack of a separate key binding for dodging. Honestly, it makes no sense why there isn't a separate key binding for it. The ps4 version of this game has it, so it's not like dodging was only ever hard coded to double-tapping a directional key. To dodge using a keyboard, you have to double-tap a directional key. The problem with using a keyboard for this game is that dodging oftenly does not work. During combat, I've found myself frequently trying to spam dodge, but to no avail. The player character gets stuck in some sort of loop that interprets your keyboard inputs as "not double-tap", for a lack of a better term.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
25
edit: apparently my review has been met with incredulity, I am adding this reddit link to show that I am not the only one experiencing those massive technical problems: https://www.reddit.com/r/nier/comments/600scm/nier_automata_pc_issues_megathread/ Technical DesasterAfter unsuccessfully evading the hype-train that has been going on for weeks, I downloaded this game.I will save you how pretty the graphics and the soundtrack are, enough people have written about it.Instead lets focus on the things that make this game utterly unplayable: The game does not understand more than one graphics card: I have an embedded Intel graphics chip and a GTX950. Sadly Nier only recognizes the first graphics chip. I had to manually disable the Intel chip for the Nvidia one to be recognized by the game Totally unaceptable performance: The movements feel like the protagonist is swimming in honey. The dialogue in the cutscenes is not at all syncronized with the lip movement (delay of up to 15 seconds). The combat is even worse because of that, it feels like playing a turn based game sometimes. Each action requires several key presses for the game to finally register it. This is most annyoing when the game throws multiple enemies at once, which happens all the time.This is not a problem with the hardware on my side, my setup is as follows:   Intel i7 6700 3.5GHz  32GB of DDR4 RAM  GTX 950 Graphics card with 4GB of vRAM  On top of that when minimizing the game or switching to another process, the game cannot be restored. The sounds continue to play and it is possible to hear that the menu is brought up if the corresponding key is pressed but the windows stays white. Not to mention that it is impossible to return to fullscreen mode for whatever reason. Completely unacceptable control scheme. The game seems to assume that it is being played on a console isntead of a PC. The default keybindings are hilarious. Basic attack requires 2 key pressed at once for example. There are not ways of configuring the mouse. I need 3 hands to play certain parts: it requires the w-a-s-d, the arrow keys and the mouse in very short succession. Instead of having 360° of freedom when facing enemies in the first level, the game only offers 8, as if a d-pad instead of a mouse was present. There is the possibilities between shot1 and shot2 yet it is not at all clear what exactly the difference is, if it exists at all. Some keys on the keypad (the default control scheme assumed by the game) do not have any keyboard equivalent at all. The list goes on, and consider that I only played a little over 1 hour.  Horrible Camera If you thought the camera from old cosole ports like Final Fantasy VII and VIII was bad, you will be overjoyed to find out that it is even worse in Nier: Automata. In a pathetic attempt to be "innovative" I assume, the game will frequently translate from one fixed and totally awkward camera angle into another fixed and even more awkward angle, oftentimes mid-battle. I found myself fighting against the camera much more often than fighting against the enemies. The few parts where the camera is really free and under the players control are like oasises in the midst of a desert.Savepoints: No savepoints whatsoever in over 1 hour makes Jack a dull boy. No savepoints whatsoever in over 1 hour makes Jack a dull boy. No savepoints whatsoever in over 1 hour makes Jack a dull boy. No savepoints whatsoever in over 1 hour makes Jack a dull boy. No savepoints whatsoever in over 1 hour makes Jack a dull boy. No savepoints whatsoever in over 1 hour makes Jack a dull boy. No savepoints whatsoever in over 1 hour makes Jack a dull boy. No savepoints whatsoever in over 1 hour makes Jack a dull boy. No savepoints whatsoever in over 1 hour makes Jack a dull boy. No savepoints whatsoever in over 1 hour makes Jack a dull boy. No savepoints whatsoever in over 1 hour makes Jack a dull boy. No but seriously, a safepoint before or after each bossfight is mandatory. Not only does the game force you to play through one hour of gameplay should you die, it forces you through many in-engine, unskipable cutscenes and dialogues that are just one big cluster♥♥♥♥ of horrible un-immersive writing as produced by a 1st year theater student.

edit: apparently my review has been met with incredulity, I am adding this reddit link to show that I am not the only one experiencing those massive technical problems: https://www.reddit.com/r/nier/comments/600scm/nier_automata_pc_issues_megathread/ Technical DesasterAfter unsuccessfully evading the hype-train that has been going on for weeks, I downloaded this game.I will save you how pretty the graphics and the soundtrack are, enough people have written about it.Instead lets focus on the things that make this game utterly unplayable: The game does not understand more than one graphics card: I have an embedded Intel graphics chip and a GTX950. Sadly Nier only recognizes the first graphics chip. I had to manually disable the Intel chip for the Nvidia one to be recognized by the game Totally unaceptable performance: The movements feel like the protagonist is swimming in honey. The dialogue in the cutscenes is not at all syncronized with the lip movement (delay of up to 15 seconds). The combat is even worse because of that, it feels like playing a turn based game sometimes. Each action requires several key presses for the game to finally register it. This is most annyoing when the game throws multiple enemies at once, which happens all the time.This is not a problem with the hardware on my side, my setup is as follows:   Intel i7 6700 3.5GHz  32GB of DDR4 RAM  GTX 950 Graphics card with 4GB of vRAM  On top of that when minimizing the game or switching to another process, the game cannot be restored. The sounds continue to play and it is possible to hear that the menu is brought up if the corresponding key is pressed but the windows stays white. Not to mention that it is impossible to return to fullscreen mode for whatever reason. Completely unacceptable control scheme. The game seems to assume that it is being played on a console isntead of a PC. The default keybindings are hilarious. Basic attack requires 2 key pressed at once for example. There are not ways of configuring the mouse. I need 3 hands to play certain parts: it requires the w-a-s-d, the arrow keys and the mouse in very short succession. Instead of having 360° of freedom when facing enemies in the first level, the game only offers 8, as if a d-pad instead of a mouse was present. There is the possibilities between shot1 and shot2 yet it is not at all clear what exactly the difference is, if it exists at all. Some keys on the keypad (the default control scheme assumed by the game) do not have any keyboard equivalent at all. The list goes on, and consider that I only played a little over 1 hour. content:

												I am a frequent steam user with hundreds of games and experiences both good and bad. I'm not against controllers, but have a personal preference to using M+KB when the option is available. I love Nier and highly recommend both Nier and Nier Automata to fans of the franchise.TL;DR: This game suffers performance issues on 'recommended' specs and requires high end specs to function as intended; Refrain from purchasing on steam if you haven't a high end PC and a controller to play it with.M+KB controls are outright pitiful and border between just-usable to heavily-handicapped. People attribute the game's unique perspective changes to the state of M+KB controls but without listing titles this is not a strong enough excuse; Top/Side view shooting sections are restrained to hyper acute mouse aiming that misses frequently with no finesse available to the user. (The game's on-foot sections are somewhat playable, but sluggish default settings and possibly performance issues make this feel subpar compared to similar priced titles.)Performance is spotty; While not unplayable, if you aren't running on higher end specs you will likely have to either downsize or simply deal with performance drops due to un-optimized engine performance in areas.I still recommend Nier Automata for it's wonderful soundtrack and interesting gameplay. But the game is a pathetic port with limited accessibility.

												Fully cleared in 36 hours. Here is my review.Pros- Well made story.- Back Ground Music fits really well in most of situation.- Philosophical and moral questions to player, just like their last game.Cons- Aweful control system if you play with Keyboard and mouse. (If you use consol pad, you can ignore this sentence.)- Bug from several quests and some game logic error, Map stuck and extra.- Game crashes without any reason once in a while. (Win10, fully updates with ATI R9x series.)- In some stages and map, game toggle your point of view to fixed. Not all the time, but in several cases it's very annoying.- JRPG's play style. Bunch of grinds.- No online, network based open world. Not even a co-op mission. Which means lack of contents once you cleared whole story. <- It said single-player in game discription. Then why there is online mode and offline mode in game? Also why  there is invincible boss at E route when I play with offline mode? what's the purpose for this?Graphics : 3/5Story : 4/5Interface : 1/5(Keyboard) 4/5(controller)Stability : 2/5Contents : 2/5Overall : [2.4/5 (Keyboard)] [3/5 (Controller)]Conclusion I suggest this game for people who are big fan of JRPG and PlatinumGames Inc.The story and BGM are awesome. Made both of my eyes wet at the E-ending.If you are story based gamer I suggest you this game.However, if you are a gamer who wants several different contents after cleared story mission, there is nothing much to enjoy. Secret shop at resistance base will unlock all of your trophies(Acheivements in steam) for in game currency. Over priced. Not a worth for 80.00 CAD. 50 to 60 would makes sense.

content:

												So get this. The game is absolutely fun. The hack and slash that Platinum games is more famous for (Among other ♥♥♥♥♥torms but we don't talk about those) And the Mix of Yoko Taro's mad mind in creating some pretty odd stories. This game seems like a real gem. And it is-- For anyone playing console.----------------------------------------------------------Allow me to be blunt, this port is AWFUL. While my computer reaches almost every bit of recommended settings (Save the graphics card, but that's only a 20 of the Nvidia card) I end up running this game as if I were trying to push an entire Garbage Truck on Neutral with my bare hands! I wish it were much of a joke, but Again, I'll be blunt: I don't reach even 30 FPS with everything at it's lowest off and on a resolution of 640x480. I can barely see the text as it starts to have disappearing pixels, but at least I can play this good game.Furthermore, while I'm lucky to not go through stuff other people are suffering (Crashes, Whitescreening, people not even able to run the game cause Denovo is missing) I did have my further misfortunes. Such as having the display of the game just jam... And then proceeding to artifact the entire screen of my computer.It's not fun to see half of your screen spazzing out and having no idea how to fix it, as you try to save both your computer hardware and software from what was really one giant flashy false alarm.I really want to enjoy this game as much as I can, and I already do. but one thing is for certain. If you look at the time I have been playing this game. My actual game time is half that. Because again, abysmal framerates kinda stagnate the entire flow fo the game. Oh and while I'm at it, I should mention the whole thing with Keyboard and Mouse. Now, I have grown used to awkward keyboard layouts, that's not something new, is it annoying I can't remap some of the actions to my mouse buttons? Kinda, but it's not the end of the world. Just. god. forbid. you Play some of the minigames with the keyboard and mouse. While the movement is fine and all, if you dare use the mouse to aim (in minigames, the core game doesn't have much of an issue) You'll rather want to just... leave the pointer as it is, as mouse movement is so sensetive and inaccurate you'll be thinking you were a drunk with a machinegun, on a tightrope.Again, this can be easilly resolved by using the arrow keys like a smart person who has alternate solutions to bad controls, but the precision aiming just wouldn't be there anymore, would it?Luckilly for everyone. There is a group of modders trying to fix it as well as the Dev team coming out to do Buxfixes. But until then, the thing stands as is.To those who are like me who own no consoles and I still don't sway you from buying the game. I hope your port doesn't end up abysmally as mine.To those who are enjoying the game to it's fullest extent, I'm glad there are people enjoying it without a niggling thought of agony.But to be perfectly frank? I get the distinct feeling, that if we got an emulator and this game. It would run better.So all and all: Don't got a console? I wish you luck it runs without issue. If you do. You're much better off buying the console version of this game.

												I preordered the game here on steam for 59,99€. Not only to support a franchise that finally made it to PC, but also to support japanese devs. The day it released i noticed the resolution is bugged and only sends a 4:3 1680x1050 image at 60 Hz at any given resolution to my monitor. As this only appeared in fullscreen i started to play in windowed mode only to find out that once i swing the sword there is a chance for the game to crash the graphics driver.The official tech Support recommended me to use an outdated driver from 2016 to avoid the crashes. But since i use new drivers and not obsolete ones, that never happened.Now almost 2 weeks later and with the best intentions in mind, there is still no official patch to address the well known issues. And after having forwarded all the important information to both - the Tech Support and AMD for the graphics driver - i see no reason to wait longer for a patch that could or could not happen.Instead i go for a refund and spend my money on other products, that actually work.

content:
29
												Every one I know loves this game, and I love kick ♥♥♥ sexy women and dystopian epics. Which might make it strange why I hated this. It basically boils down to art style, visuals, graphics, and gameplay. I don't watch much anime or get into their way of doing things, cause I don't understand it. Frills, skirt, and high heels seemed very odd choices for a combat android, and the quirky, clunky robots, some of which with cultural mimicry undertones took away what would have been a cold, threatening alien menace.A bit of freeflight would've been nice but all the flight sequences were prescripted and oriented like an 80's shooter arcade. I don't care for nostalgia gaming. Seeing the flying units in previews, I thought it would've added a nice, strategic depth with options to either fight on ground or in the air, but they were just kept to certain sequences. I found the melee combat untactical and pretty boring, just frantic, twitch bullet hell. Not to mention immersion breaking UI, glowing items that looked like Mario coins, subtitles and letter boxes you can't get rid from the menu (I heard you needed to equip an item?) A lot of this comes down to personal taste as opposed to actual quality, but these little nitpicks added up, especially when the world, story, and characters didn't grasp me to the point I could overlook these annoyances. This usually comes to be the case with me and Japanese games, but I'm willing to give things a try. In the two hours I had before requesting a refund it didn't win me.

												If you have and like to use a controller, please disregard this review!This has the dubious honour of being my first steam refund.The game opens with a shootemup sequence somewhat reminiscent of old classics like Xenon 2 and R-Type which works OK. but when the perspective shifts and the game moves to more of a twinstick shooter approach, it all falls apart for mouse and keyboard controls.At this point, you can either use the mouse to control shooting which *should* work but, for some reason, the devs chose to make it so you fire in the direction your mouse is moving (rather than at a crosshair) which means you have to keep moving the mouse to fire in one direction.The alternative is to use keyboard for controlling fire direction but that gives you too little control over where you're shooting.3rd person works better but my concern is that there will be too many unplayable sections due to control issues.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
17
A bad port of a good game.Listen, there's a lot of buzz surrounding this game so let's keep it honest here. As a game Nier Automata is borderline amazing but flawed: From an artistic perspective it is Incredibly strong in everything from attractive character designs to its amazing soundtrack, it is backed by an author that has always been good with delivering interesting (although not exactly coherent) stories but when it comes to gameplay it is saddled down with a pointless open world and combat that's relatively fun but takes AGES to get anywhere near as interesting as other Platinum titles (the good ones, that is) thanks to piling up system upon system upon system. Nier can be engrossing, it's refreshingly quirky, it's full of stylish visuals (terrible textures aside) and set pieces but if you want a perfect example of a game that's held aloft not only by its own merits but (some would say underserved) hype then you should look no further: Nier Automata is a perfect storm of kooky underdog creator, a developer that's supposed to be a master in action games (yet kind of fails to deliver, specially considering things like how normal mode is far too easy while hard will have most enemies one shot you), a genre that's seldom seen in modern games (especially on PC) and a mountain of erotic drawings and webms of sashaying androids.Is it worth a play? Yes. Is it worth sixty dollars? Weeeelllllll that's kind of the issue here... because the port is ♥♥♥♥ing awful and people are swallowing it up anyway. HORRIBLE performance that will force most people to play well under 60 FPS (in a game that was explicitly designed to be 60 FPS), bugs that range from a completely broken fullscreen mode to inevitable crashes/freezes, poorly encoded cutscenes that hitch all the time and the bare minimum effort to present many features PC users need - like more than a handful of graphic settings or sensible KB/M controls (you should really own a gamepad at this point but whatever); The PC version of NieR: Automata was clearly a project overseen either by inexperienced people or Square Enix didn't give a damn because this thing falls waaaaay below what's expected of port quality. People will immediately rush to comment "but it works fine for me!" except it doesn't - and I guarantee that anyone that might claim they can play the game "without issues" is either happy with mediocre FPS, blissfully unaware of how it's actually running on their rig or the rare 1% of the population that have 1200 dollars worth of videocards in their weird frankenstein machine (I mean even the PC Gamer reviewer noticed drops into the 45 FPS with a GTX Titan for god's sake. Geforce 980s struggle with a steady 60 FPS at 1080p even with low settings? Come on now.)  It is quite simply unnaceptable that a game that looks as shabby as NieR does takes more hardware than any other full fledged open world game OR explosion filled action game out there and the fact that so many people are ok with it is kind of appaling."But Det!" you might say, dunce cap precariously balanced on your head, "Nier is a small franchise! It's no wonder Square didn't devote money to it!" Well if Sega was able to do an amazing port of Valkyria Chronicles without issues then there is no excuse, now is there? Not when the team behind Nier themselves explicitly mentioned in interviews that the PC version came first and THEN they scaled down to PS4. The only thing people are doing by accepting ports like these are allowing the Koei Tecmo's and Warner Brother's of the world to keep delivering ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ports.Is there hope that the game will be patched? No idea. At the very least I imagine the fullscreen thing will be patched (surprise, it was already fixed by a modder well-known for fixing japanese games) but I think performance issues will be much harder to tackle, who knows about the crashes on some hardware. The long and short of it is that if you buy into this game right now, you are buying into a terrible gamble that may not pay off and frankly it is not really worth it either for your own immediate benefit nor the growing tendency to deliver bad ports because PC's better hardware is supposed to make up for whatever corners lazy developers cut.Don't. Buy it on console if you must, wait and see if this gets patched or just get it five years down the line when it'll be 10 bucks and our future space computer parts will be able to run it properly.

												Now I REALLY want to give this a thumbs up, and not just cause 2B is one of the sexiest robots I've ever seen, but I can't for one reason and one reason alone. Optimization is REALLY BAD with this game, even with a graphics card inbetween minimum and recommended. I have an nVidia Geforce 930M graphics card and 8GB of RAM, by all requirements I should be able to play this at low-medium quality with no problems, but I could not get more then like 10 FPS while walking and 15 while in the mech. I had to go do a lot of tweaking with the nVidia control panel and the game in lowest quality to even make it playable. I still dont get even 30 fps, barely over 20 at the best parts and subtitles are lagged as is some cutscenes. Now I have a budget gaming laptop admittingly but when the minimum for this game is close to a game like Fallout 4 a bit, and I can run that fine on low-medium I should by all means be able to play this nearly the same but it's impossible without a lot of tweaking. I want to recommend this game but until they fix it's optimization for PC you better have a graphics card super close to the recommended at the minimum, or your better off getting this on console. If square fixes it to run smoother on PC without a bunch of tweaking, espescially on laptops I will change this to recommended. If you have a beastly computer or laptop though this game is worth it. Oh and also as a warning you're not gonna be able to save for a bit cause you can't till your done the first mission/level whatever and there is no autosave feature. Also the recommened storage space is total bs right now, I have the Day One Edition andf its smaller then 30GB I think it was 26GB or 28GB so don't worry about space, it's not as big as GTAV or newer CoD games contrary to what it says on the store page.

												The game is ok, it isn't great and I wouldn't personally recommend it but it is not terrible.Pros:*The world is well thought out and the story makes sense(mostly). As you play the game you will get to learn more and more about the world and everything falls into place*While it has it's flaws, the combat system is fun for the majority of the game. There are times when the game disables one or more of your basic abilities (sometimes all of them) though which detract from overall gameplay*There is a lot of developer humor in the game with a lot of easter eggs, you are free to make unconventional choices and see what happens as a resultCons*The game is rather short. The game is very linear and doesn't contain a lot of playtime. With about 30 hours of gameplay I've unlocked every main ending and all misc "endings" except for one.*There doesn't seem to be any endgame content. The game is purely story driven and once you've cleared the game in all possible ways, you start over against level 1 mobs as if nothing ever happened.*When the game tries to get emotional, it often gets cringy. I understand the whole "androids developing human emotions" bit, but when it is well established that the androids reboot from backups, it makes some death scenes pointless. To further this point, the main characters both kill themselves as early as the tutorial.*You often find yourself running around holding one button. The POD firing button is just a free source of damage and the fact that you basically spend the entire game holding it down makes for mindless combat especially since the number of mobs you usually fight at once makes melee significantly more risky.All things considered it is a good game, it is merely not what it's hyped up to be and probably not worth the $60 price tag. I expect more than a weekend of play time from a game I drop that much money on. If you find this game on sale then I'd get it, otherwise you might as well wait.

content:
30
												After playing through this game once, I need to get some things off my chest about this game, as I have very mixed feelings about it.Yes, the game is a low effort port and you will definitely notice it. Yes, playing without a 2 stick controller is just not going to do, so don't try this with keyboard / mouse. But that's not why I'm not recommending this game.First impressions were very good, the game has something from a lot of games. It's a mix of Space Invaders, Dark Souls, Bayonetta, Furi and all of that in a fast paced action JRPG. Also notice that it's from the makers of Metal Gear Rising Revengeance and Bayonetta. The story starts very intriguing about what it means to be human and life in a post-apocalyptic world of robots, so it seemed like my kind of game and I really wanted to like it.About the setting:The game tries to be as realistic as possible and even explain elements of the game (e.g. UI, respawning, saving) in their robot setting, which seems very cool at first, but gets very stale after a while when you start noticing its obvious flaws and limits - from plot to gameplay. I was constantly left wondering: Why don't they just do that and avoid the whole problem altogether? Why is this even relevant? Unfortunately most of the almost philosophical topics from the start are just never touched on again and then the story doesn't even follow its own rules sometimes for the sake of being more dramatic...About the gameplay and difficulty:If you play on normal or easy, it is a very enjoyable experience. You will feel very overpowered, enjoy hack and slay styled combat the way it is supposed to be played and everything is fine.If you want a challenge and try the game on hard (there is also super hard where you always die in one hit), you just get ♥♥♥♥ed over so much. The game isn't really hard, but unfair and very punishing. With the ridiculous level scaling you will get oneshot by everything a few levels above you and even the cheapest mechanics. With the no autosave mechanic, you will sometimes have to replay whole levels again just to try once more. And good luck getting to your corpse (this alone can take a while) and standing still for 3 seconds in the middle of enemies that already killed you and without your equipment. If you die again, you loose your equipment forever, at which point you can basically reset the game. After a lot of grinding, because even the available side quests are 20 levels above you and not a valid xp ressource, when you outlevel the enemies even just slightly, the game is basically the same as normal and way too easy. The balancing really just isn't good. There would definitely be a line between super hard and way too easy, but the developers couldn't find it.About the game world:The way the story and world is designed feels more like a low effort MMO to me. You will see most of the zones (only 5) in the game very quickly and then get sent to the same places over and over again. Many sidequests are very simple go here, kill that type quests and aren't even voiced. I really just expected more.For one playthrough the amount of content might be fine, but as you may know, they expect you to play the game up to 5 times to get the full story. Considering that even the first playthrough is very repetitive, down to even most of the bosses repeating and the second playthrough being 90% the same as the first one, this is just low effort design to me. Rehashing the same content as many times as you possibly can is not what I want in a game and I already got tired of it during my first playthrough.Also the first main ending (A) you get after playing through the whole game once isn't even a motivating ending. You get no explanations, no epilogue, no foreshadowing, no motivation, nothing. They just cut out during a regular scene and you just casually start all over again and to get more info you basically have to play it at least 3 times.Summary:Even though I initially enjoyed the setting and most of the gameplay, over the course of the game, as I started noticing all the flaws, limits and the dwindling quality, my motivation was fading. So much of the game seems to be lazily put in and not thought through. The same content just gets dragged out and repeated multiple times. Adding the bad port on top, I unfortunately cannot justify recommending this game. It wasn't the worst game I ever played, but it wasn't good either.
