content:
28
												If I have one comment about Nier it is that it is severly overhyped. In full disclosure I went into this game expecting it to be "the most important game of the year" as quoted by Jim Sterling but to say the least I was disappointed. The game covers some interesting topics and the combat starts off interesting and satisfying but after a few hours becomes a bore. The story has some interesting metaphors and covers some Personhood positions and other existential philisophical topics but the writing and the voice acting make it hard to care. The characters other than 9S feel tired or just boring or hillariously cliche. The villians especially made me laugh a few times with their over the top, anime dub like delivery. You may enjoy that but personally the story feels like someone checking off every cliche in the book. It does do some interesting perspective changes and some interesting things with it and I could get into the story if the combat wasn't such a repeititive bore. The gameplay includes running from objective to objective either to talk to someone, get something to trigger a story bit, or to fight a boss, all while killing robots in between. The NPCs all sound tired  or bored so having interactions with them is just uninteresting, the story bits are alright as I explained before, but the bosses become so repetitive its kind of hillarious. Each boss either creates a shockwave, shoots purple balls, or swings at you. Theres little variation passed this. You quickly find a strategy of killing them that basically works on every one of them. This ties into the combat for me. I had never played a Platinum Games game before so I had no idea how their combats worked in their previous games, but if they are anything like this one I honestly don't get why they get so much praise. In the combat you have 5 moves you can do; a light attack, heavy attack, ranged attack, spell, or dodge. There is not much variation in the combos for the light and heavy attacks and because you're fighting hordes of guys you will often get stopped mid-combo by an enemy off screen which becomes quickly frustrating. I ended up having to just spam the spells and ranged attacks while non-stop dodging in order to get many of the hordes of enemies killed. This also applies to the bosses, you can literally dodge any attack by bosses by circling around them and mashing the dodge button and since you have an unlimited ranged attack you never have to come near them so you can keep circling and shooting till they are dead. Its embaressing.I think what bothers me the most about Nier is that its not a bad game but even though is simply an average game thats "meta" or a "game about games" and because of this somehow becomes better. This is obviously being pushed by a group of individuals that feel the need to put gaming on a pedastal so that its "better" or "just as good" as other mediums. This game shows a lot of insecurities in gamers and their lack of confidence in their hobby. This is not a good game, its a pretentious meta piece about games in games, and honestly I'm tired of this genre. Games are to have fun don't try to pretend like they have to be art and that will make the game great. The game doesn't even utilize gameplay to extend its ideas. The gameplay and story are completely seperated, its contradictory.  You can have a good story or be 'meta' but don't forget you're making a GAME and there is GAMEPLAY which shouldn't be forgotten.

												Awful, awful port. 20~ FPS during cutscenes on a decent rig at 1440p (980TI, 4970K 4.0 Ghz) with dips down to 10 FPS on certain boss fights. The game can become literally unplayable because enemy projectiles are not telegraphed at lower frame rates. Playing with a M+KB is a terrible thing all on its own. When aiming from a top down perspective you need to constantly move your mouse in the direction you want to fire, otherwise it resets back to the default position. The Dodge mechanic is bound to double tapping WASD and cannot be changed to anything else. This game demands a gamepad if you plan on playing it more than once. The game also crashes often. This is REALLY BAD because Nier Automata doesn't have an autosave function.

content:

Story — 2/10Character Development — 1/10Music — 8/10Battle System — 2/10Graphics — 5/10Story seems like it was written by some teenager in middle school. It doesn't know where it is or where it's going. Character development is sloppy. It tries to deliver a certain character, then changes that minutes after, making it hard to like the characters in any way, because they themselves don't keep a narrative or know how to build up characters. The music was fine, but nothing that I would call a masterpiece.The battle system is recycled and used in almost every hack n' slash I've played, but then that very system fails you when you face bosses. It ends up feeling jerky and cumbersome.If you look past 2B's buttocks, and at the world, it looks like trash. They didn't even try to make textures. It looks like a game from the PS3, with chroma filters masking how trashy it looks. This is not terrible, but not what I was expecting for a game in 2017. Is this what console peasants have become accustomed to?So, below is my huge rant against the game outside of the issues above and more details on why I dislike different aspects of the game.I uninstalled and requested a refund after 3 hours. It's just not for me. Most games I enjoy keep me interested within the first hour to something. The characters, the world, something. I got none of that. So, if you're expecting that I be nice to this game in some form or another, you're not going to get it.First thing that I noticed was that they over did it on the switch back and forth between camera angles. Once in a while, I get it, but not every 3 minutes. When going up stairs? Sure, I get that, makes the environment more dynamic, but corridors or anywhere they feel like it only makes it seem like they just don't want to make a fully 3D world, or draw the assets for it. It became repetitive and redundant real quick and I started hating that aspect of it early on.They probably spent too much time on 2B, because all the other female NPCs are all the same, with some differences between models. (In the ship, not outside with the resistance) I just feel like 2B got more time than necessary and the other characters took a hit for it.Character and story wise, 2B contradicts herself minutes after making a statement "Emotions are prohibited", which means that they're supposed to be robots, and emotions aren't normal, but obviously it's extremely normal for them and they blatantly show these emotions everytime they talk, die, attack, everything. The game literally tries to set a preface, doesn't follow it, tries to make a plot point, then contradicts itself and everything in it contradicts the message they're trying to convey. Another thing about it is that it tries to make you believe it's a post-apocolyptic modern society. A society that had enough means of technology to go to the moon and create life-like androids, but then proceeds to show you in cinematics, and in-game these old ancient 1960-1970s vehicles rusted and lying around, like I'm supposed to believe it's a modern world, but then tries to be Fallout or some crud. It makes no sense. —Also, I managed to relay this thing that bothered me to a friend who has beaten the game multiple times, and he tried to explain the story logic behind it, but still didn't add up. I decided to read up more about Nier (the game preceeding this one), only to find out that Nier is spinoff from another game "Drakengard". One of it's endings, specifically ending D, was supposed to lead up to Nier. The events in Drakengard ending D, which fast forward the antagonist to 2003 Tokyo and does some bad stuff (not ruining the story for people). However, 2003 does not equal 1950s, or 1960s. There is literally no reason for the object to exist, and it seems like Yoko Taru doesn't know how to create a narrative, stick with it, and not convolute it.I'm not a fan of the controls for keyboard, which would be the porter's fault, not the devs, but that and the random dashing on keyboard makes the battle system sloppy for PC. After I leave the main hour, forced battles(the <tutorial?>), it turned off auto healing and didn't even warn me. The AI is pretty dumb. I was killing level 15s at level 5The old ♥♥♥ textures make it seem like a game developed between 2008-2010. (This is everything on highest settings mind you.) The best textures were literally 2B and 9s(kinda), that's it. Nothing else had nearly as much attention, and I don't like the chromatic camera, or whatever the hell they're doing.The open-world isn't very open, I feel like I'm limited to a small city with a few buildings and caves(not really), and immediately nothing exciting is going on, the game becomes dull immediately after being semi-entertaining.Everything about it just bothers me in every aspect. I try to be a connoisseur of many forms of art (animations, game design, programming, story writing), and every part of me is bothered by every aspect. First it was abusing the camera angles. Good in theory, okay in practice, redundant when over used. Second was the battle system. It was not made to handle large battles in an ergonomic manner. Here I am trying to hold shift, move, and have a lock on, only for the large digger arm to swipe me and pummel me. When I had two on me, I was still doing "okay", but then 2B will randomly dash to one side, because of moving too fast and run into one arm when I was trying to move between them. After the whole thing, setting the bad story elements and that aside, it proceeds to put you in a 2D side view of her room, and the corridor at a completely different angle, but then puts you into the main center in 3D, and all the while my brain is cringing trying to get through it and the overlay of grey and chrome/black and white effect. Whilst not being consistant at all, I had hoped, "hey, maybe when I get outside into the world that will change".  Nope, it doesn't change. It has just grey chroma, which gives me a headache, and the brightness does ♥♥♥♥ to help that. Then I just see more repeats of the same enemies and textures being reused in one area, and everything looks the same all over. I don't have objectives on my hud(Didn't disable that), so I walked around for a good 30-50 minutes just killing things and retrieving the bodies of dumbasses that die to easy-peasy mobs, and getting a chuckle at how people are bad at video games. Finally get back to the resistance camp and you can buy an unlimited amount of health items pretty well, taking away any challenge the game could have had. (Outside of bosses anyway)If they spent less time on 2B's ♥♥♥ and more on story, AI, and battle ergonomics, they'd have a game worth playing, but still have a limited camera and silly filters going on. I just don't see 2B's ♥♥♥ justifying a $60US/$80 CAD price tag. You need an actual game to go with it. I am sure many enjoy it, but I just don't see any merit to it.

												I wish I could put a neutral stance on this, but I can't. The gameplay is pretty solid and fluid, albeit with the small frame 'hitch' now and then in certain areas but otherwise main game would run at 60FPS fine. The full-screen issue was an affliction for myself, so I had to run it windowed with a 3rd party application to get pseduo-borderless window mode with window, which should not have been an issue in the first place but it worked.The thing that broke it for me were the FMV cutscenes dropping frames like crazy when they shouldn't have been. Seriously, 30FPS FMVs have more problems than 60FPS gameplay? How? I even bothered to dump the FMVs and played them uncompressed in a player, and they ran just fine that way! It's something in the game that's messing up the playback of them.Also of note, is the GPU would drop to like 5% use on the FMV cutscenes and then back to ~80-100% in-game. So there's really something wonk with the game's video playback method, or a sync issue is happening.If you are the few that can get it to run flawless in all regards, congrats. As for me, refunded for now until at least the FMV stuff is addressed because that is way too jarring and there's over 100+ FMVs in the game. (Why does a game even use FMVs created obviously from the game's engine anyway? Why not just have had them play out in-game in the first place?)(Also of note, the FMVs are in 4:2:0 profile of YUV, limited colour range at 1600x904.)

Finished game (5 "Main" endings) on Normal difficulty. PC Port Notice I'm not gonna go into how terrible and lazy this port is. Needless to say, stay the hell away from it till it's fixed or heavily discounted even if you disagree with my gameplay review that follows. Most of the big issues with the PC Port could be found within the first 10 minutes by anyone in Squeenix, Platinum or any of the 50 other companies that worked on this game (thanks Ending E for having me sit through all of it!). Overall ImpressionsOverall, the game isn't bad. It's not great, but not terrible either. It is "Mediocre"... it doesn't really excell at anything it does. Uninspired and mediocre gameplay, terrible port, cliche story that is too full of itself contribute to my negative recommendation here.I will say however that I think this game is totally worth it at the $30-40 pricepoint.Open WorldThe Open world and general design of the map is quite lackluster. It's never really a joy to explore the world as a lot of it feels outdated and very much packed to the brim with invisible walls. On top of this, there's an ocean, a jungle, an amusment park, a freaking desert all a short walking distance from eachother. Map cohesion isn't a huge issue to me but it is obvious enough in this title.The region design, apart from the Amusment Park wasn't anything extraordinary, you'd find the same stuff in majority of games that feature such areas. Amusment park gets a pass as it isn't something I've seen many game include.Overall, the world is just there, nothing too amazing but it gets the job done.CombatWhile it is a Platinum game, it unfortunately doesn't quite stand out from any of the rest of their games. It tries to mix it up with different modes, the pods and so on but I think that detracts from the game. One character in particular doesn't even really need to attack since he can hack everything.My main problem with the combat is that there is not enough of it! The game feels like it has to point out how smart it is in including an R-Type mode with the flight unity and an Asteroids wanna-be with it's Hacking and those 2 segments feel far more involved than the combat. Specially then one of the characters basically hacks his way through almost 2 playthroughs! Many people call this "Unique" or "Innovative" or whatever. But the game is basically in a constant identity crisis that feed it's mediocrity. I feel the multitude of combat modes would not detract from the rest of the game if they were removed or lessened. There is absolutely no reason you have to spend almost a third of the game hacking or in R-Type mode and it offers very little to the overall immersion. The game could do without them and lose nothing.In any case however, the actual character combat is quite basic for a hack and slash to the point where I could very well say Metal Gear Rising, Devil May Cry and others do it far better. I would love to say that this game's combat makes it stand out, but unfortunately it does not. It can't even hold it's own against other Platinum games.With the exception of using R-Type and hacking as fillers, combat is OK but nothing special here.GameplaySeperate from the combat issues, this game wants to pass itself for a Roleplaying game. As it has become a matra, this game is not really that great at it. There's nothing new in here, you get quests that tell you to go somewhere, do something, come back.There's quite a few quests to do, if you are into that kind of thing, as well as equipment upgrades. Though on this latter one... you honestly don't need them unless you want to get the achievement.Game also features a leveling system which comes into play if you manage to get yourself underleveled compared to the area you are in. I personally haven't had any issues like that and overall maybe died 4 times total. If you find yourself underleveled in a boss fight, you can always try to resurrect a fallen player's body from one of the multitude of piles (don't worry, they regenerate) and have them fight for you. Moment an ally attacks a boss they get the enemy's full attention leaving you open to regenerate, loot or do whatever.Map traversal also comes under gameplay so let's talk a bit about it. The game's movement is... basic. You can sprint around, jump and glide. If you have access to the functionality as well as the required destination point you can teleport to it as well which will save you a lot of time. Beyond that however, the game misses out on doing anything cool with it's open world in terms of how you can travel around it. I generally found myself sprinting around a lot to go from one objective to the next.Bosses generally end up being bullethell fights where the boss spawns a silly amount of bullets that you have to dodge. There's nothing in the boss combat itself that makes them memorable or even enjoyable to some extend. Some look good until you realise you can pretty much find them in other games. One of them is basically Encydna from Devil May Cry 4, another is pretty much a Goobue from Final Fantasy with an additional pair of arms and on and on it goes. There hasn't been a boss I haven't seen similar in another game.Game doesn't do anything great in terms of gameplay. It's not bad enough for me to say it's terrible but it does not do anything to stand out.AudioThis one splits into two areas, SFX, Voice Over and Soundtrack. I'll begin with the SFX even though it's not really a long topic at all.The game's sound effects are good, I don't think I ever heard anything that felt out of place when moving around or fighting. Ofcourse, if I had then that would speak volumes about the game (yeah, pun warning!).The VO actually holds up quite well! I have nothing to say about this, it's not at a level of some other games but it gets the job done quite well.A lot of people seem to be raving over the soundtrack but personally I found it lackluster. The vast majority of it is forgetable and even is just repeated with small variations (eg. "This cannot continue" vs "We become gods"). It has some good tracks in there but it's not a Metal Gear Revengeance, a Persona or an Ar No Surge. Mediocre overall except from a tiny selection.GraphicsIgnoring the terrible port, this game has graphical issues. The characters look amazing but that is about all that looks amazing in the game.Low-poly modes, low resolution textures and the game overall looks like something out of the mid PS3 era. The only thing that makes it seem "next-gen" is it's love for particle effects as so many developers simply can't get enough of lately.Overall, graphics are nothing to write home about except from the main characters that actually feel like they had effort put behind them.StoryLeft this one for last and I know I'll be getting a lot of hate from Taro fanboys. Unfortunately, this one left me unimpressed as hell. I have no stake in Nier or Drakengard series. I have only played this and its story is quite lackluster. It's in similar vein to Ghost in the Shell and other works. Nothing in this game's story surprised me or even kept me interested in the slightest. I've seen it all before and I have seen it done far better.On top of this the game has a few logic and plot holes that are there just so it can seem smart or make things happen. Sometimes the story doesn't even play by it's own rules and it comes up with some excuse as to why that is.Overall, game is way too quick to try and show you how smart it is and rub it in your face which makes a pretty pretentious story with obvious symbilisms even more obnoxious to slog through.Complete disinterest and even annoyance at the story being so full of itself at times really made playing this game a complete slog.Nothing actually new in this story that hasn't been done before a bunch of times already.

												Story; 4/10Character likability: 4/10Gameplay: 6/10(when i intiially reviewed this - i had only done the initial playthrough and got ending A. Since have played through several more times, and still feel the same)The story is trite and boring. It's been done a million times before. Machines are bad. Humans (androids in this case) are good. The characater 2B goes from frigid ice queen, to caring mom mode - despite no character development taking place. The support 9S - is more like a "follow mom to work day" kid. Interactions with other characters in the game are boiled down to fetch quests, or protection quests. Having played as several different characters and got different endings - i'm forced to think that nobody in Square-Enix is capable of writing good game stories anymore. Additionally the multiple endings is a gimmick. tl;dr: woudln't recommend paying full price for it - wait until it's maybe €20/$20 or so in 3 months time. This is not going to be a classic game by any standards. Story is too short. Characters are boring. Each of the different gameplay modes are okay - but nothing special. Forcing players to play through again and again for some gimmick about multple endings is not good game writing.

content:
1
												This is the first game I've ever refunded on Steam, and easily the weakest experience I can ever remember having with a game.The PC port is marred by all kinds of technical flaws. There are display errors, very annoying camera quirks, performance problems, horrible keybinds (some of which do not support remapping), and just all around a weird feeling to the control.I tried playing through the tutorial on the hardest difficulty, which was admittedly very tough. The largest obstacle to overcome was however the lackluster gameplay and extremely frustrating mechanics in the game's opening sequence. I ended up lowering difficulty, and still ended up just quitting the game, feeling that going through the motions of playing the tutorial isn't worth it to unlock a game made by the same team behind such a poor start. The game killed all of my interest in it, before showing a single glimpse of why it might be worth playing.The game starts off with some incredibly outdated space invaders and asteroids style gameplay. To go along with the forced retro minigames, you get some relatively bland music not contributing to the atmosphere, absolutely pointless little cutscenes, poor writing, obnoxious dialog, frustrating mechanics, and boring visuals.Let's go over the amazing cutscene design. After having control of the game for only seconds, you get treated to a cutscene of descending slightly in altitude, which is not shown in anyway to be a relevant maneuver. After getting under a minute more of time in control, you get to see your ship light up, indicating that you are now captain of the squad... that simply dies around you and served no real purpose in the game.The first impressions of the game's writing, just feels insultingly poor. You are immediately treated to seeing characters die around you, having shown absolutely no purpose of being in the story. Your squad members just give up one at a time, stand in the way of incoming fire, let out a scream, and get blown to bits. The squad members are even worse than characters made just for killing them off. The death of your squad doesn't really provide anything to the story. Aside from the completely unnecessary squad, the combat situations are handled in a horrid way. When you or your squad make a decision to do anything in mid combat, there is some type of completely unnecessary and ritualistic practice of asking for permission from HQ. You'd think a military operation had better planning ahead than a four year old. The voice acting early on in the game seemed like solid work, but the written dialogue did not do it justice. Over 90% of early speech is completely pointless.Apart from starting off with gameplay equivalent of a decades old arcade game, the game will throw a lot of very annoying mechanics at you. The camera in the game keeps switching to new points of view every 1 minute or so in the first 10 minutes. This is particularly problematic in a continuos sequence where the camera keeps twisting around, and it can forcefully move you to keep you in screen. You'll often be shoved through a wall of enemy projectiles. To top off the midgame camera angle changes, some of them will also leave you momentarily won't warn you about leaving you with inverted controls.The early visuals are pretty dreadful. Most of the early retro gameplay sequences look like something you might see in an asset flip, as does the first broader view of the environment. The first time you get to see where you're flying, you are greeted by an ocean filled with maybe a hundred sunken structures, consisting of two different structures copy pasted over and over. This incredibly low effort visual persists over 30 seconds of down time while just waiting to fly closer to your first mission.I've heard a lot of good things about the game past the tutorial, but I can't bring myself to play through such a poor tutorial. All I could think of during my time with the game, was how I'd rather be playing something else.

												The side-quests in this game are generally worse than the ones you find in MMORPGs. The only reason I continue to play this game is because I feel compelled by the 60€ I spent on it.

												The best part of this game by a long way is the Prologue. It's a brilliant high paced blending of different action arcade game genres, moving from one to the next beautifully. Honestly, that part of the game blew my mind.Then, the rest of the game happens. It's like someone else made the Prologue then went on holiday for a few weeks. Whilst he's away some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ has turned it into a plodding open world game that's at best an average RPG where you spend most of your time picking up items off the floor. And when it finally does go back into an arcadey mode it feels so out of place after the hours of trudging around. Sometimes it just doesn't seem to work or make sense at all and does nothing but hinder and confuse (boss at fairground for example).Certain things just don't make sense such as: Why is there fishing in this game? Wtf is the point in that? And why is the prologue so much more hardcore than the rest of the game? No saves (and you can be 1 hit by the double buzzsaws). This would be fine (oh, it's one of those hardcore games) BUT in the rest of the game you can save every 5 seconds! What's the point in the bodies everywhere? What are they even adding except to break the immersion? And what's the point in that idiot following me around the whole game like Tails?If the rest of the game was like the Prologue, this could very well be a classic game. As it is, it's just a missed opportunity.

content:

												NieR:Automata was a game that started with a good impression, maintained a good impression throughout the first dozen or so hours, but then left a sour test after I had "beaten" the game. It is hard to write a review that addequately cnoveys my reason for disliking this game without spoiling how the game operates after your first play through. Let me start by saying the gameplay in Nier is fantastic. Once you figure out that upscalling is bad and you need a third party app (Borderless Gaming) to run the game without any hiccups, the game runs smoothly. I was playing the game on a 1070, i6700, 6 gigs system and never saw a slow down.The RPG systems are pretty complex as well. There are plenty of character building options for people to create their ideal play style. The sound design is equally impressive. The music score provides a variety of emotion; somber, upbeat, inspiring, etc.NieR: Automata would have been a fantastic game if they had just handled the method of story introduction better than the steaming pile of frustration the ending ends up being. It is hard to convey why this is such a big deal without spoilering things. For those that don't like treading the same ground more than once, avoid.

												Trust me when i say this is a 'cult-following' game only.      ~As someone who's beaten every single Dark Souls & Ninja Gaiden I know my way around a hack and slash.~      *This is my first Neir game and i had bought it on a whim with high hopes it wouldnt disspoint. If you're a die hard fan that is your agenda and you will not agree with what I'm about to say.*CONS:The voice acting is utterly disgusting and mono-tone.It swaps from voice dialouge to only being able to read certain dialouge. (its 2017 people there is no excuse for the lack of effort.)The open world reeeeaaaaaaaallly isnt even that open. They gave you the option to run and jump on buildings leaving the 'ground level' a virtual 'void' of uninteresting and unimmersive textures.The game does a HORRID job of convincing you that literally ANYONE in this universe gives a ♥♥♥♥ about anything going on.The enemies in the game aren't very detailed and for the most part, the mass of enemies are lack luster of anything remotely dipicting of a 'killer robot' ~They look like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off Wall-E from the pixar movie. PROS:The combat seems very refined and fluid, so if you're looking for an uninteresting and ♥♥♥♥♥ier Ninja Gaiden with an open world this is the game for you. 6/10 for its combat ONLY. If the combat had lacked literally anything else I would've given this a 3/10. This is a 'cult' following game because I feel the masses of people who enjoy this game are willing to overlook murder to say this is actually a great game. *******************************ABSOLUTELY DO NOT BUY BEFORE YOU SEE GAMEPLAY***********Stay skeptical and stop letting game designers spoon feed us garbage and get praise for it.

number of helpful: 5 of 25 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
19
												Just not a very good game.  Combat consists of using a draone for low damage high rate of fire ranged attacks, and melee weapons for higher damage close range attacks, along with a special "programs" installed on the drone (longer cooldown high-damage range attack is what you start with, but there are other options).  First two bosses after the world opens up are either immune to melee attacks, or too dangerous to approach (And change patterns often enough that you can't really learn a pattern), making melee weapons feel pretty useless, and meaning you're stuck sniping the enemy with low damage attacks.  Game aggressively grabs control of camera and completely changes movement controls in the middle of boss fights.  Presumably to make dodging certain attacks easier, but it just makes movement more confusing (And once it switch to an overhead view, aiming because much more difficult, prolonging the new type of attack).Fighting normal robots is a bit more interesting, and the only thing I actually found fun in the game, though fighting is generally not great, and a number of attacks prevent you form moving, which further discourages close-in combat, since getting hit is pretty punishing.Item pickups come in a couple forms:  Swords/drones, which are really rare, in preset locations, random crafting stuff of unclear use (Can be used to upgrade weapons or drones, but placement and use seems completely random.  Also unclear what's useful and what's not.  Can I use moose meat to upgrade a drone?  No idea), upgrades for you to equip (You have a limited amount of space, and upgrades take up varying amounts of space - this seems like a reasonable mechanic, but never found it too useful.  It includes HUD elements, so if you like less HUD, you get more space), usable items (3 healing items, and things that temporarily boost attack / defense), money, and fish from fishing.  None of these are terribly interesting or rewarding - mostly you get random items (Is selling them a good idea?  Keeping them?  Seems completely random what's useful and what's not), and money, which does have some uses, at least early game, for increasing number of items that can be equipped, and buying and upgrading weapons (If you have enough of particular types of upgrade items, randomly strewn across the world.  Why am I finding "silver ore" in the middle of a destroyed city?).  There are also "can't open this now" crates, which is much less inspired than, say, areas you can't reach with your current abilities.  And given how boring walking around the game world is, I can't imagine ever going back to open any of these crates, unless you learn how to ride the many in-game moose to speed up movement or something (And why are there only moose?  I don't believe I've seen any other non-robots wandering about, other than birds and fish from fishing).The open-ish world is large enough that running from point to point consumes most of the game, but isn't terribly interesting.  Game has two completely different overhead maps, one on the map screen, which makes it completely unclear where you can go and where you can't, and a minimap, which isn't a whole lot better.  There's also a point where someone says they put a point of interest on your map where you can go back and get loot, but I could never find it on mine.  Save points are far enough apart to be annoying, and if you die against a boss, the boss gets healed and returns to its first state, you lose all the items you used fighting it on the first attempt, and have to pick up your corpse as well to get the programs you had installed when you died.  If you no longer have enough healing items to have a chance, tough.  Bosses also often hit you multiple times in a row, and while you're being hit, you (often) can't use healing items.  It's never clear when this is, so you just press escape to see a pause screen instead of the menu system from which you can use items.Also worth noting that "open world" isn't really accurate - run off the beaten path, and you're prettly likely to run into doors you can't currently open, elevators you can't currently ride, etc.Controls reek of "Bad console port".  "m" doesn't bring up the map screen, instead it does nothing, nor does tab.  The mouse works horribly for in game menus.  Sometimes you have a mouse cursor, sometimes it moves the focused from one atem to another (At breakneck speeds...) in the same menu.  When navigating menus, you often have to use "escape" to move up out of a submenu, even when both menus are visible onscreen at once - i.e., if there's a horizontal menu with vertical submenus, and you're in the vertical submenu, left/right do absolutely nothing, instead of moving between submenus, unless you escape out of the submenu, which is really kludgy and counter-intuitive.The writing is also bad - "robotic lifeforms" is a term used repeatedly, though it's also mentioned that they aren't actually intelligent (supposedly).   Another lovely piece of dialog is along te lines of "Is that and android?  No, because it's actually a robot!", which seems to rather fly in the face of the definition of android.There's also a system where when you die you leave a corpse for other players to find (And loot or revive to fight with them), and can set a message.  Unfortunately, the method for setting a message is clunky, involving multiple screens, and you can only mix and match hard-coded phrases, which isn't any fun.  If a moose kills me right at the start, surely I should be able to leave a silly message about my combat prowess!  Or if a weird naked white-haired guy kills me, shouldn't I be able to leave a message pondering if I was just killed by Sephiroth?  As-is, messages are just pointless.Invisible walls are also a core map design mechanic - it's never clear if you can jump up on something of a reasonable height, or if you'll run into an invisible wall.  I can live with invisble walls in a game where there isn't any platforming, but in one where jumping is a central mechanic for getting around, it's just painful, weird, and makes you waste your time trying to figure out where you can go and where you can't.  A decent mini-map could resolve that issue, but as mentioned earlier, the mini-map is not terribly helpful.I'm stunned this game is getting so many good reviews, particularly when so many amazing games have been released in the last few months.  If you want to run around a post-apocalyptic world killing robots, I'd suggest Horzon Zero Dawn instead.

												It's pretty, and the soundtrack is great. However, I asked for a refund after 45 minutes, and here's why:- This is not a RPG. It's a bullet hell. If you don't have good reflexes or spacial awareness, you're screwed, because...- The camera work is horrible. It's designed to be cinematic, but the changes in perspective make dodging a nighmare. And this is a huge problem, because...- No autosaves. Ok, why not - there are many excelent games with manual saves. Oh, what is this? No manual saves either? You die on a boss after 45 mins in the tutorial, and you have to restart the WHOLE GAME?This, in addition of the issues everybody else is talking about (full screen is broken, you have to use a third party software to unlock it), the price tag, and the terrible English voice acting, meant I asked for a refund.Many people love this game, including the friend who told me to buy it, but if the story, the graphics and the OST are the only things you find great about this game, just go watch replays on Youtube, you'll save 60€.

												As a huge fan of Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance, I was pretty disappointed by this Platinum title not for one reason, but a combination of different factors.-Poor optimization (Framerate dips to low 40s in some engagements, regardless of settings tweaks)-Boring enemies and simple combat. (Metal Gear Rising was also simple, but the parry system and health-steal techniques added a level of complexity and flair that made fights engaging.)-Forced shoot-em-up sections throughout each level. (I knew they were present but didn't know they were so frequent and mindless.)-Tonally inconsistent (this is a #Serious game, but the main characters wear a gothic lolita dress and small short pants to their military engagements? what??? at least bayonetta's design was consistent with the rest of the world + story)All in all, you might be a big fan regardless. If they ever fix the optimization issues, I would definitely suggest giving it a try yourself. However, I was surprised to find that I didn't have fun with this title, and wanted to share my experience.

Are you supposed to shoot and melee the enemeies at the same time?  You technically can, but its super clumsy to do without lock on enabled.  Is there any reason why I would not want to be having the pod shooting in combat (even if he was missing the target)?  Many regular enemies in the game can be defeated by standing still and shooting the pod at them with occasional dodging, or just run past the enemies entirely.The game save system is not fun- manual saves at certain locations.  There are few automatic checkpoints.  To work around the crappy retry system in place, your best bet is to pack a lot of health potions to spam your way though a boss fight.  Dieing and replaying long sections, or easy mode spamming health potions as needed.  Neither outcome is fun for me.  This game does not make me want to get good at it.For me, the open world structure of the game causes the story to loose so much momentum that I stopped caring about it.  That is coming from someone who loves anime girls, sexy boots, swords and robots.It seems like I'm the only person who feels this way about the game.  I wish that I liked it, but it is not for me.

												I only played this for an hour, so who knows? This could be a good game. Probably not though.The game appears to be set in a post-apocalyptic world where the mascots for Google's "Android" OS have risen up to launch terrifyingly slow projectiles at you and throw themselves en masse onto your waiting sword. This is exactly as horrific as it sounds and raises questions of "How did these daft creatures manage to overthrow humanity?" and "Is Google aware / complicit in it's mascot's machinations" and "When is this game going to let me save?"After smashing through a tonne or so of enemies with less effort than it takes for my step father to snort a line, I began to feel a nervous tension as i sensed the epic beating that usually follows such little effort. It was at this point that i Alt + Tabbed, and politely asked Google "how the ♥♥♥♥ to i save in Nier: Automata"To which Google replied "The wonderful weirdness of NieR: Automata - VideoGamer.com" in which reviewer Adam Cook states "Nier: Automata is a ♥♥♥♥ing weird video game."Thanks Google...I soldier on, certain that a $60 game wouldn't send me 30 minutes into a game without a save point... It's at this point that i'm ambushed by to big digging... wheel... things... I don't know why digging wheels have this much articulation. It seems a little excessive for what i can only assume is a pretty straight forward operation. But i'm not a miner, so whatever. They beat me... and i'm presented with the title screen again. I hope and pray that the little info box that appears at the start of the game saying "no auto saves in this game" was just a little joke on the developers part...nope, restart the game... unskippable cut scene... same waves of suicidal mascots... I'm done. You lost me Nier.

												My advice is to know what you are getting going in, because i didn't This isn't the latest awesome hack and slash experience from platinum games. It's a story heavy, anime trope laced hybrid between RPG, SHMUP and hack and slash. So if you are here looking for soemthing like Bayonetta or Metal Gear Rising, I can't recommend this. I don't like the top down shmup sections, and theres alot of them, in no less than 3 or 4 variations, so its a big, important part of the game. The Visuals are generally very nice though. The hack and slash gameplay, the little i played of it seemed disappointingly basic because of the focus on the many other aspects of the game. I actually admire games with the courage to go the hybrid genre route, but i bought this game on Platinums reputation, which came with some perhaps unfair explactations, which just wanted to believe that it was a different game than it is. If you want a hack and slash, pass on it. If you want an interactive anime trope novel with a hybrid genre and gorgeous visuals, it may be for you. But for me, I found myself listening to paragraphs of cringy anime trope dialogue and entering another borign shmup section and i decided my money wasn't well spent.

number of helpful: 6 of 34 people (18%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
23
												I finished the game. My save data was deleted. "Thanks for playing"I can't beleive that's a feature of the game...Aside from that, the game's story itself is beyond bizzare in how it's told. I'm not sure exactly why they decided this, but this is the basics.Spoilers below---------------------TLDR; The game only gets good after ~13 hours. That's not fair or good game design. The 9S playthrough feels like work very quickly. A2 is the only good playable character. There is a great game hidden somewhere in here, but it never gets to see the light of day for long enough.The game is essentially split into 3 parts. The first part has you play out as the mascot of the game, 2B. This is all well and good, and the gameplay is pretty solid. The ending to this storyline however, is not. It happens about 8 hours in and tries so hard to be dramatic and sad. It just isn't. I barely care about these characters. On top of that, if they die they just have their memorys put into another android body exactly like the old one. The fact that you as the player constantly save means that dying means no loss of memory. But the ending to 2B's storyline tried to make it seem like neither character backed up their memories during the entire game... What? Poorly done and seemed super cheesy.Next up is you playing as 9S. This is fun at first as you now delve into the hacking portion of the game which is essentially a small bullet hell...well not hell, more like inconvienince. There are only around 10 truely unique hacking stages and since your best bet to defeat enemies is hacking, you'll burn through those 10 fast. Then it's all repeat. This is on top of the fact that you are playing almost an exact copy of the first playthorugh as far as the story is concerned. The only upside is that this is shorter; only about 4-5 hours or so. After this is where the game gets serious. I wish the entire game was as well executed as the last playthrough. If you stop playing after the first or second one, you haven't even really played the game. That's a huge problem. Why do I have to slog through 13 hours of gameplay to get to the actual good part of a game? It's like the rest was just a bad tutorial. So what's so good about the 3rd playthrough (yeah, there's 3...). Well, instead of focusing on a single character, the game swaps between 2; 9S and A2. 9S is the boring one of the two, but it's much better this time simply because you get a break from him when the story swaps to A2. Play an hour or two of one and swap to the other. A2 is also in general fun to play because you have some risk vs. reward in terms of dealing damage. The new berserk mode and taunting enemies helps to make combat a little more exciting considering how strong you are by this point in the game.The other huge improvement is the story. You see 9S break down slowly, and this time you actually understand why. A2 shows atleast a little character development, and the fact that she is fun to play as makes you actually care about the character that much more. Towards the end however, the story tries to tie up all the lose ends and honestly fails. The one good part about the 3rd playthroughs endings is the fact that you can opt to play a long and difficult bullet hell section where the credits attack you. Just when it starts to get tedious, the game throws a seemingly impossible section at you(It just so happens to start with the words "Square Enix" attacking) which then turns into a neat section where people who have also gotten this far all come together to help you finish it. But there is a catch.Do not make the same mistake I did. There is a cost to recieving help. Every. Single. Person. who helps you and you let die? That's someone's save files. All of them. Now some people probably made a backup because they played the other Nier game before this. I didn't.The game asks you if you would like to save someone. YesIt will cost you your save data. Yes, I have 3You worked so hard to get this far. YesYou won't get any thanks for it from that player. Yes, I'll just reload a little further backOk.The game then makes you watch as it deletes everything individually on the pause menu. Then as a huge ♥♥♥♥ you, it deletes all THREE save files LAST. I didn't think the game would do that, why would it? I said I would give up my save data to help someone, not delete everything ever. It's not that the game was unclear, just that I can't think of a reason why I would like that feature. Most people who do this just backup their data first, so what is the point of this feature? It only aims to frustrate people like me who got hit with the ultimate troll. Now there is a huge portion of the game's content that I'll never experience because I can't bring myself to play through the boring 13 hours that is the beginning of the game.What content did I miss? There are 5 'real' endings. I got all of those. There are also 21 other joke endings. Some are more obscure than others. I missed out on almost all of them. Also, if I want to play a little more as A2? Gotta play through ~13 hours of the game all over again.I do not recommend this game. There is far to much work expected of the player for far too little payoff in the end. The gameplay used in A2's arch should have been used throught the whole game. It would have made a huge difference in my opinion. I really, really wanted to like this game. There is a great game somewhere in there, but it's too few and far between.

												I got some hours playing and not finished the game. I'll try to make it simple and short for whoever will read this, with my pros and cons:+ Beautiful music+ Good playability and nice (and fast) combats+ Nice butt (XD)- No skill tree, so you lvl up and can't do a s**t with that, it just add status to your character- Locked at 60 fps and still horrible stuttering when moving around the map or in combat- The worst point is that after some hours of gameplay the game starts getting boring, repetitive, and with no skill tree I lose motivation for killing machines- Secondary missions are (again) repetitive and simple- Graphics are simply not good, there are tons of games with 5+ years old and they look much better, and the colors in this game are badSo, maybe it's a good game for people that's new in this kind of game or PC gaming (mainly for the fps cap and graphics, oh and the frame drops) but not for other people, especially when a game gets boring, because It is the opposite of what you are looking for in a game.Note that you can upgrade your weapons and add chips to your body, improving status and getting some abilities, but even then I feel like I was playing the same battles again and again. Just my point of view.

content:

												I was a big big fan of the original Nier. The world, the story, the characters and especially the music all stood out to me. The combat was lacklustre but it didn't matter but it made up for it with the rest. Here we have the opposite. I couldn't get further than the Beauvoir boss or whatever it was called before cracks started to show. The world is boring, not helped by the Playstation 2 graphics. The story hadn't started when i stopped, and that was a couple of hours into the game! The characters had were cardboard cutouts with nothing going for them. I'll admit, though, the music is still very good. Other than that, the difficulty is another point of hate for me. Easy and Normal are both exactly the same. They allow you to lock on (which saves you from using the TERRIBLE camera) and the game is so easy to beat it's laughable. On hard, however, you lose the lock on feature and most things kill you in one hit. On very hard, things kill you even harder. The rift between the two difficulties is huge and jarring to say the least. Finally, it's a crap port. It's locked to 60fps and 30 fps in Cutscenes. All the text boxes linger on the screen for too long after each sentences and, oh my god, the voice acting is dreadful. 2/10. Bad game. Saved from 1/10 by the music.

NieR: Automata is a linear action with bad controls, unbalanced difficulty and forgettable story. 1/3 of the game is mini-games (bullet hell). Achievements are a joke after you've completed the main story. Soundtrack and pre-rendered cut-scenes are excellent. Side quests are well-written, yet standard (mostly, "go to A point and back", "destroy X enemies", "gather N items"), linear and involve a lot of backtracking. Two interesting bosses (Simone, the songstress, and Eve). Two relatively meaningful choices, leading to the same unsatisfying ending.

												TL;DR: Solid combat, a lot of cool ideas, not all executed well, with restrictive save system straight out of the 90s. Interesting game, but only play if you can invest a long chunk of time in the beginning.My first thoughts:Terrible controls and still no savepoint after 1h of playtime? If the game does not respect my time, it can go **** itself.So... Next day:I got the time to move past the first way too long section and give the gameplay after that a try. Super solid combat, after remapping all buttons to something sensible. Story seems pretty wacko, but that's what I was expecting.The save-system can still take a **** up its ***. I see what it wants to do. It wants to be Dark Souls. It wants to have bonfires. It wants you to lose your XP when you die, so that you must retrieve it from your corpse... yeah, Dark Souls. The problem with that: Dark Souls doesn't punish you with endless waiting, cutscenes and long travel times between tries at a specific enemy. You also don't have to win a terrible bullet-hell-shooter in-between tries.What this game needed was some guy that just sat down with the designers, drank a tea with them to calm their nerves, and asked them to f****** focus on a few mechanics and roll with them, instead of getting bored after having them 80% done and moving on to a new one! It makes for a crazy, but rather unpolished ride. Give it a try, if you are brave. But beware of the problems, cause there are many.

												The following is simply my opinion of the behaviour of the publisher of this game.I purchased this game on the 17th of March 2017 from my local games shop (EB Games Australia). This was the advertised release date, as given by my local retailer AND the official Square Enix online store for my region.I could not play this game on the 17th of March. The Steam frontend accepted the game key, pre-loaded the data, but would not allow me to launch the game.I contacted the retailer, EB Games head office, by telephone and requested that it be unlocked. I was promised a telephone call back that day, but I never received one.I contacted Square Enix support by email, and I received several rudely dismissive responses. Square Enix support openly admitted that the game did not unlock on the 17th March Australian time, as advertised on their website, and they accused me, stating that it was my fault for assuming that it would.The AUSTRALIAN retailer, EB Games, stated that the game would be available on 17th March 2017.The AUSTRALIAN online storefront for Square Enix clearly stated that the game will be available on 17th March 2017.I trusted that information applied to AUSTRALIAN time zones, and Square Enix told me that I was wrong to do so.By this point I was too frustrated and alienated by the behaviour of the retailer (EB Games) and the publisher's official support (Square Enix). I was also upset that I had been misled regarding the release date. I contacted EB Games and requested a refund, to which they -eventually- agreed.I cannot support a publisher that misleads customers, and then blames the customers for accepting their word.I cannot support a retailer that promises to look into a problem, but then fails to respond in a timely fashion.If someone sells me a product under false pretenses, I will demand a refund.If someone treats me like a fool because I accepted the content of their advertising, I will demand a refund.The game itself might be fantastic. I do not know, and I do not want to know. I have no intention of ever buying or playing this game again. I will not support companies that treat me in this manner, and I feel that it reflects badly enough upon the products they produce to merit a negative review.The experience around trying to simply access the game for which I had paid full retail price was, in my opinion, disgusting. As such, I am using this review as a warning.If you disagree with my reason behind this negative review, then please do go ahead and downvote me. Downvote me into oblivion if you want; I do not care. You are just as welcome to register your discontent over my review as I am to register my discontent over the product for which I paid. However, I feel that the principal of the matter still stands: lying and misleading in advertising is wrong.

content:
19
												Let's start with the one positive thing I can cite without exception.MusicThe music in this game is absolutely incredible.  The soundtrack is amazing.  It's catchy, memorable, and suitably atmospheric.  Great stuff worth listening to, even outside of the game.Now on to everything else... Starting with the controls.ControlsJust plug in a controller.  The KB+M input is absolutely terrible - spamming dodge becomes more and more required as the game advances, and double-tapping a movement key to dodge becomes impractical when you need to jam out 2 dodges a second to avoid chain attacks.  Seriously, use a controller.There's a significant amount of ranged combat in the game (especially the final boss), which is a huge pain for me.  I can't aim ranged weapons with sticks in a 3d environment (I use KBM for my shooters), so I had to endure most of the game using melee only.  The final boss can only be damaged by ranged attacks, so I can't fairly determine how hard that boss is supposed to be.  Suffice to say, it was INCREDIBLY difficult for me because I just couldn't aim well enough to him.  (which is particularly hard given that fight occurs in a sandstorm)The IntroductionThe introduction begins with an 80's style top-down Shoot 'Em Up ala Gradius or Life Force, only far far simpler and way easier.  The sequence is roughly 20 minutes long, full of cutscenes, and completely unskippable.  Shortly after this schmup sequence is completed, you're set into the game's actual combat system and allowed to practice against a handful of easily defeatable dummy robots.After nailing the dummy bots, you'll be toss up against the game's first boss.  Most of his attacks will kill you in just 2-3 hits on Normal, but there's an auto-healing ability built-in to your character at the start that uses your healing items automatically when you become critically damaged.Unfortunately, this boss also has a wonderful move that is impossible to dodge without spamming the dodge button to chain "perfect dodges" in a row.  Should the attack hit you, you will instantly die and be sent back to the title screen.  And have to play the entire schmup sequence all over again. Even after beating this boss, you've still got another 30 minutes and one more boss fight (that thankfully, can't instantly kill you this time around) before you're finally allowed to save.  (On that note, if you have Microsoft OneDrive, disable it, the game will lie to you and say it saved successfully, but OneDrive actually blocked it with read-only permissions!)General GameplayThere's an "open world" aspect to the game, complete with side-quests.  Unfortunately, the world isn't that large or "open".  You're generally on rails heading into each area.  Then "open world" serves a time waster as you traverse back and forth across the same terrain fighting the same enemies over and over again.  You'll eventually get to a point where you just run past the enemies because you're sick of fighting the same thing over and over.The CombatThis is where the game really, really falls apart.  There's a lot of problems - let's break them down, one by one.1. The Camera: This thing is your WORST ENEMY.  It's slow, it doesn't automatically rotate to keep enemies (even bosses) in view, requiring you to manually pan the thing around to see what you're looking at.  Even using the built in "quick turn" feature, it'll take a couple of seconds to drunkely steer itself 180 degrees behind you so you can see what's currently trying to have its way with your ♥♥♥.  It's like the camera is a physical entity in the world, and not nearly responsive enough for such a fast paced game.2. Damage Scaling: After the introduction, the combat isn't so bad.  You get a feel for your weapons and can start taking risks to learn your limitations now that death doesn't mean replaying the introduction all over again.Unfortunately, by the last third of the game (last 2 hours, it's roughly 6 hours long), enemies start gaining massive amounts of HP and attack.  Common enemies will wipe you out in three hits, bosses in two.  Literally the final bosses have +500,000 HP and you're still dealing only 63 + 24 damage per light attack, as high as 90 + 19 for heavy attacks, and only 6 damage per "pew pew" pellet from your little robot buddy.  It turns every single boss into a ridiculous endurance marathon.  I clocked the 3rd to last boss - it took me 23 minutes to kill.  Also, the game crashed right after that, requiring me to fight it again.  (Granted, that's the ONLY time the game ever crashed on me, at least)The StoryUp front, I didn't care for a story going in.  I like my action, a good story is just a bonus.After completeing the game, I can say the story itself is nothing special.  The characters are all predictable and one dimensional - and that's okay.  I liked Metal Gear Rising: Revengence's characters, despite having the same qualities.  However, MGR was "self-aware" that it was an over-the-top spectacle fighter and played with the tropes for fun.Nier seems to take itself way, way too seriously.  Overwrought, overly dramatic, and serious to a fault.  That said, the work that went into presenting the story is exceptional.  This is some top-notch presentation here.  Unfortunately, it's in service of something that takes itself too seroiusly and aspires to be much more than it actually is.VerdictDo not buy.  The combat becomes a dull chore near the end, the camera is constantly fighting you, and the story isn't worth suffering through the gameplay for.  This is strictly an "average" game with a large budget, a big name, and a popular studio behind it.  Ultimately, had anyone else been responsible for creating it, it wouldn't be yielding the high praise that it currently is.

												First and foremost, here's one huge CON.You need to know that they couldn't decide what kind of game they wanted to make so they made 3-4 types of games in 1. RPG/side scrolling Platformer/Spaceship style shooter/Gauntlet style hacker. The game constantly changes from a perfect 3rd person RPG hack and slash with a shooter option to a side scrolling platformer and them the camera will zoom way up overhead so you are now playing a sort of Gauntlet style game where jumping to avoid enemies becomes pointless due to the overhead angle. It also will have you flying, taking on enemies from every angle so you have to now deal with aiming one way while you run another which is just plain stupid.If you notice the trailers and gameplay they released, it NEVER shows this. Because they know they wouldn't sell the game.The Game is made well and I had no crashes so I won't be asking for a refund because I'm not some infant that demands a refund because I don't like the game. There is NO save sytem for you to save when you feel like it. You can only save between missions.There is a distinct lack of color in the game. It's white-washed and bland.When I first started playing, the game was so SLOOOOOOOW. It had serious lag/framerate issues that got better and worse depending on the amount of enemies there were on the screen. Or if I got near lava/molten metal, the game got amazingly slow. Like some graphics caused it to have to work harder just to run.The "map" is a joke for the most part. Like I said, I won't be demanding a refund but I definately don't recomend the game.

content:

												Alright, just so the rabid fanboy's of this game/company can't say I never gave the game a fair chance, I've got nearly 10 hours on record, I've sacrificed my Steam refund eligibility for this game, all for the sake of trying to crack it and see why anybody actually likes this game, here's what I've found;Pros:- Decent graphics- Hold 'B', kinda the only real selling point of this gameCons:- Drops you into the story head-first with no explaination whatsoever- Boring/Spammy combat (Find enemy, press 'Attack', rinse, repeat. Nothing special)- Enemies are tanky for no reason other than to have the illusion of difficulty- Weak/Predictable story, with as far as I've gotten in my 10 hours playtime, everything was bland, boring, predictable, uninspired... you get the point, again, 'Nothing special'- Lacklustre world design, big empty buildings, samey structures, scenery and architecture- No auto-save, not even at very important parts of the game (I don't care if that's "How it's supposed to be", it's a poor design choice, and I think they should've decided that maybe that's not how it should be.- Terrible camera direction (Don't give me that "Oh it's 'expermiental'"♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, if it doesn't work, don't do it. I don't need the game changing from Bullet Hell to Sidescrolling platformer to Third-person over-the-shoulder, to Top-down or whatever, pick one, and stick with it, it's a lot less nauseating and annoying.- Random rogue-like elements tossed in for 'flavor' (Much as with the previous point, if it doesn't work, don't do it. This mechanic doesn't add anything to the game, it just adds another chore. Doesn't make fights any more perilous, it only makes dying that much more frustrating, and for no reason other than to try and perpetuate the illusion of difficulty that this game seems deperate to try and fabricate.)So, all in all I would say this game was a flop. Of course the fanboys don't see it that way, because Daddy Platinum can do no wrong. Nothing against the other games Platinum has made, I haven't played a lot of them, I have no clue if they're good or bad, but maybe that's why I'm not heads-over-heels for this game, because I don't believe in giving games a pass based off the merits of games previously developed by the company. Looking at this game individually and judging it by it's own merits though, It's a hot-mess that I can't believe Square Enix signed off on.At last, as if my recommendation wasn't enough, this game is simply nothing special or amazing. Why anybody would openly defend this game wholeheartedly is beyond me. I mean, I get it if you're just in love with 2B's thighs, I get it, but just be honest about it and don't try to pretend like your love for the game is anything more than that. At best this game is eye-candy with a touch of frustration, boredom and the corpse of a better story just decaying somewhere deep inside with just enough 'action' to keep you firmly planted at the back of your seat. Y'know, maybe the game is worth 'something', but it sure as ♥♥♥♥ ain't worth $60 I'll tell you that.Now come crucify me fanboys, not like you haven't already.If you need a second opinion that's prehaps phrased better or more eloquently, just watch this; http://www.escapistmagazine.com/videos/view/zero-punctuation/117019-Nier-Automata-Review

												From the mind of Game Director, Yoko Ono (creator of the original Nier and Alpine Racer 2) comes Nier: Automata. A brutally boring, beat-em-up brawler. Not only is this game his most uninspired work yet, the level of difficulty of this game will turn off any casual gamer.Cons: -Story leaves a lot to be desired.-Game controls very poorly on a joystick.-Battle system is way too hard, even on beginner difficulty.-Robots look unrealistic.-Open world leads to confusion quite often.-Weird buzzing at all times? (something with AI whirligig that rotates around the character?)-Why would an advanced AI from the future use a sword? Dumb.-VR support is very limited-References to Nanking Massacre being made up(???)Pros:+Framerate runs at a smooth 30 FPS even on the lowly GTX 1070+Great sound effects+Transgender Protagonist All in all: not much good, lotta bad. Give this one a hard pass. Japanese Review (降伏の条件): 私たちの良い、忠実な主題：世界の一般的な傾向と今日の私たちの帝国で取得している実際の状況を深く熟考した上で、我々は臨時措置に頼って現状を解決することに決めました。我々は、米国政府、英国、中国、ソ連の各国政府に対し、我が国帝国が共同宣言の条項を受け入れるよう、政府に指示するよう指示した。すべての国の共通の繁栄と幸福のために、そして私たちの主題の安全と幸福のために努力することは、私たちの帝国祖先によって伝承され、私たちの心の近くにある厳粛な義務です。確かに、私たちは、日本の自己保全と東アジアの安定を確実にすることを心から願って、アメリカと英国との戦争を宣言しました。それは、他国の主権を侵害したり、しかし、今や戦争はほぼ4年間続きました。軍事力と海軍力の勇敢な戦い、国家の僕たちの奉仕者の勤勉さと誠実さ、私たちの億人の献身的な奉仕など、誰もがした最高の努力にもかかわらず、戦争の状況は必ずしも日本の優位性、世界の一般的な傾向はすべて彼女の興味に逆らっている。

Unclear, unexplained idea of health, which spontaineously recovers for no apparent reason. Flickering UI panels, that disappear so fast, that you cannot read what it says. Din't see any promise for a sensible story either - a couple of meaningless dialogues in an hour of gameplay. You probably have to be true JRPG fan to enjoy playing that.

												Sorry, it seemed kind of fun to play and very charismatic. But I died fooling around on the first boss just to see what I could and couldn't get away with, and whether there were weaknesses I should be going for or just dodging. And so I got sent back to the start of the game to repeat the easy section that had just taken me half an hour.You can say git gud all you like, but part of gitting gud is being able to figure out what works and what doesn't. "Hard" games make you git gud enough to get past a roadblock, but they generally don't throw huge time sinks in the way for failure. That's not fun, and it doesn't make me git guder any faster. I'm not paying $60 to have my time wasted because I tried to learn how to play the game. That shows no respect for the player. It was fun though, so I'll be back when it's less than $20 and I don't feel like I'm paying a premium to have the developer giggle at how they made me repeatedly trudge through stuff that wasn't challenging just so that I could have another shot at the hard bit.TLDR: Good game, bad design philosophy for anyone who doesn't look up on the internet how to beat fights before going in. Or isn't a gaming god with tens of hours to spend each day playing.

number of helpful: 113 of 600 people (19%) found this review helpful114 people found this review funny
content:
17
												(POST - PLAYTHROUGH EDIT) This is, hands down, one of the greatest games I've ever played in my life. Buy this game.This is a good game because I bought it. Tastes fine. Smell alright. Very large graphics. Would not reccomend to the age of anyone. Purchase this game.FirstHere's my actual review.First off, let's talk about the port. It's not nearly as bad as the plethora of negative reviews would lead you to believe. Actually, it's probably one of the better ports out there. The framerate has yet to give me any problems, it glides through the game in smooth 60 fps. (Cutscenes are a whole different story, though.) The controls work fine as well. I feel like this shouldn't have to be said, but if you plan on enjoying many of the games that you have at your disposal on PC, you need to buy a controller, and there's no getting around it. The keyboard and mouse, while versatile, is not the ideal method of playstyle for many of these games, so drop the "I didn't buy this game to buy a controller" BS, splurge a little, and buy yourself an Afterglow 360 controller for $18. I'm sure that if you have a computer that can play games like these, you can at least afford something like that without going hungry. Now, on to the game itself.Now, I'm a fan of Squeenix and Platinum games, but I had no knowledge of their collaboration with Yoko Taro on this game until recently. I was a bit wary of this title, considering the first Nier received less than favorable reviews, and that this game had only been conceived as a result of the cult following it accumulated, but ultimately, I'm glad I took the dive and purchased this game.I have had no experience with the previous Nier games, but I'm told that it had a tendency to mix up the genres on the fly, much to the dismay of many people playing the game. Obviously, the gameplay wasn't great. You can see that just from watching playthroughs of the game on youtube, and the story was what brought it so much attenton. However, here, these changes feel smooth and crisp. In only the first level, you're playing a bullet hell, a rail shooter, a brawler, a twin stick shooter, and even gameplay resembling that of Strider, and it all works well. Nothing feels sloppy, and it's almost as if you're going through a series of smaller, snappy minigames in between the main focus of the game, the hacking and slashing. All of your movements in combat feel appropriate, and every time I've taken damage in combat, I've always been able to clearly define my mistake and understand what I did to deserve the punishment that was delivered in response. The combat is polished, satisfying, and fun, which is all I ask for in my games.One thing that really surprised me when picking up this game was the detail in the combat animations in particular. Part of what helps the game not feel as slippery as some other hack n slashers is the fact that every movement feels like it has significant weight to it. If you ever get the chance, just watch 2B make a single action from one button press and observe every element of her movement. Heavy attacks look just as heavy as they should be, with particle effects and sound queues appropriately matching the action shown, followed by a slow recovery (That can be cancelled with another attack or a dodge, mind you.) That makes sense, considering the impact of the movement. Light attacks, as you'd expect, are a lot more floaty. Swift attacks and sharper sound queues are brief and crisp enough so you can easily tell what kind of damage is being done and what kind of action was just made.I will not say anything about the story.With this all being said, do I reccomend this game? Yeah. It really does feel like a game that "has something for everyone", and I've been enjoying myself so far. Check your specs to make sure you can run it well enough, and avoid looking at any review that starts with "The port". You're less likely to receive the information you came here for, which is obviously, "Is this game any good, and should I buy it?"And to that question, I answer yes.

												This is a true master piece! The world feels alive, great dialogue and graphics are phenomenal.The weapons are fun to use, lots of combos to pull off. Different levels of challenge if you so choose so. Voiced in Japanese and English. Accompanied by 9S (which is a pleasure to listen to his dialogue)throughout your adventures along with the pods. Game seems very well optimized for the PC, I do get some low frames during very populated bot areas and during certain cut-scenes, but for the most part I'm pleased with the frame rates. The way the game forces the camera into top down, side view(shoot-'em up arcade game) is a welcoming fresh experience in a fully 3rd person RPG.  Not to mention the use of the pod being your personal infinite projectile shooter is awesome! Including the fact that 2B(your character) has no limit/stamina so you can potentially sprint/dodge for as long as you want.It's easy to see that the developers had alot of fun creating this game and pulled out all the stops to make this game a 10/10. Best to give this game a shot, I'm very content with this purchase.I can see myself completing this game.

												This game has no business being as good as it is. On paper, it's the most derivative, overwrought game imaginable. Hot anime babes in EGL gear with swords killing robots. Yet it manages to be fantastic by virtue of its apparent self-awareness, deft directorial style, and eclectic gameplay. So while being a closet weeb (like me) might help you appreciate it, it's not at all pre-requisite.I should mention that the self-awareness I'm talking about doesn't manifest in an over-the-top, breaking the fourth wall, winking to the camera kind of way. This game isn't impressed with its own cleverness the way some other games and anime are. Rather, it's fully sublimated into the gameplay and story with nice little touches you might not even notice at first. There are countless references to other games, genres of games... and some of these references are a bit oblique, so only aficionados of RPGs, Shmups, etc. might appreciate them. However, despite all the in-jokes and the frenetic pace at which gameplay styles change, the game manages to be really accessible. NieR: Automata isn't a really hard shmup, or a really hard action rpg, or a really hard platformer. The difficulty arises from the need to change between these different ways of thinking, sometimes at a breakneck pace. And yet the experience manages to be totally cohesive and intuitive. This might be disappointing for some people looking for a brutally punishing action rpg experience, but for those who want a JRPG that moves at a nice pace and isn't grindy, it's wonderful.I can't speak to the overall quality/pacing of the story, as I'm only 4 hours in, but so far it's managed to be curiously compelling.Technical details regarding the port:Everything except the cutscenes is very smooth for me on high settings, even with AA, Blur, etc. The cutscenes drop considerably in framerate, frequently below 30—even though they don't actually look any different. So I imagine this is because there's background loading happening while the cutscenes are playing? It's not the biggest problem because the cutscenes are mostly very short, but I still really hope they fix this in a patch.My setup: Windows 10Intel i7 4790 GTX 1070 8gb16gb Ram

												So far seems very good, a final fantasy type of RPG with regularly changing combat modes from top down shooter to 'Devil May Cry-esque' to 'Einhander' & 'Starfox'The Good:  Playing for about an hour and a half now, and I've played "bullet-hell" style shooting sequences alongside a well put together 3rd-person beat-em-up sequences, the changing perspectives and styles flow pretty well and keep things interesting.  Gameplay looks great at solid 60fps 2K with a GTX 1070, and I'm looking forward to dumping alot of time into this game! The not-so-good:  Many cutscenes stutter pretty badly and cut the framerate to 30fps.  I would prefer unlocked framerates, and some of the nice scenic cutscenes that do play at 60fps are hampered by transluscent black bars at the top and bottom of the screen...I also think the 3rd person 'DMC' mode could pull the camera out a bit, it makes for a kind of claustrophobic battle in some areas, though when the view pulls out for side-scroller and flight I think it's perfect.   Recommend!
