												There are some definite technical issues that pretty much every other review has discussed, but with my i7 6700k, 970, and 16gigabutts of RAM I'm able to run the game at 60FPS with most of the gwafix options at second highest, shadows at medium, and motion blur off (it makes me sick, no idea if it actually effects performance since I keep it off). The fullscreen 1920x1080 bug sucks, but I didn't really notice it until going into the Steam overlay and there's a borderless windowed program you can use that makes it properly run at 1920x1080.Now as for the game, I went in with my expectations fairly low since I really didn't care for the demo when I tried it on PS4. Maybe it's because I'm now two feet from the screen instead of an entire room lengths away so now I can see everything a lot better, but it was a lot more enjoyable now than it was before. The bullet-hell segments are really fun and make you feel badass and the combat feels smoother than I remember it being. It's also a really pretty game, the first level doesn't really show it due to the entire color pallet being rusty reds and browns, but the city ruins afterwards looks really nice with the dull-ish greys of the ruins with the vibrant greens of the forest that's growing over everything. Music is top notch and is definitely something that I'd listen to outside of the game. While she didn't compose it, the music really reminds me of Yuki Kajiura's work for whatever reason so if you've enjoyed her stuff (Madoka, Fate/Zero, SAO, .Hack//Sign as examples) then you'll probably like Automata's music as well.the valve accessory you get in the Day One Edition is surprisingly cute and its vibrant red color fits really well with 2B's entirely white and black attire.ALSO F I S H I N GTHE ULTIMATE OF ALL VIDEO GAME THINGS

content:

												Fantastic game. Few problems, though.There are spoilers, but only within the spoiler tags.I have a GTX 1070. While the framerate is almost always 60, except for occasional stutters which are pretty ♥♥♥♥, the game uses an insane amount of GPU horsepower compared to how the game looks. My pc smashes the reccommended specs, yet it's concerning that a card like this is having trouble. Are people with anything less straight up ♥♥♥♥ed?The texture work and draw distance in most areas are, for lack of a better word, ♥♥♥♥. There also seems to be a weird problem with texture streaming, resulting in a low quality texture that only properly loads in after a delay. Oh, and stuttering.I'm not sure if I'm just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but I've encountered quite a few quests where I accept, go to the place, and the objective or NPC is missing. 11B's Memento comes to mind. I picked up the mission from 16D, went through the factory while simultaneously completing another objective. Arrived at the spot where her corpse should be, accompanied by an orange marker, just like any other quest, and she was nowhere to be found. Returning to 16D, who said the exact same line of text she had said before I departed, seemed to have made the body spawn. This also happened on The Wandering Couple questline. Twice.Invisible walls. I've heard of people saying "Oh, it's just their way of messing with you." Nah. It's just laziness. I get that there's supposed to be boundaries, but there's so many areas that should obviously be traversible, but aren't.The usual bugs that everyone is reporting. Resolutions above 900p in fullscreen are upscaled. Mouse cursor stuck on top of the screen etc. Not a huge deal, and there are workarounds. I hope this is fixed soon.It's not all bad. Not at all.The synnergy that 2B and 9S have as characters is charming, as are their "operators" who are somewhat like caretakers. Most of the characters are likable to an extent.The world building is amazing. The terrain, while often looking a little gaudy as far as textures and geometry go, is varied and interesting. The shortcuts make it all come together, and things make sense geographically for the most part. The colour palette is dark and gloomy, but it fits so well. The overall presentation is nice.The map is large, but not too large. Most of it is tightly packed to the point where traversal does not feel like a chore, yet is not so compressed that it seems like too much ♥♥♥♥ going on in the same area.The soundtrack is phenomenal. Easily one of the best soundtracks in a game I've heard for a long time. While some tracks don't stand out too much, others are great and the tunes will stick in your head. Overall, the package comes together great.2B got nice bootyThe side quests help flesh out the world, and are usually pretty interesting. Sometimes they're a bit frustrating, but I haven't had a game make me actively do the side quests and send me to areas I would otherwise visit once and never return, where I've noticed new things or found story information.Speaking of story, the way the story is delivered is interesting. It's fragmented, and doesn't always shove everything into your face. There's even subtle things in the background, like when 6O starts a communication with 2B because she confessed her feelings to another operator, who turned her down. I have a feeling that the operator she confessed to was 21O (9S' operator). The game, up to the point I've currently played to, (C) has not confirmed nor denied, but it's little things like this that are fun to think about.This is a good video game, sometimes it gets a bit edgy, and you may not like it for various other reasons such as genre, gameplay, characters, or even the art style. But if you like Yoko Taro games, or Platinum, or simply enjoy this type of game, give it a go. It might pay to wait until some of the issues are ironed out before buying, though.Oh, and one more thing. Think with your brain, not with your ♥♥♥♥.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
18
												This has been my first JRPG ever, and let me tell you, so far it has been an amazing game to open me up to the world of JRPGs and RPGs alike. In my first 8 hours of playthrough (which will probably be higher by the time you read this), I have experienced a challenge that actually punishes you for dying, fair and interesting progression, two unique and fun mini-boss battles, and an intense boss battle that required you to understand the mechanics fully to defeat the boss successfully.Pros:- Graphics: The graphics for me have been stunning and smooth. I have the game set at 1920x1080p with max texture settings (Nvidia 970) and have been experiencing almost no lag or frame drops. The closest I've come to lag/frame drops is when I teleport to another location and just load in, although the frame rate almost immediately fixes itself.- Story: The story in this game despite having a slightly cliche intro turns out to be intricate and unique in many ways. The general background of the story is that aliens have attacked Earth with their robots they've created, and the few humans who have survived fled to the Moon to begin the Resistance and YoRHa Android Infantry. You as 2B, the main character, are an android soldier in YoRHa whose been tasked with tough missions against the robots on Earth. From then on you learn all the twists and turns the game's story has to offer, and what has just begun to happen down on Earth.- Gameplay: The fighting/combat system was created by Platinum Games, and as I've seen and been told by others, there's no doubt that it's fantastic. And experiencing it for myself, I can safely come to the conclusion that those people are right. Nothing in the combat system felt clunky, there are not a ton of attacks and combos available which I personally prefer (having to learn and master 30+ attack pattterns/combos isn't that appealling to me), and the attack patterns/combos the combat system does have are well designed and very easy to pick up.- Music: As a gamer, music is something that I listen closely for. Nier Automata's soundtrack has been fantastic so far, with intense tracks for heated battles, calm and casual tracks for neutral/allied areas, and cheerful and upbeat tunes for the happier places in the world. This soundtrack has been so good so far that I have already listened to and fell asleep to it. Not sure if they've made the soundtrack purchasable yet, but if or once they release it I will most definitely instabuy it.Cons:- Choices: So far in my playthrough of Nier Automata, I have been faced with little to no choices I can make that affect what happens and what plays out in the game. Maybe I haven't gotten far enough yet to need to make important choices, but there are a few things that I would have liked to do or chosen to do different throughout the story so far. But if you expect a wide variety of choices or multiple choices you can make that affect the game, this game might not be the best for that.- Weapon Variety: I have come across a few choices of weapons so far, that look different and play slightly different, but none of them have been better than my upgraded original one yet. This may just be a problem on my end because I may need to get farther or explore some more, but otherwise I have no reason to buy a replacement weapon from the weapon shop at the Resistance Camp (one of the main places you head to often)Aside from that, there's really nothing else I can think of that needs improvement. The game is very polished and enjoyable in my opinion, and from the negative things I've seen people saying about this game, it's more than likely an issue with their hardware and graphics settings rather than the game's "poor PC port." Because I haven't had a single issue regarding the graphics on my end.

												This has been my first JRPG ever, and let me tell you, so far it has been an amazing game to open me up to the world of JRPGs and RPGs alike. In my first 8 hours of playthrough (which will probably be higher by the time you read this), I have experienced a challenge that actually punishes you for dying, fair and interesting progression, two unique and fun mini-boss battles, and an intense boss battle that required you to understand the mechanics fully to defeat the boss successfully.Pros:- Graphics: The graphics for me have been stunning and smooth. I have the game set at 1920x1080p with max texture settings (Nvidia 970) and have been experiencing almost no lag or frame drops. The closest I've come to lag/frame drops is when I teleport to another location and just load in, although the frame rate almost immediately fixes itself.- Story: The story in this game despite having a slightly cliche intro turns out to be intricate and unique in many ways. The general background of the story is that aliens have attacked Earth with their robots they've created, and the few humans who have survived fled to the Moon to begin the Resistance and YoRHa Android Infantry. You as 2B, the main character, are an android soldier in YoRHa whose been tasked with tough missions against the robots on Earth. From then on you learn all the twists and turns the game's story has to offer, and what has just begun to happen down on Earth.- Gameplay: The fighting/combat system was created by Platinum Games, and as I've seen and been told by others, there's no doubt that it's fantastic. And experiencing it for myself, I can safely come to the conclusion that those people are right. Nothing in the combat system felt clunky, there are not a ton of attacks and combos available which I personally prefer (having to learn and master 30+ attack pattterns/combos isn't that appealling to me), and the attack patterns/combos the combat system does have are well designed and very easy to pick up.- Music: As a gamer, music is something that I listen closely for. Nier Automata's soundtrack has been fantastic so far, with intense tracks for heated battles, calm and casual tracks for neutral/allied areas, and cheerful and upbeat tunes for the happier places in the world. This soundtrack has been so good so far that I have already listened to and fell asleep to it. Not sure if they've made the soundtrack purchasable yet, but if or once they release it I will most definitely instabuy it.Cons:- Choices: So far in my playthrough of Nier Automata, I have been faced with little to no choices I can make that affect what happens and what plays out in the game. Maybe I haven't gotten far enough yet to need to make important choices, but there are a few things that I would have liked to do or chosen to do different throughout the story so far. But if you expect a wide variety of choices or multiple choices you can make that affect the game, this game might not be the best for that.- Weapon Variety: I have come across a few choices of weapons so far, that look different and play slightly different, but none of them have been better than my upgraded original one yet. This may just be a problem on my end because I may need to get farther or explore some more, but otherwise I have no reason to buy a replacement weapon from the weapon shop at the Resistance Camp (one of the main places you head to often)Aside from that, there's really nothing else I can think of that needs improvement. The game is very polished and enjoyable in my opinion, and from the negative things I've seen people saying about this game, it's more than likely an issue with their hardware and graphics settings rather than the game's "poor PC port." Because I haven't had a single issue regarding the graphics on my end.

												10/10 easily one of my favorite games of all time+Fascinating and powerful story and characters+Powerful feeling of scope+Artistic and aesthetic character and world design+Great combat system, reminiscent of dark souls and devil may cry+RPG elements are simple and well designed, I especially like the chip upgrade system+A few arcady feeling fights, camera angles and whatnot, touhou style gundam fights too+Didn't expect an open world but it works+Quests are fun and generally varied+dat soundtrack though+Other than the costume (which in my opinion is dope) there's no real fanservice, if you were worried this was panty simulator 2k17 then take solice in knowing that there are no actual panties, it is a leotard.-Lacks a few intricacies that would have made it perfect, difficult to describe, but the world could be more populated with more content. Not a blatant issueThese next few are me really reaching into the bucket for negatives-World design is low rez (The aesthetic is still on point though so I'd hardly call it a complaint)-Tutorial mission is pretty difficult at first and requires a new start piror to the first save. If you die within the first hour of the game you need to start again from scratch, intro cutscene and all. Pretty annoying on the third or fourth time.-Keyboard and mouse controlls aren't great, highly recomend a controllerAlso since it's been noted before, I have not had any problems with the port or subsequent graphics. There's a few annoying bugs but they're few and far between. These include execution moves not working and game crashes (I've encoutered 2 in 15 hours) Running gtx 970, amd i7 4790k and 16gb ram.Overall the atmosphere, gameplay, and story are insurmountable. The very few number of actual issues are overshadowed by the great experience you'll have playing this.

												Gameplay itself is solid and addictive. Runs extremely smooth on GTX 1070 and i7-4790K at 1080p. I've been having trouble putting the controller down since release, which is surprising to me because the reviews and gameplay I saw of the PS4 version released earlier this month didn't seem to be the most exciting but I bit the bullet anyways since Yoko Taro is a MF champ. Combat FLUIDITY and STYLE are ridiculously impressive, to the point where even if I've torn the same machine mob to scraps over and over, I'm still excited to go at it again. For anyone who's played Bayonetta 1/2 before, you understand the high points of this Platinum Games signature blend of combat fluidity and style. On the PC release of NieR:Automata, this is executed with intense style but not in excess. It's also MUCH CLEANER than previous Platinum-developed titles. Combat is fast and always has you on your toes, but it never skips a beat in every confrontation you enter, especially if you're playing on the higher difficulties. I wasn't interested much in the story concept when I was just learning about the premises of the NieR universe, but when I actually dove into the game, it was so easy to get gripped into everything going on around me. I just was not prepared for the level of weird (I say this in a good way) that was to come while progressing through the game. The basic premise is fairly vanilla and easy to understand from the game description and introductory scenes but the way it's executed is just, well, it's gonna leave you contemplating if you bought the game you thought you did in the first place. Combining this impressive combat system and a well-driven story with Mr. Taro's hundreds of genius eccentricities visible throughout the game create an impressively addictive work of art that's mischievously fun. It goes without saying that you have to experience it yourself to understand what I'm talking about. Don't be dissuaded by the high concentration of negative day one reviews complaining about small technical bugs, the fabulously unique gameplay experience and value in this package is worth what you pay.THAT SAID, although the technical problems don't affect the playability of the overall experience, they are noticeable enough to unfortunately burn the immersion from time to time. Cutscenes are unfortunately prerendered in 30fps, really punching you out of the game you were in when you've been playing at 60fps the whole time. In my experience with games in the past, this is probably never going to be changed no matter how much PCMR loses their ♥♥♥♥ about it. Normally I would forgive 30fps cutscenes if they were smooth (again, looking back to Bayonetta), but honestly the choppiness of these cutscenes would make me believe they were rendered on a standard home use desktop from 2008, which is really unfortunate. No really, *they're that bad* and it kills me that they plague this brilliant game's overall execution so significantly with some cutscenes just painfully giving you that 15fps Cinematic™ feel. In relation to framerate, the game is capped at 60fps, vsync on or off. Whether this matters to you or not depends on your monitor but I'm assuming most play on a 60 Hz panel anyways.There is also the resolution bug in which trying to play in fullscreen 1080p or above really screws the perceived framerate and actual resolution displayed. This can currently be fixed by using third-party apps such as "Windowed Borderless Gaming" and others the community has developed. It would have been nice if this problem didn't exist in the first place, it's 2017 for crying out loud. Once you manually iron this issue out yourself (although I dearly hope this issue isn't ignored for the sake of future players), the only things really disturbing are the poorly rendered cutscenes, which I BEG TO BE REDONE FOR THE SAKE OF HAVING A NEAR PERFECT GAME HERE.And of course, 2B T H I C C

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
21
												Overall - 9/10NieR:Automata is a 3rd person OTS story-driven spectacle fighter about a really pretty android fighting robots. Did I mention how pretty 2B is? The game takes place throughout several zones, with main quests and side quests ranging from fetch quests to escort quests to boss battles. After finishing your first playthrough (30 hours if you do the side quests), there are 4 more main playthroughs that dramatically change the game (many events are the same, but core mechanics change and the stories deviate), and provide replayability beyond normal NG+ systems. Great music, great visuals, great game. Weird graphics bugs which I hope get patched soon aside, I'd recommend this game.Combat: 9/10In NieR:Automata, the player can equip two weapons per loadout and can switch between two loadouts in the middle of combat. Weapons generally fall into light swords, heavy weapons, spears, and battle gauntlets (think Yang from RWBY). Because weapons in different configurations and situations perform different attacks, the player has a lot of freedom in customizing playstyle and how they fight. All of the weapons and attacks provide a lot of mobility so you rarely feel rooted in place, and fighting swarms of enemies is a lot of fun.Bosses come in a lot of different shapes, sizes, and attack patterns, including humanoids, large mechs, and giant mechs out of Shadow of the Colossus. Well placed dodges and timing attacks is important, but one complaint I've had is that most bosses can either be stunlocked or can barely be interacted with (one boss near the end has a phase where it goes invincible and harms you if you come close. The phase lasts much too long in my opinion, and a lot of the rest of the time, I was constantly breaking off pieces and stunning him, which made the fight a little underwhelming). Aesthetic/Direction -- 9/10NieR as a whole has a fairly muted color palette which makes the splashes of color in each area all the more interesting. Bright greens of the abandoned city and the forest contrast with the blues and greys of the flooded city and so on. Attacks are flashy and satisfying, enemies are interesting, characters are charming, and the immersion is really well done. The music in each area is absolutely wonderful and I'm surprised the OST doesn't come with the game or a dlc or something. The camera work is fascinating, and Platinum impressed me with how fluid the transition between over the shoulder 3rd person and side scrolling castlevania to top down shooter. Every change in perspective was refreshing and interesting, though some perspectives can make it difficult to play. Since a lot of combat happens in the air, a top down perspective makes it difficult to tell whether or not you are actually hitting an enemy or whiffing over its head, and some sidescrolling perspectives are really far away such that you can barely see 2B. Luckily you can change a lot of these camera settings in the options.Story -- ?/10NieR has 4 main storylines that dramatically change gameplay between playthroughs, adding and changing combat mechanics and minigames, etc. I've finished line A, and line B seems interesting. The story only gets more complex as you play, and I find myself caring a lot for 2B and 9S a lot more than most of the other characters.

												This game is great in my opinion.It has really good graphics, the environments are amazing and the theme really strikes my personal fancy. The music is also well put together and fits the environment and intensity very nicely.The gameplay is fluid and fast-paced with seamless transitions between the various gameplay elements (Shmup, hack and slash, side scrolling action) as well as enough depth in each so that none feel underdeveloped. The hack and slash is the main experience though the other types are never a chore to go through either and platforming definitely leaves you feeling as though you are in control of a powerful and agile character.Storywise the game excells as well, the cinematics are vibrant and easy to watch (and skippable!) and the other story-telling devices (such as chatter and journals and other collectibles) are optional enough that they aren't intrusive, but if you take the time to read/listen to what the various characters have to say then the story is enriched. There are a few issues though, which in no way should spoil your enjoyment.Personally I haven't had any issues with stability/graphical glitches/crashes and my rig isn't too high spec but apparently a lot of people have issues with Gpu compatibility and various crashes. If you're interested, check the discussions for problems with similar setups, if you can't find any give it a try and see how it runs, don't be afraid to refund it if it doesn't work for you.The initial gameplay sequence is difficult to get through, owing to the first save point being after a boss. While not terribly difficult, a mistake and/or death can be costly as it means you have to sit through the lengthy opening sequence and fights therafter. Feel free to start on a lower difficulty before the first save point if you have difficulties, since the game's difficulty can be changed at any time from the settings.Overall this game sits perfectly in my zone of interest and I'd highly recommend it to anyone who thinks they might enjoy a highly atmospheric world full of interesting characters and fun combat action.

												PC Port is beautiful a bit confusing at first with the controls depending which gameplay mode your character is in at the time. There are occasional frames per second loss depending on how your settings are and your computer runs, This game also requires a lot of hand-eye coordination and memory for combos and tactics on its higher difficulties. The only downside I can say is on easiest mode or easy mode whatever you want to call it the game basically plays for you, which is both amusing and frustrating as it leaves you with little to do playerwise. Now I'm speaking as a fan of the NieR/Drakengard/Drag On Dragoon franchise, a new fan but a fan none the less, this game is glorious, I am such a die-hard fan that you can choose to look over my review because it's very hard for me to find something wrong.

												NieR Automata is fast becoming one of my favourite games of all time.  The game traverses between a first-person hack 'n' slash, 2D platformer, side-shooter and overhead-view, and it works really well.  The combat system is simple but effective, the bosses are challenging without being OP, the storyline is as wonderfully weird as you'd expect from a Yoko Taro game and the soundtrack is one of the best I've ever come across.  Seriously, it needs to be released as a stand-alone, it's that good. Drawbacks?  Well, sometimes fights can get a little confusing if you're up against a lot of enemies at once, and the tutorial is needlessly long.  Other than that, NieR Automata should be a serious contender for GOTY, IMHO.

												I didn't go into Nier:Automata with any great expectations, I simply was looking for a fun game to play to fill a lull in my gaming life, but what I got was so much more. First thing's first; I've never played a Nier or Drakengard game before this one so you don't need that level of familiarity to enjoy this game, though I don't doubt it would add more to the experience. The combat is fast paced, varied, and fun without being overbearing so of you're looking for a game that actually is just fun to PLAY then this is your game. However, it's the story and the emotion it brings to bear that really prompted me to write out a review. Most of your time will be spent getting to know our stylish androids better, but if you see everything the game has to offer you'll feel a part of this world and this community in a way few games are capable of achieving. To summarize an already brief summary, I wholeheartedly recommend it.

content:

												Two of my favorite gaming genres are fighting games and shmups, I love arcade style action. Platinum managed to blend those styles of play into a JRPG of all things leaving me very impressed.I came to this game via being a fan of Platinum. I never played the first Nier game and don't play a ton of RPGs in general. This combat system is a bit more forgiving than games like Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance, which Platinum also designed, but I totally loved it. The boss battles were especially rewarding with timing of blocks and counter attacks and on-the-fly weapon loadout swaps.The system of managing your character's stats as chips is also really cool. You have a finite area to plug them in, and the more special chips (with a diamond symbol) can perform the same routine while taking up a smaller number of "slots" so you get the same stat boost more efficiently. The game allows you to re-arrange and swap out chips to rebuild your entire character's spec as needed. I really enjoyed remapping the whole stack for boss encounters - really unique system and I hope other games steal this idea.I just finished playing my 3rd play through (2nd is a different perspective same timeline, 3rd is continuation of the story so at least 3 plays needed, don't stop!) and wow - it shot to the top 5 games of all time for me. Don't miss it - what a surprise. A Masterpiece like this doesn’t come along very often.

												♥♥♥♥ me this game is brilliant.On the gameplay front, it's another Platinum Games masterpiece. The Bayonetta and MGR Platinum, not the starfox platinum. The only slight problem I have with the gameplay is 9S, I'd prefer to have heavy attacks for combos than an flash game hacking minigame as a heavy.And story wise, it's Yoko Taro through and through. Concerning the port, it seems it varies heavily based specifically on your setup. I've heard "bad fps with high end PC" and yet I manage to pull a constant 60 on max settings. I never had a single problem with the PC release.

												I'm bought this game going in completely blind, just off of what a friend told me, the gameplay trailer and a webtoon i just read called Nanos List. (b.c androids). 												This game is amazing and needs to be bought. However, it needs to be done so on PS4 at the moment. The game is recommended absolutely, this platform is not atm.Get the game on PS4. This was a game currently developed for console. I waited for the PC release today because of obvious wanting to try the game on my more powerful system. Running an Intel i7 and GTX 1080 so my rig is more than capable of handling the game. However, the optimization isn't there. The cutscenes run worse than in game graphics. The default keyboard mapping is not fluid at all. And the mouse sensitivity is all over the place. When aiming in the bullethell mode you're expected to use the keyboard arrows instead of the mouse. The mouse is way too sensitive in the bullethell mode, but slow when trying to move the camera in CQC. There is no dodge button, but you're instead expected to double tap the movement arrows. However the timing and animations are off and make dodging a much more difficult task than it should be. Not to mention if you want the game to actually run at the full 1080P settings, you can't fullscreen. It's only windowed, or fullscreen, no windowed full screen. And when it is full screened, the resolution is not 1080. And it will be off-centered and worse looking than in the windowed display at 1080. I played through the demo on PS4 and had a much better experience. I played the same length on the PC and was very disappointed with it's running. Refunding on Steam and going to gamestop to get the game for PS4 and now have to pay horrendous tax and deal with the drive and people. We all now how it is.TL;DR - NieR is going to be a great game. It definitely needs to be purchased. However, if you cannot wait to do so, then buy it on the PS4 because the PC port is not going to do it justice.EDIT: I've seen people recommending third party fixes. It's a valid argument, I suppose. But it shouldn't be necessary. The PS4 version runs fine as is. There shouldn't be a need for a third party application to run this game. Unfortunately, if you want to play it now, buy it for console.

content:

												[I "finished" the game, as in I finished the main endings and am now in the process of 100%ing it, this Review contains very minor spoilers.]This could very well be my new favorite game ever.The fighting is great (although I feel like 2B is still the best, 9S might me the most powerful due to his hacking ability, but judging from pure fighting, 2B feels like the best allrounder) and allows lots of variety with different weapon types in either the light or heavy attack slot, I personally mostly used two heavy weapons for example. Different Plugin-Chips allow for further specialization. The System for Plugins is great in general, allowing you to even sacrifice UI elements for more splots for other things. My only complaint in that regard is that the same Chips don't stack, so your inventory can get a little cramped, so it's best to sell or fuse regularly. Sometimes it can be useful to have different upgrades for certain quests.The different pods (that you can switch on the fly) can also be upgraded and equipped with different powers, there's a lot to customize and improve in the game.The hacking game is sometimes a little easy, but it's still a nice variation from the normal (although when playing 9S it get's a little tedious, cause it's technically his main attack).But a good fighting system was kinda to be expected since this is a Platinum game.I came for the combat, and stayed for everything else.The story and lore of this world is so interesting, I wanna explore every last bit of it.It's hard to explain, but this game keeps suprising you with new twists, story and gameplay-wise.Again, this might be my favorite game ever in terms of singleplayer games. And to everyone who is interested in some aspect of the game, or even just curious or open enough to try it, I can only recommend it to you.A little bit about the technical side of the game (since early reports claimed some issues),I get steady 60fps in all situations on Highest settings 1080p, and 55-60fps on 4k medium settings.Keep in mind that the game is locked at 60fps and officially doesnt support resolutions beyond 1080p.This is my setup:-MSI 980Ti Gaming-intel Core i5 6600k @ 4.6GHz-16GB HyperX Fury DDR4Test on my notebook (960m+i7-4720HQ):Runs at 40-60fps in 1366×768 on low details.

												I'm having fun with the game and don't have much negative to say, however there are a few things that I hope get fixed. Gameplay is fun and feels like a open world mixture of games like Devil May Cry, Dynasty Warriors, and Legend of Zelda (Certain combat elements from past 3D games I mean), along with some 3D bullet hells. The story is interesting and so far, so are the characters. For me the framerate runs fine during the gameplay and has no real problems, however the complete opposite can be said for the cutscenes, where I guess the game decides to turn my graphics card into a potato and run everything poorly. I'm hoping some type of patch with come out to fix it. Other than I'd say the game is really fun and makes interesting use of things like death, results of the death of other players, and exploration. Odd subjects, but you'll understand once you play. Definitely recommended.

												Typing this a few hours after release.PC Specs:Intel Core i7 4790K3071MB NVIDIA GeForce GTX 780 Ti16.0GB DDR3Also running the game from an SSD.Incredibly bad FPS even on lowest settings and small resolution (1600x900) and also repeated crashes. Have tried windowed and fullscreen, VSync on/off, nothing made made any difference. Cannot recommend in its current state, really quite awful. Though for some people it seems to work fine so... who knows.Edit: It seems 780 Ti users specifcally are having the worst issues. I've managed to make it playable by doing 2 tweaks:Go into Nvidia Control Panel > Manage 3d settings > and set 'Power management mode' to 'Prefer maximum performance'.Second, run the game and open Task Manager and set the game's Priority to High.These tweaks have let me play the game at 1280x720 on lowest settings without (many) crashes and a smooth frame rate.As a side note, the game fkn rocks.Edit 2 - After finishing the game:Don't care if it runs like complete garbage and still crashes sometimes for me, it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ masterpiece. I think this may be my favourite game ever.

I don't have a good graphics card at all so I thought this game wouldn't run on my machine, I was pleasantly surprised to find I was wrong!If you're like me then you see a cute anime girl and feel inclined to buy (no shame, it was a major reason for my purchase) but to my surprise, 2B isn't the reason why I keep playing this game, it's the beautiful art, music, and battle animations in combination with a wonderful feeling pace of battle!My fair warning is that when it says hard mode, it means it! Anything harder than normal gives an experience reminiscent of a Dark Souls game (maybe even harder) so if you're looking for that challenge, this game is great! If you aren't looking for a challenge, the game is still amazing on the medium mode!!

												How do I say this...At first I wanted to give this game a negative review because of the bad PC port. It was horrid. Crashes, sttutering, you name it.However with a little bit of work and with the help of the FAR mod (which solved most of the crashing/stuttering problem), I can finally experience the game.And oh my god. This game is not a game. It's art.+The music is insane. Every single location have a theme and it is stunning.+The storytelling on this game is one of the best I've ever seen.+It actually has a pretty high replaybility.+the graphics is beautiful, the character models are very detailed.+2B is waifu material.+Combat animations are sick, new players can just do hack and slash, while some experienced players can pull off some interesting combos.- If you are playing on PC, the controls are clunky.- The message system (You can leave a message next to your corpse when you die) is pretty useless.I definitly think this game is worth $60, and if you did get it, DO NOT WATCH/READ ANY SPOILERS!!!!! It ruins your experience.

												Pros: Amazing gameplay and combat. A mix of Hack & Slash and Bullet HellBeautiful Enviroments and scenery (My opinion) Good story with multiple endingsGood Replayability (My opinion again)Interesting and well designed charactersAmazing music and Soundtrack (Some of the best i've heard)Cons:Muddy Graphics (It's in no way bad but i wished they could of had a better engine)Stretched Resolution (Needs an update fast) Some frame drops (Mostly during cutscenes)60 FPS LockMouse and Keyboards controlls don't feel as smooth or responsive (Needs an update fast) Overall I rate this a 10/10 because I found it really enjoyable and it will forever remain as one of my most favorite games. A true masterpiece and a wonderful experience.  Also 9S is precious so treat him nice You also gotta love Yoto Taro for being downright amazing and honest. People: "Why do you make the girls wear a skirt and high heels?"Yoto: "Because I like women..."

												This game is one of the best this year, i am suprised by how well this is done, for a japenes console title it really is above my expectations, i have played through the first story line and very much enjoyed everything in the game, the gameplay, the music (THE MUSICE), the graphics although it is a console port, the story line is quite diffrent to what i am used to but nonetheless it still is great, as for the issues mentioned by other players thankfully i havent seen any in my experiance, am running a GTX1080 and have not seen frame drops or glitches as of yet, the cutscenes run at 30fps but i guess that was intentional, other than that i think this is one if the best games i played in the past few years and i have played many, for what it is, its worth the money, i woulkd recomend it not just for anime and japenese games fans, but anyone who is looking to play a great RPG hack and slash game.i hope more japenes devs make such games not only targeting anime fans.

												Some issues, overall seems to be a decent conversion (especially considered the typical standard of japanese games ported on PC).I compared it to the PS4 and PS4 Pro version, here's my comments in detail1) Framerate is much more stable than even the PS4 Pro, locked at 60fps. Only saw TWO small drops in the first section of the game, even in areas where some frames would be skipped on the PS4 Pro (lava section underground in the lava factory). Framerate is 30fps for cut-scenes, don't remember if this was the case for PS4/Pro versions too but I assume it was.2) There's no borderless windowed mode. Fullscreen is lost if you alt-tab3) Game doesn't run at real 1080p if you set it that way, but something slightly lower. 900p? Bit higher probably. There's a small black frame if you set fullscreen 1080p4) The additional effects present on the Pro version, are also present on the PC versionGame is still as extraordinaire as the console version, hope they can fix those small annoying issues, but I got no hopes for that. Being that the game runs on DENUVO I'm afraid modders won't be able to fix them either.I tested the game on a GTX 1070 with an intel i7 3770, windows 10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
17
												Large open world and high action combat makes for a good blend for action fans and the types who enjoy exploring. Game runs reasonably well even when using a GTX 760 for those worried about performance. The action combat is quite unforgiving, even on normal. But thats a good thing. Its not overly difficult (unless you play on hardest setting), the bad guys have visual and audio queues for attacks meaning with good timing you can get away without geting touched. However, failing to dodge an attack can leave you chugging health restores even vs the most basic of baddie.As my first venture into the series, I'm quite happy with how this game was designed. The plot needs a little bit of fine tuning, but flows reasonably well.All in all, solid game. 7/10

content:

												Highly recommended and possible GOTY contender for 2017Nier:Automata is a really good game that turns into a great game the more time your invested. This title really caught me off guard as I could not stop playing until I got endings A through E which are the required endings to fully understand the game. I havent been this invested in single player story driven game in such a long time that it brought great joy to my heart as I just had to know what was going to happen next.Now the pros of the game+Music is absolutly fantastic and would rate as one of the best video game soundtracks of all time+Sounds are varied and bring life to actions+Engaging and fanstic story that had me hooked +Really good atmosphere+Really good hack and slash combat with top down shooter mix and mash gameplay+Beautiful character animations and unique character design+Great character interactions from funny to heart wrenching+Side quest dont feel like a chore and help with weapon upgrade matierals, no annoying faming (most of the leveling up comes from side quests)Cons-Game looks pretty dated-Top down shooting sections really start to overstay there welcome-F#$k escort side quest only ones I didnt likeIt took me 46 and half hours to get endings A to E which spanned exactly a week of playing from the release date of the game. It is well worth the money, and if your tight on money at least check it out when it goes on sale. Oh be aware of performance issues which theres mod fixes out there for.

												19.3 hours to complete the game the first time. The game has been out for 2 days. Edit: Took 33 hours to complete all the main endings. I cannot recommend this game enough, it is absolutely phenomenal.Ran fine on my GTX 750ti at 1600x900 windowed.Edit: A driver update pushed this up to a full 1080p, though I did experience a fair amount of FPS issues very close to the end of ending C.

												First off, I came into this not playing any of the previous games and just based off of the trailer/screenshots and thought what the heck. Holy. ♥♥♥♥ing. ♥♥♥♥. This is probably the most fun I've had with a game since the release of Skyrim, GTA and possibly even Rocket League (I know the genres are different; speaking on fun factor here). I've never played a game quite like. It's got some of everything, from arcade-like combat, to a twin stick shooter, to a hacking mini-game, to Dark Souls "holy ♥♥♥♥ wtf" style bosses. Exploration is encouraged and rewarded with side-quests. The humor in the game is just right. Too many times I've played games in which developers "over-did" humor, making it seem like some sort of B-movie.Pros: Diverse Gameplay Beautiful Graphics/Scenery 2Booty Fun Combat Mechanics Interesting Story; a lot of "what is life" sprinkled throughout Soundtrack is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing Voice acting is good Amazing game atmosphere/settingCons: Some grahics issues on certain hardware. I've not personally had any issues other than a framerate dip.  60fps cap. Not a gamebreaker for me even though I'd like higher Sometimes 9S can get in the way when you're picking stuff up. For the 1000th time I don't want to change your combat style, 9S.All in all I'd give this game a 9/10. It's definitely worth the money in my opinion. And this is coming from someone that does often play Hack n' Slash RPG's. I'm sure you'll find this to be your "new favorite game" in your steam library. I couldn't put it down the day I bought it. Give it a shot.

												Amazing game, questionable port problems by Square Enix. Pros:The combat is tight and fluid.The soundtrack is stellar, Keiichi Okabe has nailed it once again.There's quite a sizable amount of graphics settings available.I get a pretty stable 60fps at 1080p.Cons: Resolution upscale issues and KB-M controls need fixing. Highly recommend using a controller due to the SHMUP/Twin-stick elements of the game. Crashes seem to occur for AMD GPUs.I imagine this will be fixed relatively soon, as the rest of the game is stellar, but I would have imagined a better release after there being such a sizable wait between console and PC releases.GPU: GTX 980CPU: Intel (R) Core (TM) i7-6700k  4.5 GHz Memory: 32 GB RAM (4x 8GB DDR3)Resolution: 1920x1080 60HzHDD: 2 TBSSD: 256 GBStill a masterpiece that I will hold close to my heart. But I would encourage those on the fence to wait for an official response by Square Enix and a patch to fix the aforementioned issues.

												Are you doubtfull about playing Nier Automata?  Just awnser these few simple questions1) Do you want to play a  game whit action as smooth as butter?2) Do you want to listen to a god tier lvl soundtrack3) Do you want to play a game that makes you doubt the meaning of humanity? If the awnser to one of these questions is yes then Nier Automata is for you. Quick pros and consPros1) Smooth gameplay2) Great sound 3) Great story4) Nice mix of gameplay stylesCons 1) mediocre map and UI (the game mocks this in a selfaware kind of way)2) The breaks in the action can feel ackward to  platinum fans.3) On of the characters feels a bit repatative in combat.4) Some hard crashes 5) standard dificulty is way to easy but hard takes away the lock on feature that runis the camera controls a bit.  Makeing the game harder by forceing the player to control the camera feels a bit artifical to me.

												Going into this game, I knew nothing about Nier outside of it looking interesting. Now that I am close to finishing my 2nd playthrough I must say that I really like the game. The story CAN be fairly short if you skip side quests, but the game is also meant to be played through a few times. I love how the game implements different playstyles in to one game (bullet hell, side scroller, ect...). Sometimes they feel a bit too forced, but nonetheless end up feeling good and keeping the game interesting and changing.For those who are having fullscreen/windowed issues, there are programs out to help with it, I use something called "windowedborderlessgaming" from a WesTech site and it works great for me.

												Game startup can sometimes crash if it's not left alone for about a whole minute (for me, at least, not sure what others are reporting), cinematics are locked to 30FPS, and feel lower res than 1080p, and there is an ENB-like filter that affects Steam overlay in fullscreen only. A Windowed Borderless would definitely be recommended for this game. Asude from the above cons, gameplay is extremely enjoyable, addicting, while still difficult, and feels really smooth. The subtitles are off-sync to Japanese audio in most voice sequences, so it breaks immersion slightly, but otherwise, I am thoroughly enjoying my experience in this game. Waited a while for this, and I am not disappointed!

Game is running at a stable 60 FPS.PC specs: i7 4790K, GTX 980, 32gigs RAM, SSD boot drive and the game is running of a mechanical HDD

												ok first let's talk about the bugs and issue the fullscreen bug that the one i found i've setting at 1920X1080 fullscreen but it's just 1600X1024 stretcting so i figure it out that you'll need to setting at windows and using programs like borderless gaming and you'll get full screen at your monitor resolution (mine 1920X1080) that's all problem solvedthis is all bugs that i've found after playing for 9 hourswell let's talk about the gameplay as you all well know for platinums games this was like DMC+MGR RISING with open world (and hot chick with nice butt)the combo goes smoothly and i really enjoys that you can switching weapons to Heavy and Light (and in easy mod there's an auto switch but other diffuculty doesn't)and you'll have cute shota (9S) alongside your journey (and little robot for shooting) he is really dependable because you don't have to worry about him he's no HP and does some damage that no more no lessfor the performance my gears is GTX970 I54460 8GB of ram and i setting it on high and AAX4 (some folk says that is no need just X2 will fine) 1080Pi didn't turn on fps monitor but from what i saw FPS run along by 40-60 which totally fine for me and there's some freezing for 1-2 sec at some point but that not bothered me at allthe story is amazing so far from the starts and there's 26 endings you can get (A-Z) and for the last thing that i really love about that is Soundtrack i might say that if they has Soundtrack available i'm gonna grab it for sureso if you are not offend by playing female protagonist and really love hack and slash plus open-world and Great Soundtrack (oh and probably didn't having potato computer) i'll recommended you should grab this game

												As of right now, I cannot recommend this game to any AMD card owners. The screen frequently turns white and you won't be able to see any thing. I've updated my drivers, verify the cache, and tried many other things to fix this but it has not worked. Another thing is that you cannot save the game until you're a hour or so into the game. I've played the introduction at least five times now and every single time, I was forced to close my game due to the white screen and restart from the beginning.EDIT: It seems that the community has found a fix to the white screen bug. I uninstalled my current driver and reinstalled the 16.11.5 version. I was finally able to play the game without the white screen bug.PROS:-Fluid and awesome looking combat system. The hack and slash element works and fits the theme of the game perfectly.-Amazing soundtrack. The music really draws you into the world you are exploring for the full immersion.-Good voice acting. (I'm playing with the Japanese VO)-Keyboard controls are surprisingly good once you get use to it. It's very simple and not at all hard to get use to.CONS:-This game suffers from poor optimization and many other technical bugs that render the game unplayable for many people.-A lot of pop-in that ruins the immersion of exploration. (Grass, trees, buildings, etc)Overall, I would suggest this game for any one who's into hack and slash type of game. It's definitely worth picking up!

content:

												This has been my first JRPG ever, and let me tell you, so far it has been an amazing game to open me up to the world of JRPGs and RPGs alike. In my first 8 hours of playthrough (which will probably be higher by the time you read this), I have experienced a challenge that actually punishes you for dying, fair and interesting progression, two unique and fun mini-boss battles, and an intense boss battle that required you to understand the mechanics fully to defeat the boss successfully.Pros:- Graphics: The graphics for me have been stunning and smooth. I have the game set at 1920x1080p with max texture settings (Nvidia 970) and have been experiencing almost no lag or frame drops. The closest I've come to lag/frame drops is when I teleport to another location and just load in, although the frame rate almost immediately fixes itself.- Story: The story in this game despite having a slightly cliche intro turns out to be intricate and unique in many ways. The general background of the story is that aliens have attacked Earth with their robots they've created, and the few humans who have survived fled to the Moon to begin the Resistance and YoRHa Android Infantry. You as 2B, the main character, are an android soldier in YoRHa whose been tasked with tough missions against the robots on Earth. From then on you learn all the twists and turns the game's story has to offer, and what has just begun to happen down on Earth.- Gameplay: The fighting/combat system was created by Platinum Games, and as I've seen and been told by others, there's no doubt that it's fantastic. And experiencing it for myself, I can safely come to the conclusion that those people are right. Nothing in the combat system felt clunky, there are not a ton of attacks and combos available which I personally prefer (having to learn and master 30+ attack pattterns/combos isn't that appealling to me), and the attack patterns/combos the combat system does have are well designed and very easy to pick up.- Music: As a gamer, music is something that I listen closely for. Nier Automata's soundtrack has been fantastic so far, with intense tracks for heated battles, calm and casual tracks for neutral/allied areas, and cheerful and upbeat tunes for the happier places in the world. This soundtrack has been so good so far that I have already listened to and fell asleep to it. Not sure if they've made the soundtrack purchasable yet, but if or once they release it I will most definitely instabuy it.Cons:- Choices: So far in my playthrough of Nier Automata, I have been faced with little to no choices I can make that affect what happens and what plays out in the game. Maybe I haven't gotten far enough yet to need to make important choices, but there are a few things that I would have liked to do or chosen to do different throughout the story so far. But if you expect a wide variety of choices or multiple choices you can make that affect the game, this game might not be the best for that.- Weapon Variety: I have come across a few choices of weapons so far, that look different and play slightly different, but none of them have been better than my upgraded original one yet. This may just be a problem on my end because I may need to get farther or explore some more, but otherwise I have no reason to buy a replacement weapon from the weapon shop at the Resistance Camp (one of the main places you head to often)Aside from that, there's really nothing else I can think of that needs improvement. The game is very polished and enjoyable in my opinion, and from the negative things I've seen people saying about this game, it's more than likely an issue with their hardware and graphics settings rather than the game's "poor PC port." Because I haven't had a single issue regarding the graphics on my end.

content:

												If you are like I was when I bought this game then you aren't familiar with the series, and that's OK. I really enjoyed it and I will say the demo is not indicative of a majority of the game. I am personally not a fan of bullet hell games, and if you arent either than rest assured there are fairly few top down arcade style dodge and weave sequences. Some of the boss fights feel lazy and some feel really good. The weapon and ability upgrades feel very in depth and the game rewards exploration. I will say there is a lack of character customization. I know it's an rpg with a specific main character but if they at least would've let me change the color of 2b's dress or maybe put more hair ties and hats in the game i would have been satisified. The game doesn't tell you everything, which is nice since it means there are mechanics and abilities that can be used in different ways and discovering them as a player feels awesome. The mechanics are good, i believe the studio who made nier:automata also made beyonetta and one other? Overall a solid 8/10, which is a high score for me.  The two major downsides for me is that it can feel kind of repetative and grindy sometimes, but it is a hack and slash and the story kind of detracts from the grindy aspects of it. Also cutscenes don't show what weapon you are using, it just shows the default kitana which i find lame. Also fishing is fun and the best way to get money.

content:

												AMAZING. I was super hyped for this and could have been easily let down... but let me say, this game is CRAZY and incredible and beautiful and everything I hoped it would be. I have an NVIDIA 1070 and have had absolutely no problems running it, no crashes or fps drops, nothing. Fullscreen is fine too. I did read the reviews on here before playing and I was super worried it would run like crap. I have turned off AA and Vsync just in case, and I haven't tried the game with these settings turned on. So I would say just make sure your computer can handle this game before buying. My boyfriend has an NVIDIA 1060 and his is almost as good, only some rare fps drops. I have played some BAD ports in my time, and this is pretty smooth and great in my opinion. It's day one, after all!I've been playing for about 4 hours now, and the story has already got me hooked, but the real draw is the beautiful, ballet-like combat. You fly through the air using all sorts of combos and it's gorgeous. Sometimes it'll switch to side scroller and shooter and it just flows perfectly. The prologue is fairly hard and I did die (and got one of the endings, woohoo) but once you get through it, the desolate, beautiful world opens up and you can explore, upgrade, ride wildlife, and try to figure out what the hell is going on. Overall, I wholeheartedly recommend this game. It looks great, the characters are dynamic and the story is so so intriguing. I can't wait to play more!

												I have played this game non-stop since launch, and I had never played any sort of JRPG or Nier game before. After finally completing the game after over 34 hours I can say that this game is truly one that I won't forget any time soon.The gameplay is pretty damn good, I never seemed to get bored of the combat even in the more tedious parts of the game.The soundtrack is absolutely fantastic, and never seems to be boring.The story is pretty good, other than the fact that it starts with the good ol' "aliens took over the world and humans had to run aaaahh" type thing.The cutscenes were pretty well done and I must say that some of the story moments absolutely haunted me and made me think.The only issues I encountered were the awkward controls in the 2D scenes, as I suppose they were probably made for console players. The only other issue were occassional frame drops, but this rarely ever happened.This was definitely worth $60.

												My rig is:i7-4790K@4.6GhzGTX1070@2.0Ghz16GBI got myself the borderless gaming app which worked like a charm. At the moment I am still playing in the industrial complex area in the first hour of the game, but I have all details cranked up to max playing at 1920x1080 including setting AA to 8x and the game only ever dips below 60FPS by a few frames! Update: I have now progressed beyond the prologue into the city ruins which deliver the same excellent FPS, rarely ever below 60. I also noticed that with AA set to 8x my GPU gets stressed so much that in some areas I end up getting screen artifacts, specifically randomly occuring white orbs - this even appears to happen when my 1070 is not OCed!Otherwise, an excellent game and well optimized! Update: Okay, after reaching the desert zone I did have tiny micro-stutters, but is nothing that would diminish the enjoyment of the overall experience. I am playing with reshade... the first preset which became available, which only sharpens the game a bit and adds more contrast, i.e. boosts the colours a bit... would recommend! The present can be obtained here:http://sfx.thelazy.net/games/preset/6976/

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
25
												This is by far the best game I have ever played. I have never been so pulled in, so emotionally connected, so... in love with a game in my life. I can just talk about all the reason I like it for days. But I'll list out a pros and cons list.Pros:- Long, well written and driven story mode.   - This game has over 50+ hours of content for those will to go through and look for it. Just finishing the base story takes about 25 hours if you try to do everything. It is well written and never feels like a waste of time, and all of the characters are loveable and add to the story in only ways that improve the overall feel of the story.- Fast paced, fluid Combat System.   - The combat within the game always makes every fight interesting, especially on the higher difficulties. Enemies are predictable up to a point, but then can still manage to cause you some issues by doing the unexpected. As the player though you have many chance to weave in and out of close range combat, and perform a wide variety of strategies to succeed in any fight, regardless of level difference between you and your enemies. - Beautifully Composed and Scored Soundtrack   - This feels like self explanatory statement, but to add to it all of the sngs fit the emotion you should be feeling in the areas that you here them in. The music provides you with all of the extra emotion to properly indulge in the games story and character development process. Cons: - Camera Angles.... rarely but happensThis game feels like what you would get if you paid $60 for a movie ticket to the best experience of your life. It is well worth every penny and I recommended any and all people to try it out. You will not be disappointed.

												While it does indeed have a small set of quirks that prevent it from being perfect, it's easily one of the best games I've played in a very long time. I haven't dedicated so much time in such a short amount of time to a single video game since Zelda: Twilight Princess all those years ago.Tight controls save for an occasional hiccup here or there, an interesting plot that kept me engaged, decent plot twist (not something that blows away, but instead gives a sense of melancholy), unbelievable OST, interesting characters and main characters with depth, and a main story length that doesn't overstay its welcome. It's hard to write a review that does this game justice, so all I can really do is urge a reader who's teetering on whether or not to puchase it...to purchase it.  I think Jim Sterling said it best: [www.thejimquisition.com]  "Nier: Automata is a piece of art that could only effectively exist as a videogame. ... If history forgets this game, then f*** history."

												Playing on Intel Skylake Core i7-6700HQ CPU, quad-core 2.6 GHz, 3.5Ghz turbo - Nvidia GeForce GTX 970M 4GBThe settings menu is locked to 15 fps and upon starting the game it goes down to 7fps, this was at 1080p on the medium graphics preset in the game. Tried reinstalling, didn't help. Tried making a new game save, the new game data wasn't even created.

												After 5 hours I already feel like I have gotten my moneys worth and I've only just started. I love the visuals and the character animations while fighting- The story so far has me sucked in, I love the world and characters and their dialogue is great so far. I wish every single line from every one off NPC was voice acted but I'm going to be reading everything and talking to everyone.I will update this review if I feel there is more to add but right now I don't see how this could turn into a negative review. Thank you for the awesome experience !

												FIX FOR CRASHES / LAGOn laptops with multiple Graphics Cards ensure the stronger one is set to default, for some reason Nier was using my intel default one instead of my Nvidia.Game runs beautifully now and reminds me so much of Kingdom Hearts hack and slash, really impressed.Old Review:Running an Intel(R) Core i7 - 5700 HQ CPU @ 2.70, 16Gb RAM with a bloody 970x on my PC. Drivers are all updated (tried as fix for game) and the game is unplayable at the moment due to unrelentlingly slow frame rate.It took 20 minutes to get past the intro flight scene due to the settings which I tried on High, Medium, and Low with no result. The flight scene was atleast completable with serious desync of voices to game, and once on the first hand to hand combat it became completely unplayable.As a side note I preloaded the night prior and the unpacking of the game took 3x as long as the download did which is odd. I have a 15Mps internet speedWill check back in a few days to see if a patch is put out but as of now I can not recommend.

												Large open world and high action combat makes for a good blend for action fans and the types who enjoy exploring. Game runs reasonably well even when using a GTX 760 for those worried about performance. The action combat is quite unforgiving, even on normal. But thats a good thing. Its not overly difficult (unless you play on hardest setting), the bad guys have visual and audio queues for attacks meaning with good timing you can get away without geting touched. However, failing to dodge an attack can leave you chugging health restores even vs the most basic of baddie.As my first venture into the series, I'm quite happy with how this game was designed. The plot needs a little bit of fine tuning, but flows reasonably well.All in all, solid game. 7/10

content:

												After nearly 21 hours dedicated to playing the game, I can say that without a doubt NieR: Automata is a game that will captivate players that are fans of stories, combat and world exploration. A little bit overpriced but I asure you that once you jump in everything else fades away. The story takes place in a desolate version of earth where war left heavy scars on it. The two things that stand out the most in the game are soundtrack and combat. The music is amazing in this game, sadly the game has no "jukebox" option where I can just hear the songs during boss battles. It always fits the atmosphere and helps one connect with the world and characters. I was exploring and revisiting areas just for the songs and almost nothing else.The combat is fast paced, fluid and will satasfy most of your needs to look awesome in a fight. You can collect beautifuly crafted weapons to decimate enemies and chain together in impressive and acrobatic combo moves. Boss fights are tough, but the fights are simply amazing and backed up by the music I always felt a little bad about the fight ending. There are a few downsides to the game. Namely a few bugs that stepped on my toes.- The game sometimes will switch to windowed mode and you have to manually set it back again. This happens if you use the "Windows" key or your screen goes dark if you AFK for too long.- During combat when enemies are stunned and vulnerable you can perform a special action by pressing "E". B2 will do a combo move but it sometimes doesn't work since the target either breaks out of the stunned state or slides into another direction. B2 ends up hitting an invisible target in that case.- 9S will almost always get in your way. Yes, he is immortal so he's a good punching bag. He even gains the same weapon status and skills you have making him even stronger. But he will invade your personal space 99% of the time and either shove into you, block you from moving or running and lastly screw up your jumps.- Depending on the combat behaviour for 9S, he will sometimes not fight. He will attack a target if you engage it in melee or just follow you if you don't want to fight. But in some instances where he has to stay "Ranged" he won't do anything except watch or run around after you. - You can get a game over at any given moment. Not exactly a bad thing, this is my fault for not saving and being too curious and stupid. But yes if you do not save at all and made a lot of progress then did a stupid decision in a quest you can get a game over and start over or load a last save.- The camera will sometimes screw you over. During a fight the camera isn't locked on the character's backside and lets you run around and manually rotate the camera. The keyboard adapts the controls to the angle of the camera and sometimes this results in poor responses. Like unresponsive dodges that will only make B2 stutter in place instead of dashing.- The game could use some more ballance for its graphics. Not take me wrong the graphics are beautiful in this game, sadly their are a little rough and not fully pollished and you'll have to work around the settings to get that much desired shine to it (since 80% of the world's players are into the game for looks only and get bragging rights for their rigs). The game doesn't fully support 4K and is locked at 60 fps. You can get some better performance by disabling AA and VSync (that are maxed out by default) Besides these flaws the game is amazing and the best part is that it has multiple endings depending on what you decided to do during the main mission and the best part is that you can carry out your gear into a new gameplay if you want.

content:
18
												This has been my first JRPG ever, and let me tell you, so far it has been an amazing game to open me up to the world of JRPGs and RPGs alike. In my first 8 hours of playthrough (which will probably be higher by the time you read this), I have experienced a challenge that actually punishes you for dying, fair and interesting progression, two unique and fun mini-boss battles, and an intense boss battle that required you to understand the mechanics fully to defeat the boss successfully.Pros:- Graphics: The graphics for me have been stunning and smooth. I have the game set at 1920x1080p with max texture settings (Nvidia 970) and have been experiencing almost no lag or frame drops. The closest I've come to lag/frame drops is when I teleport to another location and just load in, although the frame rate almost immediately fixes itself.- Story: The story in this game despite having a slightly cliche intro turns out to be intricate and unique in many ways. The general background of the story is that aliens have attacked Earth with their robots they've created, and the few humans who have survived fled to the Moon to begin the Resistance and YoRHa Android Infantry. You as 2B, the main character, are an android soldier in YoRHa whose been tasked with tough missions against the robots on Earth. From then on you learn all the twists and turns the game's story has to offer, and what has just begun to happen down on Earth.- Gameplay: The fighting/combat system was created by Platinum Games, and as I've seen and been told by others, there's no doubt that it's fantastic. And experiencing it for myself, I can safely come to the conclusion that those people are right. Nothing in the combat system felt clunky, there are not a ton of attacks and combos available which I personally prefer (having to learn and master 30+ attack pattterns/combos isn't that appealling to me), and the attack patterns/combos the combat system does have are well designed and very easy to pick up.- Music: As a gamer, music is something that I listen closely for. Nier Automata's soundtrack has been fantastic so far, with intense tracks for heated battles, calm and casual tracks for neutral/allied areas, and cheerful and upbeat tunes for the happier places in the world. This soundtrack has been so good so far that I have already listened to and fell asleep to it. Not sure if they've made the soundtrack purchasable yet, but if or once they release it I will most definitely instabuy it.Cons:- Choices: So far in my playthrough of Nier Automata, I have been faced with little to no choices I can make that affect what happens and what plays out in the game. Maybe I haven't gotten far enough yet to need to make important choices, but there are a few things that I would have liked to do or chosen to do different throughout the story so far. But if you expect a wide variety of choices or multiple choices you can make that affect the game, this game might not be the best for that.- Weapon Variety: I have come across a few choices of weapons so far, that look different and play slightly different, but none of them have been better than my upgraded original one yet. This may just be a problem on my end because I may need to get farther or explore some more, but otherwise I have no reason to buy a replacement weapon from the weapon shop at the Resistance Camp (one of the main places you head to often)Aside from that, there's really nothing else I can think of that needs improvement. The game is very polished and enjoyable in my opinion, and from the negative things I've seen people saying about this game, it's more than likely an issue with their hardware and graphics settings rather than the game's "poor PC port." Because I haven't had a single issue regarding the graphics on my end.

												First off, I came into this not playing any of the previous games and just based off of the trailer/screenshots and thought what the heck. Holy. ♥♥♥♥ing. ♥♥♥♥. This is probably the most fun I've had with a game since the release of Skyrim, GTA and possibly even Rocket League (I know the genres are different; speaking on fun factor here). I've never played a game quite like. It's got some of everything, from arcade-like combat, to a twin stick shooter, to a hacking mini-game, to Dark Souls "holy ♥♥♥♥ wtf" style bosses. Exploration is encouraged and rewarded with side-quests. The humor in the game is just right. Too many times I've played games in which developers "over-did" humor, making it seem like some sort of B-movie.Pros: Diverse Gameplay Beautiful Graphics/Scenery 2Booty Fun Combat Mechanics Interesting Story; a lot of "what is life" sprinkled throughout Soundtrack is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing Voice acting is good Amazing game atmosphere/settingCons: Some grahics issues on certain hardware. I've not personally had any issues other than a framerate dip.  60fps cap. Not a gamebreaker for me even though I'd like higher Sometimes 9S can get in the way when you're picking stuff up. For the 1000th time I don't want to change your combat style, 9S.All in all I'd give this game a 9/10. It's definitely worth the money in my opinion. And this is coming from someone that does often play Hack n' Slash RPG's. I'm sure you'll find this to be your "new favorite game" in your steam library. I couldn't put it down the day I bought it. Give it a shot.

												This is honestly one of the best games I've ever played. It's so well done, so well rounded, and constantly surprises me. You know those games where you think you're going to be clever, and the game calls you out on it? This is one of those games in the best possible way. It draws you into the world so hard, and it's filled with little mechanics and concepts that feel familiar from other games, but that are executed here exceedingly well. The combat in the game feels like Bayonetta, it pulls some familiar death mechanics from Dark Souls (seeing where other players died, collecting parts from your own previous bodies). The overall feel of the game reminds me so much of Phantasy Star Online, from the operators in a space-base communicating with explorers and soldiers on the ground trying to claim a dangerous planet for human settlement. Some of the massive bosses remind me of Shadow of the Colossus, and I'm sure there's dozens of other small, interesting ideas they've picked up from various other sources to refine and create a game that all my friends are honestly sick of me gushing about constantly. Buy this game, play through it- There are like 26 endings because the creators are literally insane. I cannot even put into words how much I love this game.

content:

												*--POTENTIAL SPOILERS!!!--* (maybe small bits)I just finished my first run, and WOW, I haven't had an experience like this in a while.I'm not sure where to start so i'll just list my favorite thing about this game.The Story: I like the dystopia overrun by machines who left by an alien race that died off years ago, what made it especailly interesting was learning the differences in machines between areas, how they "lived" their lives. Not to mention the relationship 2B and 9S had, it was nice to see 2B progressively warm up to "nines".The Ending(s): I only have the A H W on my endings ( for those who dont know, neither do i), but the replayablity of this game is interesting and im really hoping its not the exact same story repeated, though I dont see that happeningThe Music: ...Byoutiful...The SKILLS: very well done I must admit. It has a Dark souls vibe to it aswell, where death means losing your upgrades and having to back track for them, or lose them which by the way not recommended. They can get expensive when you get in the higher tiers.That was most of the good... Now the BAD (Keep in mind this is on the experience of one playthrough)The camera angles: omg, i wish this wasnt an issue, but having to get use to a new camera angle whenever the game decides its time for TOP DOWN/3D-2D/THIRD PERSON/ETC is really obnoxious. I had moments where I kept taking damage from enemies i couldn't see because the camera forced a perspective on me and i couldn't adjust it properly.Length: I uderstand the replay mechanics, but it still seemed too short. I may, however, change my mind after a couple more replays.Weapons: so far theres not much in weapons that interested me. I ran with my entry katana and beastlord (can literally get it at the beginning of the game) the whole playthrough because no other weapons base damage where better.Traveling: the fast travel comes a little late in the game, not too late though. You had two options, Run or take the time to bait a beast and ride it. I would've much perfered an actual vehicle, like a hoverbike maybe? make it easier to travel through land, because you trip on every bush, dip and elevated step while sprinting, make worth a lot so you work for it like 20k-30k.All in all I give it a solid 9/10, I feel my dislikes of the game isn't too much to set it off too much. Except the camera.
