												I have never written a review before, but let me just say that I've never been impressed with a game simply 30minutes in before. It normally takes awhile to get into a game, regardless of what it is. Now, don't mind the 1.8hours playing this, as I've literally only JUST sinked my teeth into this game due to issues that I had with this. I'm not a frame junkie, so framerates don't bother me much, however, I couldn't actually play the game. The last hour was spent trying to get this game running and I finally did! Those of you who have the same system specs as me (as I will list), I'll give you the required information to properly run this game smoothly (though cutscenes will be cut in half):System Specs:Intel(R) Core(TM) I7-6700HQ CPU @ 2.60Hz x2 16GB RamNvidida GTX 960MNow, for whatever reason, if you're having terrible drop rates check to see if the game is automatically selecting your integrated graphics card. My system was automatically selecting it, making the game run super choppy and practically unplayable. Here's how to fix it:1. Right Click on Desktop2. Select nVidia Control Panel3. In left panel select "Manage 3D Settings"4. In right panel select Globalicon1.png Tab5. Under "Preferred Graphicsicon1.png Processor" select "Auto-Select" and hit APPLY buttonNow try again and see if it properly selects correct GPU. If not6. Repeat steps 1 thru 3 above7. In right panel select "Program Settings" tab8. Under section 1., check the box for "only programs on this computericon1.png"9. then hit the "Add" button and find the program that you want to run on nVidia card10 Go down to section 2. and select nVidia processorCredit to this site: https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/forums/t/583807/my-computer-wont-use-my-nvidia-graphics-card/For those of you who are more frame/graphic junkies that want better frames and run this game with higher graphics and an actual borderless fullscreen, follow the instructions on this site: http://www.neogaf.com/forum/showthread.php?t=1353278Currently, the best specs to run this game on for a smooth gameplay experience with little to low issues (in the game setting itself) is: Ambient Occlusion - OffAnti-ailiasing - offDisplay Mode - Full screenEffect  -lowResolution - 1360x768Shadows - LowTexture Filter - offHaving been on the verge of refunding this game, I did some research and found great progress. Now I can play this game and enjoy it! I stopped at my first save point to help you guys out. Hope this helps!

												Typing this a few hours after release.PC Specs:Intel Core i7 4790K3071MB NVIDIA GeForce GTX 780 Ti16.0GB DDR3Also running the game from an SSD.Incredibly bad FPS even on lowest settings and small resolution (1600x900) and also repeated crashes. Have tried windowed and fullscreen, VSync on/off, nothing made made any difference. Cannot recommend in its current state, really quite awful. Though for some people it seems to work fine so... who knows.Edit: It seems 780 Ti users specifcally are having the worst issues. I've managed to make it playable by doing 2 tweaks:Go into Nvidia Control Panel > Manage 3d settings > and set 'Power management mode' to 'Prefer maximum performance'.Second, run the game and open Task Manager and set the game's Priority to High.These tweaks have let me play the game at 1280x720 on lowest settings without (many) crashes and a smooth frame rate.As a side note, the game fkn rocks.Edit 2 - After finishing the game:Don't care if it runs like complete garbage and still crashes sometimes for me, it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ masterpiece. I think this may be my favourite game ever.

 Notes: Luckily, I wasn't affected by the current issues that many PC players have been having with the game like the internal resolution bug w/ fullscreen. Performance wise is pretty solid for me as I was able to keep up with 60FPS during gameplay. In general, I was able to focus on the game itself. In addition, I am unfamiliar with Nier's lore so in short this is my first Nier title. Intro: With that said, the game made a big first impression as it just jumps you right in. For some that may be challenging, personally I thought it was great as it didn't hold your hand right from the start. Hell, not even 10min and you get your first boss fight. Combat: It's Platinum Games, the same developers of Metal Gear Rising and Bayonetta. If you're familiar with those titles, then you would feel right at home. Easy to pick up but can be hard to master. The game rewards you for well timed dodges and counter attacks. At first you may think it's convulated and clunky, however I can say for certain that the combat is smooth and fast. There also many segments of bullet hell where enemies would just barrage you with constant fire. If it's still difficult, there is an option for auto mode where the game literally plays for you, although I do not recommend it. Music: SWEET MOTHER OF JESUS, where to begin? In short, the soundtrack is good. Like VERY good. It represents a both eerie and sad tone that overall produces a very beautiful composition. During the introduction, it pounds you with epic battle music that can make your heart race with excitement. During exploration, it plays a very smooth tones with excellent vocals. There were times where I stopped just to listen to the music. Controls: With these types of games, I usually play with a controller and I highly recommend it. Keyboard and mouse can be reconfigured. Won't get into detail as it is straight forward. Story: I am not very far into the story as of yet so I can't provide the details but I am liking what I see so far. From what I've heard the game contains 26 endings. 21 of which are just a joke. The other 5 are the real endings which can be obtained from multiple playthroughs. The 5 ending are dictated in routes that your actions can influence the game's ending. Each routes represents a different ending. In other words, having patience by playing the game multiple times can earn you a complete story. Conclusion: It's a VERY good game, but it is plagued by many issues on the PC version. I would highly suggest to wait until patches roll through so that the game's current issues won't hinder your overall experience. If you're willing to risk with dealing the issues then I would recommend a purchase.

												Beat this game on PS4 with all endings and almost 100% at 50+ hours and counting. Just gonna put some random thoughts and criticisms but I'll be honest and say that this has become one of my favorite games of all time coming from someone who never played a Yoko Taro game before this one. I fell in love with this game so hard that I had to buy it on steam while I was still halfway through it on my PS4 and just preordered the soundtrack.Addictive and versatile combat that can be dramatically changed depending on your plugin chip loadout and weapon sets. It may seem cheesy by spamming ranged attacks if you're playing on a higher difficulty to avoid getting two shotted. It's very important to customize your plugin chip loadouts early on and continue to see what works and what you like and don't like. Gameplay and story elements are intertwined in clever ways, e.g. individual characters' aptitude for combat are reflected in their playstyles and abilities.Beautfil music score all throughout. Seriously.Graphics are okay, environment isn't as interactive as I had hoped. The game is semi-open world which I somewhat preferred since all the recent open world games are starting to drain me. At first I thought some of the environments were somewhat bland and devoid of color but I'll just say that they each have their own charm and grew to be comfy for me.IMO one of the best video game endings of all time (true ending), the game started pretty strong and held itself throughout and ended so strong.Plenty of twists and emotional points in the story, some may seem insignificant or poorly executed at first glance but there is depth and subtlety in the details that may require a 2nd playthrough or at least scene and dialogue investigation to fully appreciate. I had to read up and watch some videos on Nier and Drakengard before playing to get a sliver of the appreciation that people who played through those games would have gotten from this game. The game as a whole is simply amazing even with its faults, I'm in love.

												This is a true master piece! The world feels alive, great dialogue and graphics are phenomenal.The weapons are fun to use, lots of combos to pull off. Different levels of challenge if you so choose so. Voiced in Japanese and English. Accompanied by 9S (which is a pleasure to listen to his dialogue)throughout your adventures along with the pods. Game seems very well optimized for the PC, I do get some low frames during very populated bot areas and during certain cut-scenes, but for the most part I'm pleased with the frame rates. The way the game forces the camera into top down, side view(shoot-'em up arcade game) is a welcoming fresh experience in a fully 3rd person RPG.  Not to mention the use of the pod being your personal infinite projectile shooter is awesome! Including the fact that 2B(your character) has no limit/stamina so you can potentially sprint/dodge for as long as you want.It's easy to see that the developers had alot of fun creating this game and pulled out all the stops to make this game a 10/10. Best to give this game a shot, I'm very content with this purchase.I can see myself completing this game.

												The port is kinda bad, and this isn't the most beautiful game around, but god damn. It's so good....That's not really enough to go by, so let's elaborate a bit. People have been going on about this being a Platinum game, but just hearing that will give sorta false expectations.This isn't pure action game like Bayonetta, or Metal Gear Rising. This is JRPG with leveling, with combat being pretty nice stylish action. The game doesn't go through individual stages, instead you have world that you travel in, optional and revisitable locations.A lot can be said about setting and the story, but it's best kept short. The game will surprise you, and you'll be going through roller-coaster of emotions. This is truly fantastic stuff, all aided by great soundtrack.So, what didn't I like? Some of the quests are kind of pain in the ♥♥♥, and getting some upgrade materials was pretty grindy, but none of that is mandatory.Given how absolutely diverse the game is, I'm not sure what kind of genre you could sell it as easily. But if you enjoy games, this is totally worth playing.

												In honor of ending E, I'm writing a new review.After launch, this game consumed my life for a few days.  I loved every minute of it, and I didn't want it to end.  And yet...  Nier:Automata's entire story is built on the inevitability of conclusions.  The inevitability of death.  All things must come to an end, and Nier:Automata ended as well.Something about this game wouldn't let me put it down until I had finished it, but now I can hardly bring myself to start it up again, even for that sweet 100% achievement.  Not because it's going to take additional time and effort, but because it was inevitable.  I played Nier:Automata.  I loved Nier:Automata.  It will forever remain a precious memory of mine, and that's all it needs to be. (for now, at least)There is so much more to this game than meets the eye, and there's already plenty for the eye (beyond how nice 2B looks, but definitely also that).  I urge all of you to see it through to the final conclusion.  Feel that final moment of uncertainty, that hesitation as your hand hovers over that single acknowledgement...  "Are you truly-TRULY-sure about this?""Yes."And so, Nier:Automata ended for me in the most beautiful way I could ever imagine.  Not with a grand spectacle, but with the gentle closing of a door.  A door which I'll open just a crack, to look through and smile at what I left behind.

												10/10 easily one of my favorite games of all time+Fascinating and powerful story and characters+Powerful feeling of scope+Artistic and aesthetic character and world design+Great combat system, reminiscent of dark souls and devil may cry+RPG elements are simple and well designed, I especially like the chip upgrade system+A few arcady feeling fights, camera angles and whatnot, touhou style gundam fights too+Didn't expect an open world but it works+Quests are fun and generally varied+dat soundtrack though+Other than the costume (which in my opinion is dope) there's no real fanservice, if you were worried this was panty simulator 2k17 then take solice in knowing that there are no actual panties, it is a leotard.-Lacks a few intricacies that would have made it perfect, difficult to describe, but the world could be more populated with more content. Not a blatant issueThese next few are me really reaching into the bucket for negatives-World design is low rez (The aesthetic is still on point though so I'd hardly call it a complaint)-Tutorial mission is pretty difficult at first and requires a new start piror to the first save. If you die within the first hour of the game you need to start again from scratch, intro cutscene and all. Pretty annoying on the third or fourth time.-Keyboard and mouse controlls aren't great, highly recomend a controllerAlso since it's been noted before, I have not had any problems with the port or subsequent graphics. There's a few annoying bugs but they're few and far between. These include execution moves not working and game crashes (I've encoutered 2 in 15 hours) Running gtx 970, amd i7 4790k and 16gb ram.Overall the atmosphere, gameplay, and story are insurmountable. The very few number of actual issues are overshadowed by the great experience you'll have playing this.

												So far seems very good, a final fantasy type of RPG with regularly changing combat modes from top down shooter to 'Devil May Cry-esque' to 'Einhander' & 'Starfox'The Good:  Playing for about an hour and a half now, and I've played "bullet-hell" style shooting sequences alongside a well put together 3rd-person beat-em-up sequences, the changing perspectives and styles flow pretty well and keep things interesting.  Gameplay looks great at solid 60fps 2K with a GTX 1070, and I'm looking forward to dumping alot of time into this game! The not-so-good:  Many cutscenes stutter pretty badly and cut the framerate to 30fps.  I would prefer unlocked framerates, and some of the nice scenic cutscenes that do play at 60fps are hampered by transluscent black bars at the top and bottom of the screen...I also think the 3rd person 'DMC' mode could pull the camera out a bit, it makes for a kind of claustrophobic battle in some areas, though when the view pulls out for side-scroller and flight I think it's perfect.   Recommend!

												Pretty terrible if you use a keyboard.  Since lock on can't be bound to any mouse buttons, you're stuck awkwardly moving your finger back and forth from one of your movement keys to hold down lock on.  Aiming is also a bit finicky, but you should pick up a controller and enjoy this game.  Gameplay is amazing, and it feels very smooth.  This game is not for the faint of heart.  You cannot just save this game any time you want.  There are specifics locations you can do it, which is a key feature of the game.  So SAVE OFTEN.  It will be a very challenging game.  It took me about 2 hours before I could even reach the first save point, but it did take me a bit to get used to the controls.  I would recommend buying this game if you like a challenge, but playing with keyboard and mouse right now is pretty much impossible.

												The port is good. Supports just about any resolution.  Runs on just about anything (including my AMD 7870 from 2011, manages 60 FPS).  Generally an impressive job all around.  Known quirks:KB/M control isn't good.  This isn't platinum's fault (they allow fully rebindable keys), just the game itself switches around so much that it's not really worth it.   The fact that they got it working as well as they did says a lot.AMD Graphic issues: Update yo' driver.Vsync seems quirky on a couple of cards.  If you're getting 30 FPS instead of 60 (and swear seven ways to sunday that your computer can handle it), just use your driver to force tripple buffering+vsync and disable it IG.1080p: Some users have reported that 1080p is actually glitched in fullscreen mode.  I didn't have this issue, but, if you do- either step your resolution up or down one notch or use windowed mode and a fullscreen window utility.  Again, it didn't happen to me.

												This is honestly one of the best games I've ever played. It's so well done, so well rounded, and constantly surprises me. You know those games where you think you're going to be clever, and the game calls you out on it? This is one of those games in the best possible way. It draws you into the world so hard, and it's filled with little mechanics and concepts that feel familiar from other games, but that are executed here exceedingly well. The combat in the game feels like Bayonetta, it pulls some familiar death mechanics from Dark Souls (seeing where other players died, collecting parts from your own previous bodies). The overall feel of the game reminds me so much of Phantasy Star Online, from the operators in a space-base communicating with explorers and soldiers on the ground trying to claim a dangerous planet for human settlement. Some of the massive bosses remind me of Shadow of the Colossus, and I'm sure there's dozens of other small, interesting ideas they've picked up from various other sources to refine and create a game that all my friends are honestly sick of me gushing about constantly. Buy this game, play through it- There are like 26 endings because the creators are literally insane. I cannot even put into words how much I love this game.

Sometimes they feel a bit too forced, but nonetheless end up feeling good and keeping the game interesting and changing.For those who are having fullscreen/windowed issues, there are programs out to help with it, I use something called "windowedborderlessgaming" from a WesTech site and it works great for me.

												This is mostly a port performance review since I haven't played the game enough to talk about anything else.Specs: Intel i7 6700K | Gigabyte G1 980Ti | 16 GB DDR4 RAMAt this point, I've gotten through the prologue and the first area (forested city) and haven't had any crashes so far. You can select a resolution of up to 4K, although the visuals make it look like an upscale from 900p rather than an actual change in render resolution.The prologue was stupid amounts of fun with a mix of combat scenarios, camera views and a few boss battles. The game managed a constant 60 fps throughout the prologue (except for cinematic cutscenes which seem to be rendered at 720p@30fps). You do very quickly notice the subpar English voice acting though, which you can't change until you quit, except the prologue doesn't save until the end. The music is a bit muted compared to the original, but still trademark Nier and gorgeous to listen to.Things dip a bit during the first mission with more complex scenes including wildlife, settlements, trees and vegetation. I hung somewhere between 45 and 55 fps and in a combat game, you notice the difference. The visuals don't really justify the FPS dips, with rare flashes of color between drab exteriors and sparsely populated areas.I'd still recommend the game based on what combat I've seen so far and what I've heard of the story and all that, but maybe wait if rock-steady performance is important to you.EDIT: With a few more hours under my belt, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of quirky worldbuilding, bonkers characters and drip-fed storytelling.

												GTX 1060 6GB + i5-4570 owner here.Game runs smooth at max settings and AA at 2x. A few frame dips here and there but not noticable and not in combat. I won't say it's bad but I won't say it's good either. Just, different.Pros:-Interesting world.-Beautiful music.-Steady framerate 98% of the time.-Anti-dumb hack 'n slash. Not as hard as Dark Souls but the game stops you from spamming one attack button and getting away with it.-Fair. The game has an item (not a spoiler) that automatically recovers your health if you're low. But, they aren't infinite and you have to buy them.-Gameplay variety.-2B's ♥♥♥.I didn't get nowhere near as many problems as some people here are pointing out so I have to give it a like on this one.

												The port is good. Supports just about any resolution.  Runs on just about anything (including my AMD 7870 from 2011, manages 60 FPS).  Generally an impressive job all around.  Known quirks:KB/M control isn't good.  This isn't platinum's fault (they allow fully rebindable keys), just the game itself switches around so much that it's not really worth it.   The fact that they got it working as well as they did says a lot.AMD Graphic issues: Update yo' driver.Vsync seems quirky on a couple of cards.  If you're getting 30 FPS instead of 60 (and swear seven ways to sunday that your computer can handle it), just use your driver to force tripple buffering+vsync and disable it IG.1080p: Some users have reported that 1080p is actually glitched in fullscreen mode.  I didn't have this issue, but, if you do- either step your resolution up or down one notch or use windowed mode and a fullscreen window utility.  Again, it didn't happen to me.

												In honor of ending E, I'm writing a new review.After launch, this game consumed my life for a few days.  I loved every minute of it, and I didn't want it to end.  And yet...  Nier:Automata's entire story is built on the inevitability of conclusions.  The inevitability of death.  All things must come to an end, and Nier:Automata ended as well.Something about this game wouldn't let me put it down until I had finished it, but now I can hardly bring myself to start it up again, even for that sweet 100% achievement.  Not because it's going to take additional time and effort, but because it was inevitable.  I played Nier:Automata.  I loved Nier:Automata.  It will forever remain a precious memory of mine, and that's all it needs to be. (for now, at least)There is so much more to this game than meets the eye, and there's already plenty for the eye (beyond how nice 2B looks, but definitely also that).  I urge all of you to see it through to the final conclusion.  Feel that final moment of uncertainty, that hesitation as your hand hovers over that single acknowledgement...  "Are you truly-TRULY-sure about this?""Yes."And so, Nier:Automata ended for me in the most beautiful way I could ever imagine.  Not with a grand spectacle, but with the gentle closing of a door.  A door which I'll open just a crack, to look through and smile at what I left behind.

												A Great Game, once you get past all the bugs and "features" that come with games that werent developed for PC, but rather ported from console."Features" include:- Forced camera angles that dont make much sence. Confusing at first, then irritating. Fighting my first giant enemy was very awkward.....camera tries to focus on the enemy- Cannot camera distance without digging thru menu- There is something broken if you play FullScreen. There are fixes for that.- PreRendered Cutscenes at 30 fps....probably the biggest issue i have with the game. I can look past other negatives. I can wait for fixes. But when a gameplay at 1080p 60fps cuts into something crappy with only 30fps it just kills it for me. I hope devs ?re-render? the cutscenes.There are other things, but these were major for me. Game is designed for the controller, not mouse/keyboard.Now to the Positives, at least for me:- Very engaging, challanging enough, but not too difficult.- I like the story. I have only 12 hours played, but those were 12 hours well spent.- Very pretty. Wish there was a "freeze" function and ability to move camera to wherever I want. Environment is Beautiful. - You are actually not completely alone. Pet robot, and pet android, with another pet robot.Word of Caution:If you are coming from Skyrim, Fallout, or Witcher worlds, negatives i descibed above are going to be a MAJOR barrier. It takes time to get used to those controls and camera angles, but once you do get used to them, the game will be a lot more enjoyable

												NieR Automata is by far the best game I have played in my life, and for many reasons.I initally got into the series at NieR Gestalt, and went back and played some of the Drakengard games  as well.As much as those games are master pieces in their own right, this game goes far above, and beyond it's predecessors.Simutaniously this game gives many nods to the old games in a way that doesn't impede upon a new players experience.This is a game that stands proudly, and firmly on it's own two Android legs.It is full of highs, and lows, and explores themes of love, hate, anger, consciousness,  life, existence, death, and much more! (It is my wish to avoid spoilers, so I will keep this review as ambiguous as possible.)More mature players that are willing to surrender themselves to this experience will truly appreciate their time with this game.Too easy/hard? Change the difficulty settings!On my first playtrhough on normal I found the difficulty to be very fair.My advice is to go through the story, as much as you can without worrying, or looking too many things up.If you have your own experience with this you will be greatly rewarded in a way that most games won't fulfill you in.Finish it at your own speed, be it fast or slow.I personally favoured a very slow pace, and enjoyed the combat, and scenery as much as I could.It was very easy to do this once I set aside my usual overly efficient mind set, and mentality. This game was well worth the money, just make sure you have a gamepad for the best experience!I will eventually come back to 100 % this game, but for now it has left an after glow that will radiate, and resonate within me for a very long time.Thank you to everyone that was involved in the making of this game, truly! Thank you for allowing it to come to PC, as I wouldn't of gotten to experience it had it not, and after playing this game I can truly say it was an experience worth having.

content:

												Highly recommended and possible GOTY contender for 2017Nier:Automata is a really good game that turns into a great game the more time your invested. This title really caught me off guard as I could not stop playing until I got endings A through E which are the required endings to fully understand the game. I havent been this invested in single player story driven game in such a long time that it brought great joy to my heart as I just had to know what was going to happen next.Now the pros of the game+Music is absolutly fantastic and would rate as one of the best video game soundtracks of all time+Sounds are varied and bring life to actions+Engaging and fanstic story that had me hooked +Really good atmosphere+Really good hack and slash combat with top down shooter mix and mash gameplay+Beautiful character animations and unique character design+Great character interactions from funny to heart wrenching+Side quest dont feel like a chore and help with weapon upgrade matierals, no annoying faming (most of the leveling up comes from side quests)Cons-Game looks pretty dated-Top down shooting sections really start to overstay there welcome-F#$k escort side quest only ones I didnt likeIt took me 46 and half hours to get endings A to E which spanned exactly a week of playing from the release date of the game. It is well worth the money, and if your tight on money at least check it out when it goes on sale. Oh be aware of performance issues which theres mod fixes out there for.

												I'm still making my way through my second playthrough as I attempt to 100% this game. I have to say that I'm really impressed considering I found the original game to be pretty mediocre at best. The combat is excellent. The world is beautiful and memorable. The story is touching. The music is simply magnificent and has been on my daily playlist since release. Just YouTube the OST if you don't believe me. As far as I can tell the game is meant to be played through at least 3 times and you see the world from a different pair of eyes each time. The story unveils even further with every successive playthrough and one playthrough is not all that long. The port itself is decent, but not that great. However, most of my issues with the port were resolved with Kaldaien's FAR mod. It should be on the discussion board for this game.This is a rating from what I've experienced so far. I know I haven't completed this game in its entirety yet. However, I have a feeling that my conclusion won't change much upon completion. In fact, it may just get better. This game is damn good and truly a treasure.

												I've never really ever been invested into the plot of games, usually I play games for the gameplay aspect and that alone. I discovered Nier:Automata about a month before its release and followed it closely anicipating the release. When I finally finished the game (make sure you continue playing after the first playthrough) I realized how much I became invested into the story and characters. The gameplay is somewhat smooth, the combat is fluid, the atomosphere and environment are brilliant, and don't even get me started on the soundtrack. This game sucked me into the story really fast and every day I was dying to get home so I can see what happens next. Now I feel an empty void completing the story, but I don't plan to stop playing the game and I can see myself doing another playthrough in the near future. This is definitely my game of the year. If you're anything like me, this game will not disappoint and I 10/10 recommend this game to anyone.P.S. If you have an Xbox or PS controller I would highly recommend using that because for me the KB&M combo is a little wonky, at least for me

												Another excellent game by Platinum. Probably one of the best action games I've played in a long long while. On top of that, the story is a cut above the rest. It's a really cool story that throws you plenty of curve balls and gives you something to chew on. There's a whole lot of weapons, skills, and abilities to let you kind of do what you'd want within the game's combat. The game is meant to be played in multiple playthroughs, and from what I've heard there are 26 endings, technically 25 if you don't count the one joke ending (hint: OS Chip).That said, there are a few points where the game kind of drops off. For instance, the game's pacing through the first playthrough is a little weird in that if you stop and do every side quest, you end up a little overleveled for the final quarter of the first playthrough which takes away from the weight of it. Sometimes, the quests get a little tedious to the point where I began to ignore ones that I thought were going to be tedious or bad (E S C O R T M I S S I O N)Overall, I loved this game, and I will continue to love it as I torture myself for those 25 endings.P.S. nice ♥♥♥ tho

												One of the most sophisticated, gripping, and philosophical video game stories that I have ever played married to a fast paced and smooth combat system. Despite its lackluster graphics, relatively poor performance compared to graphically demanding games, a few annoying bugs (the fullscreen resolution bug was the only one that I encountered), and mechanically terrible but thematically superb side quests, this is one of the greatest games of all time. This also has one of the greatest sound tracks as well that dynamically changes during game play. If you enjoy 3rd person action games and deep stories, you owe it to yourself to play this game.I should also note that the keyboard and mouse controls are horrendous (eg. mouse control feels like an emulated analog stick). I highly recommend playing this with a controller.

content:

												Driven by a strong and compelling plot, satisfying gameplay, and an unforgetable soundtrack, few games can offer an experience comparable to NieR:Automata. What starts as a decently fun hack and slash game quickly evolves into a gripping rollercoaster of emotions. It should be noted that this is the first game I've played in this series so my opinions will be reflective of that.The Good:- Absolutely amazing story- Strong main cast- Beautiful soundtrack- Satisfying gameplay (combat, progression, gear)- Open world - Side quests that provide more meaning that just "do this, do that"- Multiple endingsThe Not so Good:- 60 fps cap- Infrequent crashing- Limited/linear gear upgrades- 900p, 30 fps cutscenes make transitions especially jarring- Port is not very well optimized for its technical prowess- Washed out colour palette (subjective)- A few shockingly low resolution textures (i.e. the rusted red crate in the resistance camp)- Hacking becomes repetitve after a whileDespite the existance of a few bugs [which will hopefully be addressed soon] and limitations that hold the game back, the unparalleled experience delivered by NieR:Automata easily outweighs its drawbacks. This is one of the few purchases as of recent that I've felt was worth the full price tag.

												Okay wow, on the surface this was an okay game with some fun familiar gameplay mechanics but going a little deeper, this game delivers some pretty heavy story notes that upon first impression appear to be superficial. I'm impressed Mr Yoko Taro and surprised that I've never discovered your games before this one. There are some heavy philosophical/existentialist themes in this game and without saying more it pulled a very heavy "6th sense" on me; emotionally it went from okay to extremely sad and melancholic.For anyone wanting to try this game, I can't stress this enough, beating the game once, isn't beating the game at all; it is just a chapter break in the story. They take 'new game+' video game mechanic and completely flip it on expectations.

												This game is wierd, and I don't mean because of the story or because its Japanese.So I am a big Platinum fan and enjoyed most of their work even from back before they became independant from Capcom. While this game is deffinately fun to play, due to it's length and lack of variety things gets pretty repetitive quite quickly.Now the story on the other hand while not quite the same tone as most Platinum games, is VERY good. Even if mostly non-sensical it will strike a cord with most gamers on an emotional level. I can now see why Yoko Taro's games have such a cult following.This leaves me very conflicted because I played this game for one thing and ended up enjoying it for another.Do you like sories that resonate on an emotional level (maybe not so much on a logical level)?Are you a fan of Yoko Taro's previous work?You should deffinately play it!If you are looking for 'dat Platinum feel'? Maybe try it out but this game is not quite that.

												I haven't bought many games recently at full price on release, especially without proper research, however I took a gamble on this game, and it payed off. This will sit in my library as a classic to come back to once I'm finished with this (whole) playthrough, I'm sure. The story is a bit slow to start, but becomes quite engaging and interesting. The setting looks fantastic, and the gameplay is really varied and interesting. The ground-based combat reminds me a lot of a semi-open world Bayonetta.There are bad points. The port isn't great; I wouldn't play without a controller and I had to use a 3rd party application to run it in a borderless window for proper 1920x1080 resolution (Day 1 release). The game plays fine on high on my i5 4670k, 8GB RAM and 970 GTX though.

												I have played this game non-stop since launch, and I had never played any sort of JRPG or Nier game before. After finally completing the game after over 34 hours I can say that this game is truly one that I won't forget any time soon.The gameplay is pretty damn good, I never seemed to get bored of the combat even in the more tedious parts of the game.The soundtrack is absolutely fantastic, and never seems to be boring.The story is pretty good, other than the fact that it starts with the good ol' "aliens took over the world and humans had to run aaaahh" type thing.The cutscenes were pretty well done and I must say that some of the story moments absolutely haunted me and made me think.The only issues I encountered were the awkward controls in the 2D scenes, as I suppose they were probably made for console players. The only other issue were occassional frame drops, but this rarely ever happened.This was definitely worth $60.

												Lurked on steam forever, my first review.  I did not play the original Nier for PS3.Pros:  Immediate story catchup, no cryptic "what's happening" in this world filling in the blank, for example as was done with the Metal Gear series.  Most started on MGS1 (that I know) and you had a vague idea who Big Boss was until you played MGS3.  A very well done story yes, but unless you played the two low key NES games you otherwise never heard of it.In game adjustment of difficulty/camera movement.  The camera style can be odd, alternating from a very open sandbox world to a corridor for a very quick alternate from 3d to 2d movement.    The game difficultly flat out tells you for the extreme gamers out there... you die in one hit, and you have one ressurection to get your "gear" back.  Con:Personal morality thing, without spoilers you are trying to kill objects that are trying to kill you... but saying things that would soothe crying children or were otherwise heartstring tugging events and I just thought "I have no soul, I am extremely heartless.TLDR;  Buy it, the $60 is a bargain with the in depth detail given for it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
18
												Now that I have finished Ending A (the main ending) as well as part of B, I feel I am ready to review this game.I'm going to break up this review into 5 sectionsPlotCharactersControlsGameplayOptimizationPLOT-While some have labeled the plot as cliché (and I can see why), This is the first game in a while that had a story that I actually found myself wanting to continue and push further. It's a very odd tale that, while not as deep, reminds me of MGS. Plot 8/10CHARACTERS-The character design was... interesting. While everyone was gawking at 2B's butt, I was confused as to why they were blindfolded as they can see/operate fine without it. If video game characters are your cup of tea for 'certain viewing times' this game will please you. if not its kind of meh. The dialogue was pretty good, I heard both English and Japanese voice actors, and both settings were good (Japanese was better IMO for obvious reasons). I never thought that the characters were too talkaive, and they never seemed to get on my nerves. Characters 7/10CONTROLS-If you have a controller, use it. While the KB&M controls are not bad per se, they definitely could have been better. While the options do not apear to accept mouse controls for attacks, THEY ARE ALREADY MAPPED. It is very odd and never is noted that you can use your mouse, but that is much better than the alternative(Shift and /). Dodging got repetitve and isn't fun to perform (double tap a movement key). However I saw a mod that fixes this, I may pick it up. CONTROLS 6/10GAMEPLAY-Dear god is this game just an absolute blast to play. The combat is fluid and fun. the animations are incredible. There's tons of stuff to keep you occupied (Reportedly up to 45 hours). The Boss fights are a ton of fun, not being to easy, but not too difficult either. Exploring, Item hunting, side questing, and ...fishing, It's all a ton of fun. GAMEPLAY 10/10OPTIMIZATION-If you haven't heard, the port of this game is nothing to write home about. with an odd 1600x900 res lock, 60 fps lock/30 fps cutscene lock. Multiple people reported a whitescreen game crash after about 10 minutes(I was one of them) but rest assured, there are fixes to almost all of the problems. The Devs are also woking to fix the port up, but there is community mods to make this game more pc friendly. OPTIMIZATION 5/10TL;DR-This game is going to become a classic. This is easily my GOTY so far. Pick this gem up as soon as you can. If you manage to grab this on sale, you might as well be commiting theft. This game will stick with me for a long time, and I will be watching for Platinum's works from now on.OVERALL-9/10 GREAT

												A great game hindered by the annoying no safe beginning area and for some pc port issues. Those 2 negatives get far outshined by the greatness of the rest tho! After getting used to the combat (By you guessed it, repeating the no save area) the game becomes incredibly fluid and fun. Dodging around doing combo's, parrying attacks and shooting powerfull lasers it all feels absolutly great. Now i have to say as well the game contains several gameplay modes like normal action mode, twin stick mode, 2d platformer mode and likely many more however i feel like some of them do not work well in the game but nevertheless these are mostly short sections so i can live with them.Audio and visually the game also does a decent job although some of the enviroments are visually lackluster but the soundtracks in every map definetly make up for any issues in that regard. About the story i can't say much yet since i havent finished it at this point. But overall i feel like this game is easily worth a buy.EDIT:Finished the story and i have to say this game really starts to shine when its all coming together at 2/3 of the game. If it wasn't for the enviroments and some repetitive aspects of the game then this game would have truly been a masterpiece.

												The combat is exciting and fast-paced, and the variety of weapons keeps it interesting throughout the game. Although if you use the same weapon and never change throughout the entire game, it will start to feel repetitive. Boss battles are massive set-pieces that feel like accomplishments to take down, even when they aren't too difficult, because of their scale. The soundtrack to this game is amazing. Even if you don't play the game, I would recomment at least litening to the ost online. With the gameplay providing a solid backbone, the story, and writing are what elevate this game to something amazing, although multiple playthroughs as different characters are a must if you want to experience the story in its entirety. This game made me feel things I haven't felt in a long time. Each playthrough comes with a different perspective, and more details on the world being brought to light. This is one of few games I would recommend even if you don't like the core gameplay loop, because the story and ost are so good.

content:

												Excellent game, but the port leaves much to be desired.NieR: Automata is a strange hybrid of JRPG, platformer, hack n' slash, and twin stick shooter set in a distant dystopian future. It comes with a phenomenal soundtrack, vast multi-biome open world, and satisfying combat system baked in. The boss fights are original, challenging, and often very strange, and the storyline is pretty interesting (if a bit strange).Keep in mind that there are multiple endings: 5 main endings with individual stories, and 26 different possible ways to end the game.My only issues with the game are with its porting. There's a well-known resolution bug that changes your resolution to something lower if you're playing in fullscreen, microstuttering if you're not using VSYNC, 60FPS cap, and several other issues. While they are annoying, they don't completely detract from the gameplay. If/once these issues are fixed, I'll have absolutely no problem with the game.Pros:Wacky but exciting storyFantastic soundtrackPlenty of content/questsSatisfying and fun combat systemVery pretty visualsCons:Multiple technical issues (Resolution bug, microstuttering, white screen on AMD)Wonky camera anglesLimited settings menu (Can't adjust draw distance)Poor keyboard + mouse supportLocked to 60FPS, 30FPS cutscenesThe game runs fine on my system with no crashes, but I've heard of framerate drops/crashing on systems with AMD cards

content:

												This is honestly one of the most memorable games i've played in a long time. The characters create an emontional story while the combat kept me entertained and challenged throughout my 20 hours digging straight through the main story. The best part is i'm still not done and still have more to work towards.I'm afraid that many people will stop playing when they see the credits roll for the first time. Its something I almost did, but i'm thankful I loaded my save again. This game features multiple endings, so keep playing to the very end.The music is astounding, even though i'm not the biggest fan of the vocals. I'm hoping steam will include a OST download at some point...On regards to the PC port, I had no issues with gameplay on my 1080 card. I hope others will get their fixes too. The only issue i had graphically was with the light rays on environments and characters, particularly in the side scroller sections. The glare makes a ugly blur and looks blocky around the character heads.The RPG elements are a nice addition, including weapons and chips that augment stats or give extra combat/ support functions. I can't really say this is a choice-driven game aside from persuing the endings, but its not an issue. Once you've FINISHED the game to the very end, you'll be allowed to backtrack through the story, whilst keeping all progress, levels, chips, and upgrades.Overall its been an outstanding experience and hope to see more games like this.Some cons:-Invisible walls around some buildings, mainly the city.-Not entirely voiced. The main story progression is fully voiced, but most sub-quests and convesations are text.-Permanent loss of chip upgrades if you die again before reaching your body, like how Dark Souls has you loose souls. Upgraded chips can be purchased towards endgame, but there are rare chips with reduced memory usage that would be a pain to loose.-Keyboard/mouse gameplay was difficult for me, particulaly in trying to aim the Pod's fire. Controllers are recommended.

												So far, the combat in this game is awesome. You have little dynamic galaga-like spaceship and mech fighting levels that are fun as hell, and kind of reminiscient of the Gummi ship from Kingdom Hearts II only waaayy better. And then you have the third person sword-play combat (which is 99% of the games combat) which is so beautifully refined and awesome. For abilities you have these chips that take up a certain amount of space and a limited of allocated space to put them in, so you have to decide which power-ups will benefit your playstyle more and its very unique and original. The swordplay has weight and the combat becomes very instinctual and fluid once you get the hang of it. And if you're playing the game on 'hard' it is HARD AS ♥♥♥♥, which is awesome. Only about five hours in and the story is already building tension and mystery. Also, the soundtrack for this game is breathtaking. It reminds me of the original Ghost in the Shell film OST, which is what I think they were going for considering the many similarities between the two. So far, it's one of the best RPG's I've played since The Witcher 3, and the best game released within the past year, and I've only played so little of it. I had to come and leave a review because of this euphoric feeling I have from playing this game. It's truly a work of art.

content:

												I’d like to start my review with a little story from my short playing session today:***When I play games on my PC I have two options:1) I play them on a 24“ monitor + a rather good speaker system2) I play them on my 40“ TV + a really good surround systemToday I went into a new area in the game while playing on my computer monitor, because I didn‘t want to switch on all that other equipment for a playing session that would only be rather short. End of story: I felt genuine regret! Not that it was a bad experience. Oh no, far from it! It was awe-inspiring. It‘s just that the visual and sound design in this game is ‚that‘ awesome.***Apart from that: The combat is satisfying, the story pulled me in right away and I so far enjoyed every single minute of gameplay!Oh, one more thing: I’m incredibly bad at action games. I usually only play turn-based stuff or very specific types of games that don’t require incredibly good reaction times. I’m so bad that I often have to quit games like this one after about two or three attempted battles. Luckily the lowest difficulty is just right for me, so that I can enjoy this awesome game. In this title boss fights are challenging, but not too difficult for me.You are good at action games and looking for a challenge? There are difficulty levels for everyone in this title.Overall there is no reason not to buy this game right now … except:The port is competent overall, but does have some severe technical problems. The worst of them ARE fixed by applying an unofficial fix (named "FAR": see the thread at the top of the forum) and using windowed borderless gaming, but IF you belong to that group of people who absolutely refuse to apply unofficial patches and use 3rd party tools: DO NOT GET THIS GAME NOW, BUT INSTEAD WAIT FOR A PATCH! (Sorry for the caps, but this is seriously important. That’s just how mandatory the fix is until this port gets patched.)I for my part use the fix and the borderless tool and I’m enjoying the hell out of this game.-----EDITS and additions after posting the review:Strictly speaking the game is playable without the fix and 3rd party tool, but usually a combination of the following can happen:- In fullscreen mode the resolution may be off (window mode has borders)- button prompts for the controller can be messed up in fullscreen mode- ingame cutscenes may stutter far below the 30 fps they were rendered in even on very performant hardware- on less potent hardware: without the FAR fix you don't have access to global illumination settings, which impact the performance heavily and the visual fidelity much less than other settings (even on a GTX 970 it may be difficult to maintain a steady 60 FPS in 1080p unless you either disable AA and AO. Toning down global illumination by only one level gives me roughly the same performance benefit that I can gain by entirely disabling both of those features.)

content:

												Achievement unlocked: "what are you doing ?"Self-destruction: ActivatedMore seriously tho, I'm not a big fan of japanese games, and it says a lot that I really enjoyed this one, its a wild and insane mix of hack and slash, slidescroller, bullet hell, shoot them up,..... the camera angles will determine the phases you are on, overall, it plays like nothing else and the novelty really is a great driving force in this game, always introducing new mechanics and throwing the player off balance.Graphically, its nothing groundbreaking, but the animations are excelent with few cliping and overall the atmosphere makes up for it, not a big deal, the PC port is meh but future updates will most likely fix it, and there already is a mod that fixes most graphical problems and uncaps framerate, so big deal either.The soundtrack is great and sinc perfectly with the action, lots of great songs, beware, the vocals are weird sometimes tho.The story is told in a very creative way, VERY MINOR SPOILERS (having the player go trough the story multiple times trough multiple characters, adding new mechanics, new quests, new perspectives and new infos allowing you to go deeper in the lore each playtrough) END SPOILERS The game is also an excelent value for money, having me play for 35 hours to complete the main story and roughly 50% of the sidequests.The only negative points IMO is the DENUVO drm which I am oposed by principle because it puts such a great game at risk in the long run and the sometimes samy sidequests in between the great ones.Overall, its a warm recomendation for me, its a japanese game so of course the fan service is strong with this one but there is so much more behind that I can't really complain, GET THIS GAME.

												A truly unique game. As someone who has played a lot of different games throughout his life, playing something this fresh and unique is very uplifting. Far from the rehashes and safe game design models of many other recent games, Nier automata blends a lot of different genres and aspects of games into one both for good and bad, but nevertheless for a very unique experience. Even if a certain blend doesn't work, many of the elements stay only for a short while, so you will quickly move on to the next. This is ontop of a great soundtrack, very entertaining and fun to play around with combat from platinum Games themselves and a crazy yet interesting story.Can recommend for any game enthusiast looking for something new.

												Pro: The game itself is awesome. To sum it up: impeccable art direction (incredible graphics and audio, oozing style and atmosphere), the game universe is fascinating, the story is quite good, and the characters are great, you just want to know what's going to happen to them, while enjoying the walk and chases in these derelict cities overrun by vegetation and enemy robots.Con: The quality of the port is debatable: a recent AAA PC game, high-res, from a big name in the game industry, and it runs only in windowed mode? WTF? Square Enix has never been that great in PC computing anyway. But the pros overweigh the cons by a huge factor: you just can't afford to miss this game. I'm an old gamer (not old school: I enjoy what modernity brings us ; I just happen to haven some decades of gaming behind me), I'm a sucker for mature narration and good characters, and I know when I see them, and they're all here, just for us to play. I can't wait to see what this game still has in store for me.

												Some issues, overall seems to be a decent conversion (especially considered the typical standard of japanese games ported on PC).I compared it to the PS4 and PS4 Pro version, here's my comments in detail1) Framerate is much more stable than even the PS4 Pro, locked at 60fps. Only saw TWO small drops in the first section of the game, even in areas where some frames would be skipped on the PS4 Pro (lava section underground in the lava factory). Framerate is 30fps for cut-scenes, don't remember if this was the case for PS4/Pro versions too but I assume it was.2) There's no borderless windowed mode. Fullscreen is lost if you alt-tab3) Game doesn't run at real 1080p if you set it that way, but something slightly lower. 900p? Bit higher probably. There's a small black frame if you set fullscreen 1080p4) The additional effects present on the Pro version, are also present on the PC versionGame is still as extraordinaire as the console version, hope they can fix those small annoying issues, but I got no hopes for that. Being that the game runs on DENUVO I'm afraid modders won't be able to fix them either.I tested the game on a GTX 1070 with an intel i7 3770, windows 10

												In its current state I would say don't grab this, grab it on PS4 if you REALLY want itMy main gripe right now is that mouse and keyboard controls are absolute garbage, while I get that you should be using a controller (and I would be, if it were not for my controller going missing into the void literally today) I don't find a PC game that is configured like this to be acceptable.In its current state these are problems I noticed that ended up making me just flatout turn the game off, despite waiting for it since announced.The game randomly ignores keyboard inputsThe game has digital mouse control, it essentially just sees that you recently moved it on X/Y axis and goes 'yo thats fine' meaning you only get 8 directions, some enemies are actually not possible to hit without lockon (which is disabled in harder modes)The game bugs out when camera angles change, you have to let go of all buttons for it to "reset your inputs" to the new cardinal directions.Sometimes when dashing it, no matter what, dashes you backwards and locks you in place.Default binds are fairly dumb, the biggest ones being light/heavy attach which are set to / and \ but also hardbound to left/right mouse.The game breaks all capture software permenantly when you change any video settings and requires you restart the game to capture again.The issues with the m+kb controls are bad enough that they seriously detract from the game, if you don't have a controller you should flatout not buy this.

												I've been playing video games for around 14 years now and all this time has left me jaded towards the medium. I've found it increasingly harder to find games that can capture my enjoyment and provide me an awe inspiring experience that can take me away from the real world like when I was younger. Nier Automata is one of those rare gems in gaming that brings me back to why I fell in love with the medium in the first place. Nier is the only game since the Witcher 3 that had me blink and 10 hours had passed without my noticing. Yoko Taro and his team have created a masterpiece that nobody should miss.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
19
												Excellent game, but the port leaves much to be desired.NieR: Automata is a strange hybrid of JRPG, platformer, hack n' slash, and twin stick shooter set in a distant dystopian future. It comes with a phenomenal soundtrack, vast multi-biome open world, and satisfying combat system baked in. The boss fights are original, challenging, and often very strange, and the storyline is pretty interesting (if a bit strange).Keep in mind that there are multiple endings: 5 main endings with individual stories, and 26 different possible ways to end the game.My only issues with the game are with its porting. There's a well-known resolution bug that changes your resolution to something lower if you're playing in fullscreen, microstuttering if you're not using VSYNC, 60FPS cap, and several other issues. While they are annoying, they don't completely detract from the gameplay. If/once these issues are fixed, I'll have absolutely no problem with the game.Pros:Wacky but exciting storyFantastic soundtrackPlenty of content/questsSatisfying and fun combat systemVery pretty visualsCons:Multiple technical issues (Resolution bug, microstuttering, white screen on AMD)Wonky camera anglesLimited settings menu (Can't adjust draw distance)Poor keyboard + mouse supportLocked to 60FPS, 30FPS cutscenesThe game runs fine on my system with no crashes, but I've heard of framerate drops/crashing on systems with AMD cards

content:

												NieR Automata is by far the best game I have played in my life, and for many reasons.I initally got into the series at NieR Gestalt, and went back and played some of the Drakengard games  as well.As much as those games are master pieces in their own right, this game goes far above, and beyond it's predecessors.Simutaniously this game gives many nods to the old games in a way that doesn't impede upon a new players experience.This is a game that stands proudly, and firmly on it's own two Android legs.It is full of highs, and lows, and explores themes of love, hate, anger, consciousness,  life, existence, death, and much more! (It is my wish to avoid spoilers, so I will keep this review as ambiguous as possible.)More mature players that are willing to surrender themselves to this experience will truly appreciate their time with this game.Too easy/hard? Change the difficulty settings!On my first playtrhough on normal I found the difficulty to be very fair.My advice is to go through the story, as much as you can without worrying, or looking too many things up.If you have your own experience with this you will be greatly rewarded in a way that most games won't fulfill you in.Finish it at your own speed, be it fast or slow.I personally favoured a very slow pace, and enjoyed the combat, and scenery as much as I could.It was very easy to do this once I set aside my usual overly efficient mind set, and mentality. This game was well worth the money, just make sure you have a gamepad for the best experience!I will eventually come back to 100 % this game, but for now it has left an after glow that will radiate, and resonate within me for a very long time.Thank you to everyone that was involved in the making of this game, truly! Thank you for allowing it to come to PC, as I wouldn't of gotten to experience it had it not, and after playing this game I can truly say it was an experience worth having.

												So far this game is extremely solid and takes a little while to really appreciate what is actually going on structurally. I think people see it and assume it's some kind of Devil May Cry game, but the reality is that it's like a 3 dimensional bullet hell game and a close quarters melee game combined into one. Piled on top of that very interesting blend of game modes is a pretty interesting story that branches into multiple endings, as well as some pretty deep item/weapon/skill management elements. Overall it's a game that manages to have engaging gameplay that could've been really shallow, but is fortified through story and weapons/skills and an open world.Personally, one of the most interesting features of this game is the way it treats the camera. Often it will give you the standard dual axis control scheme, but other times it goes into a 2.5D sidescroller or a top down shooter style, which works remarkably well. Overall it has a pretty cinematic vibe in the way it handles player control with the camera. The story is also good, but like all good story driven games, it's mostly there to facilitate gameplay and doesn't really strike me as a movie I'd watch through cutscenes or anything like that.

You must understand it from a perspective different from a gamer. Without a doubt a masterpiece. Final Verdict 9/10

content:

												"Poor english" warning!I was kinda expecting another MGR:R or Bayonetta game as platinum was involved with this title. What I got was a bit of that and whole lot of emotions that I though a game couldn't make me feel.If you are in for this for the combat alone, you might be a bit disapointed. Controls are snappy and responsive, although the camera is a bit jank at times. There just isn't that much to do with combos as enemies either die so fast or have hyperarmor and poise trough your attacks so you end up getting hit, unless you evade mid combo. My playthough was on hard and I was +/- 5-ish levels from the enemies most of the time. Some plug-in chips (permanent stat boosts and special abilities) and Pod-programs (your little turret friend) can help to counter some of the comboing thing which made the combat more fun for me.The feel of the world is empty, with the occasional mob pack roaming around. The amazing music adds very much to this feeling of emptiness. As the layout of the land changes so does the music to reflect it. The areas may not look graphically amazing by modern day standards (low quality models and textures up close) but the are each unique by their own means.Most of the sidequests are quite stale. "Go there. Kill this. Talk to this person. Gather this. Come back." But the little bit of dialogue you get from most of them made questing worth for me. Some of them made me a bit emotional, be it happy, sad, troubled... I didn't expect this from mere sidequests. But some might just find the story dull.When things do pick up, man do they pick up and fast and wierd ways. Story included. Most bosses are quite hectic and awesome aside a few bad ones. Bosses mix the games different mechanics nicely although most of them are just your typical Platinum style bosses with 3rd person view.I won't go to the story much as I want to keep it as spoiler free as possible. I just say it digs quite deep about the meaning of being human/alive. But if you get this game, DON'T STOP AT THE FIRST ENDING. The game has so much more content after you have beaten it once. Never have I felt so, I don't know, uncertain... ? at a games end. In most turns it manages to mess with your brain in wierd ways. The element of suprise is one of its biggest pros.Conclusion: Storywise the game is one of the most memorable I have played. It certainly got me interested in the universe. Gameplaywise it isn't the greatest character action game out there, but it's quite high up there. The genre mashing makes it unique (even though it's similar to the first Nier which I haven't played).And if you fear that the game is too difficult it does feature a easy mode so you can experience the story if you would like.

												Well I have to say this is one of the best game I've played in quite sometime. Story is sort meh or little above average. Has the typical angsty teenage love crush story been there done that in SO many animes. But I digress for a Japanese title, however gameplay is king. Part Rpg, part hack n' slash, part platforming, part shoot em up you'd think this game would be a mess, implementation seemlessly transition together quite nicely. At time times you'll feel badass beating enimies using certain atrributes and fighting style and be justified for it. Some parts do get a little odd or prolonged but for the most part it's quite well exicuited giving rise to some gripes.Especially when the game takes control that it's trying to be different or meta to an extreme. Example when you you're systems are infected with a virus you have to trot to a safe zone while immobilized and vunerable to enimies around around you. Tril and error and mostly luck will get you passed this point. I know the game is probably saying "have you ever tried taking control of an fried toaster?" and the game (umung other thing) gives that exerience. I understand it's trying to break the form. However it's an annoying, cumbersome, and really do not see the point in my eyes. Maybe I'm not understading the conveyance, but I wasn't a a happy gamer at that point. Maybe some could explain the intention and meaning. But I really don't see it.All in all great game; pays homage to many classic generas in direct and indirect ways with a lot of heart and care. Gives credence to replayablity in way that's works very well. I wish more game would offer it the way it's presented.

												This game had such a prodound experience on me, I will remember it for the rest of my life. I realize this sounds cheesy, but let me explain.In the beginning I cared about my character. After a while I found myself caring about other characters not just myself. This then elevated to caring about other characters as my character would in the world. Then as I played more, and got deeper and deeper in the story and relationships, I began thinking, feeling, and acting as my character in the world. Nier is so incredible that when I played, I became that character fully, sharing their pain, thier love, their emotions...etc. I found myself reacting to situations as if they were actually happenening afk. I began to physically experience the story as the characters in the game would, getting chills, quickening heartbeat, sadness, joy, anger...I've never had this sort of experience with a game before.When I was finished, I honestly felt as though I had been with the characters through it all from the moment I began.I cannot express anymore how incredible the experience of this game is.( I'd recommend using the original language of Japanese and eng subs - but if you're really against that they have like 5 languages to choose from ^_^ )Nier Automata makes me happy. sad. angry. nervous. proud. confident. In some ways, just as (if not more) events in my actual life.

												This is quite frankly one of the best games I've ever played. A responsible active battle system, on top of a beautiful world for you to explore, with deep characters and a multi-layer storyline, topped with a great soundtrack.Keep in mind that "playing again once you beat it the first time", in this game, is not "replayability". It's part of the story. If you thought you knew what the game was about after finishing it once, you're in for a ride. You've not finished this game at all until you play it to at least three of the endings.The plot thickens. The characters get more human. You get to all the characters better (even the enemies), understand what happened from their point of view, and actually get to the bottom of what is actually happening.I highly recommend you play this with a joystick (I myself play with a DS4). Oh, and if you're wondering, you can play it with the audio in Japanese, and English subtitles.

												18 hours logged on steam,A few of them probably in pause menu afk..Spoiler free I wouldn't say I'm too far into the game..I've just unlocked fast travel.. Graphics, once I installed the mod..absolutely perfect running at 60FPS no glitches mostly maxed settings. Soundtrack, is absolutely amazing...adds real depth to the game, music is usually really well suited and fits well to the areas that your currently in. I think Emi Evans who did a lot of the Dark Souls soundtrack is quite involved..Gameplay, The combat is really adjustable,dynamic and fluent with many on the fly settings.. Plays highly similar to that of Metal Gear Rising mixed with Final Fantasy 15. Many ways and forms to evade certain enemy attacks,link hundreds of combos together..with over 40 weapons each with their own particular 4 styles.The chip system once you get past the peculiartiy of it is really quite intricate.. A way to describe or compare it would be to FF9 abilities stones/AP... You have a chipboard.. which is your max AP which is upgradable as you progress and farm materials.. And the chips you find along the way are the abilities...you can tailor them specifically for what you need.The story so far seems pretty rich, but easy to understand, I particurlarly like how it stands out from most other games as i've not really seen anything set in this setting...Controls..Have to be honest i'm using a 360 controller.But i picked up the controls in a matter of minutes.Check it out!

												I didn't go into Nier:Automata with any great expectations, I simply was looking for a fun game to play to fill a lull in my gaming life, but what I got was so much more. First thing's first; I've never played a Nier or Drakengard game before this one so you don't need that level of familiarity to enjoy this game, though I don't doubt it would add more to the experience. The combat is fast paced, varied, and fun without being overbearing so of you're looking for a game that actually is just fun to PLAY then this is your game. However, it's the story and the emotion it brings to bear that really prompted me to write out a review. Most of your time will be spent getting to know our stylish androids better, but if you see everything the game has to offer you'll feel a part of this world and this community in a way few games are capable of achieving. To summarize an already brief summary, I wholeheartedly recommend it.

												Here is a simple quick review:Easily game of the year 2017, or at the very least best soundtrack of the year.*Awesome fun gameplay----------------------> Check*Great polish and attention to detail-----------> Check*The absolute best soundtrack in a long time -> Check*Will it make you cry?-------------------------> Check*Will you want to play it all over again and again and again?---------->Check*Does it have any replay value?---------------------------------------->Check (26 endings)*Will you get your money's worth out of this?------------------------->Double Check!This game reminds me of how games used to be in old times, especially with it's weird (in a good way) style of camera movement and awesome gameplay, it will remind you of the good old times, to be frankly honest, if you buy this game for (60$) just to listen to it's score, then that alone is already so much worth it.Bottom Line: this is my first review ever and as you can tell I'm no expert in writing reviews,I just can't praise this game enough.10/10

												In the past couple of years I have played plenty of games, watched plenty of series and movies as well as spending plenty of time with my lads. After 5 years time this game reminded me what it is to enjoy a game. A game that is immersive, a story that is interesting yet sad. A combat system that is fluent. A grinding system that knows its limit so that you won't spend decades in the search of one item and the soundtracks... those are a masterpiece. There are plenty of games with better graphics, better effects, a better story, better sounds, but do they all have these great aspects in a single game? If it weren't for Witcher 3 and GTA V I'd call this game the most complete and finished product that has been created in the past 5 years. It reminded me once again what it is to enjoy games.Luckily enough my setup can handle this game at max settings without any resolution bugs or whatsoever. There are some players experiencing some issues, but that shouldn't stop you from trying this game as the person behind it is a genius that you will encounter rarely in the gaming industry. For the given issues there are plenty of work arounds. I talk about the content as this game is easily spoiled, but the trailers show you a fraction of what is waiting for you once you purchase this divine product.

												UPDATE - I'm still leaving this to not recommended for the time being until it is patched, but there is a work around for the blank screen on AMD RX 400 series cards. First, do a clean install with Display Driver Uninstaller. Make sure to do it through safe mode, and you might want to create a backup / system restore just in case. Link here. https://www.guru3d.com/files-get/display-driver-uninstaller-download,1.htmlNext, install driver 16.11.15 - http://support.amd.com/en-us/download/desktop/previous/detail?os=Windows%2010%20-%2064&rev=16.11.5#You should be good to go then. there is some noticeable stuttering here and there with this temporary fix, but it's certainly better than not being able to play the game at all. ORIGINAL REVIEW BEFORE WORK AROUND - Needs to be patched. There is definitely an issue with getting a freeze into a blank/white screen (one time it was blue for me even) for different users with different hardware. Many, including myself, can barely get pass the first boss, and for some it happens straight from launch. It seems to be fairly across the board for AMD users currently, despite Square Enix claiming its driver 17.2.1, and there are reports of it happening from Nvidia users. I have an RX 480 8gb personally, and have tried different drivers and messing around the settings and it still happened despite my efforts. It is unplayable due to this issue.There is also the issue of fullscreen not properly displaying, instead displaying a much lower resolution. For me I use 1920x1080, and it seems to be displaying in 1600x900 or so leading to desaturation and stretched images  or black bars. It can be worked around with the Borderless Gaming program, but Borderless Gaming does put in some input lag which is not ideal for a game such as Nier: Automata. This needs to be fixed as well.

												NieR Automata is fast becoming one of my favourite games of all time.  The game traverses between a first-person hack 'n' slash, 2D platformer, side-shooter and overhead-view, and it works really well.  The combat system is simple but effective, the bosses are challenging without being OP, the storyline is as wonderfully weird as you'd expect from a Yoko Taro game and the soundtrack is one of the best I've ever come across.  Seriously, it needs to be released as a stand-alone, it's that good. Drawbacks?  Well, sometimes fights can get a little confusing if you're up against a lot of enemies at once, and the tutorial is needlessly long.  Other than that, NieR Automata should be a serious contender for GOTY, IMHO.

												Two of my favorite gaming genres are fighting games and shmups, I love arcade style action. Platinum managed to blend those styles of play into a JRPG of all things leaving me very impressed.I came to this game via being a fan of Platinum. I never played the first Nier game and don't play a ton of RPGs in general. This combat system is a bit more forgiving than games like Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance, which Platinum also designed, but I totally loved it. The boss battles were especially rewarding with timing of blocks and counter attacks and on-the-fly weapon loadout swaps.The system of managing your character's stats as chips is also really cool. You have a finite area to plug them in, and the more special chips (with a diamond symbol) can perform the same routine while taking up a smaller number of "slots" so you get the same stat boost more efficiently. The game allows you to re-arrange and swap out chips to rebuild your entire character's spec as needed. I really enjoyed remapping the whole stack for boss encounters - really unique system and I hope other games steal this idea.I just finished playing my 3rd play through (2nd is a different perspective same timeline, 3rd is continuation of the story so at least 3 plays needed, don't stop!) and wow - it shot to the top 5 games of all time for me. Don't miss it - what a surprise. A Masterpiece like this doesn’t come along very often.
