												Yoko Taro's approach to storytelling is like increasing the temperature of a hot tub by 1 degree at a time. You won't notice the difference until you look down after 30 hours and realize you're in a pool of lava. Only then will you realize you actually prefer lava.Each Drakengard game starts with a simple and relatable premise: Man and dragon fight evil empire. Father wants to find a cure for his sick daughter. And NieR: Automata, at its surface level, is about androids battling machine-servants of aliens while humanity takes refuge on the moon. If it sounds like your typical JRPG sci-fi story, congratulations: You've fallen into Taro's trap. To call the events of the game a mindf**k is both accurate and a disservice. It implies a lack of meaning or direction, when in reality you're given everything you need in order to understand the story; it just might not come in the order you like. Not only is the main story an enigma that leaves you hungry for more details, but even the sidequests add important context to the events of the story, as well as having some seriously strong foreshadowing that you'll likely miss until you're thinking in retrospect. And that's the real beauty of a Taro story: it keeps you occupied for weeks after you finish the game as you slowly stumble upon epiphanies, information the game gave you clear as day but that your brain failed to piece together until it was too late. After several of these moments you'll come to not only love the game, but respect the writers as intellectual superiors that played you like a damn fiddle while, somehow, respecting your intelligence at the same time. If you've played a JRPG in the past, you know that there is often a trifecta of qualities and you have to pick two and only two: graphics, gameplay, and story. If a game has great graphics and gameplay, it usually has a bad story (Bayonetta, DMC, etc.). If it has a fantastic story, it usually either has bad gameplay or bad graphics (Xenoblade). The pattern so far for Drakengard has been good story, decent gameplay, and bad graphics. However, they've teamed up with Platinum Games this time, who's known for great gameplay, good graphics, and bad story. Combined, they've managed to cover each other's flaws beautifully. This game is a treat to look at, the gameplay is fun as hell, and the story is some of Taro's best work yet.I can't remember the last time I had so few complaints about a game, and I'm an incredibly harsh critic of games (especially ones that I love). Throughout NieR: Automata, I kept thinking "what's the catch?" There has to be a really terrible part coming up soon, right? No game goes this long without any glaring issues. That point never came, though.If you've never played Drakengard, you'll probably still have a great time with this game. If you've played most of the series up to this point, it's a masterpiece.

												I bought this game mostly on a whim because I had some money lying around in my Steam wallet and because Jim Sterling recommended it. This turned out to be a fantastic decision. Here's a quick rundown of why I can highly recommend this game:Pro:- The storyline is fantastic: it comes with several plot twists, is highly nuanced, extremely dark and full of philosophical undertones (-> existentialism and absurdism). As someone who really enjoys that kind of thing (e.g. I also really liked SOMA for this reason) this alone makes the game worth while.- The soundtrack is incredible and I really hope it finds its way onto Spotify. It's not just that the individual tracks are beautiful and memorable but also that they are used to great effect in the actual game. For example, some of the songs sync up really well with certain boss battles.- Overall, the game is quite original and is certainly a breath of fresh air in an industry oversaturated with AAA titles full of rehashed concepts.- The animations are really fluid and the combat (especially the boss fights) looks pretty damn cool.- While the graphics aren't particularly noteworthy from a technical perspective the game features tons of varied and beautiful environments. At the same time it manages to keep a cohesive aesthetic throughout the entire game.- Some of the sidequests are really interesting and tie into the main storyline in important ways.Contra:- Some of the sidequests have dull / annoying objectives (fetch quests, escort quests etc.) and there is quite a bit of backtracking. The game is clearly aware of this as one of the main characters even complains about it multiple times. That doesn't make it that much better, though.- There are some technical issues with the game such as the fact that it doesn't run in 1080p fullscreen currently (however, this can be easily fixed using Borderless Gaming). Also, there is a noticeable amount of texture pop-in particularly in the ruined city area. However, I did not encounter any serious glitches or crashes.- The combat can get a little bit repetitive by the end of the game.- The game initially recommends the "normal" difficulty but even as someone who doesn't really play singleplayer games for the challenge I found that the game became way to easy towards the end. If you put any effort into optimizing your plugin chips you'll be nearly invincible on normal.Overall I'd give NieR: Automata a strong 9/10 and even though we're only 3 months into 2017 I'd be quite surprised if a better game comes out this year. Also, if you decide to pick up this game you must keep playing after the first "ending" since otherwise you'll miss most of what makes this game so good.

content:
17
												Neir is a fast-paced hack-and-slash title with lots of other elements - such as bullet hell, top-down combat, and platforming - tied together with an absolutely god-tier story and execution. Having completed the game, I can say with confidence this is one of the best video games I've had the pleasure to play, both because the gameplay is awesome and the story is unmatched.  It is absolutely a one-of-a-kind video game in all of the best ways.That said, a more detailed, spoiler-free breakdown below. See "Verdict" at the bottom for the tl;dr version:The Good: Story, direction, soundtrack, execution of gameplay mechanicsBasic combat is fast, brutal, and has a high skill ceiling (but, see "Difficulty" below)Non-traditional combat elements (bullet-hell, top-down combat, platforming) bring an interesting and fun feel to the game not present in any other hack-n-slash titlesThe story is absolutely incredible, both in its writing and presentation. Thematically, everything in this game fits so well; how saves, upgrades, respawning, and every other gameplay mechanic works in this game are explained within the universe that the game takes place. This does wonders for immersion and is a very unique experience you won't find in other titles.RPG mechanics find an excellent balance between allowing for customization, and not requiring constant micro-management.The soundtrack is phenomenal.Dual-Audio support; you can easily select if you'd like to use the original Japanese or English audio/voice actors in settings. Both have full subtitle support for all voices in game, whether in cutscenes or during gameplay.The Bad: Performance, difficulty, gameplay cameraNote 1: I'm running an Intel i7-6700k, Gitgabyte GTX 970 Windforce (4Gb), and 16Gb RAM on Windows 10.Note 2: The FAR fix by Kaldein, which can be found pinned to the top of Nier: Automota's discussion thread in Steam, will fix all performance issues listed below with little effort. Kaldein is a reputable and well-established modder in the community, and has put out a variety of high-quality fixes for poorly performing games.The FAR fix will fix the following performance issues:Performance is very poor by default. Without getting into the technical details, the game is terribly optimized and many features are broken by default (most glaring are fullscreen and vsync). FAR makes performance anywhere from 30-75% better framerate-wise.Fullscreen does not function by default, it is either totally broken or it will not run the game in fullscreen at your monitor's native resolution (instead it runs it at a lower resolution and upscales).In-game Vsync is broken by default; it causes performance issues and locks gameplay to 30fps.The following performance issues CANNOT be fixed:Freezing is a common occurence for some users. The FAR fix seems to mitigate freezing, but it can still happen. Disable all background programs and overlays to avoid freezingKeyboard/Mouse controls aren't the best, the main issues being with dodging and aiming in the bullet-hell parts. Keyboard/mouse is usable, but you WILL WANT to use a controller w/ NierGameplay is capped at 60fps, I don't personally see this as a huge issue, but some willCutscenes are capped at 30fps/900p, and suffer from noticeable stuttering and frame drops.Other non-performance issues: Difficulty, gameplay cameraDifficulty is hand's down the biggest issue with this game, bar none. Normal difficulty is very simple and presents little challenge. Hard is frustratingly difficult early on, but regresses to being very simple once you get about 1/3 of the way through the game. Very Hard literally makes all enemies one-shot you (that's the description under "Very Hard") and it's unbeatable for all intents and purposes. Default camera: The default camera settings are pretty poor, low-sensitivity and a close camera makes it very difficult to see what is happening. If you are playing on hard or very hard, you WILL take random pot-shots that one-shot you and you could not see coming. Increase the camera height and sensitivity for a much better experience.Hard/Very Hard difficulty remove the "Lock-on" button. The main purpose of this is so that you cannot constantly spam targeted range attacks at enemies, which makes sense. The problem is it makes it very difficult to quickly and accurately switch between enemies and change your camera, which is very important on Hard/Very Hard. To help with this issue, I suggest changing the default "Lock-On" key to "Reset Camera" when you are on Hard/Very Hard.Verdict: ABSOLUTELY BUY this game if you are even mildly interested.Though I didn't spend as much time on the great parts about this game so I can avoid spoilers, that's not to say the good doesn't vastly outweigh the bad. The story is GOD TIER. The thematic immersion of gameplay elements is one-of-a-kind. The melding of hack-n-slash with other gameplay types is extremely fun and very well done. The soundtrack and voice acting are stellar. The RPG mechanics are incredibly balanced. THESE THINGS FAR OUTWEIGH MY COMPLAINTS.The current performance issues can be a pain, but the FAR fix makes the game run extremely well and very enjoyable to play.The difficulty is my biggest complaint, but the gameplay is still phenominal. I'm a pretty hardcore hack-n-slash player though, so this may not be as much of an issue for others.

												If you're a fan of action games from Platinum this may be a step down in the gameplay department by a bit if you play the game on normal. However, it can be a bit punishing if you play it on hard which makes it a tough sell as a pure action game.  All and all it's a great game with a deep philosophical undertone with some bad gameplay pacing issues. There's also a ton of side missions and a lot of hidden bosses and side quests that make it interesting after the story, but it’s marred that you have to select the correct chapter for that mission while the game doesn't let you know if the selection you're selecting has access to it.  TL;DR: Turn it up to hard and take your time with it to get as many side quests done on your first go around.

												2 weeks after its release, the game is still unplayable for GTX 700 series owners (and possibly RX 480 and noticed some GTX Titan complains here and there), it's still brimming with technical issues and poor optimization across platforms (poorly optimized for consoles which carried over and brought even more problems for the PC version).It's an action game and, given that the game's engine is bound to the framerates you can get, attaining 50+ or solid 60 is mandatory for the enjoyment of the game. And that makes the poor optimization that results to framedrops (no matter its source) worse than it is in any other game.2 weeks later, no patch yet to be seen. Imagine paying for a game you found you cannot complete due to crashing, and have to wait for "some day" to be resolved. Imagine that you waited for that game for months, if not years if you were a fan of the Nier/Drakengard games.I cannot upvote this game on the grounds of "it plays on other people's machines". If you cannot approproately support the hardware diversity of the PC. I cannot believe this it the kind of treatment PC consumers receive from Platinum, after the work they did with Metal Gear Rising:Revengeance. Now I know which company's game I won't preorder again.

												I would recommend this game to people who know what they are getting into and like these type of action-packed spectacle fighters. To those who are on the fence, I'd say wait for a sale because IMO it is a mixed bag. But overall still a good game and I quite like it.The good part:The gameplay itself. Altough I haven't played that much yet I really like the fighting, the variety (changing from 3d fighting to 2d and sometimes twin stick is actually more fun than I at first thought when I heard about it), the music and sound. In general I don't have anything bad to say about the game itself... and that is a good thing :)The bad is the technical side. I am running at 21:9 (2560x1080) and it does work without any tricks but it is clearly not optimized for that. You will sometimes see stretched and blurry menus and what you would expect. But the game itself and the cutscenes work in 21:9 just fine so that's a plus. Besides that I am running a gtx 1070 and had no fps drops, crashes or the likes so far. FPS were stable but the cutscenes are limited to 30 fps and you do notice that quite heavily. There are other times where you feel this is a console port (menus, twin stick shooter...) but overall it's runs fine on my pc.

												Developers have acknowledged the optimization issues and the community is trying to help at the time of this post.Nier: Automata is a sequel to Nier set in sum 7000 years into the future from Nier Gestalt in a post-apocolyptic setting following what was the 14th Machine War. The player plays as an android who belongs to an organization to protect humanity, or what's left of it, called YoRHa. YoRHa seemingly created these sentient androids as strategy to preserve what is left of humanity and hopes to defend the remaining humans on the moon. While open world games can be a hit or miss (moreover miss) Nier: Automata makes good use and sense for their open world enviornment through the different biomes and environments. Players will regularly inspect subtle design choices in the environments giving a very believable artistic edge to the fantasy style of the game. Even the fixed camera angels during some of the transitions feel right and add some integrity to the games style. (It's really nice to see a post-apocolyptic style game that isn't a brown and dusty bowl.)Gameplay is also very refreshing. Players are regularly rewarded for correcting their combat mistakes, even the tutorial forces players to really begin understanding the mechanics before you can even reach the first save point. This helps deter players who think they can glide through the gameplay by mashing buttons without a thought. And while the game is (what seems to be) loaded with sidequests to help add some gameplay fluff, they can be vital for extra materials, items, and levels so players are not grinding out levels to progress the main story more smoothly.The sounds are what I would expect from this series. Like Nier, Nier: Automata has the same excellent composers perfect for the style of the settings. Each track seems to have a lot of thought and care poured in by how well they reflect the setting and situation. Being as mechanical and robotic as it is, its surprising how much time went into giving the many robots and androids different personalities and traits giving a lot of life to the machines. And while I am not in love with the english voice acting they aren't necessarily bad in any way, though it is good the team decided to include dual audio as they should.While being familiar with Nier is preferred, it is in no way required to get the full enjoyment out of this game.This brings back what games should be.

content:

This review is from someone who has never heard of Nier or played any of Yoko Taro's games. Deep story with well over 40+ hours of story to unfold. AND IM TALKING DEEEP M8!@! I have 55 hours at the time of writing this with only 15 endings under my belt, and I haven't started my "Very Hard" playthrough yet. Yes....I'm addicted. The Combat system while easy for newcomers to hack and slash, also has a lot of depth in terms of combos. Mostly being the combos that involve your Pod companion(he it pew pews while you slice and dice) and combos with delays.There a plenty more combos involving dash and jump, but you'll figure it out.With 30+ weapons that all have different weights/timings/combos that switch out on the fly , I'm sure everyone can find weapons suitable to their playstyle.Last but not least, the SOUND TRACK, this is the center piece that brings everything together. The chilling feel of anxiety brushes over you everystep of the way, drawing you in to the story. I even listen to the sound track when im not playing the game...it's that ♥♥♥♥ing good!I had no performance issues other than Video cutscenes run at reduced framerates (assuming due to the compression?).Other than that, the game crashed once in 55 hours of gameplay.Game is capped at 60 FPSCpu: i7-3770kGPU: GTX 1080Resolution: 1920x1080So make sure to call your phycologist and schedule an appointment for ~5 days after the purchase of this game. Tell them you need to talk some real deep ♥♥♥♥, they will more than likely know why you are calling and refer you to a Nier recovery specialist.Proposal: Buy this game for the Glory of Humankind :yorha:

												TL;DR Worth every 0.00001 of a penny (penny value may varies base on your region)STORY: Yoko Taro story is legendary as usual, dark theme with humour mixed in that you just can't find anywhere else. He'll randomly try to cheer you up as you progress along and holy hell do you need one sometimes. Think of it like you suffering through college and your uncle popping in once a while and give you a fluffy cat toy even though you don't have a cat.MUSIC&SOUND: music fit every part of the story and story fit every part of the music. Can't ask for anything more except for....well........more. GAMEPLAY: play it on Hard cuz you won't regret suffering through every bit of it. Not on "very hard" though, that's just sadisticGRAPHIC&DESIGN: Do you like explosion that was placed in for explosion sake? You'll get none of that here. Everything has it's place and purpose. Fanservice is also baked right into the character so there won't be a filler/fanservice episode/part of the story. Probably the only game that make me return to singleplayer after 10 years of pure multiplayer. It's just amazing of how much work goes into this.

												I've never really ever been invested into the plot of games, usually I play games for the gameplay aspect and that alone. I discovered Nier:Automata about a month before its release and followed it closely anicipating the release. When I finally finished the game (make sure you continue playing after the first playthrough) I realized how much I became invested into the story and characters. The gameplay is somewhat smooth, the combat is fluid, the atomosphere and environment are brilliant, and don't even get me started on the soundtrack. This game sucked me into the story really fast and every day I was dying to get home so I can see what happens next. Now I feel an empty void completing the story, but I don't plan to stop playing the game and I can see myself doing another playthrough in the near future. This is definitely my game of the year. If you're anything like me, this game will not disappoint and I 10/10 recommend this game to anyone.P.S. If you have an Xbox or PS controller I would highly recommend using that because for me the KB&M combo is a little wonky, at least for me

												I'm still making my way through my second playthrough as I attempt to 100% this game. I have to say that I'm really impressed considering I found the original game to be pretty mediocre at best. The combat is excellent. The world is beautiful and memorable. The story is touching. The music is simply magnificent and has been on my daily playlist since release. Just YouTube the OST if you don't believe me. As far as I can tell the game is meant to be played through at least 3 times and you see the world from a different pair of eyes each time. The story unveils even further with every successive playthrough and one playthrough is not all that long. The port itself is decent, but not that great. However, most of my issues with the port were resolved with Kaldaien's FAR mod. It should be on the discussion board for this game.This is a rating from what I've experienced so far. I know I haven't completed this game in its entirety yet. However, I have a feeling that my conclusion won't change much upon completion. In fact, it may just get better. This game is damn good and truly a treasure.

												I recently discovered the 'NieR' series on a hunt for music/OSTs that were akin to 'Shadow of the Colussus'. A lone comment in a reddit thread lead me to the first 'NieR' album and was pleasantly surprised to learn that NieR: Automata had literally just launched. Compelled by the music of that first album, I decided to purchase the game and give it a whirl.Initially I was concerned that I would need to play 'Drakengard' or the original 'NieR' in order to fully appreciate the game, as I had not. The game stands alone perfectly, like a different house in the same neighborhood (thousands of years in the future).I won't spoil the plot for you (So I won't remark on characters, etc.), but please note that game's story plays out a bit different than most. Instead of a -very- long story, it's a tad bit shorter if you think of it in a linear fashion. However, the story is structured in such a way that you revisit the same story from a completely different angle in a truly varied way, and it feels quite different (thus far). It's NOT the typical: change Yes to No and Ending A becomes Ending B. It's nothing like that, you'll definitely want to keep playing.Good: Combat is fun, the customization is an interesting spin, the music is SUPERB. Controller combat wasn't bad, I thought I was going to hate it, but it works well. Try all the weapons, try all the abilities. This game isn't about min/max. The scenery is bleak feeling, but gorgeous.Bad: Fullscreen looks atrocious, but the windowed setting looks great. There isn't an auto-save, so be warned! I was hoping for a little more varied enemies, but it's not too bad.Things I wish I knew first: Use your POD target/lock on to allow for certain combos. All weapons are fun in their own way, it's worth trying them all and upgrading them all as you can. Don't worry about 'maxing' them on the first play through.Last thoughts: For purchasing on a whim, based on the music, I'm more than pleasantly surprised how fun it is. This game is fantastic. 9/10

												So after beating the game (Completing all the main endings) I have to say that this has been the most fun I've had in a game for a while. From the smooth transition from attacks with different weapons (animations are on point from the start of the attack to recovering from a swing) to the hectic bullet-hell sections with constant views. Although I wish there were more bosses but every one we got was fantastic. Even the story although slow at some points kept me engaged and interested to the end. There are some small quirks with the game (frame rate drops between some cinematic parts. When shifting camera angles, movement controls go a little wonky. But nothing gamebreakinig that I have encountered. Overall this game was a blast to play and highly recommend to everyone to play.For the dark souls players try hard mode. From the first mins of the game it will force you to "git gud". And the bosses are easily the stars (outside of 2b,9s and A2) of this game. By far the final boss is the best encounter of any game I have played in a long time and shows how platinum games has beautifully combine all the mechanics to give us a satisfying fight.

												*--POTENTIAL SPOILERS!!!--* (maybe small bits)I just finished my first run, and WOW, I haven't had an experience like this in a while.I'm not sure where to start so i'll just list my favorite thing about this game.The Story: I like the dystopia overrun by machines who left by an alien race that died off years ago, what made it especailly interesting was learning the differences in machines between areas, how they "lived" their lives. Not to mention the relationship 2B and 9S had, it was nice to see 2B progressively warm up to "nines".The Ending(s): I only have the A H W on my endings ( for those who dont know, neither do i), but the replayablity of this game is interesting and im really hoping its not the exact same story repeated, though I dont see that happeningThe Music: ...Byoutiful...The SKILLS: very well done I must admit. It has a Dark souls vibe to it aswell, where death means losing your upgrades and having to back track for them, or lose them which by the way not recommended. They can get expensive when you get in the higher tiers.That was most of the good... Now the BAD (Keep in mind this is on the experience of one playthrough)The camera angles: omg, i wish this wasnt an issue, but having to get use to a new camera angle whenever the game decides its time for TOP DOWN/3D-2D/THIRD PERSON/ETC is really obnoxious. I had moments where I kept taking damage from enemies i couldn't see because the camera forced a perspective on me and i couldn't adjust it properly.Length: I uderstand the replay mechanics, but it still seemed too short. I may, however, change my mind after a couple more replays.Weapons: so far theres not much in weapons that interested me. I ran with my entry katana and beastlord (can literally get it at the beginning of the game) the whole playthrough because no other weapons base damage where better.Traveling: the fast travel comes a little late in the game, not too late though. You had two options, Run or take the time to bait a beast and ride it. I would've much perfered an actual vehicle, like a hoverbike maybe? make it easier to travel through land, because you trip on every bush, dip and elevated step while sprinting, make worth a lot so you work for it like 20k-30k.All in all I give it a solid 9/10, I feel my dislikes of the game isn't too much to set it off too much. Except the camera.

												Reading about other people's performance issues, I actually researched Steam's return policy prior to purchasing this, and fully expected to use it.  I can happily say that I have not had any trouble with it.  I have this game for both the PS4 and my PC and I can comfortably recommend it for either system.  If you have any doubts about whether your PC can run it though, I'd suggest just springing for the PS4 version to be on the safe side.  My PC specs are:CPU:  i5-4690GPU:  MSI GTX 970 (Nvidia)RAM:  8 GB1 TB Hard Drive - Not SSDGamepad:  Xbox One Wireless controller for WindowsGame Settings:Full Screen1920x1080Anti-Aliasing: OnEffects:  HighShadows:  HighAmbient Occlusion: OffI'm not overclocking or anything like that and I run my computer power on Balanced mode.  I've had a few instances of frame rates dropping for a second or two, but it goes back up to full speed (60-ish).  I do have one minor gripe, a quirk with the mouse cursor not automatically disappearing when I use my controller, but moving it to the right edge of the screen is a simple enough solution.The 1920x1080 on fullscreen mode bug is still an issue, but the game still looks better than the PS4 version on my computer, so I can ignore it until a fix comes out.The game is an open-world(ish) action/hack-and-slash/rpg.  It is a smooth and fast paced combat system along the lines of Devil May Cry and God of War.The story telling and npc interaction really, really reminds me of the old Legend of Zelda games, though.  And the music also gives me that same sort of feeling that I had when playing those older jRPGs.It's worth buying, in my opinion, but if you have doubts, you can always rent it if you have a PS4 and try before you buy.

content:

												So it seems like this is one of those games that runs well on some machines and not on others. Since on my PC it seems to run at smooth 60 fps (turned on MSI Afterburner to make sure) with some minor 2-5 fps (to 55 fps) dips on some enemy explosions, I have to rate it as running extremely well in my case. However there is something unique to my use case, which might indicate the problem. I am running the game on a 1680x1050 monitor (bet most of you don't have one of these 16:10 puppies), so the problem might include rendering 1080p or even 16:9 image or upsacling to certain resolutions, but who knows, not exactly my field. My default options were also kinda wierd, since it wasn't any of the presets, but it runs well I guess, albeit the X4 AA seems to do almost nothing (don't really care about the graphics too much anyway, but worth considering I guess), so maybe playing around with the options could help. Also there is a minor problem, which is that on 16:10 monitors the fullscreen option completely breaks. When fullscreen, the image will be rendered as if it was on a 16:9 display, which would be quite normal, but it renders at full height (without bars), meaning that some of the left screen space is literally not shown. Hence I am playing in windowed mode, which does work perfectly fine (but is not borderless, which screws with immersion a little bit). My rig (which is quite crapos in terms of it's CPU and mobo):ASUS STRIX 1060 GTX (6GB)AMD ATHLON II X4 651K (3Ghz Quad that is really old)8GB RAMMSI A75MA-P35 mobo (Again, really old)Windows 8.1 (Don't enjoy spyware)XBOX Controller (Not really the rig, but pertinent information)The game itself is extremely fun, though I am just starting out. It hasn't crashed at all, but there is no saving initially (haven't gotten so far) and I am playing it on Hard, which does kill you with 2 bullets or attacks with the exception of the Boss Bot, which can off you with one swing. The biggest tips I can give you is that when perspectives/control modes shift in flight mode, you can and must still shoot not to be flooded by bullets and the moment you land, the start button opens your menu which contains a ton of healing items, but I never saw the game tell me that. Here I go to replay that mission for whateverth time.Hope this info together with other reports helps clear up what's going wrong for other players and make your purchase decision. I guess if you have pretty much the same rig as me, it should be fine. Sorry for the grammar mistakes, I did type this out quickly since I want to keep playing. This had better have a good Yoko Taro story. >.<EDIT: Using Borderless Gaming as suggested by Gazda did fix the fullscreen issue, as long as I remember to get the mouse out of the way this is pretty much perfect. Also on perspective changes it can dip to 50s and even slightly sub that for a bit, not that I would notice without my FPS counter.

												I had to refund this. I cannot in good conscience recommend this in the state it is in right now. The game itself is amazing. An hour in and I'm already invested in the characters. However, this port is absolutely unacceptable. I wanted so badly to support Yoko Taro's game on PC, but not like this. *Ridiculous draw distance and unslightly pop-in everywhere (as others mentioned, entire buildings pop-in...)*Crashes are sporadic, though not -too- often for me personally(others can't even get past the start screen).*Fullscreen has a lot of issues, and seems to run at lower resolution than listed. 1080p isn't 1080p, etc.*No 4k support. Seriously, in 2017?*Antialiasing settings don't really have much effect visually.*Screenshots do not look like in-game on max settings.*Saving settings in the title screen has been glitchy for me, and will sometimes freeze the game.*Denuvo... although we all knew this going in.I could go on, but others have done a better job explaining than I have. I'm running the game on a GTX 1080, with an i7 3770k running at 5Ghz. I get better performance running The Witcher 3 or  Dues Ex: Mankind Divided in 4k than I do on this ps4 port.As it is now, I've refunded this game, and will consider repurchasing/recommending it when (if?) they polish these glaring issues. The port is the only thing holding back this gem of a game. This is not how you do a port. Not for $59. Very disappointing.

												Each generation got their defining games.Ocarina of Time, Half-life, etc... they all marked a milestone in some ways.Nier : Automata is one of those games.It pushes the boundaries of video games in a manner we weren't imagining before.From the first to the last minute of this experience, the game will grab you and never let you go.You'll be sent into a rollercoaster of emotions, from the epicness of the action scenes to the sadness of some story scenes.It involves the player with real inventivity, using all means to make the player feel like a part of the game.And as always with this game franchise, it's technically beautiful, with on-point and gorgeous soundtracks.This is one of the most serious contender for GOTY at this moment and we can only hope that this game will receive its due reward.

												How can I describe this game...Absolutly one of the best games so far in the year, maybe in the last generation. Goty 2017 potential to be honest.Let me start saying that this game starts slow, the first hour or 2 to me were just a pain in the ♥♥♥ honestly. I dropped the game and start playing something else (thought on refunding), but then i start seeing all the hype on youtube and friends praying its story/gameplay/mechanics/rpg elements so I grew some balls and start playing it again. OHHHH boy! how wrong i was. Everything started to get intense, enemies getting stronger, the Story got so good that I slept only 4 hours for 2 days just to play this, couldn't think about anything else. After beating the story I went to rest, but now I do feel to do all the sidequest I left behind because all the lore that I feel I NEED to know since I didn't play the Yoko Taro's previous games besides this one. Recollect every Archive/Weapon just to know everything that this game has to offer.The only thing i need to say is that backgrounds were indeed beautiful, but i feel some things/details were lacking; buildings were kinda plain to me, shadows not so good for the current game generation, grass felt a little bit weird to me. But believe me, it won't damage your gameplay experience, just details that bothered, at least a little bit, to me.Pros:-Amazing OST, one of the best so far in videogames.-A really ♥♥♥♥ed up but amazing story with a HUGE character development.-A well driven futuristic-RPG mechanics.-Hack'n'Slash combat system-Balanced enemies and difficulty, it can be pretty easy for those who doesn't want a challenging game, or it could be worse than DS saga in Hard-Extreme Difficuly.-Open World (not so big nor small, just perfect for the game)-Good character design.-A2 and B2's A♥♥.Cons:-Visually it's indeed very beautiful, but kinda one of its weak points for me at least (not on pair with recent games).-Cinematics locked to 30 fps-Not the best PC port but it's playable.PD: Please, you can Indeed play this game with Keyboard and mouse as I did, but if you have a controller, please play with it.a 9.5/10 game

												UPDATE - I'm still leaving this to not recommended for the time being until it is patched, but there is a work around for the blank screen on AMD RX 400 series cards. First, do a clean install with Display Driver Uninstaller. Make sure to do it through safe mode, and you might want to create a backup / system restore just in case. Link here. https://www.guru3d.com/files-get/display-driver-uninstaller-download,1.htmlNext, install driver 16.11.15 - http://support.amd.com/en-us/download/desktop/previous/detail?os=Windows%2010%20-%2064&rev=16.11.5#You should be good to go then. there is some noticeable stuttering here and there with this temporary fix, but it's certainly better than not being able to play the game at all. ORIGINAL REVIEW BEFORE WORK AROUND - Needs to be patched. There is definitely an issue with getting a freeze into a blank/white screen (one time it was blue for me even) for different users with different hardware. Many, including myself, can barely get pass the first boss, and for some it happens straight from launch. It seems to be fairly across the board for AMD users currently, despite Square Enix claiming its driver 17.2.1, and there are reports of it happening from Nvidia users. I have an RX 480 8gb personally, and have tried different drivers and messing around the settings and it still happened despite my efforts. It is unplayable due to this issue.There is also the issue of fullscreen not properly displaying, instead displaying a much lower resolution. For me I use 1920x1080, and it seems to be displaying in 1600x900 or so leading to desaturation and stretched images  or black bars. It can be worked around with the Borderless Gaming program, but Borderless Gaming does put in some input lag which is not ideal for a game such as Nier: Automata. This needs to be fixed as well.

												This is a great game that you should play if you have the time. Why? That has been covered by other reviews so I am going to focus on people who are worried that this is a sequel and they are going to miss out.Yes this is technically the 4th game in the Drakengard Series (Drakengard 3 -> Drakengard 1 -> Nier Gestalt/Replicant -> Nier Automata) but it plays a significant time after Nier Gestalt/Replicant thus you will not miss out on anything significant. The Main Story(s) of this game is fully enjoyable without any prior knowledge but there will be anecdotes and small mentions of previous games, mainly Nier Gestalt/Replicant. So if you dont want to miss out on those little things play the games or watch a summary on youtube, but it definitely isnt necessary. Altough I definitely would recommend at least watching a summary of Nier Gestalt/Replicant and watching the cutscenes, it will enhance your enjoyment of the game.Now go and enjoy this amazing game.

												Yoko Taro's approach to storytelling is like increasing the temperature of a hot tub by 1 degree at a time. You won't notice the difference until you look down after 30 hours and realize you're in a pool of lava. Only then will you realize you actually prefer lava.Each Drakengard game starts with a simple and relatable premise: Man and dragon fight evil empire. Father wants to find a cure for his sick daughter. And NieR: Automata, at its surface level, is about androids battling machine-servants of aliens while humanity takes refuge on the moon. If it sounds like your typical JRPG sci-fi story, congratulations: You've fallen into Taro's trap. To call the events of the game a mindf**k is both accurate and a disservice. It implies a lack of meaning or direction, when in reality you're given everything you need in order to understand the story; it just might not come in the order you like. Not only is the main story an enigma that leaves you hungry for more details, but even the sidequests add important context to the events of the story, as well as having some seriously strong foreshadowing that you'll likely miss until you're thinking in retrospect. And that's the real beauty of a Taro story: it keeps you occupied for weeks after you finish the game as you slowly stumble upon epiphanies, information the game gave you clear as day but that your brain failed to piece together until it was too late. After several of these moments you'll come to not only love the game, but respect the writers as intellectual superiors that played you like a damn fiddle while, somehow, respecting your intelligence at the same time. If you've played a JRPG in the past, you know that there is often a trifecta of qualities and you have to pick two and only two: graphics, gameplay, and story. If a game has great graphics and gameplay, it usually has a bad story (Bayonetta, DMC, etc.). If it has a fantastic story, it usually either has bad gameplay or bad graphics (Xenoblade). The pattern so far for Drakengard has been good story, decent gameplay, and bad graphics. However, they've teamed up with Platinum Games this time, who's known for great gameplay, good graphics, and bad story. Combined, they've managed to cover each other's flaws beautifully. This game is a treat to look at, the gameplay is fun as hell, and the story is some of Taro's best work yet.I can't remember the last time I had so few complaints about a game, and I'm an incredibly harsh critic of games (especially ones that I love). Throughout NieR: Automata, I kept thinking "what's the catch?" There has to be a really terrible part coming up soon, right? No game goes this long without any glaring issues. That point never came, though.If you've never played Drakengard, you'll probably still have a great time with this game. If you've played most of the series up to this point, it's a masterpiece.

content:

												NieR: Automata is one of the few games that I have played that offer one of the best soundtracks. Be mindful that the director is Yoko Taro, so this game may not be for the faint of heart. It's storyline is pretty good as it references back to NieR and even parts of Drakengard. There are a total of 26 different endings, but only 5 of them are important. The game is very good, however I feel as if it could be better. The rest of the endings acts as a comic relief. With all that being said, here are my pros and cons of this game.Pros: - Soundtrack - Supports xinput (xbox controller) - Debug mode (unlocked after beating the game) - Good learning curve - Physics for hair and outfits are pretty good for most times, but it can be approved. - A lot of the side-quests are actually interesting - Requires some skills to play (similar to Devil May Cry series) - Combat is pretty addicitive - Plenty of comic reliefs in this game, which is great so you won't have to feel so depressed - Awesome animations - Sexy asf androids - Ok balance in difficulties, but it could be better. - Adjustable difficulty - Hacking mini-game is pretty fun and simple (only on 9S) - The alternation between hack-and-slash and bullet-shooter is awesome - Weapon stories are really fun and entertaining to read (makes upgrading each and every one of them worth it) - English voice acting is pretty good for something made in Japan.Cons: - Scaling issues (gets annoying after a while of seeing your screen blink so many times on startup) - Requires a decent computer. (In my case, this wasn't a problem, but I know not everyone has a high range computer) - Frames may slow down during scenes - Post-game is way too easy (enemy levels do not scale with player level, but rather with how far you're into the story. For example, once you beat the game and go back to an early part of the game such as chapter 2, your character may be level 70 and the robots will be like level 5) - Pod materials are way too hard to find. (Couldn't upgrade my pods until second playthrough) - Fishing is awesome, but trying to 100% the fishing encyclopedia is a pain. - As mentioned above, difficulty balance could be better. Balance is only good up until mid-late game (Around level 50). After that, everything becomes way too easy to kill. - As mentioned, physics for hair and outfit are pretty good, but if you were to observe closely at times, it looks like the hair/outfit twitches. - Animal bait is pretty much useless after you get a specific item - Pod C is only useful in Hard or Very Hard mode because of it's capabilities to lock on to targets. Other than that, you're better off using Pod A or Pod B. - The 3D map can be a bit hard to read sometimes, but the game will literally tell you to just suck it up and get use to it (gotta love Yoko Taro lol) - Lock on camera can get somewhat buggy if you're fighting in a cluster of enemies (only in normal and below difficulties).If you want to truly appreciate this game and get the most out of it, my tip would be to do all the side-quests and unlock all the archives. The side-quests in this game are probably one of the best. They aren't your average "collect X amount of this and receive X EXP and X potions". A lot of them have very interesting stories to them that deal with machines/androids. You may find them sad, tragic, funny, or cool. Although you don't have to play NieR or Drakengard 1/2/3 to understand NieR Automata, it would be just a bit better know some lore, as the archives and weapon stories reference back to NieR and Drakengard.

content:

												Okay, game. You got me.That was a surprisingly cool ending considering you spent about an entire ~40 hour playthrough raising my expectations of how cool and surprising the next chapter would be over and over. Now, to try and review this game as part of its series would probably out of my ability since I never played any of the other prequel games in this franchise which, from what I understand, spans half a dozen titles of the same quality and lenght as the latest Nier: Automata, In fact, the more time I spent on the game wiki reading about the backstory, the more I was convinced I needed to stop before I would innevitably end up comming back to my senses at 4am on a work week, exhausted, emotional and with more questions about the story than ever before.That said, as a stand-alone experience, Nier: Automata was enjoyable AF. The gameplay is very fast paced and the controls are precise and responsive. The levels and boss fights are varied, inventive and the good kind of challenging. The beautiful dynamic soundtrack is top notch. The graphics are very serviceable for a console port but the art and animations frankly embarass the crap out of some of its contemporary 2017 AAA titles I won't name. And finally, the story, while convoluted, confusing and very japanese (and I mean that in a grudgingly fond way), is still enjoyable and manages to build some great emotional attachment to the cast of characters by the end. Just don't expect Pixar so turn your brain off a little for maximum effect.The fighting could seem repetitive at first if you didn't try different weapons and combos that have different bonus effects and animation moves. The chip system would also have you farm the crap out of some areas hoping to get those elusive diamond grade chips to fuse into the ultimate final form. The game also has very respectable replay value thanks to interesting side chainquests that aren't just your run of the mill fetch-me-12-boar-tusks or climb a tower to unlock the map but rather meander into more interesting stories and take you to gorgeous hidden spots with their own unique challenges that I'd never have found on my own.There's something to be said about games that rely on replaying the same level more than once to get the full story but honestly, this game never felt lazy for a second, which is something that's very difficult to achieve in open world games because after the gaming industry has evolved to where it stands today, we've come to have very high expectations and it doesn't take that much to break our enjoyment anymore. Yet, in Nier: Automata, everywhere I looked, everytime I prod in an unintended direction, every tire I kicked, I could see the evidence of the passionate artists who licked every surface and facet with madenning attention to detail.Lastly, there're a few technical issues with full screen performance and the hacking minigame controls using kb/m right now but I expect those to ironed out and there are already community fixes available. Generally, the game run perfectly on my aging 780ti.Rock solid 8/10.

												I originally reviewed this game after beating the first playthrough. I've now completed all the main endings so I feel I can give a more accurate review.NieR: Automata is the story of androids 2B, A2 and 9S as they struggle to understand what's going on in a world infested with machine lifeforms. Platinum Games had a heavy involvement and as you'd expect, the combat system is extremely well thought out and fluid. While occasionally the camera can be a bit problematic, generally the game plays very well as it switches between action RPG hack-and-slash and various shooter/bullet hell genres.The initial play through (Route A) takes around 10 hours if you ignore some of the sidequests. After its completion, the game will tell you that the game is expected to be played a few times through for different endings. I would strongly suggest playing through Endings A to E; the remaining ones are largely joke ones.The music by MONACA and Keiichi Okabe is amazing throughout and perfectly captures the atmosphere of vain hope and sadness that resonates throughout the main story.The real strong point of the game is the story and the emotional attachments you forge with the characters, which makes the different story routes all the more impactful. Without spoiling anything, you want to be aware that this is a pretty hard-hitting game and it's almost as if Yoko Taro delights in making the player suffer.To anyone considering the game, please at least play Routes A, B and then C/D/E (the latter three don't take long). Only then will you fully understand what's going on in the world. By just completing A and B (like many magazine/websites have), you barely get to know anything.The PC port has some issues (1080p actually just upscales 900p so it looks blurry unless you use a Borderless Window program) and it can sometime drop frames / stutter / freeze briefly even on good machines. Once these are sorted out, it'll leave a game that I consider to be a real contender for one of the greatest games ever.Genuinely, I haven't played a game this good in years and thoroughly recommend it...if you're prepared for being hit right in the feels, over and over again.Amazing game.

												In a few words, this game is amazing.Fun Hack n' Slash gameplay with tight controls, very difficult and unforgiving game, mainly so in the prologue, I don't recommend starting it on hard, it's a game that, unless you're used to the genre you should start in Normal or easier, if you're absolutely incompetent, don't worry, the game can be very accessive by enabling chips that basically play the game for you.The story, though, now that's the thing, this game has 5 true endings, unlike other games you don't start the game all the way over to get the different endings, each and every play through is truly different from the previous one, either by introducing a different playable character or more story elements, so if you're afraid of getting burned out by starting a new game+, don't be, try it out first, it's a whole new thing.This game can be very depressing, be it via the main story or it's side quests. Sometimes it will throw you something that gives you hope, but most of the time, it will try to crush you, make you question your existence and objectives and I love it. This game said something that I've always thought about, it connected to me in a very deep level, so I hanged on, 'till the very last true ending, ending E......that ending really gives you hope to keep on, no matter how hard it gets.Oh, and to the person who I gave up all my time and effort to help! Life can be quite the ♥♥♥♥♥, it might be meaningless and you will suffer a lot, but so what? Memory wasn't made for us to remember or good times, it's there so we don't repeat our mistakes. Suffering and hardship makes us stronger, if we can get past it! Time is only wasted if you think it is, when you do the things you love, that isn't wasted time, nah, that's called 'time well spent'.So struggle, scream, cry and fight, even if it's all really meaningless and futile, because isn't it fun, to hang on to this tiny hope, to deny when life it says to give up, to fight the impossible? I know I love it and I wouldn't have it any other way, so hang on, I'm here with you, even if you think you're alone.

												This game is a masterpiece in every way possible.The story is fascinating from the very first moment, and it has solid hack and slash gameplay with a lot of abilities and tricks to it as you would expect from a game like this.Though what really keeps you in your chair for hours straight are the characters, their development and relations.All of them are well written and have a really unique personality. You just want to stick with them till the end and see what their fate will bring.The way the story is presented is also really unique. The route system let's you think you beat the game, yet you have beat only the first route and with every route new mechanics are introduced and the gameworld changes in certain ways.This way the game kept me amazed and surprised even after i've beat the first two routes.Whilst i was half way through the game someone asked me wheter or not this game was worth the buy and i said that it was probably my favorite gaming experience 2016/17, now that i have basically finished the main story i can confidently say that it is probably my favorite gaming experience of all time, that NieR:Automata will always have a special place in my heart and that it deserves the GOTY award.Also this is the first time that i picked up a game OST for 16€, and found myself watching the entire credits just to listen to a song in fact i might even buy the disc version of the OST once it is released.

												This game is Amazing! I'm releaved that it became as good as I hoped it to be. I loved NieR: Replicant/Gestalt and Automata comes around the corner and manages to become even better. The gameplay is solid. The graphics look good most of the times. And the OST, OH GOD THE OST! It's so effing good! If you loved the OST of the first game then you most likely will adore this one! There are only 2 things that are "bad" about this game. Some players can't even play it (Thank god this didn't happen to me) and the other is that it really is missing a native borderless window, because in fullscreen it lookes weirdly streched.But all together I would give this game a 9.5/10. This games isn't just one of my recent favourites, but it has become one of my all time favourite games. Giving a crazy japanese guy the resources for this was a great decision!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
1
												I saw this game described as a masterpiece and have to agree with that idea because the amount of effort put into all aspects of its design is clear when playing. It's refreshing to see a game have a world that's so thought out that the many optional quests actually add a lot to the story/message (developing characters, organizations, etc). I particularly liked seeing various machines pick up individual components of humanity in isolation and seeing what problems being emotionally incomplete/imbalanced caused, especially when the emotions were relatable.Without going into more detail, I'll say that I appreciate the designers' playfulness and creativity (even with minor things like adjusting game settings). It feels like they go the extra mile and end up making experiences that dramatically stand out from how other games are.But for me, someone whose favorite genre of music is videogame music, that's where this game shines most. I loved the original NieR soundtrack and had been excited about this game's soundtrack for months. It ended up shattering my expectations and impressed me immensely. The tracks for the main areas in the game have at least four versions, so the music stays fresh and extra interesting. Sometimes vocals will be highlighted/emphasized and other times there will be more instruments or a faster pace. I'm excited that I'll have both relaxation and energy music for so many songs. And more than I get from other game soundtracks, many of the songs in this have moments that stand out as amazing with tracks that build to them wonderfully. If you're on the fence about buying this game, consider checking out the soundtrack as part of your decision. It keeps playing in my head, and that's wonderful.I ended up having to upgrade my graphics card (formerly a GTX 650) to play this game, but the environment was stunning with a GTX 1060. Lighting, particles in the environment, and the incredible level of detail in textures made me feel like I was in the real world. I ended up dedicating four consecutive days to playing this game and my immersion made it feel like I left the real world for that time. And with adjustable difficulty and a system that lets you go back and do/get things that you missed, I'll play it more in the future.After so long, I didn't expect NieR to get a sequel, but I get the feeling that the designers had been flushing their ideas out for much of the wait. There are callbacks to the original game that made me wish that I had replayed it shortly before playing this one so that I could understand the callbacks completely, but this game is complete independent of it, and knowledge of the first game isn't necessary for a great experience.I hope your experience of this game brings you as much joy as it brought me :)

												I had problems with fps at start, and I disliked the "start at the very beginning if you fail tutorial" weirdness.But...Nier:Automata turned out to be one of the most wholesome games ever.Gameplay is amazing, stories are both funny and heart wrenching and designs are beautiful.Those who are tired of meta narratives, beware, this is one of them.Do you really need to attack everything that attacks you? Is sating your curiosity always worth it?Are the rules given to you for purpose or not? What do you do with absolute choices that are all equally bad?Nier tries to make you tackle these questions yourself, sometimes forcefully, sometimes by only giving hints to them being there.Also the thing that made Dark Souls and Undertale stories stick on people is rising again.The mechanics are part of narrative. People, please try to make more games like that, it is what makes games a great storytelling media when used right!But I'll just say, play Nier:Automata, you can play this game even with lower end graphics cards if you fiddle with their settings enough.And Yoko Taro, you drunken ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, I LOVE YOU, please be yourself until the very end.

content:

												Came into this game with extremely high expectations set by the first NieR and the Drakengard series (particularly DoD3, the latest release.) Was not disappointed and, arguably, found a better experience than the first NieR. Seven hours into a semi-open world RPG is not enough to accurately say whether it will or will not try to pull the multi-genre stunts that NieR did, but so far it has done a fantastic job of focusing the gameplay.The soundtrack is absolutely fantastic, as we have come to expect from this game. The game does a good enough job at level design to hide an actually fairly short render distance, though I have sometimes experienced the smallest of texture popping. Nothing unreasonable. Playing on a controller, the controls are responsive and fluid; I've not seen any dropped inputs nor laggy ones (effectively meaning I only have myself to blame for bad timing for any mistakes.) The voice acting isn't award winning by any means, but works for the tone of the game and VAs seem to have appropriately nailed when hamming it up is necessary VS when actual serious dialogue is being spoken. Machines, however, may prove to be grating on your ears.Combat has a low skill floor with a high skill ceiling, allowing casual players to enjoy the combat while also allowing the more extreme veterans to really go to town with combination attacks, dodges and Pod use. You have the ability to take on enemies twice your own level, albeit through a bit of a slog, as long as you're proficient in dodging and weaving in and out of enemies. Movement controls are tight and I'm pleased to report that jumping doesn't seem "floaty" which was something I thought the game might suffer from based on trailers alone. Flying sections so far never overstay their welcome, though I would class as less enjoyable than the rest of the game overall. The map is frankly confusing - to the point they even have an in-story claim that the map has received complaints. Humorous to see, and yet not something I'm willing to forgive it for, either. Not unreadable, but a headache. Similarly, fullscreen resolution for 1920x1200 is broken, presently meaning you may have to play in windowed mode. The game also suffers a common problem of low framerates in pre-rendered cutscenes and while it doesn't drop frames during actual gameplay, it noticably stutters when having to load in areas, and I'm on a top end i7 6400 and Nvidia GTX 1070 Founder's Edition so I'm having neither CPU or GFX card issues. The stutters aren't impactful however, and considering the game drops literally no frames anywhere else and runs a smooth 60, I'm overall a happy campter. (Please also note: 60FPS cap on the game.)Won't comment pre-emptively on story simply because I am not that far into it, but based on all past experiences with this franchise, I'm in for one hell of a weird ride and I couldn't be more excited for it.

Don't do this to me anymore...My heart will break completely"These are the sentences I would use after spending 36+ hours on this game, that became one of my favorites because of it's great story, beautiful environment, badass main characters that are not only "walking amazing butts" (Lookin at you 2B and A2), but also during the game are well developed to the point that you start caring more and more about them.Route A might seem a bit boring with the side quests, but once you finish it, the game offers even more gameplay mechanics and you realize why those side quests were there.I personally didn't have any technical issues (besides fullscreen bug) and was able to enjoy it at stable 60 fps, which helped admire beautiful combat effects. 												This game is wierd, and I don't mean because of the story or because its Japanese.So I am a big Platinum fan and enjoyed most of their work even from back before they became independant from Capcom. As for Nier and Drakengard, well my knowledge of those games basically comes from watching Clemps' summary, btw hes youtube channel is great, check it out if you need some background on the world of this game.I came into this for the Platinum gameplay experience and on that front I was dissapointed. Even if mostly non-sensical it will strike a cord with most gamers on an emotional level. I can now see why Yoko Taro's games have such a cult following.This leaves me very conflicted because I played this game for one thing and ended up enjoying it for another.Do you like sories that resonate on an emotional level (maybe not so much on a logical level)?Are you a fan of Yoko Taro's previous work?You should deffinately play it!If you are looking for 'dat Platinum feel'? Maybe try it out but this game is not quite that.

												2 weeks after its release, the game is still unplayable for GTX 700 series owners (and possibly RX 480 and noticed some GTX Titan complains here and there), it's still brimming with technical issues and poor optimization across platforms (poorly optimized for consoles which carried over and brought even more problems for the PC version).It's an action game and, given that the game's engine is bound to the framerates you can get, attaining 50+ or solid 60 is mandatory for the enjoyment of the game. And that makes the poor optimization that results to framedrops (no matter its source) worse than it is in any other game.2 weeks later, no patch yet to be seen. Imagine paying for a game you found you cannot complete due to crashing, and have to wait for "some day" to be resolved. Imagine that you waited for that game for months, if not years if you were a fan of the Nier/Drakengard games.I cannot upvote this game on the grounds of "it plays on other people's machines". If you cannot approproately support the hardware diversity of the PC. I cannot believe this it the kind of treatment PC consumers receive from Platinum, after the work they did with Metal Gear Rising:Revengeance. Now I know which company's game I won't preorder again.

												I saw this game described as a masterpiece and have to agree with that idea because the amount of effort put into all aspects of its design is clear when playing. It's refreshing to see a game have a world that's so thought out that the many optional quests actually add a lot to the story/message (developing characters, organizations, etc). I particularly liked seeing various machines pick up individual components of humanity in isolation and seeing what problems being emotionally incomplete/imbalanced caused, especially when the emotions were relatable.Without going into more detail, I'll say that I appreciate the designers' playfulness and creativity (even with minor things like adjusting game settings). It feels like they go the extra mile and end up making experiences that dramatically stand out from how other games are.But for me, someone whose favorite genre of music is videogame music, that's where this game shines most. I loved the original NieR soundtrack and had been excited about this game's soundtrack for months. It ended up shattering my expectations and impressed me immensely. The tracks for the main areas in the game have at least four versions, so the music stays fresh and extra interesting. Sometimes vocals will be highlighted/emphasized and other times there will be more instruments or a faster pace. I'm excited that I'll have both relaxation and energy music for so many songs. And more than I get from other game soundtracks, many of the songs in this have moments that stand out as amazing with tracks that build to them wonderfully. If you're on the fence about buying this game, consider checking out the soundtrack as part of your decision. It keeps playing in my head, and that's wonderful.I ended up having to upgrade my graphics card (formerly a GTX 650) to play this game, but the environment was stunning with a GTX 1060. Lighting, particles in the environment, and the incredible level of detail in textures made me feel like I was in the real world. I ended up dedicating four consecutive days to playing this game and my immersion made it feel like I left the real world for that time. And with adjustable difficulty and a system that lets you go back and do/get things that you missed, I'll play it more in the future.After so long, I didn't expect NieR to get a sequel, but I get the feeling that the designers had been flushing their ideas out for much of the wait. There are callbacks to the original game that made me wish that I had replayed it shortly before playing this one so that I could understand the callbacks completely, but this game is complete independent of it, and knowledge of the first game isn't necessary for a great experience.I hope your experience of this game brings you as much joy as it brought me :)

												Okay, game. You got me.That was a surprisingly cool ending considering you spent about an entire ~40 hour playthrough raising my expectations of how cool and surprising the next chapter would be over and over. Now, to try and review this game as part of its series would probably out of my ability since I never played any of the other prequel games in this franchise which, from what I understand, spans half a dozen titles of the same quality and lenght as the latest Nier: Automata, In fact, the more time I spent on the game wiki reading about the backstory, the more I was convinced I needed to stop before I would innevitably end up comming back to my senses at 4am on a work week, exhausted, emotional and with more questions about the story than ever before.That said, as a stand-alone experience, Nier: Automata was enjoyable AF. The gameplay is very fast paced and the controls are precise and responsive. The levels and boss fights are varied, inventive and the good kind of challenging. The beautiful dynamic soundtrack is top notch. The graphics are very serviceable for a console port but the art and animations frankly embarass the crap out of some of its contemporary 2017 AAA titles I won't name. And finally, the story, while convoluted, confusing and very japanese (and I mean that in a grudgingly fond way), is still enjoyable and manages to build some great emotional attachment to the cast of characters by the end. Just don't expect Pixar so turn your brain off a little for maximum effect.The fighting could seem repetitive at first if you didn't try different weapons and combos that have different bonus effects and animation moves. The chip system would also have you farm the crap out of some areas hoping to get those elusive diamond grade chips to fuse into the ultimate final form. The game also has very respectable replay value thanks to interesting side chainquests that aren't just your run of the mill fetch-me-12-boar-tusks or climb a tower to unlock the map but rather meander into more interesting stories and take you to gorgeous hidden spots with their own unique challenges that I'd never have found on my own.There's something to be said about games that rely on replaying the same level more than once to get the full story but honestly, this game never felt lazy for a second, which is something that's very difficult to achieve in open world games because after the gaming industry has evolved to where it stands today, we've come to have very high expectations and it doesn't take that much to break our enjoyment anymore. Yet, in Nier: Automata, everywhere I looked, everytime I prod in an unintended direction, every tire I kicked, I could see the evidence of the passionate artists who licked every surface and facet with madenning attention to detail.Lastly, there're a few technical issues with full screen performance and the hacking minigame controls using kb/m right now but I expect those to ironed out and there are already community fixes available. Generally, the game run perfectly on my aging 780ti.Rock solid 8/10.

												I recently discovered the 'NieR' series on a hunt for music/OSTs that were akin to 'Shadow of the Colussus'. A lone comment in a reddit thread lead me to the first 'NieR' album and was pleasantly surprised to learn that NieR: Automata had literally just launched. Compelled by the music of that first album, I decided to purchase the game and give it a whirl.Initially I was concerned that I would need to play 'Drakengard' or the original 'NieR' in order to fully appreciate the game, as I had not. The game stands alone perfectly, like a different house in the same neighborhood (thousands of years in the future).I won't spoil the plot for you (So I won't remark on characters, etc.), but please note that game's story plays out a bit different than most. Instead of a -very- long story, it's a tad bit shorter if you think of it in a linear fashion. However, the story is structured in such a way that you revisit the same story from a completely different angle in a truly varied way, and it feels quite different (thus far). It's NOT the typical: change Yes to No and Ending A becomes Ending B. It's nothing like that, you'll definitely want to keep playing.Good: Combat is fun, the customization is an interesting spin, the music is SUPERB. Controller combat wasn't bad, I thought I was going to hate it, but it works well. Try all the weapons, try all the abilities. This game isn't about min/max. The scenery is bleak feeling, but gorgeous.Bad: Fullscreen looks atrocious, but the windowed setting looks great. There isn't an auto-save, so be warned! I was hoping for a little more varied enemies, but it's not too bad.Things I wish I knew first: Use your POD target/lock on to allow for certain combos. All weapons are fun in their own way, it's worth trying them all and upgrading them all as you can. Don't worry about 'maxing' them on the first play through.Last thoughts: For purchasing on a whim, based on the music, I'm more than pleasantly surprised how fun it is. This game is fantastic. 9/10

												TL;DR Worth every 0.00001 of a penny (penny value may varies base on your region)STORY: Yoko Taro story is legendary as usual, dark theme with humour mixed in that you just can't find anywhere else. He'll randomly try to cheer you up as you progress along and holy hell do you need one sometimes. Think of it like you suffering through college and your uncle popping in once a while and give you a fluffy cat toy even though you don't have a cat.MUSIC&SOUND: music fit every part of the story and story fit every part of the music. Can't ask for anything more except for....well........more. GAMEPLAY: play it on Hard cuz you won't regret suffering through every bit of it. Not on "very hard" though, that's just sadisticGRAPHIC&DESIGN: Do you like explosion that was placed in for explosion sake? You'll get none of that here. Everything has it's place and purpose. Fanservice is also baked right into the character so there won't be a filler/fanservice episode/part of the story. Probably the only game that make me return to singleplayer after 10 years of pure multiplayer. It's just amazing of how much work goes into this.

content:

												Now that I have finished Ending A (the main ending) as well as part of B, I feel I am ready to review this game.I'm going to break up this review into 5 sectionsPlotCharactersControlsGameplayOptimizationPLOT-While some have labeled the plot as cliché (and I can see why), This is the first game in a while that had a story that I actually found myself wanting to continue and push further. It's a very odd tale that, while not as deep, reminds me of MGS. Plot 8/10CHARACTERS-The character design was... interesting. While everyone was gawking at 2B's butt, I was confused as to why they were blindfolded as they can see/operate fine without it. If video game characters are your cup of tea for 'certain viewing times' this game will please you. if not its kind of meh. The dialogue was pretty good, I heard both English and Japanese voice actors, and both settings were good (Japanese was better IMO for obvious reasons). I never thought that the characters were too talkaive, and they never seemed to get on my nerves. Characters 7/10CONTROLS-If you have a controller, use it. While the KB&M controls are not bad per se, they definitely could have been better. While the options do not apear to accept mouse controls for attacks, THEY ARE ALREADY MAPPED. It is very odd and never is noted that you can use your mouse, but that is much better than the alternative(Shift and /). Dodging got repetitve and isn't fun to perform (double tap a movement key). However I saw a mod that fixes this, I may pick it up. CONTROLS 6/10GAMEPLAY-Dear god is this game just an absolute blast to play. The combat is fluid and fun. the animations are incredible. There's tons of stuff to keep you occupied (Reportedly up to 45 hours). The Boss fights are a ton of fun, not being to easy, but not too difficult either. Exploring, Item hunting, side questing, and ...fishing, It's all a ton of fun. GAMEPLAY 10/10OPTIMIZATION-If you haven't heard, the port of this game is nothing to write home about. with an odd 1600x900 res lock, 60 fps lock/30 fps cutscene lock. Multiple people reported a whitescreen game crash after about 10 minutes(I was one of them) but rest assured, there are fixes to almost all of the problems. The Devs are also woking to fix the port up, but there is community mods to make this game more pc friendly. OPTIMIZATION 5/10TL;DR-This game is going to become a classic. This is easily my GOTY so far. Pick this gem up as soon as you can. If you manage to grab this on sale, you might as well be commiting theft. This game will stick with me for a long time, and I will be watching for Platinum's works from now on.OVERALL-9/10 GREAT

												I absolutely love this game. I have only completed the first playthrough so far, but I'm very excited for the rest.The story is interesting and weird (which, for any fan of the original Nier, was to be expected). I love the way the story is told through multiple playthroughs.The gameplay is fantastic. You have a light and heavy attack slot that you can put different weapons in. Which slot you put a weapon in determines the attacks (so the same weapon in different slots will function differently) so you can customize your attacks heavily based on which 2 weapons you are using.The only negative (other than the compatibility issues, see below) is the fact that most of the missions are pretty simple "follow the marker" stuff, but the story and the combat are more than enough to keep things interesting.It's so rare for me to be interested enough to stick with a single player RPG these days, but this is one I can't get enough of. Play it!Note: There are a few technical issues. The major issue that I ran into was fullscreen not running at the proper resolution. There are fixes for many of the issues available already (found in the steam forums).

												Calling this a "game" is insulting honestly. My time with Nier Automata is best described as: "A beautifully crafted experience."+An amazing story that ranges from heart-full, to heart-break+A soundtrack that is soothing and peaceful, or energetic and adrenaline-pumping+The controls feel fluid and fun, especially with all the changing perspectives and different styles of combat +Each time you beat the game, it introduces more curiosity and encourages another run through with the biggest twist of all being at the true ending +You get to have Moose friends and are able to ride them anywhere as your trusty steed(s)- You may have to tinker around with graphics and resolution settings a little - For some odd reason or another, you can kill your Moose friendsStop making me cry already/10    PS: Where was my free T-shirt when I pre-ordered? "S**t Square Enix!"
