												A great game hindered by the annoying no safe beginning area and for some pc port issues. Those 2 negatives get far outshined by the greatness of the rest tho! After getting used to the combat (By you guessed it, repeating the no save area) the game becomes incredibly fluid and fun. Dodging around doing combo's, parrying attacks and shooting powerfull lasers it all feels absolutly great. Now i have to say as well the game contains several gameplay modes like normal action mode, twin stick mode, 2d platformer mode and likely many more however i feel like some of them do not work well in the game but nevertheless these are mostly short sections so i can live with them.Audio and visually the game also does a decent job although some of the enviroments are visually lackluster but the soundtracks in every map definetly make up for any issues in that regard. About the story i can't say much yet since i havent finished it at this point. But overall i feel like this game is easily worth a buy.EDIT:Finished the story and i have to say this game really starts to shine when its all coming together at 2/3 of the game. If it wasn't for the enviroments and some repetitive aspects of the game then this game would have truly been a masterpiece.

content:

												I’d like to start my review with a little story from my short playing session today:***When I play games on my PC I have two options:1) I play them on a 24“ monitor + a rather good speaker system2) I play them on my 40“ TV + a really good surround systemToday I went into a new area in the game while playing on my computer monitor, because I didn‘t want to switch on all that other equipment for a playing session that would only be rather short. End of story: I felt genuine regret! Not that it was a bad experience. Oh no, far from it! It was awe-inspiring. It‘s just that the visual and sound design in this game is ‚that‘ awesome.***Apart from that: The combat is satisfying, the story pulled me in right away and I so far enjoyed every single minute of gameplay!Oh, one more thing: I’m incredibly bad at action games. I usually only play turn-based stuff or very specific types of games that don’t require incredibly good reaction times. I’m so bad that I often have to quit games like this one after about two or three attempted battles. Luckily the lowest difficulty is just right for me, so that I can enjoy this awesome game. In this title boss fights are challenging, but not too difficult for me.You are good at action games and looking for a challenge? There are difficulty levels for everyone in this title.Overall there is no reason not to buy this game right now … except:The port is competent overall, but does have some severe technical problems. The worst of them ARE fixed by applying an unofficial fix (named "FAR": see the thread at the top of the forum) and using windowed borderless gaming, but IF you belong to that group of people who absolutely refuse to apply unofficial patches and use 3rd party tools: DO NOT GET THIS GAME NOW, BUT INSTEAD WAIT FOR A PATCH! (Sorry for the caps, but this is seriously important. That’s just how mandatory the fix is until this port gets patched.)I for my part use the fix and the borderless tool and I’m enjoying the hell out of this game.-----EDITS and additions after posting the review:Strictly speaking the game is playable without the fix and 3rd party tool, but usually a combination of the following can happen:- In fullscreen mode the resolution may be off (window mode has borders)- button prompts for the controller can be messed up in fullscreen mode- ingame cutscenes may stutter far below the 30 fps they were rendered in even on very performant hardware- on less potent hardware: without the FAR fix you don't have access to global illumination settings, which impact the performance heavily and the visual fidelity much less than other settings (even on a GTX 970 it may be difficult to maintain a steady 60 FPS in 1080p unless you either disable AA and AO. Toning down global illumination by only one level gives me roughly the same performance benefit that I can gain by entirely disabling both of those features.)

content:

												NieR: Automata is one of the few games that I have played that offer one of the best soundtracks. Be mindful that the director is Yoko Taro, so this game may not be for the faint of heart. It's storyline is pretty good as it references back to NieR and even parts of Drakengard. There are a total of 26 different endings, but only 5 of them are important. The game is very good, however I feel as if it could be better. The rest of the endings acts as a comic relief. With all that being said, here are my pros and cons of this game.Pros: - Soundtrack - Supports xinput (xbox controller) - Debug mode (unlocked after beating the game) - Good learning curve - Physics for hair and outfits are pretty good for most times, but it can be approved. - A lot of the side-quests are actually interesting - Requires some skills to play (similar to Devil May Cry series) - Combat is pretty addicitive - Plenty of comic reliefs in this game, which is great so you won't have to feel so depressed - Awesome animations - Sexy asf androids - Ok balance in difficulties, but it could be better. - Adjustable difficulty - Hacking mini-game is pretty fun and simple (only on 9S) - The alternation between hack-and-slash and bullet-shooter is awesome - Weapon stories are really fun and entertaining to read (makes upgrading each and every one of them worth it) - English voice acting is pretty good for something made in Japan.Cons: - Scaling issues (gets annoying after a while of seeing your screen blink so many times on startup) - Requires a decent computer. (In my case, this wasn't a problem, but I know not everyone has a high range computer) - Frames may slow down during scenes - Post-game is way too easy (enemy levels do not scale with player level, but rather with how far you're into the story. For example, once you beat the game and go back to an early part of the game such as chapter 2, your character may be level 70 and the robots will be like level 5) - Pod materials are way too hard to find. (Couldn't upgrade my pods until second playthrough) - Fishing is awesome, but trying to 100% the fishing encyclopedia is a pain. - As mentioned above, difficulty balance could be better. Balance is only good up until mid-late game (Around level 50). After that, everything becomes way too easy to kill. - As mentioned, physics for hair and outfit are pretty good, but if you were to observe closely at times, it looks like the hair/outfit twitches. - Animal bait is pretty much useless after you get a specific item - Pod C is only useful in Hard or Very Hard mode because of it's capabilities to lock on to targets. Other than that, you're better off using Pod A or Pod B. - The 3D map can be a bit hard to read sometimes, but the game will literally tell you to just suck it up and get use to it (gotta love Yoko Taro lol) - Lock on camera can get somewhat buggy if you're fighting in a cluster of enemies (only in normal and below difficulties).If you want to truly appreciate this game and get the most out of it, my tip would be to do all the side-quests and unlock all the archives. The side-quests in this game are probably one of the best. They aren't your average "collect X amount of this and receive X EXP and X potions". A lot of them have very interesting stories to them that deal with machines/androids. You may find them sad, tragic, funny, or cool. Although you don't have to play NieR or Drakengard 1/2/3 to understand NieR Automata, it would be just a bit better know some lore, as the archives and weapon stories reference back to NieR and Drakengard.

content:
2
												Okay, game. You got me.That was a surprisingly cool ending considering you spent about an entire ~40 hour playthrough raising my expectations of how cool and surprising the next chapter would be over and over. Now, to try and review this game as part of its series would probably out of my ability since I never played any of the other prequel games in this franchise which, from what I understand, spans half a dozen titles of the same quality and lenght as the latest Nier: Automata, In fact, the more time I spent on the game wiki reading about the backstory, the more I was convinced I needed to stop before I would innevitably end up comming back to my senses at 4am on a work week, exhausted, emotional and with more questions about the story than ever before.That said, as a stand-alone experience, Nier: Automata was enjoyable AF. The gameplay is very fast paced and the controls are precise and responsive. The levels and boss fights are varied, inventive and the good kind of challenging. The beautiful dynamic soundtrack is top notch. The graphics are very serviceable for a console port but the art and animations frankly embarass the crap out of some of its contemporary 2017 AAA titles I won't name. And finally, the story, while convoluted, confusing and very japanese (and I mean that in a grudgingly fond way), is still enjoyable and manages to build some great emotional attachment to the cast of characters by the end. Just don't expect Pixar so turn your brain off a little for maximum effect.The fighting could seem repetitive at first if you didn't try different weapons and combos that have different bonus effects and animation moves. The chip system would also have you farm the crap out of some areas hoping to get those elusive diamond grade chips to fuse into the ultimate final form. The game also has very respectable replay value thanks to interesting side chainquests that aren't just your run of the mill fetch-me-12-boar-tusks or climb a tower to unlock the map but rather meander into more interesting stories and take you to gorgeous hidden spots with their own unique challenges that I'd never have found on my own.There's something to be said about games that rely on replaying the same level more than once to get the full story but honestly, this game never felt lazy for a second, which is something that's very difficult to achieve in open world games because after the gaming industry has evolved to where it stands today, we've come to have very high expectations and it doesn't take that much to break our enjoyment anymore. Yet, in Nier: Automata, everywhere I looked, everytime I prod in an unintended direction, every tire I kicked, I could see the evidence of the passionate artists who licked every surface and facet with madenning attention to detail.Lastly, there're a few technical issues with full screen performance and the hacking minigame controls using kb/m right now but I expect those to ironed out and there are already community fixes available. Generally, the game run perfectly on my aging 780ti.Rock solid 8/10.

												In a few words, this game is amazing.Fun Hack n' Slash gameplay with tight controls, very difficult and unforgiving game, mainly so in the prologue, I don't recommend starting it on hard, it's a game that, unless you're used to the genre you should start in Normal or easier, if you're absolutely incompetent, don't worry, the game can be very accessive by enabling chips that basically play the game for you.The story, though, now that's the thing, this game has 5 true endings, unlike other games you don't start the game all the way over to get the different endings, each and every play through is truly different from the previous one, either by introducing a different playable character or more story elements, so if you're afraid of getting burned out by starting a new game+, don't be, try it out first, it's a whole new thing.This game can be very depressing, be it via the main story or it's side quests. Sometimes it will throw you something that gives you hope, but most of the time, it will try to crush you, make you question your existence and objectives and I love it. This game said something that I've always thought about, it connected to me in a very deep level, so I hanged on, 'till the very last true ending, ending E......that ending really gives you hope to keep on, no matter how hard it gets.Oh, and to the person who I gave up all my time and effort to help! Life can be quite the ♥♥♥♥♥, it might be meaningless and you will suffer a lot, but so what? Memory wasn't made for us to remember or good times, it's there so we don't repeat our mistakes. Suffering and hardship makes us stronger, if we can get past it! Time is only wasted if you think it is, when you do the things you love, that isn't wasted time, nah, that's called 'time well spent'.So struggle, scream, cry and fight, even if it's all really meaningless and futile, because isn't it fun, to hang on to this tiny hope, to deny when life it says to give up, to fight the impossible? I know I love it and I wouldn't have it any other way, so hang on, I'm here with you, even if you think you're alone.

												I originally reviewed this game after beating the first playthrough. I've now completed all the main endings so I feel I can give a more accurate review.NieR: Automata is the story of androids 2B, A2 and 9S as they struggle to understand what's going on in a world infested with machine lifeforms. Platinum Games had a heavy involvement and as you'd expect, the combat system is extremely well thought out and fluid. While occasionally the camera can be a bit problematic, generally the game plays very well as it switches between action RPG hack-and-slash and various shooter/bullet hell genres.The initial play through (Route A) takes around 10 hours if you ignore some of the sidequests. After its completion, the game will tell you that the game is expected to be played a few times through for different endings. I would strongly suggest playing through Endings A to E; the remaining ones are largely joke ones.The music by MONACA and Keiichi Okabe is amazing throughout and perfectly captures the atmosphere of vain hope and sadness that resonates throughout the main story.The real strong point of the game is the story and the emotional attachments you forge with the characters, which makes the different story routes all the more impactful. Without spoiling anything, you want to be aware that this is a pretty hard-hitting game and it's almost as if Yoko Taro delights in making the player suffer.To anyone considering the game, please at least play Routes A, B and then C/D/E (the latter three don't take long). Only then will you fully understand what's going on in the world. By just completing A and B (like many magazine/websites have), you barely get to know anything.The PC port has some issues (1080p actually just upscales 900p so it looks blurry unless you use a Borderless Window program) and it can sometime drop frames / stutter / freeze briefly even on good machines. Once these are sorted out, it'll leave a game that I consider to be a real contender for one of the greatest games ever.Genuinely, I haven't played a game this good in years and thoroughly recommend it...if you're prepared for being hit right in the feels, over and over again.Amazing game.

												In the past couple of years I have played plenty of games, watched plenty of series and movies as well as spending plenty of time with my lads. After 5 years time this game reminded me what it is to enjoy a game. A game that is immersive, a story that is interesting yet sad. A combat system that is fluent. A grinding system that knows its limit so that you won't spend decades in the search of one item and the soundtracks... those are a masterpiece. There are plenty of games with better graphics, better effects, a better story, better sounds, but do they all have these great aspects in a single game? If it weren't for Witcher 3 and GTA V I'd call this game the most complete and finished product that has been created in the past 5 years. It reminded me once again what it is to enjoy games.Luckily enough my setup can handle this game at max settings without any resolution bugs or whatsoever. There are some players experiencing some issues, but that shouldn't stop you from trying this game as the person behind it is a genius that you will encounter rarely in the gaming industry. For the given issues there are plenty of work arounds. I talk about the content as this game is easily spoiled, but the trailers show you a fraction of what is waiting for you once you purchase this divine product.

I dont know what to do with my life right now.Actually I lied I am going to play it again brb for another 10 hours Game is amazing 10/10 Wonderful graphics, amazing soundtrack, fun combat and amazing characters in my opinon. Love everything about it besides the ladders, they can be annoying!27 Hour Update:3 playthroughs and you get the true ending and I am devistated by it, never has a game made me feel so much like this. It is a wonderful thing. Get this game please.

												Combat is nice and quick.  The genre blending throughout is a delight.  Aesthetics is where this game really shines.  Visually it is very stylish, but what it does with videogame story telling is it's real strength.  If you enjoy science fiction with a philosphical bent, you will love what this game does.I actually found myself feeling bad at times for the enemies I had to kill.  Like this was just a big misunderstanding, a breakdown in communication.  This has happened even for the run-of-the-mill cannon fodder enemies.  No game I have ever played has accomplished evoking that.Word of warning though: this game requires multiple play throughs.  However, mercifully, it doesn't make you hunt for things to change.  I'm not somebody who likes playing the same content multiple times, but I've been enjoying doing it in this game because it does such a good job of building up the different characters through the playthroughs (you play as a different character on the other play throughs).Unfortunately this game suffers from performance issues.  There is a fan patch that helps correct these, you can find more info here: https://steamcommunity.com/app/524220/discussions/0/135512104777399045/

												This game is absolutely amazing from start to finish. I cannot recommend this game enough. Hopefully this game sells well enough to warrant a direct sequel or a remaster of any of the older nier or drakengard games. Now lets talk about the pros and the cons.Pros:1.) amazing soundtrack2.) good character development3.) combat is fun and engaging4.) Lots of variety in ways you play (hack and slash, bullet hell parts, etc.)5.) Absolutely amazing story6.) cool boss fights7.) Plugin and pod program system is vast and impressive8.) References to the original nier (a plus in my book :D)When you start the game on your 3rd playthrough, it becomes a completely different game. The story and feel moments absolutely steal the show.Cons:1.) Shoddy PC port (white screen crashes a frequent for people, Full screen bug that plagues almost everyone, frame rates dip to sub 30 in story heavy cinematics, etc.)2.) Really bad object and terrain pop-ins. No matter what version of the game you have, you'll just be walking and then a building finally decides to fully render itself.3.) Unimpressive textures. Some of the textures in this game are not great. The game suffers from alot of texture baking4.) Some people report on game breaking bugs that make it impossible for them to continue the game. I haven't experienced these issues personally, but to not at least mention them as a possibility would be a disservice to what I would consider an honest review.5.) 1 Boss in particular (no spoilers obviously) is just a big bullet hell scene. While the fight is still kinda cool, its still a little disappointing and comes off as lazy boss design.6.) Its a yoko taro game, so expect plenty of depressing and sad moments. (i put it as a con because depressing scenes arent really my thing) This game will make you care for its characters, and it will make you cry.If you can look past the bad pc port or get your hands on a ps4/ps4 pro copy of the game, play this game. You would be doing yourself a great disservice to gaming if you at least didn't try it. I fully recommend you play through the game multiple times, however. The story changes each time you play through it, revealing more of the story, from a different characters perspective. If you want to fully grasp the story of this game and its universe, you need to play through the game at least 3 times. If you haven't already, then you need to buy and play this game. Its that good, I promise.

content:

												Pretty sure one, if not THE most brilliant examples of narrative and story telling.Not nearly as convoluted and cryptic as other titles, but rather straightforward (which IMHO does not detract from the experience whatsoever).Yoko Taro pretty much put a sequel to the game, within the game, which hits you like a truck. The story, themes and relationships in the game are so open to interpretation and so blurry, that in itself pushes the narrative. Initially I had doubts about the pacing and sidequests, but everything came full circle towards the end and ends up making alot of sense.If you can look past a few flaws otherwise, you will be rewarded with one of the most emotional and meta experiences out there. The sequence towards end of route E is magical. An example for such a flaw would be, that the gameplay is not a 10/10.In terms of controls: I played this on a steam controller and did not have any issues whatsoever with either the technical or layout aspect of things.The game has replay value, because playing through it again after you know everything of the story, you will notice alot of subtleties you missed before. Also ontop of that you will get chapter select, debug modes etc to finish 100% and test things.Oh did I mention this has the best OST of anything out there, hands down? Because its has.Every track has different versions and while they're all extremely solid on their own, what makes the game is the perfect blend and crossfade between different songs and versions, it almost works like a sort of Leitmotif. The ambience absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing nails it.'Weight of the World', which is the closing/main theme, has 4 different versions IIRC that you will all get to hear throughout the game, until a final epic version that will blow your mind (and tearducts).This is the first time I considered buying a gaming OST, even though its 60 Euros.Short version: If you like story and narrative, BUY THE GAME and give them enough money for a story DLC.P.S: 2B = 2Booty

content:

												On my first 'playthrough', I found this game to be rather odd. On my second 'playthrough', I found it to be rather frustrating but nonetheless intriguing.On my third 'playthrough', I have come to the conclusion that this game is freaking insane. I don't understand this at all. what on earth type of drugs is the creator taking? The end isn't the end, the beginning isn't at the beginning. I don't even know who is the main character, I am starting to wonder if up is up and down is down. I can't tell you you'll love the game. it's strange, it can be frustrating, it can be tough at times, and annoying at other times. There have been times where I was just feeling sick of it and to think if I hadn't come back to it for a third 'playthrough'... I would have missed some really major stuff! This game take a LOT of risks. I think a lot of people will be turned off it before they get to find out some of the crazy stuff, such as... the end is not the end. How to recommend it.... it's made by platinum, the people who made Bayonetta and metal gear rising, so the action is good. The music is lovely, if not a little repetitive. The visuals are muted, but there is some lovely effects in there. I mean, some people might think it looks dull. personally I like it. maybe it could have more colour in it. The story... I really don't know. there is all sorts of stuff in there. you can play through it once and feel like you got a complete story, but then if you keep on digging and play again, and again, it unfolds into something far far deeper. I recommend this because... It's kept my attention despite its shortfalls.

												So after beating the game (Completing all the main endings) I have to say that this has been the most fun I've had in a game for a while. From the smooth transition from attacks with different weapons (animations are on point from the start of the attack to recovering from a swing) to the hectic bullet-hell sections with constant views. Although I wish there were more bosses but every one we got was fantastic. Even the story although slow at some points kept me engaged and interested to the end. There are some small quirks with the game (frame rate drops between some cinematic parts. When shifting camera angles, movement controls go a little wonky. But nothing gamebreakinig that I have encountered. Overall this game was a blast to play and highly recommend to everyone to play.For the dark souls players try hard mode. From the first mins of the game it will force you to "git gud". And the bosses are easily the stars (outside of 2b,9s and A2) of this game. By far the final boss is the best encounter of any game I have played in a long time and shows how platinum games has beautifully combine all the mechanics to give us a satisfying fight.

												I'm usually one of those people that doesn't care about the stories and video games. I play games for the gameplay. Nier: Automata's story really left an impression on me. The story itself was good but it gained real impact from how it was told. I wasn't just watching something or reading something, I felt like an active participant in the narrative. It was an incredible experience.The gameplay is great and controls well.  The music is excellent and really enhances the tone of the story. Each area in the small open world uses strong visual designs and apart from the desert, which looks like a desert, I never grew tired of having to move through them.Overall, this game is one of my top gaming experiences.I also witnessed the best version of Romeo & Juliet as conceived by machines.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
2
												Loved the original Nier (Gestalt/Replicant) on Ps3, coming from that Nier Automata is an improvement in gameplay.Music which is a major point alongside story pushes Nier Automata beyond what you mostly play.The story takes you into one view at a time, you learn about the current character you're playing, the choices and paths this character takes..Just to be plunged into another characters point of view upon completion of the 'Prologue'.Once done with this new characters point of view and story, you actually begin the real 'Story'.This makes the game very deep and lets the player connect the lines between what's going on and keeps you curious on what to come.The animations are very fluid in combat, the artstyle very pleasant.The graphics are not at the very top end, but aint something you'd scoff off either.For the small flaws it has (mainly technical) you can actually aquire fixes from the community side of steam of Nier, like adding dualshock 4 buttons when using a DS4, or graphical corrections with a small fix.Overall the game is very story driven, with lots of side content and interesting character development.Has quite a bit of unexpected events and will not care about your feelings or connections, it will deliver the story no matter if it leaves you sad or happy in the end.While i haven't ordered any OST for any game apart from Nier Gestalt, this is now my second OST for a game i own.. Let that be a telling factor about the soundtrack.[EDIT]: So the game description says partial controller support, it actually has full controller support, i suggest you play this with a controller of your choice.It needs a keyboard to type in your savegame file name, thus the partial controller.Love the game to bits, 9/10 from me, will stay with me for a long time ^_^ Thank you Yoko Taro and Platinum Games!

												There are some definite technical issues that pretty much every other review has discussed, but with my i7 6700k, 970, and 16gigabutts of RAM I'm able to run the game at 60FPS with most of the gwafix options at second highest, shadows at medium, and motion blur off (it makes me sick, no idea if it actually effects performance since I keep it off). The fullscreen 1920x1080 bug sucks, but I didn't really notice it until going into the Steam overlay and there's a borderless windowed program you can use that makes it properly run at 1920x1080.Now as for the game, I went in with my expectations fairly low since I really didn't care for the demo when I tried it on PS4. Maybe it's because I'm now two feet from the screen instead of an entire room lengths away so now I can see everything a lot better, but it was a lot more enjoyable now than it was before. The bullet-hell segments are really fun and make you feel badass and the combat feels smoother than I remember it being. It's also a really pretty game, the first level doesn't really show it due to the entire color pallet being rusty reds and browns, but the city ruins afterwards looks really nice with the dull-ish greys of the ruins with the vibrant greens of the forest that's growing over everything. Music is top notch and is definitely something that I'd listen to outside of the game. While she didn't compose it, the music really reminds me of Yuki Kajiura's work for whatever reason so if you've enjoyed her stuff (Madoka, Fate/Zero, SAO, .Hack//Sign as examples) then you'll probably like Automata's music as well.the valve accessory you get in the Day One Edition is surprisingly cute and its vibrant red color fits really well with 2B's entirely white and black attire.ALSO F I S H I N GTHE ULTIMATE OF ALL VIDEO GAME THINGS

												Really awesome game right here.I would go on to tell you how great it is BUT it is blatenly obvious to me that this is a really bad port. It feels and looks like a console game on my rig, which is brand new with a gtx 1070. Therefore i will just skip the detailed review and go into the technichal aspect of the game right away, since i know that that is what really matters here. For me, and for a lot of others alike.The game made a really bad first impression when i realized that you can't play it fullscreen, or i was unable to figure out how. Guess that's a possibility. BUT it should be made so that it is easily played in fullscreen. On top of that, everything was set to either middle or low specs by default. Again, bad first impression. Once in game i notice pop ins and severe problems with shadows on trees. The game does look good, but the pop ins and weird shadows make it really hard to enjoy it. Which sucks since the combat is amazing, but not only the combat. The game made a really good first impression gameplay wise in general. So all in all a great game, but the poor optimization will turn you off if you are easily annoyed by things like that. I hope the devs fix this, the fullscreen issue especially. I will still rate this game positive however. But i will come back to turn it around if i do not see positive change.

												Pretty terrible if you use a keyboard.  Since lock on can't be bound to any mouse buttons, you're stuck awkwardly moving your finger back and forth from one of your movement keys to hold down lock on.  Aiming is also a bit finicky, but you should pick up a controller and enjoy this game.  Gameplay is amazing, and it feels very smooth.  This game is not for the faint of heart.  You cannot just save this game any time you want.  There are specifics locations you can do it, which is a key feature of the game.  So SAVE OFTEN.  It will be a very challenging game.  It took me about 2 hours before I could even reach the first save point, but it did take me a bit to get used to the controls.  I would recommend buying this game if you like a challenge, but playing with keyboard and mouse right now is pretty much impossible.

												So far seems very good, a final fantasy type of RPG with regularly changing combat modes from top down shooter to 'Devil May Cry-esque' to 'Einhander' & 'Starfox'The Good:  Playing for about an hour and a half now, and I've played "bullet-hell" style shooting sequences alongside a well put together 3rd-person beat-em-up sequences, the changing perspectives and styles flow pretty well and keep things interesting.  Gameplay looks great at solid 60fps 2K with a GTX 1070, and I'm looking forward to dumping alot of time into this game! The not-so-good:  Many cutscenes stutter pretty badly and cut the framerate to 30fps.  I would prefer unlocked framerates, and some of the nice scenic cutscenes that do play at 60fps are hampered by transluscent black bars at the top and bottom of the screen...I also think the 3rd person 'DMC' mode could pull the camera out a bit, it makes for a kind of claustrophobic battle in some areas, though when the view pulls out for side-scroller and flight I think it's perfect.   Recommend!

												I'm not much for writing reviews, but Nier:Automata deserves every ounce of praise given to it and more.What is it?   -- It is hack/slash RPG with a simple combat system that shows remarkable depth over time.  -- It is a arcady bullet-hell game at times.  -- It is a story driven game that will drive you to tears and heartbreak.  -- It is an open world that begs to be explored and appreciated.   -- It is home to one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard. It is one of the most satisfying games, story and gameplaywise, that I have ever had the experience of playing. If I am to be fair, Nier:Automata is not without its flaws:  -- I had some studdering/fps issues at times even after using Borderless Gaming (which I highly recommend for this game).  -- The keyboard controls (especially dodging) are rather sh*tty, I did not have much choiced but to use a controller.   -- Aiming without a lockout is rather poor.  -- The game can be too easy sometimes, but the difficulty jump between normal and hard is unfair. (Think 5x more damage from all enemies)But all of these flaws are either avoidable or ignorable. They did not ruin the game for me in the slightest.Nier:Automata is a melting pot of various ideas and genres, and successfully manages to combine them while setting itself apart from everything. Yoko Taro created a beautiful world, story, and characters. If I were to compare this game to anything, it would be to a black hole. The game pulled me into its world and never let go until I beat the game. And, mild spoiler:  All the advertised gameplay and campaign is actually a little less than HALF the full story.I apologize. I have been rambling. I don't write reviews well, but I had to try for this game. It touched me and will forever hold a special place in my heart. This is undoubtably, one of the single best games I have ever played. You will not regret buying this game.

												When I first started hearing about this game I had only seen a few gameplay videos. I thought, "This is cool." Then I started hear praises over the game. But no one would say anything about it other that you need to play it. So I tried the demo on PS4 and loved the combat. So I bought it here on my pc since I dont have a PS4. And to top it off, the soundtrack is the best I've ever heard in a game this far. You know its good when you can listen to it all day at work for 2 weeks straight.As this being my favorite game now I'm giving it 10/10 for everything.Story 10/10Music 10/10Direction 10/10Art Direction 10/10Combat 10/102B's booty 10/109s 9s/10Buy this game and play it with no spoilers. Don't browse reddit or youtube while playing this game. Best played with no knowledge of the world other than the description on steam.This masterpiece was a rollercoaster of emotions for me. And thank you Square Enix and Platinum Games.Now off to 100% the game and restart on very hard mode :)

												This game is absolutely amazing from start to finish. I cannot recommend this game enough. Hopefully this game sells well enough to warrant a direct sequel or a remaster of any of the older nier or drakengard games. Now lets talk about the pros and the cons.Pros:1.) amazing soundtrack2.) good character development3.) combat is fun and engaging4.) Lots of variety in ways you play (hack and slash, bullet hell parts, etc.)5.) Absolutely amazing story6.) cool boss fights7.) Plugin and pod program system is vast and impressive8.) References to the original nier (a plus in my book :D)When you start the game on your 3rd playthrough, it becomes a completely different game. The story and feel moments absolutely steal the show.Cons:1.) Shoddy PC port (white screen crashes a frequent for people, Full screen bug that plagues almost everyone, frame rates dip to sub 30 in story heavy cinematics, etc.)2.) Really bad object and terrain pop-ins. No matter what version of the game you have, you'll just be walking and then a building finally decides to fully render itself.3.) Unimpressive textures. Some of the textures in this game are not great. The game suffers from alot of texture baking4.) Some people report on game breaking bugs that make it impossible for them to continue the game. I haven't experienced these issues personally, but to not at least mention them as a possibility would be a disservice to what I would consider an honest review.5.) 1 Boss in particular (no spoilers obviously) is just a big bullet hell scene. While the fight is still kinda cool, its still a little disappointing and comes off as lazy boss design.6.) Its a yoko taro game, so expect plenty of depressing and sad moments. (i put it as a con because depressing scenes arent really my thing) This game will make you care for its characters, and it will make you cry.If you can look past the bad pc port or get your hands on a ps4/ps4 pro copy of the game, play this game. You would be doing yourself a great disservice to gaming if you at least didn't try it. I fully recommend you play through the game multiple times, however. The story changes each time you play through it, revealing more of the story, from a different characters perspective. If you want to fully grasp the story of this game and its universe, you need to play through the game at least 3 times. If you haven't already, then you need to buy and play this game. Its that good, I promise.

												Combat is nice and quick.  The genre blending throughout is a delight.  Aesthetics is where this game really shines.  Visually it is very stylish, but what it does with videogame story telling is it's real strength.  If you enjoy science fiction with a philosphical bent, you will love what this game does.I actually found myself feeling bad at times for the enemies I had to kill.  Like this was just a big misunderstanding, a breakdown in communication.  This has happened even for the run-of-the-mill cannon fodder enemies.  No game I have ever played has accomplished evoking that.Word of warning though: this game requires multiple play throughs.  However, mercifully, it doesn't make you hunt for things to change.  I'm not somebody who likes playing the same content multiple times, but I've been enjoying doing it in this game because it does such a good job of building up the different characters through the playthroughs (you play as a different character on the other play throughs).Unfortunately this game suffers from performance issues.  There is a fan patch that helps correct these, you can find more info here: https://steamcommunity.com/app/524220/discussions/0/135512104777399045/

content:

												Pretty sure one, if not THE most brilliant examples of narrative and story telling.Not nearly as convoluted and cryptic as other titles, but rather straightforward (which IMHO does not detract from the experience whatsoever).Yoko Taro pretty much put a sequel to the game, within the game, which hits you like a truck. The story, themes and relationships in the game are so open to interpretation and so blurry, that in itself pushes the narrative. Initially I had doubts about the pacing and sidequests, but everything came full circle towards the end and ends up making alot of sense.If you can look past a few flaws otherwise, you will be rewarded with one of the most emotional and meta experiences out there. The sequence towards end of route E is magical. An example for such a flaw would be, that the gameplay is not a 10/10.In terms of controls: I played this on a steam controller and did not have any issues whatsoever with either the technical or layout aspect of things.The game has replay value, because playing through it again after you know everything of the story, you will notice alot of subtleties you missed before. Also ontop of that you will get chapter select, debug modes etc to finish 100% and test things.Oh did I mention this has the best OST of anything out there, hands down? Because its has.Every track has different versions and while they're all extremely solid on their own, what makes the game is the perfect blend and crossfade between different songs and versions, it almost works like a sort of Leitmotif. The ambience absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing nails it.'Weight of the World', which is the closing/main theme, has 4 different versions IIRC that you will all get to hear throughout the game, until a final epic version that will blow your mind (and tearducts).This is the first time I considered buying a gaming OST, even though its 60 Euros.Short version: If you like story and narrative, BUY THE GAME and give them enough money for a story DLC.P.S: 2B = 2Booty

content:

												Nier is by no means a perfect game.  It is also not a game for everyone.  However, in todays climate when many video games feel like the mangled birth of corporate decisions, focus groups, market analysis and ultimate desire to only sell units, Nier is a breath of fresh air and definitely something we need more of…Nier is a fun, genre hopping game. One minute you’re in an on-rails shooter, next a twin stick shooter, a few minutes later your smashing it up in Devil May Cry style like it’s going out of fashion.  You might be sliding over sand dunes or riding a boar before you’re thrown into what feels like a 2d platformer, but somehow it doesn’t come off as cheap. There’s more, but I don’t want to spoil… Nier is a thoughtful game, although it might not be as smart as it thinks it is. There’s SO many wonderful and ingenious things about Nier, but I can’t share the, as it would spoil it for you.  It made me think hard, it made me feel for the characters in the conflict, it made me laugh.  It toys with existentialism, fatalism, nihilism and theories on determinalism.  It gives you the tools for unadulterated violence, yet forces you to question the impact of using it. I did see some of the games big reveals a million miles away though.Nier is a weird game.  It forces you to play through its 1st half twice before it really lets you know what’s going on.  It’s also a game where an android asks you to eat a mackerel so it can see what effect it has on you.Nier is an amazing sounding game, and like Hyper Light Drifter, the soundtrack is one of its biggest stars and REALLY adds an amazing texture to everything.Nier is a visually-confused game.  The main characters look pretty silly if you ask me (a prepubescent boy in a blazer and knee high books?  A white-haired French maid who can’t stop flashing her undies?  I guess it doesn't want you to forget for one minute that this is a Japanese game eh?) but they animate incredibly well.  The robots are the real stars though, with a very studio Ghibli vide, and some of the bosses are amazing.  However, the game world itself is blocky, unimaginative and has some very poor textures that make me wonder if this was designed for the PS2 or not.  I never thought I’d see a modern game with uglier environments than Tales of Zestira, but here we go.Nier is sometimes a frustrating game, with one boss in particular being annoying in the extreme, and trying to find upgrade materials being a huge pain.  it also gives you a lot of fetch quests.Finally, Nier is a unique game that always kept me on my toes and looking forward to what would come next in temrs of both sotry an gameplay.  Aside from the combat, there is NOTHING like this on the PC.  Its not perfect, but it is thoughtful, inventive, and ultimately giving the player something different from the 999th open world icon collect-athon bore fest or the 999th indie retro pixel rogue like alike. For that I think it might be worth your time.  I usually only buy one full-priced game a year, and I’m glad I chose this over Mass Effect androgynous 😊.  So far, Nier is my top game of 2017

												Okay, if this game doesn't get "Overwhelmingly positive" in a few weeks I'm gonna be mad.Seriously now, the game is a masterpiece. And what I mean by masterpiece is TRULY a masterpiece. Like Jim Sterling said: "if history forgets this game, then ♥♥♥♥ history". It's up to us to remember this game, and I will remember it on all of its glory.This game should be played by every person that appreciates playing videogames. It is a work of art, on all of its factors. The scenery, the combat mechanics, THE STORY! It immerses you to a point where you believe to be truly an android. THE ENDINGS ARE COUNTLESS, the main story endings are 5, with ending E being the "true ending" but I enjoyed every part of every single ending, and then there is like 21 more joke endings to complete the game. Believe me when I say this: THE STORY IS ONE OF THE BEST I HAVE EVER PLAYED.The soundtrack deserves its own paragraph. I said previously that the story of this game is ONE of the BEST. Well, truly believe me when I say, the soundtrack is THE BEST I HAVE LISTENED TO, PERIOD.10/10 game for me. GOTY all the way.

												This game is a modern masterpiece.I've never experienced a game that blends gameplay genres as smoothly as this does -- it honestly feels like a breakthrough in gaming. Video clips can't do it justice and, even worse, can make it seem gimmicky. But when you experience it for yourself, it seems so effortless and natural that you'll wonder why no other game has ever been able to pull it off. The combat animations have a ridiculous level of detail, yet the control responsiveness is unmistakably Platinum Games. Everything is tight and fluid and intuitive.The soundtrack is, quite frankly, unforgettable. It adds so much to the experience, and the dynamic layering is perfectly done. Words can't do it justice.The story and themes are mature and deep, and you'll be thinking about it long after you finish. The final act is among the most exciting and satisfying experiences I've ever had with a game.This game has 5 canon endings (ABCDE) and you haven't played the full game until you've seen them all.

												I don't really write reviews but NieR:Automata has compelled me to write one. I am at a lack of words to describe this game. But, I also want people to know how important this game is for me and for gaming itself. Nier:Automata takes chances, tries to do something different and compeletely succeeds in doing so. Have you felt a void, the void that you feel when you finish a great game, a great novel, a great movie. The premonition that you will never again have this experience again, that is the feeling I got after finishing Nier. I was genuinely sad that it has ended. There are few games that tell thier story more through gameplay than through cutscenes, Yoko Taro, the director of Nier:Automata has created one such masterpiece where every second of gamepaly is an experience that the player never forgets, mainly through the fluid fighting system, interesting RPG elements, interesting characters and amazing music. Infact I would like to stress the fact that music in Nier:Automata is simply the best videogame soundtrack ever created and soundtrack itself is worth paying full price for the game. As for the story you play as an android, which are robots that are basically human in the way they think and act, but they are not really human as well. This is the main agenda for the story do these androids have a will of their own or the machines they are fighting do they have feelings or are they just imitating humans. Not only this is a story of the androids 2B, 9S and A2 but also of the enemies they are fighting." Souls and heaven, huh? Do either of those things exist?"" They will find out in the end. And so will we. " I don't want to say more about the story except that the story keeps on becoming more engaging and tragic as the game progresses, enough to keep you glued to finish the game 3 times to compeletely know the story. Each time you play the game you learn something new about the world and about the characters, though I do admit that 2nd playthrough of Nier:Automata is kind of subdued as compared to the first and third playthrough but is still very entertaining. Nier:Automata like Dark Souls 1 and The Witcher 3 is a masterpiece that will be rememberd for years to come for setting new standards in gaming. It is an outstanding work of art too important be ignored by any gamer.

												I've never really written a review, but finishing this game made me. Even though it will have the structural integrity of a 5th grader's first essay, I feel like it's something I have to do. Because if it means I'll give at least one person the final nudge to buy this game, it'll mean the world to me. The combat was fun and intuitive, the soundtrack was a masterpiece, and the story and the way the game concluded, was something I can't really describe. This game was an amazing experience, despite me having to play it on 800x600 because my pc is trash. I honestly don't think I've ever played something as great as this title. This game is an action packed, emotional rollercoaster with a little bit of philosophical thought. You'll want to get off Yoko Taro's Wild Ride, but he won't let you. No. He'll strap you in, lube you up, put on his elbow-length latex glove and show you how deep the rabbit holegoes. The ending will get you. All of the endings will get you. And when the vocals kick in, you WILL cry little b*tch tears. This game isn't like other games. This game shows you the ugly but also the beautiful. It's cruel, yet cheerful at times. Hopeless yet hope-filled. I recommend this with all my heart.A massive thank you to the director, the developers, and everyone who was behind this game. You're gonna carry that weight of the world.

												If you're an average RPG/hack and slash gamer, the first thing you want to know is this game has 26 endings over multiple NG+ cycles.I can't recommend this game enough. I bought NieR:A because I was a fan of Drakengard and I expected the same kind of RPG action. It delivers a lot more than that. I feel like the advertising is a bit misleading and doesn't do it justice for how polished it actually is. I was very skeptical, but after the end of the first mission I wasn't having any regrets.The vast majority of the game is presented in third person - but in typical fashion, the start of the game bends genres in nods toward Galaga and Einhander type air battles, as well as side scrolling platforming and twin-stick shooting. It pulls this off just by changing the camera angle and I found that to be quite satisfying. In fact, there's a ton of things that end up being strangely satisfying, like the end of 2B's walking animation if you just nudge the analog stick slightly.In a world full of half-baked games, this one will stand out. The story is tragically heavy at times and surprised me with how much sadness it could wrench out of me (who's an emotional blank slate) with just a single scene. It hits all the marks.NieR:Automata delivers. Absolutely worth it at full price.

												I know, a game about a hot girl and some young dude? What is this? Another J-RPG of those?NOPETo put things in context. I do not like J-RPGs, they seem too focused in leveling up a mindless number, have weak stories from a character development point, and just... those gimmicks for horny dudes. For years I have avoided a large part of the games tailored from japan because of all of this and just Dark Souls has recently got through my kind of "barrier" for games that I like, and this game is not Dark Souls, but oh my god, it is a beautiful game.Here you will be surprised. Continuously. The plot deepens every minute you spend on it, the combat evolves occasion after occasion and... well, I don't want to spoil it for you, but you're going to find yourself thinking about the mind of a soldier, the importance of humanity and, in the end, of life itself. Not trying to be pretentious, but I dare you to get to the end of the game without at least thinking once or twice about something deep that matters to you.If I can say something that is important to me about this game is that you will not be the same after playing Nier Automata. And that is something I can promise

content:

A breath of fresh airNieR : Automata is a great expansion to the universe created by Yoko Taro that has been portrayed through first Drakengard and prequel to Automata - original NieR game.As long as your expectation is not oriented purely towards graphics or technical aspects, Automata delivers both great story and gameplay thanks to cooperation between Yoko Taro and Platinum games.Thanks to this alliance, great story has been given an adequate vessel allowing players to experience the world of NieR without getting bored, frustrated or tired.Story:Let's make it clear - if you're reading this, with a precision of approximately 99,95% i can tell you're a fellow weaboo.If you know Neon Genesis Evangelion, you'll feel right at home.If by any chance you're also familiar with earlier creations of Yoko Taro, you won't be disappointed - if not, well knowledge of either Drakengard or NieR is not needed to enjoy or understand the game, but some of the references won't connect for you. Veterans will appreciate certain character, references and musical themes.Graphics/Technical aspects:Probably the weakest point of the game. Speaking solely about PC version it's a solid improvement from other Platinum games PC ports although it's still far from perfect.-Visual fidelity is generally on par with console version-60FPS lock-Support for arbitrary resolutions (although only 16:9 aspect ratio works correctly)-Few PC specific features like MSAA or audio mute when out of focus (no borderless windowed mode though)As of writing this review PC version struggles with some issues, some more fatal than others. Besides issues with launching the game on certain GPU/driver configurations to inadequate performance when compared to other games with similar requirements the game works completely fine, once you get it working you can expect solid crash free experience with no FPS drops although unless you own a beefy rig don't expect the "perfect" experience.Audio:No letdown here either, music composed by Keiichi Okabe lives up to soundtracks of his previous creations.Official OST has around ~46 tracks although actual amount of music clips in game is easily triple of that count, each track has few different versions based on speed, vocals and even 8-bit remixes. There are even some tracks from original NieR game.GameplayAs expected from Platinum games, it's quick and fluid. Combo system is easy to learn but hard to master. In general you won't be having issues with playing the game on normal mode if you take your time to do side quests.Overall game design is based around "route" system with each route giving you different ending out of 5 main endings.This also means that each route is mostly same game played from the start although there many differences between each route, starting from being able to control different character to unlocking availability of different sidequests during each route and ending on uncovering more and more plot with each route beaten. Automata tries to be more than one game at the same time, combining 3D action-slasher with 2d bullethell kind gameplay and topping it up with hacking minigames (and it doesn't end there). All of the mechanics are integral parts of the game and they never overstay they welcome.The good One of most unique games in recent years Adequate execution of Yoko Taro's ideas Great synergy between world building, gameplay and audio Classic Platinum combat mechanicsThe bad Few issues with PC version (with some of them being quite serious) Really raw and simplistic graphics (thankfully art style compensates for crude graphics fidelity) Few areas could use more shortcuts and connections between each other It's easy to get overleveled if you focus on doing all of the side quests Perhaps it could use some more side quests (or i'm just salty that it was over too soon?)Overall i'd give the game a solid 9/10 maybe a 10/10 if it ever gets some more substantial DLCs, patches for PC issues and perhaps even mods to improve upon raw and sterile graphics that were most likely a result of relatively small budgets and targetting for console hardware.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
6
												I'm not much for writing reviews, but Nier:Automata deserves every ounce of praise given to it and more.What is it?   -- It is hack/slash RPG with a simple combat system that shows remarkable depth over time.  -- It is a arcady bullet-hell game at times.  -- It is a story driven game that will drive you to tears and heartbreak.  -- It is an open world that begs to be explored and appreciated.   -- It is home to one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard. It is one of the most satisfying games, story and gameplaywise, that I have ever had the experience of playing. If I am to be fair, Nier:Automata is not without its flaws:  -- I had some studdering/fps issues at times even after using Borderless Gaming (which I highly recommend for this game).  -- The keyboard controls (especially dodging) are rather sh*tty, I did not have much choiced but to use a controller.   -- Aiming without a lockout is rather poor.  -- The game can be too easy sometimes, but the difficulty jump between normal and hard is unfair. (Think 5x more damage from all enemies)But all of these flaws are either avoidable or ignorable. They did not ruin the game for me in the slightest.Nier:Automata is a melting pot of various ideas and genres, and successfully manages to combine them while setting itself apart from everything. Yoko Taro created a beautiful world, story, and characters. If I were to compare this game to anything, it would be to a black hole. The game pulled me into its world and never let go until I beat the game. And, mild spoiler:  All the advertised gameplay and campaign is actually a little less than HALF the full story.I apologize. I have been rambling. I don't write reviews well, but I had to try for this game. It touched me and will forever hold a special place in my heart. This is undoubtably, one of the single best games I have ever played. You will not regret buying this game.
